Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Turkey&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Turkey+April+2019+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2019-04-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Turkey&amp;rft.issn=09668632&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
In June 2018 Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected as president for a second term in snap presidential and parliamentary elections, in which his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a coalition majority with the right-wing Nationalist Action Party (MHP). Mr Erdogan and the AKP will remain in power throughout the forecast period (2019-23), and probably beyond.
Following the 2018 elections, an executive presidency has replaced the former parliamentary system of government. The new system provides few checks on the president's powers, raising the risk of discretionary policymaking.
Since the failed coup in July 2016 there has been a deterioration in Turkey's relations with its Western allies. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a rupture to be avoided, but tensions will remain high and relations could sour quickly.
Turkey's relationship with the US will continue to be tense. Points of contention include Turkey's perceived pivot towards Iran and Russia and, from Turkey's perspective, the lack of support from the US after the failed coup.
Turkey's relationship with the EU will remain transactional. Turkey will not make progress with accession talks and is unlikely to manage to renegotiate the terms of its customs union with the EU.
The government's focus on domestic power struggles, economic growth and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. In the coming years, with no scheduled elections until 2023, we expect the amount of policymaking focused on short-term growth to be more limited.
We forecast a slowdown in real GDP growth, from 7.3% in 2017 to an average of about 2.6% per year in 2019-23, reflecting the impact of the August 2018 currency crisis, higher domestic and international interest rates, a persistently difficult business environment and global trade tensions.
The lira will depreciate in nominal terms against the US dollar during the forecast period, to about TL6.4:US$1 at end-2023, as a result of negative foreign investor sentiment, high inflation and the large current-account deficit.
As a result of the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar in 2018 (which will boost competitiveness), we forecast that the current-account deficit will shrink in 2019-23, to an annual average of about 2.9% of GDP. Turkey will struggle to meet its high external financing needs throughout the forecast period.

Turkey's score deteriorates only slightly in 2019-23, but in the global rankings the country falls by 11 places, to 59th. The failed coup in 2016 and the government's response increased the level of uncertainty about the direction of economic policy. Shortcomings include a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Political instability and adverse market conditions will delay further privatisation deals.
2021-23: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in several sectors.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but macroeconomic instability and concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2021-23: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Capital controls are not considered, despite the scale of the currency collapse.
2021-23: Negotiations with the EU to update the customs union are likely to be protracted, given poor Turkish-EU relations.
Taxes
2019-20: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Tax rises introduced in 2018 to curb the widening of the budget deficit reduce company profits.
2021-23: Income tax base becomes broader as exemptions and exceptions are reduced.
Financing
2019-20: Asset quality likely to deteriorate on the back of financial market turmoil in 2018. Central Bank of Turkey to lower rates gradually as inflation moderates in 2019. Risk of the US imposing fines or sanctions on some Turkish banks.
2021-23: Lending growth to pick up again as banking system regains strength. Continued reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2019-20: Relatively high labour costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment.
2021-23: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2019-20: First phase of third airport in Istanbul becomes operational. Slower progress made on other projects.
2021-23: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. Other major urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks might persist.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Spending on research and development remains moderate, at about 1% of GDP, holding back efforts to move the economy up the value-added ladder.
2021-23: Turkey's young population spurs further rapid digital transformation of the banking sector.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West. The country became a member of the Council of Europe in 1949 and NATO in 1952, and signed an association agreement with the then European Community in 1963. A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but a coup attempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey currently has a presidential system of government, with parliament elected for a five-year term. To win seats, parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the AKP leader, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who was re-elected as president for a second term in June 2018. Following his re-election a presidential system of government was introduced and the post of prime minister was abolished.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability and stabilising the lira following the August 2018 currency crisis are Turkey's biggest policy challenges. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and tightening global liquidity conditions require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy tight to attract adequate capital inflows and slow the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar. The Kurdish issue, which has blocked economic development in the south east, is one of Turkey's most pressing policy challenges, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015, and there has been a resurgence in violence. Politicisation of the judiciary since the coup attempt has undermined its independence. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The corporation tax rate was raised from 20% to 22 in 2018. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Reducing tax evasion was one of the elements of previous IMF programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2018 goods exports totalled an estimated US$175bn and imports about US$216bn, creating a trade deficit of about US$41.8bn and a current-account deficit in the region of US$27.2bn (or 3.6% of estimated GDP). The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
In June 2018 Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected for a second term in the first round of a snap presidential election. On the same day his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a parliamentary coalition majority with its right-wing ally, the Nationalist Action Party (MHP). The election process appeared mostly free, but largely unfair. Opposition candidates received little or no media coverage; the pro-Kurdish Peoples' Democratic Party (HDP) candidate, Selahattin Demirtas, had to campaign from prison; and the government restrained freedom of speech and freedom of association. Mr Erdogan secured a majority of the vote after a high turnout. Results published by opposition observers were similar to those announced by the government.
Mr Erdogan's re-election concluded Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. This move was initiated with a constitutional referendum in April 2017, which the government narrowly won. The new system grants the president wide-ranging executive powers-including the selection of most of the officials in the judiciary-and will greatly weaken parliament. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the AKP and Mr Erdogan, who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in July 2016, to remain in power until 2023, and probably beyond.
Mr Erdogan will continue to restrict political dissent and stifle the opposition. Despite allowing the state of emergency to expire on July 18th 2018, parliament passed a security law on July 25th that imposes stringent barriers on freedoms.
Security risk remains high, as Turkey appears vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and the Islamic State (IS). Neither the government nor the PKK is interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will return to 1990s levels. The fact that the ruling coalition is made up of the AKP and the MHP will hinder attempts to resolve the Kurdish issue, as the nationalist-minded MHP is pushing for hawkish policies aimed at constraining and delegitimising the HDP.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Parliamentary and presidential elections were held in June 2018 (they had originally been scheduled for late 2019). Mr Erdogan was re-elected as president in the first round, securing 52.6% of the vote with a turnout of 86.2%. In the parliamentary election the AKP lost its absolute majority (although it secured a coalition majority alongside its partner, the MHP), as the HDP managed to poll more than the 10% threshold needed to enter parliament.
Local elections took place on March 31st. The AKP and the MHP retained a majority of the national vote. However, in the midst of an economic recession the ruling parties lost vital cities such as Ankara, the capital, and Istanbul, the largest city (still being contested). Losing major cities is a blow to the AKP given the public resources that the cities command. However, Mr Erdogan's tight grip on national institutions and the media mean that he will continue to dominate Turkish politics in the coming years.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Domestic political and security issues will continue to shape Turkey's actions in the foreign-policy sphere. Turkey's relations with the EU and the US are likely to remain antagonistic and transactional, rather than strategic. We do not expect a breakdown in relations, but there is an elevated risk of a rupture in the country's ties with its traditional Western allies. Many factors have contributed to the deterioration in relations, including a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey after the failed coup; US military backing for PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurdish groups; Turkey's forging of closer relations with China, Russia and Iran; and US sanctions on Turkish officials owing to Turkey's detention of Andrew Brunson, a US pastor, on terrorism charges (sanctions were lifted after Mr Brunson was released in October 2018).
In 2019 relations with the US will continue to be tested owing to Turkey´s decision to purchase the Russian-made S-400 missile defence system. The decision puts Turkey at risk of being excluded from the ongoing development of the F-35 fighter jet programme and of facing economic sanctions under the US Countering America's Adversaries Through Sanctions Act (CAATSA). We expect that Turkey and the US will find a solution that enables Turkey to obtain a waiver from US sanctions or avoid them altogether. With the economy in recession, Turkey can ill afford the cost of sanctions. The US is unlikely to want to pursue a course of action that would lead to a strengthening of Turkey-Russia ties and potentially set the stage for a complete collapse in US-Turkey relations.
We do not expect Turkey to back down from the purchase, given the effect that it would have on its relationship with Russia, a necessary partner in neighbouring Syria. Russia props up the regime of Bashar al-Assad, the Syrian president, and maintains a large military presence in the country. Thus, a deterioration in relations could put at risk Turkey´s control of territory across the border region, from the Mediterranean to the Euphrates River-territory that was gained to block the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds affiliated with the PKK along the border. It could also limit Turkey´s influence in Idlib, a city in northern Syria, which is controlled by Islamist rebel groups. In September 2018 an agreement between Turkey, Russia and Iran was reached to forestall a regime offensive against Idlib. Such an offensive could result in another surge of refugee flows into Turkey.
Relations between Turkey and the EU will also remain transactional, as both have a common interest in handling refugee inflows from Syria and Iraq. However, EU-Turkey relations would deteriorate quickly if the EU was to suspend Turkey's moribund accession negotiations, or if Turkey re-imposed the death penalty, closed the Incirlik air base to NATO forces or withdrew from NATO altogether.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
The government's past focus on domestic power struggles, and foreign policy challenges, has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. Nonetheless, Turkey's economy has shown resilience during previous bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing to its solid public finances, its well-capitalised banking sector, and its dynamic and diversified private sector.
After local elections in March 2019 Turkey's political landscape enters a period of electoral calm that-barring any unforeseen events-should last for several years, until the next parliamentary and presidential elections (due in 2023). This context of relative political stability should put the AKP in a position to take a more long-term approach to policymaking. Compared with the past three years, it should also limit the amount of ad hoc policy measures that boost the economy in the near term, but that diminish the government's credibility. However, an element of unpredictability and unorthodoxy will remain in the near term. The economy is in recession and, following its recent poor performance in local elections, the AKP will continue to feel under pressure to support growth. Shortcomings such as cronyism and corruption, skills mismatches (a major factor behind the high unemployment rate), and tax evasion are unlikely to be addressed in the 2019-23 forecast period.
In the case of a banking crisis (not our core forecast), Turkey's options would remain limited, as Gulf Co-operation Council (GCC) countries appear unwilling to offer financial support. This is because Turkey is forging closer ties with Iran, a country with which Saudi Arabia has tensions. Turkey's ties with Saudi Arabia deteriorated (from an already low base) after Jamal Khashoggi, a Saudi journalist, was murdered in the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, Turkey's largest city, in October 2018. Furthermore, any potential IMF programme would include a level of foreign involvement that the government would be likely to view as unacceptable, and that would run counter to Mr Erdogan's nationalist, anti-Western rhetoric. Only China appears able at present to offer a financial lifeline to Turkey (perhaps as part of China's Belt and Road Initiative).
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
The public finances have traditionally been one of the Turkish economy's most reassuring aspects. Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios reflect the positive impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past.
Despite several tax rises in 2018 and official promises of budgetary tightening, higher government spending on defence, security, infrastructure, public employment and social benefits caused the deficit to widen in 2018-to 2% of GDP, from 1.5% in 2017.
In 2019-23 we expect a cautious approach to on-balance-sheet fiscal policy. This, alongside a recovering economy, will cause the deficit to narrow gradually, from a forecast 2.3% in 2019 to 1.7% of GDP in 2023.
The central government debt/GDP ratio deteriorated slightly in 2018, rising to 28.9% of GDP in 2018 (from 28.3% in 2017), in the context of economic turmoil after the August currency crisis and various government handouts ahead of the June 2018 elections. The ratio will decline slightly, to about 26.5% by end-2023 as macroeconomic conditions normalise and the budget deficit shrinks.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
In September 2018 the Central Bank of Turkey's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) raised its main policy rate, the one-week repo (repurchase agreement) lending rate, to 24%, from 17.75% previously. The MPC's decision was a response to the lira's sharp depreciation against the US dollar in August, as well as to the record rise in annual consumer price inflation. The average cost of central bank funding is currently above the main policy rate, however. The bank is providing funding for the banking system at its overnight lending rates, which are 1.5-3% greater than the one-week repo rate.
At its meeting on March 6th the MPC kept its one-week repo lending rate unchanged, at 24%. We expect the central bank to keep monetary policy tight in the first half of 2019. From mid-2019 to 2020 the central bank will gradually lower its policy rate in response to declining inflationary pressures and a normalisation of financial market conditions. In 2021-23 we believe that the central bank will continue to overshoot its inflation target of 5%. This reflects the government's continued pro-growth stance; it will put pressure on the central bank to keep nominal rates below what would credibly be required to lower inflation to the 5% target.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
Real GDP growth accelerated sharply in 2017, to 7.3% (from 3.3% in 2016), supported by government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit, improved export competitiveness and a pick-up in global demand. However, the surge in economic growth exacerbated internal and external imbalances. These imbalances-coupled with heightened policy unpredictability, foreign investors' concerns regarding the independence of the central bank, reliance on short-term capital inflows, a rising interest rate environment in advanced economies and a diplomatic spat with the US-contributed to the lira losing about 40% of its value against the US dollar in January-August 2018. The sharp depreciation of the lira caused consumer price inflation to accelerate from already high rates, increased input costs for corporations and raised the debt-servicing costs of foreign-currency-denominated liabilities. Higher domestic interest rates and rising risk premiums further dent the economic outlook.
After quarterly growth of 0.2% in the second quarter of 2018, GDP contracted by 1.3% in the third quarter and by 3.3% in the fourth quarter. High-frequency indicators until February 2019 (latest available data) suggest that in the first quarter of the year the deterioration in economic activity was contained. However, this was probably the result of stimulus ahead of the local elections in March, and we do not expect a sustained recovery in economic activity until the end of 2019. As a result, after decelerating to 2.8% in 2018, we expect that GDP will contract by 1.7% in 2019 on average (mainly owing to base effects).
In 2020 we expect growth to rebound to 4.1% as the economy recovers and spare capacity is depleted. In 2021-23 economic growth will average about 3.6% per year. There are substantial downside risks to our forecasts; these growth profiles do not reflect the possible impact of a severe banking crisis (not our core scenario), although we expect non-performing loans to rise and credit availability to be impaired in the coming quarters.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
In full-year 2018 the currency crisis and rising global commodity prices drove inflation higher, to 16.3% (from 11.1% in 2017). In 2019 inflation will remain elevated in the first half of the year and then moderate gradually on the back of a limited depreciation of the lira (against the US dollar), a lower average global oil prices and the emergence of spare capacity in the economy. Accommodative fiscal policies in response to the economic weakness in the final months of 2018 will prevent inflation from declining faster than would otherwise be the case. On average, we forecast inflation of 16.1% in 2019-only marginally smaller than the 2018 rate.
The moderating trend in inflation will continue in 2020, with an average inflation rate of 10.2% as global oil prices continue to decline (owing to a slowdown in the global economy, with the US entering a technical recession) and the exchange rate depreciates slightly (in nominal terms) against the US dollar. In 2021-23 we expect inflation to stabilise at an annual average of about 7.2%-still more than the central bank's medium-term target of 5%. Economic growth in these years will be close to the economy's potential growth rate (limiting upward inflationary pressures).
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
In 2018 the lira depreciated by 24.5% on average against the US dollar (in nominal terms). The lira depreciated significantly in January-August, with the exchange rate briefly reaching a low point of TL7.2:US$1 on August 13th. After a substantial recovery from September, the lira remained broadly stable against the US dollar for the remainder of the year. In the first months of 2019 the lira has again depreciated against the US dollar owing to political uncertainty and polarising campaign rhetoric around the March local elections, declining central bank foreign-exchange reserves and the re-emergence of tensions with the US-this time owing to Turkey´s purchase of the Russian-made defence system.
Having again reached TL5.80:US$1 in mid-April, we expect a gradual appreciation from this level in the second half of the year, and a year-end exchange rate of about TL:5.70:US$1. This forecast rests on our expectation that Turkey and the US will resolve their dispute, that government policy will be credibly reoriented, and that the central bank will maintain a tight monetary policy stance, lowering interest rates only as price pressures fade. There are large risks to this forecast, both in terms of probability and impact. If any of our expectations do not materialise, the lira could again depreciate substantially.
In 2020 we expect the exchange rate to depreciate as the current-account deficit widens and as central banks in advanced economies re-embark on a path of monetary policy tightening. Thereafter still elevated inflation and a significant current-account deficit (although not as large as that in 2017) will result in a gradual depreciation of the lira against the US dollar in nominal terms, to TL6.4:US$1 by the end of 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The current-account deficit as a share of GDP narrowed in 2018, to 3.6%, from 5.6% in 2017, as the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar depressed imports (owing to a decline in domestic demand) and boosted export competitiveness.
In 2019-23 we expect an average annual current-account deficit of about 2.9% of GDP. We expect a further contraction in the deficit in 2019 given the weak economic conditions and only a gradual widening thereafter. The deficit will remain contained (by historical standards) owing to significant gains in competitiveness from the 2018 currency crisis that will boost exports and limit import growth throughout the medium term.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Liberal Party, led by the prime minister, Justin Trudeau, to remain in power after the October 2019 election, but fallout from the controversy over alleged political interference in a criminal corruption case means that the result will be tighter than previously envisaged.
The renegotiation of the North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA) has reduced trade uncertainty, although the new agreement has yet to be ratified. Trade policy will remain a risk during the administration of the US president, Donald Trump, owing to Canada's reliance on the US, its key export market.
The federal budget will remain in deficit in 2019-23, as higher receipts from the planned carbon tax, the legalisation of cannabis and other sources will be more than offset by increased spending on infrastructure and other measures.
The Bank of Canada (BoC, the central bank) lifted the policy rate three times in 2018, to 1.75%. We expect it to keep rates on hold in 2019-20, owing to the weaker economy and housing market, and the benign outlook for inflation. Modest tightening will resume in 2021 and continue in 2022-23.
Consumer price inflation will ease to 1.7% in 2019, from 2.2% in 2018, reflecting generally lower oil prices. Inflationary pressures will ease further in 2020, in line with a weaker economy, before picking up again from 2021 as economic growth regains some momentum.
We forecast that real GDP growth will slow from 1.8% in 2018 to 1.6% in 2019 and to 1.5% in 2020 as private consumption growth moderates and an economic slowdown in the US dampens export demand. Real GDP growth will average 2% per year in 2021-23.

Canada's score improves slightly in 2019-23, pushing the country up to ninth place in our global business environment rankings. The best features of the business environment are political stability and openness to trade, although tax policy and the labour market will remain constraints.
Country forecast overview: Canada's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The government revises the Canada Business Corporations Act to introduce provisions on board gender diversity, annual election of directors, single election of directors and shareholder empowerment.
2021-23: Progress on increasing competition in certain sectors, such as telecommunications and dairy, will be uneven.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: The government will continue to welcome foreign investment but will sometimes reject foreign takeovers owing to national security considerations. Chinese investment and takeover bids will come under particular scrutiny.
2021-23: Foreign investment is likely to rise in value terms as resource nationalism in the oil and gas sector eases.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Canada, Mexico and the US ratify the revised North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA), now called the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), which retains the essence of the original treaty.
2021-23: Canada continues to diversify its trade ties. Free-trade talks with China resume.
Taxes
2019-20: The government provides benefits and tax breaks to improve business competitiveness compared with the US.
2021-23: The government introduces reporting mechanisms for multinational enterprises to reduce tax avoidance.
Financing
2019-20: The Bank of Canada (the central bank) develops a system-wide framework to measure stress in banking, insurance and investment funds.
2021-23: The government completes its update of financial legislation, including the Bank Act, the Co-operative Credit Associations Act, the Insurance Companies Act, and the Trust and Loan Companies Act.
The labour market
2019-20: Canada will enact policies to streamline processes and increase quotas to expedite the hiring of foreign talent by companies.
2021-23: The government further encourages the entry of skilled workers and professionals by raising its immigration target.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Plans to construct new oil pipelines from Alberta progress slowly, as the projects face opposition from environmental groups.
2021-23: After years of uncertainty, pipelines to carry energy resources from Alberta begin to come on stream.
Technological readiness
2019-20: The technology sector benefits from workers moving from the US, especially those on that country's H1B visas, for whom the political climate becomes more difficult.
2021-23: Expertise in artificial intelligence takes root, particularly in the academic centres of Toronto and Montreal.

Background: The Canadian economy was the ninth-largest in the world in 2017 (measured in US dollars at market exchange rates). It is highly integrated with the US economy, which absorbs 76% of its goods exports and is the source of about 51% of its imported goods. The US exerts a powerful economic and cultural influence on Canada. Fifty-eight per cent of Canadians say that English is their mother tongue, just over 21% say French and just under 21% have another language as their first. The majority of French-speakers live in Quebec, Canada's second most-populous province. Canada's unity is sometimes called into question, but support for sovereignty is currently muted in Quebec. Neither of the main parties in contention to lead the provincial government after the 2018 election is seeking an independence referendum.
Political structure: Canada is formally a constitutional monarchy, with the governor-general (always of Canadian nationality and appointed in Ottawa) acting as the representative of the British crown. In practice, the Canadian House of Commons is sovereign. Canada is a federation of ten provinces, each with substantial powers, and three territories. At the federal level are the Commons, the main seat of legislative power, and the non-elected Senate, which plays only a marginal role. The Liberal Party heads a majority government since winning the general election in 2015.
Policy issues: The federal government must balance the assistance that it is providing to the fossil fuel industry through approving new oil pipelines with the need to maintain its green credentials. The government will increase its spending on infrastructure significantly, including through its Canada Infrastructure Bank.
Taxation: The federal corporate income tax rate is 15%. Provincial governments charge corporate tax at rates between 2% and 16%. As at 2019 the top federal income-tax rate, on taxable income above C$210,371 (US$157,300), was 33%.
Foreign trade: The US absorbs about three-quarters of Canadian exports, so the health of its economy is crucial for Canada. Canada's trade deficit was US$16.6bn in 2018 and the current-account deficit was US$45.5bn (2.7% of GDP).

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
The Liberal Party, led by Justin Trudeau, has shifted Canadian politics to the left since it won a majority at the 2015 election. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects challenges to policy initiatives and friction with provincial administrations to intensify ahead of the next federal election, due in October 2019. The ongoing controversy over alleged political interference in a criminal corruption case also risks tarnishing Mr Trudeau's political brand.
The political scandal centres on allegations by the former attorney-general and justice minister, Jody Wilson-Raybould, that Mr Trudeau and his officials put inappropriate political pressure on her to abandon the criminal prosecution for fraud of SNC-Lavalin, a large Quebec-based construction and engineering firm. The saga took a new turn on March 29th when Ms Wilson-Raybould provided the parliamentary justice committee with a secret recording of a telephone conversation between herself and the clerk of the Privy Council, from December 2018. In that conversation the clerk highlighted the prime minister's concerns about the damaging impact of a prosecution on SNC-Lavalin, continuing a debate that had been under way internally for months about the option of proceeding under a deferred prosecution agreement, which would have let the company off with a fine. Ms Wilson-Raybould refused to intervene and the company faces the prospect of a trial.
The secret taping angered many Liberal members of parliament, who believed that it was time for Mr Trudeau to act, after weeks of him and other Liberals trying to broker a compromise with Ms Wilson-Raybould. She had quit the cabinet in February. Another cabinet minister, Jane Philpott, followed suit in March. Citing the unwillingness of the pair to state that they had confidence in him and his government, Mr Trudeau expelled them from caucus on April 2nd and indicated that they could not run as Liberals in the federal election. Just as it seemed that the Liberals had drawn a line under the issue, the leader of the main opposition Conservative Party, Andrew Scheer, revealed on April 7th that he had received a letter from Mr Trudeau's lawyer, threatening to sue him for libel over his comments relating to Mr Trudeau's role in the controversy. The affair is likely to result in further political fallout for the government and give added momentum to the Conservatives in the lead-up to the federal election.
Friction between the federal and provincial governments will intensify. The nationalisation in 2018 of the Trans Mountain pipeline expansion project, which is fundamentally opposed by the provincial government in British Columbia (BC), has raised questions over federal jurisdiction. Moreover, on April 1st the Trudeau administration imposed a carbon tax in four provinces-Saskatchewan, Manitoba, Ontario and New Brunswick-that did not have pricing plans meeting federal standards. However, broad agreement on 75:25 cannabis tax revenue-sharing between provincial administrations and the federal government, which came into effect in October 2018, together with the renegotiation of the North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA), which has helped to ease trade uncertainty, should help to limit tensions.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Political fallout from the SNC-Lavalin affair has seen the Conservatives edge ahead of the Liberals in opinion polls since February. However, we still expect the Liberal Party to form the government after the federal election due by October 2019. This reflects the advantages of incumbency, its recent successes on international trade policy, the legalisation of cannabis and decrying Saudi actions towards human rights. Since the October 2015 general election, the opposition parties have been in transition. The Conservatives have an experienced shadow cabinet and are building momentum under Mr Scheer. They will be further boosted by the United Conservative Party's defeat of the left-leaning New Democratic Party (NDP) government in the Alberta provincial election on April 16th. At the federal level, the Conservatives will focus on the Liberal government's perceived vulnerabilities, namely taxes and government spending. The Conservatives also contend that the Liberals have lost control of the border by allowing 40,000 people to walk across from the US over the past two years and claim asylum. The profile of the NDP leader, Jagmeet Singh, will be lifted by his election to parliament in February. However, the NDP trails well behind the two larger parties in terms of fundraising ahead of the election. The Conservatives are in the best shape in this regard.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Under the Liberals, Canadian foreign policy emphasises multilateralism over unilateralism, engagement over isolation, mitigating the effects of climate change and upholding human rights. This is in clear contrast to the policies pursued by Donald Trump's administration in the US. As a result, bilateral relations with the US will be strained during the remainder of the Trump administration. Canada will, nonetheless, seek to preserve relations with the US, its most important diplomatic and economic partner by far. Where possible, Canada will attempt to circumvent the White House by strengthening its ties to other levels of US government. Canada will also increase efforts to diversify trade.
The successful negotiation of the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), which will replace NAFTA and preserve the trilateral arrangement, mitigates significant trade risk for Canada. The revised deal maintains most of the substance of the earlier US-Mexico deal. In particular, the USMCA retains the Chapter 19 dispute-resolution mechanism, which Canada relies on to protect some of its industries (primarily lumber) from potential US anti-dumping measures. The new deal grants the US greater access to the Canadian market for dairy, poultry and eggs (these sectors are also managed by the government to ensure sufficiently high prices for farmers). This concession is broadly similar to what Canada had offered during negotiations for the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal, from which the US withdrew in 2017. In another move that should ease regional trade tension, Canada negotiated an exemption from any future tariffs that the US might impose on automotive imports. The new agreement was signed in November 2018 but is awaiting ratification by the three governments, and there is a significant risk of delay from the US side.
The implementation of the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) is expected to provide enhanced access to key Asian markets over the forecast period. A trade deal signed with the EU in 2016 has removed 98% of the EU tariff lines. With full implementation, the figure is set to rise to 99%.
China was a key target for the government's trade diversification policy until December, when Meng Wanzhou, a senior executive of Huawei, a Chinese telecommunications firm, was detained in Canada at the request of US authorities. Bitter exchanges between Canada and China since her arrest have cast a chill on bilateral relations. On March 1st the Canadian government announced that it would proceed with hearings on her extradition, and shortly afterwards China blocked canola (rapeseed) imports from two Canadian canola producers, on the grounds of biosecurity concerns. We expect tensions to persist throughout 2019, preventing progress on exploratory free-trade talks.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Canada will continue supporting domestic industries that are negatively affected by US trade protectionism. In 2018 the finance minister, Bill Morneau, announced measures to increase the competitiveness of Canadian businesses after the introduction of tax cuts in the US at the start of last year. These included a tax break on capital expenditure in manufacturing. Environmental policy will also be important in the remainder of the parliamentary term. Government support for the fossil fuel industry is crucial for economic growth in the short to medium term but appears incompatible with the federal government's green credentials. The Liberal Party will continue to seek a balance between these two objectives to preserve its voter base. On the one hand, the government has rolled out a national carbon tax of C$20/tonne (US$15/tonne) in provinces that did not have an equivalent carbon pricing programme in place. The federal tax will rise to C$50/tonne by 2022. However, the consensus on taxing carbon emissions seems to be weakening as opposition mounts. On the other hand, the government seems likely to approve (in June) the construction of the controversial Trans Mountain Expansion pipeline, designed to enable higher volumes of crude oil from Alberta to be transported to a port in BC. Additional major investments are being undertaken to develop Canada's natural resources.
Policymakers will continue to keep a close eye on the property market, which remains a key risk owing to recent monetary policy tightening and overleveraged Canadian households. Following the imposition of tighter mortgage-lending requirements since 2016, the market appears to be rebalancing as the quality of new mortgage lending improves. Price growth has slowed markedly, with some measures showing a dip in house prices in late 2018/early 2019, although trends vary across the country.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
The government is committed to a programme of infrastructure spending that will entail a series of budget deficits, but this will be partially offset by increased receipts due to the expected introduction of a cap-and-trade system and greater tax income as a result of cannabis legalisation. However, lower average oil prices in 2019-20 compared with 2018 will weigh on plans to reduce the fiscal deficit, as increased government support will be expected to shore up the economy and government receipts are likely to undershoot official projections.
According to the federal budget for fiscal year 2019/20 (April-March) handed down on March 19th, the budget deficit for 2019/20 will be C$19.8bn (US$14.8bn), equivalent to 0.9% of GDP. This is broadly unchanged from the Fall Economic Statement (FES, the mid-year budget update), published in November 2018. Official projections show the budget deficit declining to C$9.8bn, equivalent to 0.4% of GDP, by 2023/24. Following the budget, we have trimmed our budget deficit projections across the forecast period (our fiscal forecasts are calendar-year based). We now estimate that the fiscal deficit stood at 0.9% of GDP in 2018, and expect it to expand slightly, to 1.1% of GDP, in 2019 as the government looks to support the fossil fuels industry through rebates and additional incentives amid a softer price environment. In 2020 the government will respond to an economic slowdown with additional fiscal spending, which will push the deficit up to 1.3% of GDP; however, we expect the slowdown to be short-lived. The government will look to narrow the deficit in the longer term, and we expect it to fall gradually, to 0.8% of GDP by 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The Bank of Canada (BoC, the central bank) lifted its policy rate by 125 basis points between July 2017 and October 2018, in response to rising inflation and tightening monetary policy in the US. However, the BoC proceeded more cautiously than the Federal Reserve (Fed, the US central bank), and the Canadian policy rate has remained below its US equivalent-an unusual situation. The BoC had been on course to raise its policy rate, currently 1.75%, to what it considers to be a more normal range of between 2.5% and 3.5%. This reflects concern that prolonging the period of low interest rates would` encourage households to increase their borrowing, adding to near-record levels of household debt as a proportion of disposable income. However, the BoC kept monetary tightening on hold at its past three meetings, owing in part to lower energy prices, which pushed down the headline inflation rate.
Given the benign outlook for inflation, weak household spending growth, the softening housing market and signs of weaker economic momentum in the US, we now expect the BoC to leave the policy rate unchanged in 2019. We previously forecast that it would increase rates by 25 basis points this year. We continue to expect that the BoC will keep rates on hold in 2020, when the US enters a cyclical slowdown, which, because of the two countries' interlinkages, will cause economic growth in Canada to slow. Modest monetary tightening will resume in 2021 and continue for the remainder of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
Real GDP growth slowed to 1.8% in 2018, from 3% in 2017. This reflected weaker growth in most GDP components, notably private consumption and business investment, although export growth picked up. We expect real GDP growth to soften further in 2019, to an average of 1.6%. Monetary tightening and high household debt levels will dampen private consumption growth this year, and export growth is also expected to moderate, as a result of weaker economic expansion in the US, Canada's key export market.
Much of 2018 was characterised by the escalating trade dispute with the US. The renegotiation of NAFTA reduces one of the key downside risks to our forecast, although the agreement has yet to be ratified, and the steel and aluminium tariffs imposed on Canada by the US in 2018 remain in place for now. Other risks to the economic outlook include a renewed drop in global oil prices, which would act as a drag on economic activity.
Real GDP growth will slow further in 2020, to 1.5%, as the US enters a cyclical downturn. Economic expansion in Canada is expected to pick up again in 2021, and real GDP growth will average 2.1% per year in 2022-23. This will be supported by continued government spending on infrastructure and stronger export growth, driven by recovering demand in the US and enhanced trade ties with the EU and CPTPP members.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Rising oil prices until October 2018 and the increasingly protectionist trade policy of the US added to price pressures for much of 2018, when the headline rate of consumer price inflation picked up to an average of 2.2%. The headline inflation rate fell back to 1.6% year on year in the first quarter of 2019, below the BoC's 2% target rate, owing to lower petrol prices, although core inflation was 1.9%. We expect the headline inflation rate to average a benign 1.7% in 2019, reflecting the lagged effect of previous monetary tightening by the central bank, slowing export demand and generally lower oil prices. The mild economic slowdown in 2020 will lead to a further easing in the inflation rate next year, before it picks up again from 2021 as the economy strengthens.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
Tighter monetary policy, a broader improvement in the global economy and the draining of the surplus in the oil market lent support to the Canadian dollar in the first half of 2018, although falling oil prices have weighed on the currency in recent months. We expect the Canadian dollar to depreciate further against its US counterpart, from a full-year average of C$1.30:US$1 in 2018 to C$1.35:US$1 in 2019 and C$1.38:US$1 in 2020, reflecting weaker global oil prices, softer economic growth and a more dovish approach from the BoC, which we now expect will leave its policy rate unchanged in 2019. A pick-up in growth from 2021, and the resumption of monetary tightening, will underpin an appreciation in the Canadian dollar over the remainder of the forecast period, with the currency forecast to average C$1.28:US$1 in 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The exchange rate, commodity prices and the health of the US economy will continue to shape the outlook for the current account, which we expect will remain in deficit in 2019-23. The impact of softer global oil prices in 2019-20 will be offset by slowing domestic demand and, therefore, import growth. As a result, the merchandise trade deficit and the shortfall on the current account will remain broadly stable as a proportion of GDP, with the latter averaging 2.7% of GDP during this period. The CPTPP, the effects of which will first be felt at the start of the next decade, will result in higher trade volumes between Canada and Pacific nations. We expect that this will help to narrow the current-account deficit to 2.4% of GDP in 2023.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The head of the ruling regime, Nicolás Maduro, and his party, the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), are under intense political and economic pressure. Under The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast, we expect regime pragmatists to oust Mr Maduro and form a government with Juan Guaidó, the opposition leader who has declared himself interim president and who is openly offering regime pragmatists a series of benefits (amnesty, international financing, a transitional government, lifting of sanctions) that Mr Maduro can no longer credibly promise. There is a risk that the existing regime will retain cohesion and cling to power beyond 2019 if it finds financing to meet its debt obligations and boost dwindling oil production.
Following years-long economic collapse, GDP will continue to contract in 2019-20. High inflation has led to a collapse in private consumption, and difficult operating conditions have hurt investment. Following a change in policy under a new government, we expect economic growth to resume in 2021.
The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. Following our forecast transition this year, a new government will stabilise the economy, but the wholesale rethink of the institutional framework needed to restore investment and confidence is unlikely.
The recession that began in 2014 has devolved into a hyperinflationary crisis and will continue to deepen in the short term. The economy will not return to growth until 2021-assuming that a new government takes power and implements reforms. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, reinforcing our forecasts of only a weak recovery.
US dollar measurements of Venezuela's market size provide an overly positive picture of the economy, given the marked overvaluation of the fixed exchange rate. In reality, recession and extremely high inflation (driven by shortages of foreign exchange and basic goods) will continue to restrict purchasing power. After 2020, under a new government, we expect purchasing power and the business environment to improve.

Venezuela is in 82nd position globally in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings for 2019-23, the worst position in our ranking. This reflects the highly heterodox macroeconomic policies of an authoritarian government, a lack of legal security and weak institutions.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Start of rollback of interventionist measures like price controls, but political-instability concerns slow liberalisation. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and undermine free competition.
2021-23: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Regulation by new government protecting property rights introduced in an attempt at attracting investment.
2021-23: Despite efforts, actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2019-20: Currency controls are made less opaque but restrictions on the private sector's access to foreign currency remain in place.
2021-23: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2019-20: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2021-23: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2019-20: Inflation remains high and concerns about economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2021-23: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2019-20: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. The current freeze on redundancies is fazed-out
2021-23: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Underinvestment in the water network and electricity grid ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2021-23: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued water and electricity rationing.
Technological readiness
2019-20: E-government services remain almost non-existent and deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment.
2021-23: Limited regulator capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has plummeted as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices has plunged the country into a massive economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded republican institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and side-lining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy mired in a years-long economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. At the same time, mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign-exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Using IMF data, The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$22.3bn in 2018 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages. We estimate the current-account surplus at 4.1% of GDP that year.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
The civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), is under severe economic and political pressure. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that a national unity government composed of opposition and regime "pragmatists" will form a transitional administration later in 2019. The transition process, however, remains extremely uncertain, and we expect the entire forecast period (2019-23) to be characterised by political instability.
On January 23rd the president of the opposition-controlled National Assembly, Juan Guaidó, declared himself interim president and was swiftly recognised by most Western nations as the legitimate president of Venezuela. Mr Guaidó has re-energised a disillusioned population, allowing him to convoke massive demonstrations, sowing concerns among regime members of country-wide unrest at a time when dissatisfaction within the military's lower ranks is at an all-time high. More crucially, Mr Guaidó secured US sanctions on oil trade conducted by PDVSA, the state-owned oil company. Prior to this the US was the destination of around 40% of Venezuelan exports, PDVSA's largest cash-paying client and a key source of production inputs. All of this translates to a severe blow to the patronage flows underpinning the regime's internal stability. In an effort to regain some control, the regime recently stripped Mr Guaidó's of his parliamentary immunity and jailed his chief of staff. Nevertheless, we believe that the regime would draw the line at arresting Mr Guaidó, as it would prompt sizeable unrest and international backlash.
Mr Guaidó is presenting his leadership as a path out of the current quagmire for dissatisfied regime members. He has repeatedly called for the military to depose Mr Maduro, offering the lifting of oil sanctions, the arrival of international aid and financing, and amnesty for defectors. Overall, considering that the regime's raison d'etre is the enrichment of its members, which Mr Maduro can no longer guarantee, we expect that pragmatists within the regime will eventually side-line or expel "hardliners" in exchange for influence in Mr Guaidó's more prosperous government.
A Guaidó-led transition government is our baseline forecast; however, such an administration would face considerable hurdles and it is unclear how much muscle the opposition would have in a power-sharing transitional government. If opposition figures cannot deliver on its promises quickly enough, the government could well collapse, given the challenging tasks ahead. These include securing debt relief; rebuilding the rule of law; and attracting tens of billions of dollars in foreign investment. Through all this, the opposition would need to be careful to not upset its partners. Most of the opposition's economic rationalisation plans require reforms that eliminate the economy's distortions, closing the avenues for corruption and enrichment that regime members have used for years.
Three key assumptions underpin our baseline view. Firstly, that regime pragmatists will have enough capacity to overpower hardliners who would rather rule a ruined country than share a prosperous one. Years of economic malaise and failed dialogues have been insufficient to prompt regime change in itself, and, the military-a key powerbroker-remains behind Mr Maduro despite repeated rumours to the contrary. Secondly, that regime members will deem Mr Guaidó's amnesty and transitional government offers credible. Risks to this assumption include a deep-seated distrust of the opposition and fear of being prosecuted outside of Venezuela (a credible fear given accusations of drug- and weapon-trafficking levied at regime members). The third assumption underpinning our forecast for a unity government is a continued lack of hard-currency to sustain the patronage system. The main risk to this assumption comes from the possibility that Russia or China, erstwhile financiers, would bail out the regime. This is not our baseline forecast, but Venezuela's oil wealth remains a draw. Another risk to our assumptions around the regime's access to hard currency centres on transnational crime and the informal export of precious metals, and whether these enterprises could be enough to make up the lost revenue from oil exports.
Given the very high risks to our baseline view, there are several alternate scenarios, with varying probabilities. Our main alternate scenarios are the following (in order of likelihood): Firstly, a continuation of the PSUV's authoritarian rule (with or without Mr Maduro). Secondly, a complete collapse of the regime followed by an opposition-led government. Lastly, prolonged chaos-including, possibly, armed conflict-if divisions within the regime become clearer but no faction gains outright control of the state apparatus.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
The opposition's recently announced plans for a transitional government call for the renovation of all electoral authorities and for elections within 12 months of the transitional government's formation. As we currently expect such a government to coalesce within 2019, we expect elections at some point in 2020. International assistance in organising the elections would be necessary and forthcoming.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Mr Guaidó has marshalled hitherto unexpected levels of support from the international community. Most governments in the Americas, under the banner of the Lima Group, have recognised Mr Guaidó. The US is Mr Guaidó's most committed champion, instituting crippling oil sanctions and openly calling for the military to accept Mr Guaidó in place of Mr Maduro. The US's hawkish approach introduces risks of a military intervention. We currently do not foresee large-scale military action, in part because such an initiative currently lacks international legitimacy. However, the US administration has sunk considerable political capital into Mr Guaidó and smaller-scale interventions, such as targeted bombings, are a possibility, especially given that the US no longer has substantial economic sanctions to throw at the regime. Such action, however, is not included in our baseline forecasts.
Russia and China seem unwilling to provide the necessary financing-amounting to tens of billions of dollars per year-to stabilise the economy and PDVSA. Mr Maduro has openly courted the two countries, but with little apparent success in actual investment. Despite dealing with US sanctions, Russia recently sent a limited number of military personnel to Caracas, the capital, which will further antagonise its relations with the US. Nevertheless, we believe that both Russia and China would be willing to work with a successor government in an attempt at protecting their current investments in Venezuela.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Our expectation of a change of government later in 2019 implies huge changes to policymaking as a new administration works to end hyperinflation, restructure public debt, and rebuild institutions to restore confidence and promote investment. Until then, we foresee no fundamental change in policy by the Maduro regime, which remains technically unable and politically unwilling to undertake the deep and wide-ranging policy and institutional changes needed. Monetisation of large public deficits, coupled with mismanagement of the state-dominated oil industry, has led to hyperinflation and shortages of foreign currency, basic goods and industrial inputs. Any efforts to tackle these issues have been self-defeating, and so imbalances will persist and foreign exchange will continue to be rationed.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect that more orthodox economic policies will be implemented under the transition and successor governments. However, the pace and depth of the adjustment will be constrained by uncertainty over the stability of any new administration, and whether this takes precedence over the likely demands for reform from multilateral and bilateral lenders. Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and multilaterals (totalling US$19bn in 2019-22) and the restructuring of the government's debt obligations. This in itself will be a huge task for any administration. At the same time, PDVSA will need wholesale reform to open itself to the foreign finance needed to increase output, a process that will require considerable political capital.
Pockets of resistance are likely to exist. Internal stability within the PSUV is a major risk to our forecast, as the success of any government will depend on PSUV pragmatists fending off more radical party members. Hardliners would oppose international assistance, foreign investment and policy reforms on both ideological and personal grounds (as many regime insiders profit from the state's control of the economy).
Outside of these areas, we do not expect much success in rolling back the PSUV's strong interventionist bent in the economy. Thus, we expect limited real investment inflows, with the vast majority going into the oil sector, which will restrict economic recovery and fuel continued unrest.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
Authorities have not published complete official data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We expect that the fiscal deficit this year will be close to double figures as a percentage of GDP. The government relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency.
High inflation and the overvalued official exchange rate make debt/GDP ratios misleading indicators of fiscal stability. Considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) understates the true size of total public liabilities. Most sovereign and state-owned bonds (including PDVSA's) are in arrears. Bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy changes or a change in government. The exceptions to arrears are debts that threaten Citgo (PDVSA's US subsidiary) and leased facilities in the Caribbean. So far, Venezuela has taken a defensive stance, treating each claim individually and stalling as much as possible before complying when seizures seem imminent. Given PDVSA's extremely strained financial situation and the lack of further sources of financing, the strategy seems unsustainable.
Following sanctions on January 28th, the US government now considers Citgo to be under Mr Guaidó's purview, but it is unclear how much power Mr Guaidó will have over the company. The regime now has little incentive to defend Citgo from creditors, and it is also it is unclear if creditors could even claim it. PDVSA's strained financial situation means that the risk of default and seizure on Citgo, its Caribbean facilities and even shipments will remain high in the short term. Stalling tactics (including partial compliance with payments) will continue.
Under our baseline forecast, we expect a restructuring with external creditors in 2020. Owing to the need to maintain political stability, we do not expect the closure of the various handout programmes in operation, nor the complete removal of utility subsidies or the reformation of inefficient state-owned firms. Therefore, we expect public expenditure to be hard to reduce; the deficit will be substantial throughout the 2019-23 period.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The government's financing needs will continue to force the Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank) to print money. Money supply (M2) continues to grow rapidly, expanding by 75% month on month in February. By end-January Venezuela had significantly raised reserve requirements for the banking sector, which "contained" hyperinflationary pressures and allowed the bolívar to stabilise somewhat in short term. But this is a one-off effect; hyperinflation and significant currency depreciation will return in April. We expect a new administration to place a much greater emphasis on tackling hyperinflation and expect a substantial monetary adjustment in the context of a macroeconomic stabilisation plan. The introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) in such a context is highly likely.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 15% in 2018, we expect further contractions in 2019-20. A forecast recovery in 2021-23 rests on the assumption of a political transition that, supported by international assistance, produces a credible macroeconomic programme with improved management of oil wealth. However, reform will be limited in scope by a weak government, and we expect only a partial rebound in real GDP, following a decline of around 60% in 2013-20.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2019, reflecting the effect on real wages of hyperinflation, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will also contract, reflecting difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange. Moreover, power cuts are now very common-a result of severe underinvestment in the country's power infrastructure-and have significantly further damaged Venezuela's overall economic capacity. Our forecast for a recovery in investment later in the forecast period assumes a political transition and a pick-up in oil investment.
We expect oil output to bottom out at 900,000 barrels/day (b/d) over the coming quarters, kept from going lower by PDVSA's joint-venture partners. But until US sanctions on oil are lifted, margins will be smaller, as PDVSA has lost access to its closest and better-paying market. Under our baseline forecast of openness to foreign investment under a new government from 2019, production will start to recover in 2020 but will end the forecast period (2023) well below 2m b/d, the average output in 2017.
Export volumes will only start to recover in 2020, as an increase in domestic demand, which has been artificially constrained, will initially absorb the increase in oil output. For the same reason, import demand will rise sharply in 2019.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Decimated domestic supply, severe limits on imports and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official data have not been published since 2015, but the opposition-led National Assembly estimated that monthly inflation was 54% in February. In the context of a projected macroeconomic stabilisation plan later in 2019, we expect much tighter monetary policy and lower inflation. However, supply bottlenecks and bouts of inflationary pressure are likely.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
Under our current baseline forecast of a political transition later in 2019, the introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) amid deep imbalances and as a means to try to tackle hyperinflation is highly likely. The exact nature and implementation of such moves are hard to foresee, but our baseline forecast includes the continuation of some currency controls for the duration of the forecast period.
Since the start of 2018, the government has repeatedly devalued the currency and promised liberalisation of exchange controls. The official rate is determined by an auction process, but the government-which monopolises the country's exports-does not supply the system with foreign exchange, making the system unsustainable and access to foreign exchange practically impossible. At end-March the official rate stood at BsS3,300:US$1, compared with a black-market rate of over BsS3,700:US$1.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
We expect a small current-account deficit in 2019, buoyed by non-payment of interest on bonded debt ("savings" in excess of US$5bn in 2019 alone). Our export data, which are based on IMF data, may overstate receipts, as some exports are actually payments in-kind for loans, the repayment of which may not be included in their totality under forecast interest repayments (we have excluded repayments to Chinese lenders to maintain consistency with the World Bank's data on which our debt forecasts are based).
By 2020, with a new government in power, we expect that-following debt renegotiation-external financing will be restored. Although we expect exports to grow as oil production increases, we also expect a surge in imports, as Venezuela's own productive base has been decimated and imports have been compressed to artificially low levels. In addition, the government will be complying with its debt obligations, meaning that the restructured debt will actually result in increased outflows in interest payments. These factors will erode the current-account surplus to a deficit of 2.8% of GDP in 2023.
We currently expect that a new administration will secure enough finance to stabilise the balance-of-payments dynamics. However, there are considerable risks to this rosy outlook. In addition to assuming the installation of a pragmatic transition administration capable of retaining power, it hinges on substantial finance from the IMF, the quick implementation of a successful macroeconomic stabilisation package, the fast resolution of a debt renegotiation process in 2019-20, substantial inflows of financial and real investment into the economy in 2020-23, and a fast recovery in oil output after years of underinvestment and mismanagement.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
BCV: Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank)

Full text: Russia--highlights: Political outlook
Support for the president, Vladimir Putin, remains high. Modest economic performance and real cuts to government spending could lead to social discontent, but The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that this will remain contained. The opposition has been marginalised, and the likelihood of a political transition appears low. Mr Putin and his government face a long-term challenge of elite renewal that will be compounded by weak economic growth, although international sanctions provide an excuse for domestic economic failings. The authorities have turned to nationalism as a source of legitimation, but this is an unreliable and unpredictable mechanism for social control.
Russia--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.23 5.51 63 67 13 14
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 16 countries: Azerbaijan, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Kazakhstan, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Romania, Russia, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia and Ukraine.
Tensions with the West, and especially the US, have dampened the business environment outlook. We expect US and EU sanctions, as well as Russian counter-sanctions, to remain in place in the medium term. Poor relations with the West have increased the risks to foreign companies operating in Russia. Capital controls are unlikely, but remain possible in the case of a severe financial crisis (for instance if global oil prices drop sharply-not our core scenario). The gains made by Russia's entry to the World Trade Organisation (WTO) now look to be under threat as a result of increasing protectionism. Long-standing weaknesses of the investment environment will persist. Increased state intervention is likely to be mixed with market-oriented policies in some areas. There will be some measures to attract (mostly non-Western) foreign investment, such as in energy projects that have special technological and capital needs, but western sanctions will constrain such steps.

We forecast 1.5% GDP growth in 2019, a persistently feeble recovery from the recession in 2015-16. Government spending will continue to decline in real terms in the 2019-23 forecast period, possibly eroding the popularity of the government. In the medium term protectionist trends, the deficiencies of the banking sector, world financial sanctions and a poor investment profile will constrain growth potential. We forecast annual average growth of well below 2% in 2019-23. Barriers to faster medium-term growth include dependence on natural resources, a poor demographic outlook, the absence of a "culture of failure", low investment levels and a tricky business environment.

The population is forecast to decline over the forecast period and beyond, which is a significant impediment to growth prospects. Russia faces a demographic challenge resulting from low birth rates, low life expectancy (compared with Western countries) and an ageing population. The high rates of immigration that would be required to change the demographic profile are politically difficult. Outside low-skilled sectors, gaps in the labour market are expected to be tight, with implications for inflation and productivity. The ageing workforce will push up pension and healthcare costs significantly.
