Russia is one of the largest markets in Europe in terms of population, but the devaluation and subsequent depreciation of the rouble (against the US dollar and the euro), and the recession in 2015-16, have cut the size of the economy and reduced consumer purchasing power in US dollar terms. Personal disposable incomes have started to recover, but income growth will be slower than in the pre-crisis period, and consumer sentiment remains subdued. There will be significant regional variation, with some urban centres, in particular Moscow, the capital, recording higher income and consumption growth rates.
Russia--highlights: Long-term outlook
  2019-30 2031-50 2019-50

Growth of real GDP 1.7 1.5 1.6

We forecast average real GDP growth and real GDP growth per head slightly less than 2% in 2019-50. An unfavourable demographic profile, a difficult business environment, a fragile banking system, poor policy-making, and overreliance on natural resources will place constraints on Russia's long-term growth. Given its strong industrial tradition, Russia's chances of diversifying its economy could be strong, but this potential is unlikely to be fully realised in the medium term, following a sharp deterioration in political and economic relations with the West and structurally low investment levels.

Background: The transition to a market economy in the early 1990s was accompanied by a collapse in industrial production and a sharp drop in living standards. A contested privatisation process led to a highly concentrated ownership structure. Executive weakness and bureaucratic dysfunction contributed to a sharp decentralisation of power. After becoming president in 2000, Vladimir Putin sought to restore central control over the regions and tame independent corporate interests. Mr Putin presided over a period of strong economic growth in his first two terms. His re-election as president in 2012 and 2018 heralded the development of a more authoritarian domestic environment.
Political structure: Boris Yeltsin won the first democratic presidential election in June 1991 and was re-elected in 1996. Repeated confrontations with the legislature culminated in the dissolution of parliament in 1993 and a violent showdown in the following month. The powers of the executive were greatly increased by a new constitution, adopted in 1993. Mr Putin was elected president in 2000 and re-elected for a second term in 2004. His second term in office was characterised by increasing centralisation of the state. A loyal ally, Dmitry Medvedev, won the presidential election in 2008 and took over in May of that year. Mr Putin returned to the presidency for a third term in 2012. Following a constitutional change, Mr Putin's third term lasted six years, to 2018. He was re-elected to a fourth term in March 2018.
Policy issues: During Mr Putin's third term as president greater emphasis was placed on conservative values, anti-Westernism and great-power nationalism. The stand-off with the West is leading to a rollback of Russia's integration into the world economy, and attempts to insulate the Russian economy from Western financial channels. This is likely to strengthen further the state's role in the economy. Tit-for-tat sanctions have encouraged the government to emphasise import substitution. The focus on curbing "foreign influence" on domestic politics is likely to endure, along with close controls on civil society, the internet and the media.
Taxation: Reforms since 2000 have aimed to rationalise the tax system and cut the number of taxes and the corporate tax burden. Changes to the tax regime in 2001 included the introduction of a flat rate of personal income tax of 13% and a simplification of the administration of social security contributions. The corporate tax rate was cut from 24% to 20% in 2009. In 2019 the basic rate of value-added tax (VAT) rose from 18% to 20%.
Foreign trade: Mainly because of high international oil prices, export revenue has soared since 2000, except for dips during the global recession in 2009 and the collapse in oil prices in 2014-16. Import growth has picked up since 2000 as a result of rising real incomes and real rouble appreciation. Merchandise exports totalled US$444bn in 2018, and imports about US$249bn. Oil and gas account for about 60% of Russia's exports, with metals contributing a little more than 13%.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
The president, Vladimir Putin, was re-elected for a fourth term in March 2018. He enjoys sweeping formal executive powers by virtue of the 1993 constitution and his concerted drive in his first presidential term to recentralise power. A preponderance of political powers is attached to the office of president, including command of the armed forces and the right to appoint most of the important posts in the executive and judiciary. Parliament does not have direct influence on the formation of the cabinet, but must approve the president's candidate for chairman of the government (prime minister). Following a reform in 2012, most regional heads are now directly elected, but the selection of candidates is subject to approval by local legislatures. This "presidential filter" allows the centre (Moscow, the capital) to exercise significant control.
Parliamentary forces: In the election to the State Duma (the lower house of parliament) on September 18th 2016 United Russia, the "party of power" that is effectively controlled from the presidential administration, gained a constitutional majority, winning 54.2% of the vote and 343 of the 450 seats in the Duma. Although United Russia gained almost 100 seats compared with the 238 that it won in the controversial election in late November 2011, the party claimed almost 4m fewer votes than in 2011, given the low turnout of 47.8%. The three nominal opposition parties-the Communist Party of the Russian Federation (CPRF), the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia (LDPR) and Just Russia-saw their share of seats fall significantly. The election result indicates that the government is continuing to marginalise all formal political opposition. More importantly, it avoided a repeat of the 2011 election, when an apparent decline in support for United Russia helped to galvanise mass protests.

Political outlook: Political stability
In March 2018 Vladimir Putin was re-elected as president for a fourth term. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects broad continuity in his policy agenda, which focuses on "conservative cultural values", an authoritarian political culture and overt anti­Westernism. This means ongoing confrontation with the US and the EU regarding Ukraine, and a continued muscular foreign policy. Despite some pro-market rhetoric, economic policy will remain statist, nationalist and protectionist. Mr Putin's term runs until 2024, but given how heavily the political system leans on his charismatic leadership and popularity, attention will shift to how Mr Putin will manage an eventual presidential transition.
The weakness of most political and legal institutions-as well as the personalised and opaque governance system around Mr Putin-risks introducing elevated uncertainty into the political arena during the transition period. Most Russians associate Mr Putin's tenure with stability and prosperity, compared with the tumultuous 1990s, and this factors heavily into the popular aversion to political change. Any successor is likely to come from the team around Mr Putin and will not herald a sharp change in the policy agenda. However, it could be difficult for a successor to build legitimacy, given the weak long-term economic outlook and the strength of Mr Putin's legacy. Concern about political stability is likely to deter the government from pursuing radical reforms, especially if these prove unpopular.
Social unrest is a risk, but not our core scenario
Social unrest (which the government portrays as being orchestrated by the West) represents the biggest threat to political stability. As a result, the authorities monitor public opinion closely. Public support for the government and Mr Putin has fallen since June 2018, when the government announced its decision to raise the pension age from 2019. In August 2018 Mr Putin offered concessions softening the pension reform, attempting to present himself as the guardian of the Russian population against government plans that supposedly ran counter to popular interests. However, polling conducted by the Levada Centre, a well-respected Russian pollster, indicate that since mid-2018 into early 2019 approval of both the government and the president have fallen to pre-2014 levels (the illegal annexation of Crimea boosted Mr Putin's approval ratings markedly in February 2014). Aside from the issues of succession and pension reform, the greatest risks to political stability relate to the economy and the financial system.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
Russia is formally a "super-presidential" political system, with a high degree of power vested in the executive. The "vertical of power" was a leitmotif of Mr Putin's efforts to reconstitute and recentralise state power during his first two presidencies. In practice, however, the capacity of the president and the government to implement policy is circumscribed by weak institutions and an inefficient and inflexible bureaucracy. Russia has been characterised as a hybrid state, in which the formal institutions of governance co-exist with informal networks that can subvert constitutional order and the rule of law.
Although Mr Putin is more powerful than any other individual in Russia, his capacity to influence the political system as a whole is limited. Limitations on the media, and civil society, also hamper public oversight of policy formation and implementation. As a result, when major policy issues are at stake, there is a tendency towards "manual control", in which leading officials, or Mr Putin himself, take direct responsibility for the implementation of policy, which is then heavily publicised in state media. This personalisation of the policymaking process only reinforces the informal practices that it is intended to resolve. Businesses should not assume that government legislation, or even executive orders from the president, will necessarily change practices on the ground, or that legal judgments will be consistent with new laws.
There is likely to be a partial rebalancing of power away from the centre in favour of the regions in the 2019-23 forecast period. The re-establishment of direct gubernatorial elections in 2012 (albeit with nominations partly controlled by the centre) has prompted regional heads to focus more closely on local issues, and also endow them with greater legitimacy. Lower global oil prices compared with their pre-2014 levels will cut federal financing to the regions and municipalities, possibly fuelling popular discontent in remote regions.
The ineffectiveness of the state and bureaucratic interference in the economy are serious obstacles to doing business. Weak institutional and political accountability makes policymaking vulnerable to lobbying by powerful political-economic groups. Russia will remain a "limited access order" in the forecast period, in which politically connected insiders maintain high barriers of entry to new market participants.
Quality of public administration remains poor
The quality of the public administration is unlikely to improve significantly in 2019-23. Contrary to most impressions, the number of bureaucrats is not particularly large compared with other countries. Civil servants represent less than 3% of the employed labour force, similar to China and Turkey, and far less than the OECD average of about 9%. The problem with the bureaucracy is that it is sometimes corrupt and often inefficient, not that it is too big. In fact, a smaller civil service might even compound the problems of inefficiency.
The court system is slow, underfunded, and open to political influence and capture by private interests. Corporate "raiding", in which companies use law-enforcement services and/or the judiciary to seize the business of a competitor or to silence a businessman deemed that is a danger to the stability of the state, is a significant risk to doing business. The decision in 2013 to merge the Supreme Arbitration Court, which ruled on business disputes, with the Supreme Court, which oversees criminal and other civil disputes, represented a further setback to judicial independence. The arbitration courts had been separated from the general court system in the 1990s and had built up a track record of upholding property rights and supporting corporate governance.
Corruption cases are often used to settle business or political scores
Corruption remains a serious business risk. The largely state-controlled media cannot be relied upon to investigate and publicise corruption. Anti-corruption investigations are often used as a tool in political and business disputes, rather than to enforce the rule of law. Fiscal pressures may push the government to take more concerted steps to try to reduce the scale of high-level corruption in areas such as state procurement. However, tackling the broader problem of corruption would require deep structural and regulatory change, which could prove highly disruptive (provided the government has the willingness to embark on such a path, which, at any rate, remains unlikely). The political environment has grown more authoritarian since Mr Putin returned to the presidency in 2012, and even more so since the beginning of the conflict between Russia and Ukraine in 2014. The operations of independent media outlets have been further restricted, and controls on the internet have been increased. Curbs on the freedom of the press reduce the likelihood that efforts to counter corruption in the bureaucracy and state enterprises will be successful.
Political outlook: Election watch
In March 2018 Mr Putin was comfortably re-elected for a fourth term as president. With Dmitry Medvedev reappointed as prime minister (signalling policy continuity), it remains to be seen who could succeed the president in 2024; we believe that it is too early to identify a possible successor. Gubernatorial elections took place in 22 regions in September 2018; United Russia, the party closely associated with Mr Putin, performed poorly, hinting at rising popular discontent. This means that the 2021 parliamentary election will be a major test for United Russia.
Political outlook: International relations
The Minsk II ceasefire agreement, signed in February 2015, is highly unlikely to lead to a resolution of the conflict in eastern Ukraine, where Russia backs separatist rebels in the eastern Donbas region. The current status quo of a regularly breached ceasefire with contained levels of fighting seems likely to endure for several years-certainly at least until the 2019 Ukrainian presidential and parliamentary elections. A frozen conflict will prevent Ukraine from joining the EU and NATO, which Russia views as a direct threat to its national interests.
Russia-Ukraine relations have deteriorated further in recent months as a result of rising military tensions in the Sea of Azov, Ukraine's decision in September to terminate the 1997 Treaty on Friendship with Russia and a schism in the Orthodox Church in October after the Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople supported an appeal to establish an independent Ukrainian Orthodox Church.
The Ukraine conflict has led to a deterioration in Russia's relations with the West since 2014. In response, the US and the EU have imposed sanctions on Russian officials, as well as on the Russian financial, energy and defence sectors; firms in these sectors cannot raise capital on US or EU financial markets. Russia has responded with a ban on almost all Western food imports. Additional US sanctions also prohibit global firms from conducting business with Russian companies for the construction, modernisation or repair of energy pipelines (although projects started before August 2017, such as the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline connecting Russia to Germany, are excluded from the ban).
We expect existing US and EU sanctions to remain in place in the forecast period. US-Russia relations will remain poor, owing to deep-seated differences on Syria (where Russia props up the regime of Bashar al-Assad, the Syrian president), Iran (with which Russia is strengthening trade and political ties), Ukraine (where Russia backs separatist rebels), and the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces treaty (that the US withdrew from in February, accusing Russia of non-compliance). The US imposed new sanctions on Russia in March, April and August 2018, but their implementation has remained uneven and US statements have been contradictory. Additional US sanctions on Russia in 2019 are likely, but these will not alter Russia's foreign policy; however, we do not believe that the US will impose stringent sanctions, for instance on Russian sovereign debt or state-owned banks, as these could hurt US investors, destabilise international financial markets and possibly lead to a sharp retaliation from Russia (for instance through cyber-attacks).

The business environment score improves slightly, from 5.23 out of 10 in the historical period (2014-18) to 5.51 in the forecast period (2019-23). Owing to more rapid improvements in other countries, Russia falls from 63rd to 67th out of 82 countries in the global ranking. The improvement in Russia's score is primarily driven by gains in the macroeconomic environment and market opportunities categories. Russia's GDP now exceeds the pre-crisis peak recorded in 2014, but real incomes have declined for five successive years. Incomes will recover over the forecast period, leading to a rise in household consumption, although the growth rate will be low. The government will record substantial fiscal surpluses in the forecast period and the Central Bank of Russia (CBR) will hold inflation close to the 4% target from 2020. Government spending on infrastructure will increase over the forecasting period, particularly for transportation. The basic tax rates for individuals and business are unlikely to be raised. International sanctions will remain in place, but rising state resources and the gradual diversification of foreign funding will lead to a modest improvement in financing conditions. Russia continues to score well for quality of labour market and technological readiness, thanks to its educated workforce, a legacy of the former Soviet Union.
Russia's business environment remains difficult
Government policy towards private enterprise and competition will remain the worst-scoring category and is expected to deteriorate further. The state's dominant role in the economy will endure and could also threaten more competitive areas of the economy, such as information technology. The overall political environment is unconducive to long-term investment given both geopolitical risks and uncertainty over how and when an eventual political transition could be enacted. Despite international sanctions and protectionists measures, capital controls or limits to currency convertibility are unlikely.

Business environment outlook: Russia's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: No further sales of stakes in state-controlled companies. Sanctions may increase role of state in some sectors.
2021-23: State involvement in economy remains high, deterring and limiting competition in most sectors.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Special investment contract scheme providing tax cuts and regulatory guarantees for foreign investors is launched.
2021-23: Government remains committed to localisation policies and state subsidies that distort operating environment in favour of local firms in some sectors. Outside these sectors, foreign firms face similar operating conditions to local firms.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: EU and US sectoral sanctions remain in place; US sanctions expanded but fall short of targeting Russian sovereign debt. The Russia-led Eurasian Economic Union concludes some free-trade agreements.
2021-23: Sectoral sanctions and Russian counter-sanctions remain in place. Further import restrictions to promote localisation of production remain possible. Risk of exchange controls remains low.
Taxes
2019-20: Excise duties on alcohol and tobacco rise. Gradual cut in oil export duties, offset by increase in mineral extraction tax.
2021-23: Some non-tax levies brought into the tax code. Basic tax rates for businesses do not change.
Financing
2019-20: International financial sanctions limit access to external capital markets. Further measures adopted to facilitate non-US dollar-denominated lending and trade, but capital flows and financial links to and from Asia will remain modest.
2021-23: Central Bank of Russia (CBR) reforms improve the stability of the banking system, but the sector remains state-dominated, distorting capital allocation. Companies continue to rely heavily on retained profits to finance investment.
The labour market
2019-20: Education spending rises, albeit from a low base. Migration from Central Asia remains substantial, but low-skilled.
2021-23: The size of the local workforce begins to decline, further constraining productivity growth. The retirement age rises incrementally. Investment in retraining and lifelong learning remains inadequate.
Infrastructure
2019-20: New private public partnership model run by Vneshekonombank is developed, with substantial public funding.
2021-23: Infrastructure spending rises, with a particular focus on the regional road system, supported by the National Welfare Fund (the sovereign wealth fund).
Technological readiness
2019-20: Roll-out of fourth-generation mobile networks continues, but coverage still patchy and unreliable in remote areas.
2021-23: Research and development spending increases, but remains significantly below OECD average.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.6 7.2 54 45 12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 16 countries: Azerbaijan, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Kazakhstan, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Romania, Russia, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia and Ukraine.
Russia's leadership regards macroeconomic stability as a prerequisite for state security, and it will remain a high priority throughout the forecast period. The federal budget will remain in surplus through the forecast period, limiting additional borrowing (especially externally). The fiscal rule aims to balance the budget based on a conservative oil price of US$40/barrel (in 2017 prices), well below The Economist Intelligence Unit's oil price forecast throughout 2019-23 (as at April 2019). Excess revenue from the oil sector will be accumulated as foreign-currency reserves, providing a buffer in the case of financial or geopolitical shocks.
Despite rising reserves, we expect the Ministry of Finance to successfully resist political pressure to significantly loosen fiscal policy so as to contain popular discontent with low living standards. The fiscal rule will also prevent the appreciation of the rouble (against the US dollar), as a result of which Russia is expected to run a current-account surplus throughout the forecast period. Public debt is low; the external debt of state-companies is significantly higher but will remain stable over the forecast period as international financial sanctions constrain access to Western capital markets.
The main risk to macroeconomic stability will continue to be the heavy reliance on revenue from the oil and gas sector. However, Russia's oil sector is at the low end of the global cost curve, and would probably maintain production and investment at a price as low as US$25/b.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
3.3 2.8 73 78 13 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 16 countries: Azerbaijan, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Kazakhstan, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Romania, Russia, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia and Ukraine.
Policy towards private enterprise and competition has always been one of Russia's worst-scoring indicators, and the country slips further in the global ranking in 2019-23 (ranking 78th out of 82 countries). The Federal Anti-Monopoly Service estimates that the state controls up to 70% of the economy. Competition is distorted in many sectors by state subsidies and soft budget constraints. Politics and business are closely entwined, and the justice system compromised. Sanctions have deepened the dependence of firms on state banks and government subsidies, especially in the defence sector; state-directed lending is widespread. Russia is one of just 12 countries on the "Priority Watch List" for intellectual property rights protection and enforcement of the Office of the US Trade Representative.
There will be little privatisation over the forecast period
Some officials continue to stress the need to reduce the state's role in the economy, but a major privatisation programme is unlikely; if such a programme was launched, foreign investors' appetite would be constrained by sanctions. The government has budgeted for almost no privatisation receipts in 2019-21. Major state companies may use their privileged position to acquire control of foreign competitors, as with state-owned oil transportation firm Transneft's acquisition of a controlling stake in the Novorossiysk Port in October 2018.
The court system is often compromised, but less subordinate to political interests than is widely assumed. In a number of high-profile cases the state or powerful insiders have used the judiciary to expropriate businesses. This will remain a significant risk for leading entrepreneurs, but such cases remain rare. Contrary to widespread opinion, businesses continue to win court cases against the state frequently. The merging of regular and arbitrazh courts in 2014 appears to have reversed some of the improvements in the quality of jurisprudence in commercial cases. An improvement in the protection of commercial and property rights over the forecast period is unlikely.
The government will continue to make some progress in removing the technical and administrative barriers to conducting business, including by expanding e-government services and reducing the frequency of cumbersome and time-consuming regulatory checks. However, protection of intellectual property is likely to remain weak. Given the confrontation with the West, the Russian government has little incentive to strengthen oversight, and the State Duma (the lower house of parliament) has considered waiving patent protections for companies based in countries that impose sanctions on Russia.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
3.3 3.3 78 80 16 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 16 countries: Azerbaijan, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Kazakhstan, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Romania, Russia, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia and Ukraine.
There are significant regional variations in the business environment
Policy towards foreign investment is Russia's second worst-scoring category in the forecast period, and no improvement in the score is anticipated. The government will continue to promote measures to encourage import substitution, including through an extensive subsidy programme for manufacturers and the agricultural sector. International sanctions and Russian counter-measures are expected to remain in place, and US sanctions are likely to be further extended. The cost of compliance for foreign companies will be significant, whereas Russian companies will face difficulties in navigating a highly uncertain and changing environment. There will continue to be significant regional variations in the operating environment for businesses. However, the government and regional authorities remain keen to attract foreign investment, particularly when this leads to the localisation of production of previously imported goods. Special Investment Contract schemes will gradually become available for foreign companies to negotiate preferential regulatory and tax regimes for greenfield investments.
Foreign investment in "strategic" sectors, which includes most investments in hydrocarbons, metals, defence and communications, will continue to be closely controlled by the government. Permission from a government commission is required to acquire a stake of more than 25% in so-called strategic industries. In practice, the law on strategic sectors is not expected to be a significant impediment to foreign investment, although obtaining approval is time consuming. The significance of formal rules on foreign direct investment, as on other matters, has waned. Obtaining the personal endorsement of local or sectoral actors and that of the president is of greater relevance.
Geopolitical tensions with the West have raised the risk that rulings of international investment arbitration bodies may be disregarded by Russian courts. However, Russia has continued to formally abide by WTO rulings on state subsidies, while in practice retaining high-and increasing-levels of protectionism. The increasing role of the Russian security services in economic policymaking may result in additional restrictions being placed on foreign investment in certain sectors. The "securitisation" of economic policy-making has also had a negative effect on the quality of legislation, which is often adopted quickly, with little stakeholder consultation or consideration of the impact on business. This particularly concerns the information technology sector.
Despite the "securitisation" of economic policy, the government, and particularly regional authorities, will remain eager to attract foreign investment. In 2019 the government will establish a new framework for Special Investment Contracts, providing protection against regulatory or tax changes and giving foreign companies access to state support for the localisation of manufacturing production and state procurement tenders. Foreign car companies will also be eligible for compensation of scrappage fees, one of the main protectionist measures to support the automotive industry.
Russia will conduct only a limited "pivot to the east" over the forecast period. The restricted pool of potential investors and Western sanctions will enable non-Western companies to demand favourable terms, particularly in the resource sector and high-tech sectors. High-level investment by Chinese firms is likely to receive official backing (albeit under important scrutiny on so-called security grounds), allowing such companies to often overcome the administrative and regulatory barriers encountered by foreign firms.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.9 7.8 55 48 12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 16 countries: Azerbaijan, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Kazakhstan, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Romania, Russia, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia and Ukraine.
We do not expect formal capital controls to be imposed
Russia is a member of the WTO, having made considerable progress over the pre-crisis period in liberalising its foreign trade and exchange regime. However, the stand-off with the West over Ukraine since 2014 has led to tit-for-tat sanctions, with a significant risk that further trade restrictions will be imposed. Ensuring sanctions compliance increases the cost and duration of a wide range of international transactions, and could delay payments (especially in US dollar). Russian economic policy has grown increasingly protectionist, and the EU has made a number of complaints to the WTO in relation to increased non-tariff barriers. The capital account was liberalised in 2006, although Russian tax residents are still required to repatriate earnings from foreign trade deals. The government plans to remove requirements for the repatriation of funds from contracts denominated in roubles by 2024 and to relax requirements for foreign-currency contracts. The authorities stopped short of reintroducing formal exchange controls when the rouble came under strong pressure in 2008-09 and 2014-15. Formal capital or exchange controls are unlikely, except in the case of severe oil price (and thus exchange-rate) volatility, and are not part of our core forecast.
Tensions between Russia and the West are systemic in nature, and there is little likelihood of a resolution to the conflict in Ukraine in 2019-23. We expect US and EU sectoral and Crimea-related sanctions to remain in place throughout the forecast period. The US is likely to impose further sanctions on Russia in 2019. These could include restrictions on the purchase and trade in new sovereign debt, but this is not our core scenario, as the US will remain wary of Russia's potential retaliation (for instance through cyber-attacks). Companies based in third countries that trade with sanctioned Russian entities could also face increased pressure from the US Treasury, particularly banks and defence contractors.
The use of economic sanctions is now well established as a policy tool
The use of economic sanctions is now well established in Russia as a policy tool, and a diplomatic conflict with any foreign country (in particular in the post-Soviet area) could result in some kind of restrictions being imposed on that country's imports. Russia's ban on Western food imports is now seen as a central element of government economic policy to develop the local industry, and is likely to remain in place throughout the forecast period. The government adopted only symbolic counter-measures in response to the April and August 2018 US sanctions, but there remains a risk that the leadership will place restrictions on the operations of individual Western companies.
Beyond formal sanctions, informal and non-tariff barriers to trade will remain substantial. Even before the latest trade conflict with the West, Russia had introduced a whole range of restrictions on food and agricultural products using phytosanitary justifications. It will continue to provide extensive state support to important sectors such as automotive, agriculture and medical goods. A number of disputes have been formally raised at WTO level between the EU and Russia. Russia's focus on economic sovereignty increases the risk that it will not implement rulings against it reached by the WTO or other multilateral bodies, although in June 2018 it removed anti-dumping tariffs against Italian and German automobiles following a WTO ruling.
Russia will continue to promote regional trade integration within the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) and the Eurasian Economic Union (EEU). It will actively seek new free-trade agreements (FTAs) between the bloc and third countries. Free-trade deals with Iran and Israel are likely in the forecast period. Negotiations over an FTA between China and the EEU are unlikely to be concluded by 2023. The effective operation of the EEU as a single market has always been in doubt and has been undermined by Russia's sanctions and counter-sanctions with the West, but work to harmonise regulations across the bloc will continue.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.3 5.3 62 69 14 15
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 16 countries: Azerbaijan, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Kazakhstan, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Romania, Russia, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia and Ukraine.
Following a rise in value-added tax (VAT) at the start of 2019, the government is committed to keeping the corporate and income tax rates stable for the remainder of Mr Putin's term, to 2024. However the underlying tax code is subject to regular changes; the Russian Chamber of Trade and Industry estimates an average of 30 changes to the tax code are made each year. The time it takes to pay taxes is now comparable with that in the advanced OECD countries. Enforcement of tax regulation remains uneven, and the tax authorities are often implicated in cases of corporate raiding. Russia's income tax rate is low, at a flat rate of 13%. The standard VAT rate, at 20%, is slightly higher than the unweighted OECD average of 19.3%. As of the start of 2019, VAT is now also charged on electronic goods and services provided by foreign companies Employers also pay a 30% social insurance premium into a non-budgetary fund that significantly raises the effective rate of personal tax. The standard rate of corporation tax is 20%, which is low by international standards. The tax system for mineral resources is responsive to price movements and is not generally seen as an impediment to investment. The production-sharing agreements signed in the 1990s are unlikely to be revised further; however, the government is highly unlikely to conclude further deals of this kind.
Main tax rates will not fluctuate substantially
We expect the government to keep the main tax rates stable over the rest of the forecast period, in line with recent pledges. The budget is forecast to be in surplus throughout the forecast period and tax-collection rates will continue to rise, mitigating the need for further increases in the tax burden.
Land and property taxes for families with children will be cut throughout 2019. Following a pilot project, the government is likely to roll out a scheme to bring self-employed into the formal economy with a low tax rate of 4%. Take-up is likely to be limited and the grey economy will remain large.
As part of a systemisation of the tax system, several non-tax levies, in particular charges for emissions and environmental damage, will be brought into the tax code. Although this will not formally increase the financial burden on business, transferring these charges to the oversight of the tax authorities is likely to result in stricter enforcement.
The government is overhauling the tax system in the energy sector
The government plans to complete a "tax manoeuvre" in the oil sector by 2024 that will reduce export taxes on oil and oil products to zero over the next six years, while increasing the mineral extraction tax (MET). The government estimates that this will increase the tax burden on the oil sector by Rb220-270bn (US$3.4bn-4.2bn) a year-a modest sum. Some oil refiners will receive subsidies to hold down gasoline prices. The government is likely to make further changes to the tax regime in response to movements in the oil price and industry lobbying, including conceding preferential agreements for mature fields.
In mid-2018 Andrei Belousov, a presidential advisor, called for a windfall tax on major resource companies that had benefited from high commodity prices and the low rouble (against the US dollar). We do not expect a windfall tax to be formally adopted, however the authorities will put heavy pressure on resource companies to maintain high levels of investment, particularly in infrastructure and initiatives that support the goals of the 12 "National Projects" developed by the government in 2018.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.8 5.5 61 65 12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 16 countries: Azerbaijan, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Kazakhstan, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Romania, Russia, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia and Ukraine.
Access to finance is a constraint for Russian business, and corporate investment is driven by retained earnings. International sanctions on several major state-owned banks will keep the cost of financing high. However, reduced reliance on external funding has increased the resilience of the banking sector and focused government effort on developing local sources of capital. The CBR has made progress in cleaning up the banking sector, but the political influence of the largest banks constrains effective regulation. State banks dominate the financial sector and directed lending is widespread, allowing many non-competitive enterprises to continue to operate.
International sanctions constrain external borrowing
Owing to sanctions, all borrowers, whether subject to Western sanctions or not, will continue to encounter restricted access to external financing, and borrowing costs will remain elevated for the foreseeable future. Even before the sanctions were first imposed in 2014, the cost of financing for business was significantly higher in Russia than in other emerging markets. If sanctions are eased or lifted (not our core scenario), risk premiums on loans to Russian banks will come down only slowly, and it is unlikely that international banks will return to the Russian market quickly.
The finance ministry and the CBR will maintain substantial foreign-exchange reserves to support sanctioned banks and major enterprises, and provide foreign-currency liquidity as required through special-purpose vehicles. These will also provide the resources to bail out systemically important institutions in the event of another financial crisis (not our core scenario).
Vnesheconombank (VEB, a state-owned investment bank) will be an important part of the government's investment programme in 2019-24, providing state guarantees and financing for major public-private partnerships. The conservative budget rule and tight fiscal policy will lead to the steady accumulation of public savings. The value of the National Welfare Fund (NWF, the sovereign welfare fund) will exceed 7% of GDP in 2019, the threshold the government believes is sufficient for fiscal stability.
Efforts to "de-dollarise" foreign trade relationships will continue to remain small in scale over the forecast period. Non-Western countries will account for a greater share of external financing, but banks in third countries will remain wary of dealing with sanctioned entities.
Banking sector fragmentation has decreased in recent years
Financial regulation has improved from a low base, with the CBR using the crisis following the rouble devaluation to force the closure of a significant number of small, poorly managed and under-capitalised banks. Nevertheless, corruption and related-party lending remain widespread. These led to the collapse of three major banks in 2017, indicating that deficiencies in financial oversight remain. The banking sector was more stable in 2018, but fragilities will remain throughout 2019-23.
The financial sector will remain dominated by state-owned banks, which will inhibit the efficient allocation of capital. The banking sector will continue to provide insufficient intermediation. Businesses will continue to rely on retained profits to finance a large share of their investment programmes.

Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.5 6.4 28 35 6 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 16 countries: Azerbaijan, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Kazakhstan, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Romania, Russia, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia and Ukraine.
The labour market will remain an attraction for investors. Advantages include the low cost of labour (although senior-level Russian talent is expensive) and a well-educated workforce (a legacy of the Soviet education system). Education levels are high relative to per-head income, and university enrolment is comparable with OECD levels. Despite the muted demand outlook, labour shortages are likely to be a constraint in some sectors, particularly high-skilled areas. Employment protection for permanent employees in Russia is above the OECD average, and official statistics suggest that the use of temporary contracts is low in international comparison. As a result, the labour market tends to adjust to demand shocks through reducing wage levels and hours worked, rather than the overall employment level. Bonuses often make up a significant share of earnings, increasing payroll flexibility for employers. A long-delayed rise in the pension age is now being implemented, but resources to enable older workers to retrain and continue employment are inadequate.
In the coming years the retirement age will rise incrementally, to 65 for men and to 60 for women, providing a boost to the working-age population. Nevertheless the labour force (defined as 15-64) will fall by 0.5-1% a year in 2019-23 and this decline will continue in the medium- to long-term. Net positive migration from Central Asia will remain high, but this will principally fill gaps in low and medium-skilled positions.
Labour costs are low relative to high education levels
The labour market is likely to remain inflexible, although this will be mitigated by a substantial informal sector. The government is unlikely to enact major liberalisation of employment legislation. The large state role in the economy and government subsidies to main industries will continue to create incentives to hoard workers and hinder the efficient allocation of labour to faster-growing sectors. Labour mobility will also remain low. Increased investment in regional roads and transport from smaller towns to major agglomerations will provide a modest boost to labour availability and flexibility where growth and demand are strongest.
Despite demographic pressures, labour costs will remain low relative to the education level of the workforce. The budget rule will keep the rouble weak against the dollar and inflation is likely to remain close to target.
Unions will remain subordinate to regional and national officials. The incidence of strikes and labour-related unrest should continue to be comparatively low, and the authorities will typically intervene quickly to resolve disputes.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.3 4.8 64 64 15 15
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 16 countries: Azerbaijan, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Kazakhstan, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Romania, Russia, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia and Ukraine.
A modest improvement in the score and ranking for this category is expected over the forecast period, as the government has made investment in roads (an area of persistent weakness, partly owing to extreme weather conditions) a priority over the next six years. Air-transport capacity is extensive, but connections between regional centres (rather than via Moscow, the capital) are thinner. Mobile-phone penetration exceeds that of the other BRICS countries (Brazil, India, China, South Africa). The quality of federal (arterial) roads has improved in recent years, but there is strong regional variation in the quality of infrastructure, and more than half of the regional road system is unpaved. A large share of goods is transported by railway. A focus on major, politically important construction projects has diverted funds from small, but more effective, projects. It is estimated that the development of Crimea, which Russia illegally annexed in 2014, has absorbed up to a quarter of infrastructure spending since 2014.
Infrastructure links with China will grow
Infrastructure spending has been low and flat as a share of GDP since 2012, but is expected to rise over the forecast period. In 2018 the president pledged Rb11trn (US$170bn) over 2018-24 to improve the road network, with a particular focus on improving the quality of the regional road system. About 25% of these funds are supposedly due to be raised from the private sector.
The quality of electricity supply will remain good, apart from in Crimea, which has suffered major blackouts. There is currently a surplus of energy supply, but much of the generating capacity is old and in need of replacement. Price liberalisation will push up business costs, but should reverse the recent fall in investment in 2019-23.
The government will seek to boost public-private partnerships led by VEB and underpinned by sovereign guarantees. VEB is aiming to fund projects valued at Rb3trn, but according to the prime minister, Dmitry Medvedev, partnership with private banks could increase this portfolio by four times. Major domestic businesses will come under heavy pressure to participate in these initiatives.
Rail infrastructure will remain good, but a reluctance to raise tariffs will hold back investment. Cargo transport speeds will remain low, and commercial users, in particular in the agricultural sector, will encounter bottlenecks.
Transportation infrastructure for the Northern Sea Route through the Arctic Ocean will be a major focus of investment in the forecast period. A private energy company, Novatek, will develop the second phase of the Yamal liquefied natural gas (LNG) field. The Power of Siberia gas pipeline, linking gasfields in eastern Siberia to China, is will begin operations before mid-2019. A second gas pipeline to China from western Siberia (the Altai pipeline), which would in principle give Gazprom, the state-owned gas monopoly, the power to switch supplies between Europe and Asia, remains under discussion. Russia will be a participant in China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), but the number of projects initiated under its aegis will be limited. There has been no progress on a high-speed rail line from Moscow to Beijing, China's capital.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.9 7.5 32 33 4 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 16 countries: Azerbaijan, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Kazakhstan, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Romania, Russia, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia and Ukraine.
Technological readiness is one of Russia's best-scoring categories. Internet usage and mobile-phone penetration are high, and e-commerce has grown rapidly in recent years, despite declining real incomes. The government will invest heavily in digitising its services online over the forecast period, but Internet regulation will also become more stringent. Spending on research and development (R&D) is low as a share of GDP, and Russia accounts for just 0.23% of international patents. The government is officially eager to harness new technology to raise productivity and trend growth, but previous efforts to foster the development of high-technology sectors have had limited success. Robotisation is one-tenth of the OECD average and the lowest among the BRICS, despite Russia's large manufacturing sector.
Investment levels are low
Spending on R&D is just 1.1% of GDP, and investment levels remain low, at about 20% of GDP (compared with about 45% of GDP in China). Government spending on education will rise modestly as a share of GDP over the forecast period, which will boost public funds for research. Commercial R&D investment is pro-cyclical and is also likely to pick up in the first half of the forecast period as the economy continues to recover from the 2014-15 recession. Overall levels of R&D spending will nevertheless remain below the OECD average (2.3% of GDP).
The rapid growth in e-commerce (expanding on average by almost 20% a year over the past four years) is expected to continue. E-commerce accounts for 6-7% of total retail, compared with 10-15% in OECD countries.
Development of Russia's information technology (IT) and software industries may be inhibited by growing regulation, as well as censorship. The government is concerned about "information security" and is likely to adopt a "sovereign Internet" bill to enable to Russian section of the Internet to continue to function if cut off from external servers. This will also increase the authorities' ability to block content. This bill and localisation and storage requirements will impose costs on communication and IT companies, reducing funds available for research and investment and delaying the roll-out of fifth-generation mobile coverage. Major foreign IT companies will be exposed to high levels of scrutiny by the authorities. The government is eager to replace foreign software with domestic alternatives, reducing opportunities for international IT companies.
Low levels of competition, high barriers to entry and a focus on the development market will continue to deter corporate investment in innovative technologies. The state will seek to incentivise innovation through procurement policy, and to coerce large state-owned companies to increase R&D spending, with limited success.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
Russia's stand-off with the West has strengthened statist, nationalist and protectionist trends within the government. Economic sovereignty-understood as insulating the economy from external shocks-will remain a priority. This includes a large and positive sovereign external asset position, protectionist measures to support domestic manufacturing through import substitution and a cautious approach to foreign investment. The authorities are also reducing the use of the US dollar in an effort to insulate the country from potential US sanctions, but The Economist Intelligence Unit expects these efforts to remain relatively limited in scope as the majority of Russia's trade continues to be conducted in US dollars.
During Mr Putin's fourth presidential term we expect economic reform to continue to be subordinated to the imperatives of political stability. The policy agenda will focus on ambitious national development targets, which include boosting investment, improving education and healthcare, and reducing poverty. Despite global oil prices forecast at US$61-76/barrel (significantly higher than 2015-17 levels), achieving these goals will be challenging. The government aims to boost revenue through tax and pension reforms passed in mid-2018.
The banking sector represents one of the main downside risks to the economy. The sector is struggling with the legacy of the 2008-09 global financial crisis. The imposition of sanctions on Russia from 2014 that prohibit state banks from raising capital in the US and the EU, followed by the collapse of the rouble against the US dollar in 2015, led to a surge in non-performing loans (NPLs). In 2017 the Central Bank of Russia (CBR) took a majority equity stake in B&N Bank, a major private lender, and bought more than 99% of Otkritie, formerly Russia's largest private bank, as part of a bail-out process. The situation improved last year, with the NPL/total loan ratio peaking at about 11% in mid-2018, but the CBR continues to provide funding to support the banks that it has taken over. The situation could deteriorate if a sharp depreciation of the rouble (not our core forecast) leads to corporate defaults on external debt.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy
Fiscal indicators
(% of GDP)
  2018 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023
Government expenditure 16.2 16.1 16.0 15.5 14.6 14.5
Government revenue 18.8 18.4 17.9 17.5 16.6 16.4
Budget balance 2.7 2.4 1.9 2.0 2.0 1.9
Government debt 10.3 9.3 8.8 8.1 7.3 6.6
In response to the collapse in oil prices in 2014-16, which significantly reduced fiscal revenue, the government sharply cut spending in real terms. In 2018 oil prices recovered to an average of US$71.1/b (up by 30.7% year on year), and the economic recovery boosted tax revenue from non-hydrocarbons. As a result, the budget posted a surplus of 2.7% of GDP in 2018.
Under the Ministry of Finance's fiscal rule, if oil prices exceed US$40/b, the additional revenue is converted into foreign currency to boost the National Wealth Fund (NWF). The CBR (which implements the fiscal rule) suspended foreign-currency purchases until mid-January 2019 to support the national currency, but has since resumed the purchases.
The government's 2019-21 budget plan will maintain a fiscal surplus. Expenditure will grow modestly in real terms, but will continue to contract as a share of GDP. Military spending will remain high, but spending will be redirected towards health and education. Revenue assumptions will remain conservative, retaining the US$40/b oil price assumption-we expect oil prices to average about US$70/b in the 2019-23 forecast period. Budget revenue growth is therefore likely to remain strong, and we forecast an average budget surplus of about 2% of GDP in 2019-23.
Public debt is low (10.3% of GDP in 2018) and will decline in the forecast period as a result of budget surpluses and the willingness to limit reliance on debt (so as to make the economy resilient to potential external shocks such as sanctions or a drop in oil prices). At end-February 2019 the NWF had total assets of US$59.1bn (or about 3.6% of GDP). Given that we expect the oil price to exceed US$40/b in 2019-23, the NWF will grow steadily. This will provide the government with a fiscal cushion to mitigate the impact of further potential Western sanctions.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy

Lending rate (av; %) 8.9 9.4 10.2 9.8 9.6 9.4
Deposit rate (av; %) 5.4 5.6 5.8 5.7 5.6 5.6
The central bank will remain cautious
In December 2018 the CBR increased its policy rate by 25 basis points, to 7.75%, in anticipation of the inflationary pressures expected in 2019, driven by the increase of the value-added tax (VAT) rate and the resumption of foreign-currency purchases from January 2019. This followed a 25-point increase in September, in response to the imposition of additional US sanctions in April and August 2018, which led to a depreciation of the rouble against the US dollar.
The CBR held its policy rate steady in March 2019. It noted that inflation in February (5.2% year on year) remained within its forecast band and that the inflationary effect of the value-added tax (VAT) rate increase has materialised, but remains moderate (the impact to annual inflation stands at about 0.6-0.7 percentage points). The central bank expects above-target inflation of about 5-5.5% in 2019, before a return to the targeted 4% in 2020, in line with our forecast.
Given the CBR's pre-emptive tightening in December 2018 and the modest impact of the VAT increase, we expect it to hold the policy rate steady in 2019. However, any downward shock on global oil prices or new sanctions on Russia would prompt the CBR to tighten policy quickly to soften the resulting depreciation of the Russian currency against the US dollar.

In 2018 growth was driven by private consumption and exports. A pick-up in household borrowing and sharp consumer price disinflation drove private consumption. Rising oil prices and post-Soviet record-high oil output boosted exports. Large government infrastructure projects, such as the construction of the bridge over the Kerch Strait, supported investment growth.
According to a first estimate from the Federal State Statistics Service (Rosstat), real GDP grew by 2.3% in 2018-the fastest growth rate since 2012. The 2.3% figure exceeded our previous 1.7% estimate and the projections of the Ministry of Economy, which tend to be overoptimistic. Rosstat had previously estimated average growth of 1.5% year on year in the first three quarters. The jump in the full-year figure was attributed to the inclusion of construction work at the third phase of the Yamal liquefied natural gas (LNG) field in the Far East, which was launched last year. As the 2.3% full-year growth rate implies an implausible 4.5% year-on-year growth rate in the fourth quarter, we expect a significant revision to the official data on quarterly growth breakdown.
In 2019 we forecast a slowdown to 1.5% real GDP growth. Private consumption will continue to drive growth, albeit more weakly. Higher domestic interest rates will dampen consumer credit growth, and rising inflation-driven by the VAT increase-will reduce purchasing power. International sanctions-as well as broader political and business uncertainty-will remain significant constraints on investment, as will the lack of a "culture of failure" (the absence of entrepreneurial spirit weighs on innovation and investment). Export growth will also moderate as risks to the Chinese economy increase, the tariff war weighs on global trade, and as oil prices fall by a forecast 7.1% on average from 2018 levels. Oil production is likely to decline slightly following a new deal between Russia and OPEC to reduce global output in 2019.
In the medium term outdated capital stock, a declining workforce, dependence on natural-resource sectors, institutional weaknesses, low productivity growth, a difficult business environment and statist policies will limit real GDP growth. We forecast that growth will average 1.7% per year in 2019-23.

Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Growth in agriculture has fluctuated considerably in recent years, as harvest depends on weather conditions, averaging about 3% annually over 2007-17 (with fluctuations ranging from a 12% contraction in 2010 to a 14.8% expansion the following year, from a low base). Basic restructuring, debt workouts and the onset of agricultural land reform have gradually started to turn around a sector that was traditionally regarded as Russia's most inefficient. It is only since 2002 that farmers have been legally entitled to buy and sell land, and to use it as collateral. However, local authorities remain reluctant to initiate land privatisation.
Agriculture will be one of the strongest growth sectors in 2019-23
The imposition of an import ban on a wide range of Western food products from August 2014 has increased profits for domestic producers and their incentives for expansion. We expect the government to maintain the food-import ban throughout the forecast period, but uncertainty over how long the embargo will last constrains long-term investment. In principle, large productivity gains are possible-output of wheat per hectare, for example, is 35% less than the OECD average.
Although state aid to the sector has risen, lower competition could constrain efficiency gains, particularly as foreign investment falls. Moreover, import substitution has no clear record of success historically, often because of local production inefficiencies. To date, the sums earmarked by the government for support to agriculture have been too small to have much of an impact on a sector that still employs about 10% of the labour force.
Manufacturing output plunged by almost 15% during the recession of 2009. It rebounded strongly in 2010-13, but has grown much more slowly-and dipped in 2015 as a result of the devaluation of the rouble-in subsequent years. Contrary to a widespread misconception, Russia has one of the world's largest manufacturing sectors. However, much of this is not internationally competitive and relies on state orders or state support in the form of soft budget constraints.
Heightened tensions with the West have led to renewed emphasis on import substitution, especially in the military sector, which has been particularly targeted by international financial sanctions. Domestic producers are likely to lobby hard for further state support in the forecast period, with some success. The rouble's low exchange rate (against the US dollar and the euro) will support the limited expansion of domestic manufacturing production, although this process will be constrained by the tight labour market and limited availability of financing. If global oil prices rebound, the CBR may intervene to hold down the rouble against the US dollar to support domestic producers (this would have the welcome side-effect of building up sovereign reserves and increasing fiscal revenue). However, the undervalued rouble (against major currencies) also increases the cost of imported manufacturing inputs. Defence spending will remain high as the government seeks to develop its domestic military industrial complex (in part to fill gaps in supplies opened up by the conflict with Ukraine, with which Russia used to have strong industrial ties in the defence sector as a legacy of the former Soviet Union), as well as to keep the military on side politically.
Services will recover only slowly, as household spending will remain weak
The structure of GDP growth shifted towards services strongly in the 2000s, and the sector now accounts for more than half of the economy. Average sectoral growth in 2007-17 was slightly above 2% annually, with a contraction in 2015-16 during the recession. The services sector benefited both from high productivity gains as market transition led to the rapid emergence of entirely new subsectors, and strong growth in household incomes. In 2003-08 the strengthening of the rouble (against the US dollar) and improvement in Russia's terms of trade as a result of high commodity prices also pushed up household purchasing power. These factors will not be replicated over the forecast period, and growth in much of the services sector will be low. International sanctions will limit the expansion of financial services, which cannot raise debt on US and EU capital markets, and reduce funding for investment in other areas. Proposals to involve the private sector more actively in the provision of social services are at an early stage but are potentially a significant growth area. The ageing of the population opens up the potential for greater demand for health, insurance and related services, but lower than previously expected incomes may not provide sufficient incentive for prospective suppliers.
Economic forecast: Oil and gas

Natural-gas production (bn cu metres) 642 603 585 591 598 601
 % change -3.1 -6 -3.0 1.0 1.2 0.5
The extractive sector represents about 10% of gross value added and almost 60% of exports. Growth is likely to be slow in the oil sector over the forecast period, as a result of the gradual depletion of mature fields, as well as international sanctions that restrict investment and the export of some technological equipment to Russia. Although Russia possesses enormous onshore fields, many of these are in the closing years of productive life. New reserves in the Arctic and offshore are more difficult and costly to extract, and this will be accentuated by a ban on the sale of Western high-technology equipment.
The government has allowed limited competition into the gas sector, as privately owned Novatek and state-owned Rosneft, which is primarily an oil producer, have entered the market. State-owned Gazprom will retain its dominant position, bolstered by its ownership of the gas pipeline network.
Western financial sanctions constrain investment in the energy sector
The US has applied sanctions on Gazprom, restricting its access to financing and the transfer of technology for deep-water, offshore and shale exploration. It also applied sanctions that constrain the ability of Western companies to work with Russian energy companies; however, these do not apply to projects-such as the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline-that started before mid-2017. We expect these to remain in place throughout the forecast period, constraining the ability of the company to develop its operations further. The EU is highly unlikely to apply sanctions on Gazprom, given the bloc's high dependence on Russian gas imports; in addition, the bloc will continue to block American attempts to derail the Nord Stream 2 project.
Gas output had been stagnating for years until 2017, as Gazprom devoted greater attention to acquiring downstream assets abroad than the development of new gasfields. The company's main west Siberian fields are maturing, but there has been little progress with developing new fields, such as Yamal and Shtokman (estimated to be among the largest gasfields in the world). US sanctions and lower gas prices mean that the company does not have sufficient financing to realise all the infrastructure projects that it has put forward, with the pipeline to Turkey (currently known as Turkish Stream) the most likely casualty of the company's straitened circumstances.
Despite tough negotiations over pricing with China, we expect the Power of Siberia pipeline project, which will deliver 38bn cu metres of gas a year to eastern China, to go ahead (albeit with some delays), which will involve the development of new fields in eastern Siberia. A second western pipeline (Altai) to China is unlikely to be realised in the forecast period. As a result, despite the rhetoric of a "pivot to the east", Europe will remain the principal external customer for Gazprom in the short to medium term at least.
Crude oil represents a major commodity export
Following the financial collapse in the late 1990s, crude oil production rebounded strongly in the early 2000s, reflecting efforts by Russian oil majors to consolidate assets, streamline operations, cut costs, and introduce Western management and technology. It also reflected spare capacity at the west Siberian oilfields, where output slumped steeply in the 1990s. However, oil-production growth has slowed sharply in recent years, as easy gains have been achieved and high marginal taxes weigh on investment. The government and oil industry are currently negotiating revisions to the tax regime in an effort to maintain public revenue from the sector and continue to incentivise investment. Owing to the recent "oil-tax manoeuvre", the export duty rate on oil and oil products will be gradually lowered to zero by 2024, whereas the mineral extraction tax (MET) will correspondingly rise. In theory, the tax amendments should incentivise exports and could lead to a rise in the domestic price of oil and petroleum products. However, the government is wary of a popular backlash, and is proposing to introduce subsidies for some oil refiners and a floating excise rate on petroleum products intended to hold down the price of gasoline when crude oil prices rise.
EU and US energy sanctions are likely to remain in place in 2019-23
The US and the EU have placed sanctions on Rosneft, Russia's leading oil company, and Gazprom Neft, an oil-producing subsidiary of Gazprom. The US has additionally sanctioned Lukoil and Surgutneftegaz (both energy companies), despite the fact they are nominally privately controlled. EU and US sanctions are likely to remain in place throughout our five-year forecast period. The short-term impact on production will probably be limited; however, in the long term the restrictions are likely to impair the country's oil production potential. Lower oil prices will also curtail investment and output growth. Maintaining and expanding production requires foreign expertise and financing to maximise output from mature wells and develop new fields, most of which are technically challenging. However, Western oil majors (such as Exxon in February 2018) have been forced to cancel or suspend a number of joint ventures in Russia. Rosneft may further expand ties with Chinese oil companies, including via long-term supply contracts. At present Chinese companies are unable to substitute for Western technology, but this could change over the medium term.

Russia experienced consumer price disinflation from late 2015 until mid-2018, with inflation at a record low of 2.2% year on year in January-February 2018-far below the CBR's 4% target. Disinflation was assisted by record harvests in 2016-17 and, until April 2018, the strength of the rouble against the US dollar and the euro. Inflation picked up from June, ending 2018 at 4.3% year on year. A weaker harvest pushed up food prices, and the depreciation of the rouble against the dollar boosted imported inflationary pressures.
In 2019-23 we expect average inflation to remain close to-but slightly above-the 4% target. External inflationary pressures are likely to be low. The rise of the VAT rate will boost inflation to an average of 4.9% in 2019. Our forecast of a modest slowdown in the US in 2020 will lead to a depreciation of the rouble against the US dollar; this will continue to fuel inflation, albeit at a lower level than in 2019.

In 2018 the rouble depreciated to an average of Rb62.7:US$1, from Rb58.3:US$1 in 2017, owing to the imposition of new US sanctions and the government's fiscal rule, which prevented the strengthening of the rouble alongside rising oil prices. When the US imposed new sanctions on Russia in April and August, the rouble depreciated against the US dollar, to Rb70.6:US$1 in mid-September, before recovering to an average of Rb69.5:US$1 in October-December.
The outlook for the rouble in 2019 is similar. Oil prices are forecast to average US$66/b and we expect the Federal Reserve (the US central bank) to keep its policy rate on hold, which will support the rouble. This will be offset by Russia's fiscal rule and by the likely imposition of additional US sanctions on Russia. This will drive a further average depreciation of the rouble, to about Rb67.5:US$1 in full-year 2019.
In 2020 a downturn in the US business cycle will drive a decline in global oil prices (from 2019) and weigh further on the rouble. In 2021-23 we forecast a slight overall nominal appreciation as oil prices increase to US$70-76/b. Risks are to the downside-any rapid reduction in global oil prices or imposition of new sanctions could lead to renewed volatility.

The current account will remain in surplus
The current-account surplus rose to the equivalent of 6.6% of GDP in 2018, from 2.1% in 2017, as higher global oil prices boosted the value of exports and a weaker rouble constricted import growth. Non-oil commodity exports performed strongly, with the value of ferrous metal exports rising by 24.3%. A strong harvest in the past two years has also resulted in remarkable growth in agricultural exports. These factors boosted Russia's trade surplus sharply, to US$195bn in 2018, from US$115.4bn in 2017.
We expect the current account to remain comfortably in surplus in 2019-23, owing to large trade surpluses. International sanctions will depress foreign direct investment inflows throughout 2019-23. Although we expect these inflows to recover as the forecast period progresses, they will remain well below their pre-2014 levels.
