Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Russia
Stocks and flows
According to balance-of-payments data from the Central Bank of Russia (CBR), foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows averaged just US$2.8bn per year in 1994-2002, before increasing steadily to reach a record total of US$75bn in 2008 (equal to 4.2% of GDP), the second-largest total among emerging markets after China. As a result of the global financial crisis, FDI inflows plummeted in 2009, to US$36.6bn. In the following three years FDI inflows recovered, to an annual average of just below US$50bn, but shot up to US$69.2bn in 2013. However, a large proportion of inflows in 2013 was accounted for by the return of Russian capital linked both to the Cypriot banking crisis and the Russian government's "de-offshoreisation" agenda. In 2014 inflows fell substantially, by 67% year on year to US$22bn, the lowest level since 2005, following a sharp rise in political risk linked to the Ukraine conflict and the gradual imposition of international financial sanctions. The decline continued in 2015-the first full year of international sanctions, when FDI totalled just US$6.9bn, or 0.5% of GDP. In 2016 FDI inflows recovered to US$32.5bn, or 2.5% of GDP, but almost half of the increase can be attributed to the sale in December 2016 of a 19.5% stake in Rosneft. They dipped slightly in 2017 as a result of this high base, to US$28.6bn, or 1.8% of GDP. In proportional terms, Russia has attracted much less FDI than most transition economies in eastern Europe. Before 2014 Russia's stock of inward FDI was comparable with the other BRIC economies (Brazil, India and China). In 2015 the stock of FDI declined to US$348bn, but picked up to US$478bn in 2016 and US$530bn in 2017, although this is still below the high of US$566bn in 2013.
Origin and distribution
According to the CBR, almost one-third of the total stock of inward FDI is accounted for by Cyprus-based investors (largely from Russian-owned companies registered offshore). Although EU countries dominate Russian foreign trade, EU investors (other than from Cyprus) account for only about 15% of inward FDI stock-and some of that total, as for the Netherlands, is probably also dominated by returning Russian capital flight. In 2013 the UK's share of FDI inflows into Russia was greatly boosted by BP's purchase of close to one-fifth of shares in Rosneft, Russia's largest oil firm. At the end of 2016 Singapore's share was greatly increased when a Singapore-registered investment vehicle served as the conduit for the sale of another 19.5% of shares in Rosneft. According to official figures, China accounts for only a small share of the FDI stock, at US$3bn as at end-September 2018 (from a high of US$4.2bn at end-2017).
Inward FDI is highly concentrated, both sectorally and geographically. Slightly less than one-quarter of the inward FDI stock is in mining, with perhaps one-fifth each in the retail sector and manufacturing. Before 2014 there was a surge of investment into various sectors, including pharmaceuticals and automotives. Flagship companies-such as AvtoVAZ, a carmaker that makes the Lada, and Rosneft, a state-owned oil firm-have been allowed to sell stakes to foreign multinationals. However, with the intensification of the geopolitical stand-off between Russia and the West over Russia's involvement in the conflict in eastern Ukraine, some major foreign firms have started to reduce exposure to the Russian markets. New investment in manufacturing and retail has sunk sharply in the wake of the devaluation of the rouble and ongoing recession. Most of the FDI stock is in Moscow, the capital, and St Petersburg, as well as energy-producing regions like Arkhangelsk and Sakhalin. Five of the 83 regions account for more than 70% of inward FDI. Prior to the latest crisis some new FDI locations had started to become important-for example, an industrial cluster in the Kaluga region (supported by business-friendly policies from the local authorities), which includes an industrial project of Volkswagen (a German carmaker) and several greenfield schemes.
Determinants
In the years running up to the crisis of 2008-09, good market opportunities, as well as improvements in the business environment, resulted in a sharp increase in FDI inflows. The attractions of natural resources, high returns on investment and a fast-growing market helped to counteract investor concerns about the security of property rights, corruption and the absence of a level playing field. The comparative attractiveness of Russian regions depends more on the regional authorities' will than on more challenging factors, such as geography, the existence of a skilled workforce or impressive infrastructure. Among determinants of FDI, investors were most interested in the legal environment, and financial and tax incentives. Perceptions of political risk, international sanctions and geopolitical tensions are likely to be the main determinants of FDI over the forecast period (2019-23). International sanctions will restrict investment into the financial, defence and hydrocarbon sectors (which will also suffer as a result of low energy prices).
Impact
Given a strong current-account position and the generally small size of FDI inflows, the impact of FDI on the balance of payments has been negligible. In addition, the sectoral distribution of FDI (to energy, and to ventures mainly serving domestic demand for traditional products) has had limited impact on technological capacity and competitiveness. Foreign investors have played a vital role in only a few industries (for example, beer, tobacco and automotives). Foreign banks expanded rapidly before 2014 but never controlled more than one-third of the financial sector. They are likely to lose market share to state-backed banks over the forecast period. More than 90% of current investment in fixed capital is under full Russian control. Companies with foreign participation employ only about 5% of the Russian workforce.
Potential
There exists wide potential for higher FDI in Russia, for instance in the underdeveloped hi-tech sector or in the energy sector for the exploration of Arctic oil and gas reserves. However, FDI will remain constrained by international financial sanctions that the EU and the US started to impose on Russia in 2014. Most notably, sectoral sanctions specifically target the energy, defence and financial sectors, and restrict the export of dual-use, oil-drilling and defence equipment to Russia, making investment in these sectors extremely difficult. The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that these sanctions will remain in place over its forecast period. East-West tensions will remain high, Western banks will remain reluctant to finance large-scale projects in Russia for fear of sanctions and the Russian business environment will remain difficult. As a result, FDI to Russia will remain severely constrained in the long term.

From 2014 onwards population data include Crimea, which was illegally annexed by Russia in March 2014 following an illegal referendum that has not been recognised by the international community. This artificially added 2.9m people to Russia's population statistics. The inclusion of Crimea in Russia's demographic projections reflects the fact that Russia's national accounts include economic activity on the Crimean peninsula, whereas Ukraine's national accounts data do not.
Russia suffered a major demographic shock after the fall of the Soviet Union
Russia suffered a serious demographic shock following the collapse of the Soviet Union. The population shrank by 5.3m between 1993 and 2008, when it picked up slightly owing to increasing immigration. The natural decrease during this period amounted to about 12m people. The mortality rate has exceeded the birth rate for more than 20 years owing to low fertility rates, below-standard healthcare and poor lifestyles. The stress of the transition to capitalism in the 1990s further contributed to falling birth rates and increased morbidity.
The decline in population would have been even greater had there not been considerable net migration into Russia over this period. A large proportion of foreigners come from other countries of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS). With the onset of the conflict in eastern Ukraine in 2014, more than 1m refugees from eastern Ukraine are reported by UN agencies to have moved to Russia. At the start of 2015 the government replaced its quota system for economic migrants with a new regime imposing strict rules for obtaining work permits for citizens outside the Eurasian Economic Union (EEU). Citizens of EEU countries (which include Armenia and the Kyrgyz Republic, both large sources of inward migration to Russia) can remain indefinitely in any other EEU country, as long as they have a valid employment contract.
Average male life expectancy in Russia declined significantly in the 1990s and was still below 60 as late as 2005. There has been some recovery since then, and life expectancy at birth is currently about 65 years for men and 76 years for women. Alcoholism accounts for much of the gap in life expectancy. Just 11% of Russian women smoke daily, compared with more than 40% of men. Heart disease and high blood pressure are among the main causes of premature death, along with car accidents (especially in northern regions). The incidence of tuberculosis and HIV/AIDS is underreported but high, especially in remote regions.
Population decline will resume over the forecast period
The population has stabilised over the past five years as a result of immigration, an improvement in health and a rise in the birth rate-a result of a larger cohort of women of child-bearing age. The birth rate in 2018 stood at 12.8 per 1,000, up from 9.8 in 2005. The mortality rate per 1,000 people stood at 13.5 in 2018, down from 16 in 2005.
The government's long-term plan aims to lower the mortality rate, raise birth rates and improve health outcomes. The plan includes financial incentives to encourage women to have children. Over the past five years the government has introduced some health measures, such as banning tobacco advertising and smoking in public places and increasing taxes on alcohol and cigarettes. These moves may contribute to a modest improvement in life expectancy over the medium term.
Despite modest gains in life expectancy, The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that annual population growth will be negative in the 2019-23 forecast period (it was positive in every year in 2008-17). Government incentives are unlikely to have a major impact on the birth rate, and the share of women aged 20-29 is forecast to fall significantly in 2019-23.
Population is ageing rapidly
Russia has an ageing population, which will prove increasingly difficult to support. We project that the labour force will fall by 1.5m, or 2%, between 2018 and 2023. In 2018 the government raised the pension age by five years for women (to 60) and five years for men (to 65, in the region of the male life expectancy). Despite this recent reform, pension liabilities will remain a growing burden on the public finances in the coming years, all the more so as reforms of pension benefits are highly controversial and the authorities remain wary of triggering potential social unrest. Immigration from Central Asia will continue to provide a large pool of flexible, low-cost labour-much of it in the grey economy.

The Russian economy contracted sharply in 2015 (in US dollar terms) owing to the drop in global oil prices, and fell further in 2016, but it remains the 12th-largest economy globally (in nominal terms). Combined with high inflation (which weighed on real wages), the devaluation and subsequent depreciation of the rouble against the US dollar in 2014-16 has sharply reduced household spending power. The combination of the confrontation with the West (which will depress investment), stagnating global energy prices and slow movement on vital structural economic reforms will damage Russia's medium-term economic growth potential, with a concomitant impact on household income and wealth.
GDP per head (at purchasing power parity) reached a high of US$26,177 (58% of the German level) in 2013. It fell to US$24,620 in 2015, but The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that it recovered to its pre-crisis levels in 2018. It will now increase steadily, to about US$32,000 in 2023.
Wages contracted sharply in 2015, falling by almost 10% in real terms, and rebounded by only 0.9% in 2016 and 2.8% in 2017. We estimate that they started to rebound in 2018, growing by an estimated 7.8%, as a result of low inflation, minimum wage rises and a pick-up in economic growth. The scale of the decline in income is likely to have been sufficient to trigger long-lasting shifts in household spending patterns, with a greater emphasis on price competitiveness and basic household goods.
Average incomes will recover slowly, but the luxury market will remain robust
Income inequality remains high and the market for high-end luxury goods will remain one of the strongest in Europe. Sales of passenger cars have been in decline since 2012, before the current economic crisis, but sales of luxury foreign brands such as Porsche and BMW (both of Germany) have fallen by much less. The car industry has started to recover in 2017, but passenger-car sales are projected to be well below the 2012 peak even in 2020. Further state support for the domestic car industry is likely, such as through vehicle scrappage schemes under which consumers can get discounts on the purchase of a new vehicle if they scrap their old vehicle. First introduced in 2014, it has been renewed on a regular basis ever since, and the government is considering plans to extend the scheme to trucks. The government has also allotted Rb10bn (US$172m) in 2017 for car leasing and loans to support customers in buying cars. Further market stimulus programmes came into effect in July 2017, offering subsidies to families with two dependent children.
Russian sanctions on EU food imports will remain
Russia is expected to maintain its ban on EU and US food imports throughout the forecast period (2019-23). This will help to boost domestic agricultural production across a range of food products. However, reduced access to domestic and external funding could crimp the expansion plans of domestic retail businesses. Public financing constraints and multiple claims on government funds are likely to restrict the investment in infrastructure and communications needed for consumer-centred businesses to thrive outside of the big cities.

Since his third presidential term, Vladimir Putin has adopted a more traditionalist, patriotic ideology. There has also been a more anti-Western tone since Russia's illegal military takeover of Crimea in March 2014. Some foreign companies could benefit from advertising, and marketing, campaigns that stress local content and branding, rather than luxury or foreign products, which had been more effective in the past. In many consumer segments, however, foreign brands will continue to be regarded as synonymous with higher quality. Further protectionist measures remain possible across a range of sectors, which could disrupt the operations of companies relying on crossborder supply chains. However, the authorities will continue to welcome investment to develop domestic production of established foreign brands.
Despite the weaker economic outlook, e-commerce has room for strong growth
New retail and consumer trends, in particular e-commerce, remain at an earlier stage of development than in western Europe, and are likely to grow significantly faster than the overall economy. The density of modern retail networks is still significantly below that of western Europe.

Long-term outlook: The long-term outlook

Russia's advantages for growth include an abundant natural-resource base, a low starting income and an educated workforce, but these are offset by institutional weaknesses, an overreliance on commodity exports, weak productivity growth and a poor demographic outlook. On the basis of Russia's initial conditions and UN demographic forecasts, as well as an assumption of limited policy improvement over the medium term, The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts average growth in real GDP and real GDP per head of less than 2% in 2019-50 (the long-term forecast period). Russia's share of the world economy, having expanded in 2000-08, will decline in the decades to 2050.
Skill levels compare favourably with those in many emerging markets
Initial conditions: Russia's natural resources are a mixed blessing. During much of the past decade high oil prices and favourable terms of trade were the main drivers of growth. However, there is a significant negative correlation between long-term growth and natural-resource dependency. This is a result of "Dutch disease"-whereby an overvalued exchange rate (as a result of commodity exports) prevents the development of globally competitive non-resource sectors-as well as of widespread opportunities for rent-seeking. Russia's size (about 17m square km) is an economic disadvantage, as it implies long distances between population, natural resources and business centres, as well as 11 different time zones. State involvement in the economy is high and has risen in recent years, and soft budget constraints have sustained a large number of internationally uncompetitive manufacturing firms.
Workforce skill levels may still compare favourably with those in many emerging markets. In aptitude tests pupils perform close to the OECD average and significantly better than peers in many emerging markets. The number of adults with tertiary education is significantly above the OECD average, as a legacy of the excellent educational system of the former Soviet Union. Nevertheless, over the past two decades Russia has suffered some deterioration in its human capital. Russia's technological resources are being depleted, as evidenced by the decline in the research and development sector and in the education system.
Demographic trends: The demographic profile is unfavourable, combining negative features of the developed and developing worlds (a falling and an ageing population, comparatively low life expectancy and a declining working-age population). The UN has revised up its baseline forecast for Russia's population, but the outlook remains poor, owing to low birth rates, below-standard medical care and a high mortality rate. Based on UN forecasts, we project that the population will decline to about 136m by 2050, down from 147m in 2017 (this includes the population of Crimea, which Russia annexed illegally in 2014). Crucially, the working-age population is likely to shrink even more quickly than that of the population as a whole.
A weak demographic outlook weighs on growth
In the absence of large-scale immigration-made difficult by domestic political considerations, widespread popular suspicion towards foreigners (especially from Western countries) as well as international tensions-Russia is unlikely to have the labour resources to sustain high rates of economic growth. Despite strong domestic opposition, the imperative to raise the retirement age will soon become irresistible, not least to sustain the pension system. However, poor health will continue to affect the quality of the workforce and make it all the more difficult to sustain the productivity improvements needed for catch-up growth. Investment in healthcare is likely to remain well below the OECD average as a share of GDP. The ageing population will impose increasing pension costs that will exert strong pressure on the budget and may act as a brake on reform. Despite the recent rise in the retirement age (to 60 for women, and 65 for men), the current pension system is inadequate to manage rising liabilities.
External conditions: Russia's energy-driven economy benefited greatly during most of the past decade from high oil prices and favourable movements in the terms of trade. This boost is likely to be absent over the longer term, however, as increased global supply and climate change policies hold down the value of Russia's main export. Tensions with the West are likely to endure for many years. This will depress foreign investment, place restrictions on the import of technological equipment (for instance for oil-drilling or dual-use goods), divert resources to military expenditure, and encourage statist and illiberal trends within Russia. A limited pivot to high-growth countries in Asia will yield some benefits, but economic integration will be constrained in the medium term, at least by deficiencies in infrastructure. The impact of climate change may be mixed: rising temperatures could boost agricultural yields in some areas, but increase the likelihood of wildfires and drought in others.
Competition is low and the regulatory burden high
Institutions and policy trends: Institutional deficiencies abound, and the concentration of economic power in a few massive conglomerates impedes competition. The institutional and policy outlook for growth is mixed. Sustained economic growth, especially beyond a certain level of development, requires a climate of political openness in which policies are subject to public scrutiny, minimising the scope for corruption and maximising the chances for good governance. The prospects for such an opening have been set back by the conflict with the West, which has strengthened authoritarian trends. International sanctions, which may last for many years given the unlikely prospects of a resolution to the conflict in eastern Ukraine, have also consolidated groups within the policymaking elite that favour statist development models and import substitution, making it less likely that the economy will be opened up to greater competition. Attempts to reduce the regulatory burden on business can be expected, but an inefficient and cumbersome bureaucracy, as well as regional discrepancies, will hinder policy implementation. Far-reaching reforms to strengthen the rule of law and increase competition are not our core forecast, but remain possible. Russian per head income is already higher than the quality of the country's institutions would lead us to expect. Major reform could therefore deliver a much higher per head growth trajectory than currently forecast. However, given the consolidation of anti-Western attitudes within the elite, and the dominant role played by the security services, there is a risk that the government will respond to weak economic growth by further tightening social controls, while maintaining tensions with the West at a high level.
Long-term performance: An unfavourable demographic profile, difficult business environment, fragile banking sector, low productivity growth, absence of a culture of failure, weak institutions and over-reliance on natural resources will place strong constraints on Russia's long-term growth. Even with favourable assumptions about the expansion of the capital stock and continued productivity gains, excepting a dramatic change in Russia's political economy, we forecast average annual long-term real GDP growth well below 2%.
Given its strong industrial tradition and well-educated workforce, Russia's chances of diversifying its economy could be good, but this prospect has receded following a sharp deterioration in political and economic relations with the West. Even if the forecast rate of growth to 2050 is achieved, there will be only marginal catch-up with the advanced Western economies. Convergence prospects with developed Europe therefore appear poor.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
This year The Economist Intelligence Unit has developed a model to calculate the impact of climate change on long-term growth, and we find that the Russian economy will be about 5% smaller in 2050 than it would have been without this hit to growth. A report released in March 2018 by Antistikhiya, a research centre affiliated to the Russian Ministry of Emergency Situations, estimates that the long-term economic cost of climate change could amount to Rb900bn (US$15.8bn, or about 1% of GDP). According to the report, average winter temperatures across Russia may rise by 2-5°C by the middle of the century. This would have a significant impact on Russia's northern territories. The Arctic Ocean is expected to be largely ice-free and navigable in the summer months by 2025-30, which could potentially allow for the Northern Sea Route to emerge as a major transit corridor between China and Europe (although major investment in infrastructure would be required). However, higher temperatures will also lead to the melting of permafrost in some northern areas, causing infrastructure-including roads, buildings and pipelines-to sink into marshes. Permafrost covers 65% of the country, and 93% of gas production and 75% of oil production is located in permafrost regions; in Siberia alone there are 350,000 km of energy pipelines. The energy sector already suffers from a high number of leakages and accidents; according to Greenpeace, an environmental campaign group, 35,000 accidents happen every year in western Siberia's oil and gas sector, 21% of which are owing to buckling pipelines. The impact of climate change on the agricultural sector will be mixed. Northern parts of the country will become more temperate, allowing for an increase in arable land. However, this will be offset by a decline in the productivity of regions further south and west, which will lead to increased incidents of droughts and wild fires. The Russian government has shown limited interest in pursuing policies to limit carbon emissions amid low popular concern about global warming.
International financial sanctions
In April and August 2018 the US Treasury imposed new rounds of sanctions on Russian individuals and companies. These sanctions marked a step-change in the US sanctions regime against Russia: for the first time the US government targeted internationally listed non-state companies operating outside the defence, energy and financial sectors (all three sectors were already targeted by both EU and US sanctions since 2014). The direct macroeconomic impact of the sanctions is limited, and fluctuations in global oil prices will be a more important driver of economic growth in Russia over the long term. However, we believe that both US and EU sanctions will remain in place over the medium, and possibly the long term. As a result, the ability of the EU and the US to disrupt the operations of major enterprises is likely to be a source of significant concern for the Russian government. Crucially, non-US citizens and entities also face sanctions for conducting business with them because US sanctions apply to all transactions conducted in US dollars or by entities that have subsidiaries in the US, or are controlled by Americans. The Russian government might need to provide financial assistance to roll over loans and compensate for lost export earnings for some of the targeted companies that are effectively shut out of international financial markets because they cannot use US dollars. This could further reduce the funds available for infrastructure, education, healthcare, social spending and other long-term investment priorities. Partly as a result of sanctions, in recent years the Russian government has played an active role in developing an alternative financial architecture as a counterweight to the US (such as the BRICS-Brazil, India, China, South Africa-or "New" Development Bank, the Asian Development Bank, and the expansion of mechanisms for conducting non-dollar denominated international transactions). For all the rhetoric of de-dollarisation, however, the sanctions have underlined the economic power asymmetries, and the limitations of Russia's pivot to the East. In the long run, the fact that the EU and the US effectively exert a veto on the ownership structure of major Russian companies will also be a cause for concern for the Russian government.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions
Sources for global and domestic data are for historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit.
Global data
Historical series: UN; OECD; IMF
Oil prices: Dated Brent crude average price
Domestic data
OECD, Economic Surveys: Russian Federation
Population: Rosstat; US Census Bureau
Balance of payments: CBR; IMF, IFS
Foreign direct investment: IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report; CBR
Inflation: Rosstat
Exchange rate: roubles per US dollar: IMF, IFS; CBR
Real effective exchange rate: index, 1997=100; trade-weighted, based on 20 leading partners
GDP growth and expenditure breakdown: Rosstat
US$ PPP GDP: 2005 International Comparison Programme benchmark estimate extrapolated on the basis of Russian and US GDP deflators
Export and import price indices: US dollar-based; 2008=100
External debt data: World Bank, International Debt Statistics
Abbreviations
CBR: Central Bank of Russia
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
Rosstat (formerly Goskomstat): Federal State Statistics Service
UN: United Nations
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development
Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2014-18) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2019-23). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2014-18. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2019-23 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2014-18 ranges are then used to derive 2019-23 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2019-23, not to the likely situation in 2023 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2016 or 2021). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The government, led by Alexis Tsipras of the Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), is likely to hobble along for just a few more months following the departure of the nationalist Independent Greeks (AE) from the coalition regarding the Macedonia name-change deal, which the Greek parliament ratified on January 25th. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects political instability to rise during of a busy electoral cycle in 2019, further weakening Greece's governance and its commitment to political and economic reform.
We forecast that an early election will be held before the end of the parliamentary term in October 2019, possibly in conjunction with the European Parliament and the May local elections. We expect New Democracy (ND) to win the most seats and to form a government. The centre-right party would probably have to secure the support of at least one other party to muster a majority.
Greece will remain subject to strict policy conditionality in the medium term, until its debt to its international creditors is substantially reduced. Protests are likely to continue as the government strives to meet ambitious annual primary surplus budget targets of 3.5% of GDP until 2022 and 2.2% from 2023, as agreed with Greece's international creditors. Mr Tsipras's promises to lower taxes and reverse spending cuts could cause tensions with the EU and investors.
Greece is facing its biggest macroeconomic challenge now that it has exited the bail-out programme and no longer has access to official borrowing at preferential interest rates. However, Greece will not face short-term financing difficulties, as it will have sufficient funds to cover its debt repayments until the end of 2020. A Greek exit from the euro zone represents a risk over the long term.
After expanding by 1.9% in 2018, we expect real GDP growth to 1.8% in 2019 and 2020 and an annual average of 2.1% in 2021-23. Public debt is forecast to continue to exceed 175% of GDP in 2023. Meeting large primary surplus targets and restoring competitiveness will prove to be difficult.
Inflation (EU harmonised) is forecast to rise slightly, from 0.8% in 2018 to 0.9% in 2019 and 1.1% in 2020, reflecting moderate domestic demand growth and weaker global energy prices. In 2021-23 we expect oil prices to increase, bringing inflation to 1.5% per year. We expect moderate current-account deficits in 2019-23 (the forecast period).

Greece's business environment will improve moderately in the forecast period, with progress in almost all categories, apart from political stability. However, Greece will remain subject to sub-optimal fiscal and other policy conditions, which will constrain real GDP growth, and keep Greece's debt burden high.
Country forecast overview: Greece's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The country's privatisation agency (under new management) gains momentum, unblocking some delayed deals.
2021-23: Efforts to valorise public property through concession management and long-leasehold development agreements.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: The Investment Incentives Law of 2016 offers more tax relief and fewer subsidies, and focuses predominantly on small firms. Plans to cut down on bureaucracy make modest progress.
2021-23: "Fast-track" legislation could become more important if the economy normalises. It will cover "strategic" investments in energy, tourism, transport, communications and health.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Remaining capital controls introduced in June 2015 are eliminated. Capital buffer of about EUR26bn sufficient to cover almost two years of the government's medium- and long-term financing needs.
2021-23: There is a significant risk of Greece leaving the euro zone in the long term if growth continues to disappoint. Grexit would probably result in the reintroduction of foreign-exchange controls and possibly restrictions on trade.
Taxes
2019-20: Extensive efforts to widen the tax base. Government pledges to pursue aggressive tax collection, but implementation is difficult. Indirect taxes increase. Mandatory introduction of electronic point of sale terminals helps.
2021-23: Limited progress in cutting corporate income tax or value-added tax (VAT). Measures to tackle tax evasion stepped up.
Financing
2019-20: Liquidity tight. Uncertainty constrains lending capacity. Pressure to reduce non-performing loans (NPLs) intensifies, but foreign interest picks up. A moratorium on foreclosures is lifted for the majority of debtors.
2021-23: The need to increase provisions for still high NPLs hampers lending. More Greek bank foreign subsidiaries are sold off.
The labour market
2019-20: Labour market reforms now mostly passed, but implementation is problematic. Unemployment remains high.
2021-23: EU funded job-creation schemes, particularly for youth, raise employment, but create few productive jobs.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Energy infrastructure comes to the fore as Trans-Adriatic Pipeline (TAP) nears completion. Privatisations pick up pace.
2021-23: Technical assistance from the EU helps absorption of European funds to revive infrastructure investment.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Greece rolls out high-speed internet, at a slow pace. The private sector adopts electronic payments by law.
2021-23: Significant financial and technical assistance from the EU, but Greece remains a laggard.

Background: After 400 years of Ottoman rule Greece emerged as a sovereign state in 1830. A devastating civil war followed the retreat of German occupying forces in 1944. A military junta ruled the country from 1967 to 1974, but since then a democracy has been in place. In 1981 Greece joined the European Economic Community, now the EU. It became a member of the economic and monetary union (EMU) in 2001, but its public finances became unsustainable, resulting in a sovereign debt crisis in 2009-10. Greece's public debt has put its continued membership of the EMU into question.
Political structure: Greece is a parliamentary republic, with deputies elected for four-year terms. The prime minister and the government hold executive powers. The president is elected by the 300-member parliament for a five-year term. The government requires the support of parliament to hold office. Since the 2010 crisis the traditional party system has broken down. Voters blamed the parties that ruled Greece after the return of democracy in the mid-1970s-New Democracy (ND) and the Panhellenic Socialist Movement (Pasok)-for causing the crisis, which led to the imposition of painful austerity by the country's external creditors. The result has been political fragmentation and the rise of populist parties such as the left-wing Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), which came to power in 2015, and far-right parties such as the neo-fascist Golden Dawn (XA).
Policy issues: The ND-Pasok government of 2012-14, like its two predecessors, imposed draconian austerity packages. It also enacted fiscal and some structural economic reforms to meet the conditions of two EU-IMF bail-out packages, totalling EUR240bn. Implementation proved difficult and ultimately brought down the government. After a seven-month confrontation with Greece's creditors, the Syriza-led government negotiated a new three-year European Stability Mechanism (ESM) programme in August 2015. In 2012 Greece restructured its public debt, reducing the value of private-sector creditors' holdings by EUR107bn. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any further debt write-down. Now that Greece has exited the programme, it is subject to an "enhanced supervision" monitoring regime by its euro zone creditors.
Taxation: The tax rate on corporate profits is 28% (29% in 2018) and on distributed dividends is 10%. The top marginal personal income tax rate is 45% for income of more than EUR40,000. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at rates of 24%, 13% and 6%.
Foreign trade: In 2018 goods exports (fob) were worth EUR32.4bn and imports (fob) amounted to EUR54.9bn. The current account registered a deficit of EUR5.3bn, equivalent to an estimated 2.9% of GDP.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
The government led by the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, of the Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza) is in its final stage. In early January 2019 the small, right-wing nationalist Independent Greeks (AE) dropped out of the ruling coalition in protest against the Macedonia name-change deal, depriving the government of a stable majority in parliament. Syriza has just 145 seats in the 300-seat parliament. The government had to rely on the help of members of the opposition and AE defectors to survive a vote of confidence on January 16th and get the Macedonia agreement through parliament. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Syriza minority government to attempt to pass legislation aimed at boosting its electoral support before the next general election, but it is unlikely to survive more than a few months. Local and European Parliament elections are scheduled for May, and the general election is due by October, but we expect the general election to be called early, possibly in conjunction with the elections in May.
Political instability has intensified owing to the agreement with Macedonia to change that country's name to the Republic of North Macedonia, which the Greek parliament ratified on January 25th. This is likely to lead to a further weakening of the country's governance and its commitment to political and economic reform ahead of Greece's busy 2019 electoral cycle.
In August 2018, after eight years of austerity and unpopular reforms under three economic adjustment programmes, Greece exited the third bail-out programme signed by the Syriza-led government in 2015. During his period in power Mr Tsipras has lost much popular support and will struggle to revive his party's political fortunes before the next election. We remain sceptical that real GDP growth will rise much higher than 2% during the 2019-23 forecast period, and expect that failure to implement other structural reforms agreed with Greece's international creditors could lead to delays in the implementation of the debt-relief measures agreed with Greece's EU creditors.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Syriza trails the centre-right New Democracy (ND), led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis, in opinion polls; the gap has exceeded 10 percentage points for some time. ND's lead may narrow during the election campaign, as Mr Tsipras is a formidable campaigner and there is little overt enthusiasm for Mr Mitsotakis or his party. However, given widespread popular disaffection with the Syriza government, which is likely to have increased owing to the Macedonia name-change deal, the election-due by October 2019-is ND's to lose. If, as we expect, ND wins the largest share of the vote, it would benefit from the 50-seat bonus rule for the winning party. Even so, it would probably have to secure the support of at least one other party to muster a parliamentary majority.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Domestic political instability and protracted economic and financial crises have limited Greece's influence in the EU and in the Balkans. Recent government efforts to restore influence, including the Macedonia name-change deal and talks on closer co-operation with the US, are fraught with difficulty, as domestic pre-election tension is likely to condition foreign policy decisions. Ratification of the name-change agreement aims to end Greece's opposition to Macedonia's accession to NATO and its application for EU membership, but the leader of ND has said that if elected, his government would seek to renegotiate the deal.
Tensions between Greece and Turkey will persist. However, we believe that both sides will seek to prevent their historical enmity from escalating into military hostility. Points of contention include long-standing territorial disputes in the Aegean Sea, and the Greek courts' rejection of Turkey's extradition request for Turkish soldiers who fled to Greece on the night of the July 2016 failed coup in Turkey. Turkey's release in August 2018 of two Greek soldiers arrested in March of that year while on patrol in the border area of Evros has eased tensions slightly.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
With a general election looming in 2019, the Syriza government opted to exit Greece's third economic adjustment programmes in August 2018 without a precautionary credit line. In June 2018 Greece's official creditors agreed to close the final review of the third bail-out programme, paving the way for a disbursement of EUR15bn, which was released in August. Of this, EUR3.3bn was earmarked to repay more expensive IMF debt, and the balance to create a buffer for Greece to use while it builds up market access. The total buffer, estimated at EUR26bn, should be sufficient to cover almost two years of the country's financing needs, to end-2020. This is more onerous than a precautionary credit line would have been, as Greece will be accruing interest on money that it does not currently need. However, intense political pressure not to invite further policy conditionality led the government to choose the more expensive option.
However, the government will still be subject to severe policy constraints during the forecast period and beyond, until its huge government debt is substantially reduced. General government debt was an estimated 184% of GDP at end-2018, and also almost entirely owed to official creditors (the EU and the IMF), making another debt write-down, as happened in 2012, highly unlikely. Economic policy and performance will be subject to an "enhanced surveillance" regime, which is a more exacting system of post-programme monitoring than those applied to other former bail-out countries.
The implementation of further debt-relief measures also agreed with Greece's EU creditors in June 2018 will be conditional on quarterly reviews of the state of the economy and of the government's adherence to its commitments, the most pressing of which include tackling Greek banks' heavy burden of non-performing loans, reviving the government's privatisation programme, removing remaining capital controls and clearing state arrears to the private sector. Greece has also committed to long-term fiscal prudence. It must achieve annual primary budget surpluses (budget balance minus interest payments) of 3.5% of GDP in 2018-22 and 2.2% thereafter, until 2060. As the quarterly reviews will be published (the most recent was released on February 27th and updated on April 4th), transgression by Greece could adversely affect market access. The debt-relief measures include a ten-year grace period and a ten-year maturity extension on EUR96bn of its loans (provided by the European Financial Stability Facility). Greece will also get a reduction in the interest rates (for EUR130.9bn worth of loans), and a return of profits from the securities market programme and from the Agreement on Net Financial Assets, which comprises the official sector holders of Greek debt-the European Central Bank (ECB) and national central banks of euro area countries. The value of the return is estimated to be about EUR5bn in total in 2018-22.
In the short term Greece should have sufficient funds to meet its financing needs, but it will need to have re-established itself in the debt markets before its cash buffer runs out. After a three-year absence Greece has tapped the financial markets five times since July 2017, most recently in early March 2019 with a well-subscribed ten-year issue, yielding 3.9%. The spread on the secondary market between Greek ten-year government bonds and equivalent German government was about 380 basis points in early April. Amid rising domestic political instability ahead of the next general election in Greece, as well as and growing global economic and financial uncertainty, further issuance will be challenging.
In the medium and long term, the political and, arguably, the economic price of meeting high annual primary surplus targets may become unbearable. During the past two years Greece has exceeded its annual primary surplus targets, but at the expense of economic growth, which has been disappointing. Meeting such targets will remain a constraint on growth, as will other negative factors such as poor demographics and a weak business environment. Grexit is not a short- or medium-term risk; however, given that Greece is unlikely to improve competitiveness inside the euro zone or to grow its way out of its huge debt burden, Grexit will represent a possibility in the long term.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
After almost a decade of austerity Greece recorded an overall budget surplus of 0.8% of GDP and a primary surplus of 3.9% in 2017, exceeding the bail-out programme target of 1.75%. From 2018, however, we expect fiscal performance to deteriorate gradually, with the budget balance returning to moderately widening headline deficits and primary surpluses falling short of the official target of 3.5% of GDP for 2018-22, reflecting constraints on revenue collection, a relaxation of spending restraint ahead of the next general election and only moderate economic growth. There is also uncertainty about the application of the Council of State's ruling that previous pension and bonus cuts implemented in 2016 were unconstitutional, raising the risk of retroactive payments. Although the primary surplus target will decline to 2.2% of GDP from 2023, it will still be difficult to achieve.
The restructuring of government debt owed to the private sector cut the debt/GDP ratio to 159.4% at end-2012, from 171.9% in 2011. However, large primary surpluses in 2016-17 were insufficient to arrest the growth of gross consolidated government debt. We expect that, without a debt write-down and assuming moderate nominal medium-term GDP growth rates, the public debt/GDP ratio will still be more than 175% at the end of 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The ECB adopted an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy in response to the European sovereign debt crisis, bringing major policy interest rates down to zero or below; it also launched an asset-purchase programme that amounted to EUR2.6trn and came to an end in December 2018. Nevertheless, policy will remain ultra-loose in the medium term as the ECB reinvests principal payments from maturing securities. Economic activity in the euro zone softened in 2018, and growth will slow further this year. Together with a more subdued outlook for commodity prices in 2019-20, we expect this to prompt the ECB to hold off on normalising its policy stance this year. At its last meeting, on March 7th, the bank delayed its next rate rise until late 2019 at the earliest. It also announced a third round of targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTROs), starting in September. We expect a 25-basis-point increase in the main refinancing rate to 0.25% in early 2020 as underlying price pressures build. Policy tightening should then proceed at a gradual pace. An increase in the deposit rate, currently at -0.4%, may come sooner, in 2019, easing the pressure on banks' lending margins and supporting profitability. Risks to our outlook stem from the nomination of a new ECB president in late 2019.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
Compared with 2007 levels, real GDP has shrunk by more than one-quarter, government consumption by almost one-quarter, household consumption by one-fifth and gross fixed investment by almost two-thirds. The recovery, which began at the start of 2017, is fragile and vulnerable to domestic and external developments. Real GDP accelerated from 1.4% in 2017 to 1.9% in 2018, but the economy lost momentum in the final three months of last year, contracting by 0.1% on a quarter-on-quarter basis. We expect real GDP growth to remain constrained at 1.8% in 2019 and 2020 and at an annual average of about 2.1% in 2021-23. The risks to our forecast are balanced: upside risks include continued strong tourism performance if capacity constraints are addressed; downside risks include the frailty of the banking sector and political instability.
A combination of more-and higher-taxes, higher social security payments, debt repayments and spending cuts will continue to put pressure on household disposable income. Although we expect a modest acceleration in household spending in 2019-23, this will be from a low base and will be constrained by large primary surplus targets (of 3.5% of GDP per year up to 2022 and 2.2% in 2023), continued high unemployment and insipid lending growth.
Quarterly gross fixed investment has been volatile in recent years but recorded strong full-year growth in 2016-17, albeit from a low base. However, reflecting base effects and a loss of momentum, investment contracted by an average of 12% year on year in 2018, leaving fixed investment still about 65% below its 2007 peak. We expect a pick-up from this year, to an annual average of 5.2% in 2019-23. Underinvestment during the crisis and the depletion of Greece's capital stock are likely to restrict growth potential in the medium term.
Greece's external trade will be constrained by its relatively uncompetitive goods exports. In the medium term we expect tourism to continue to support services export growth, contributing to annual average growth of exports of goods and services of 4% in 2019-23, down from 8.8% in 2018. However, the Greek tourism sector faces considerable challenges that range from the UK's planned departure from the EU and increased competition from Turkey to insufficient public investment.
How the economy performs in the next five years (and beyond) will determine if the country remains in the euro zone. Although the risk of Grexit has abated since the height of the financial crisis, we believe that there is a risk that Greece will exit the euro zone in the long term, given the difficulties that it will face in attaining rapid growth while meeting large primary surplus targets and in restoring competitiveness without a currency devaluation. Greece's exit from the euro zone (not our core scenario) would lead to a sovereign default and severe recession in the first few years, but the economy would then recover, assuming a responsible fiscal policy guided by the necessity to achieve a primary surplus.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
The economy has returned to growth, but significant slack in the labour market, subdued domestic demand and a sharp decreases in global oil prices in the final quarter of 2018 will dampen inflationary pressures. We expect inflation to rise modestly, from an average of 0.8% in 2018 to an annual average of 1% per year in 2019-20 and 1.5% per year in 2021-23 as domestic demand growth accelerates.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
The euro rallied in late 2017 as the region's economic recovery strengthened and expectations of quantitative easing (QE) tapering increased, and as political risk waned in Europe but rose in the US. After peaking at almost US$1.25:EUR1 in early February 2018, the euro has depreciated gradually. This was a response to the formation of a populist, Eurosceptic government in Italy, which increased political risk in the region, and to monetary tightening in the US. More recently, the euro has hovered around US$1.14:EUR1-at lower levels than we had anticipated-on the back of softening momentum in the euro zone. We expect it to appreciate gradually throughout 2019 as growth in the bloc picks up again in the second half of the year and momentum in the US slows. We forecast that the euro will average US$1.16:EUR1 in 2019 and will continue appreciating throughout our forecast period, to US$1.22:EUR1 in 2020-21, as monetary policy in the euro zone is tightened gradually, and to US$1.24:EUR1 on average in 2022-23, supported by the large current-account surplus.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The economic crisis helped to reduce Greece's current-account deficit, which shrank primarily as a result of a compression of imports owing to contracting domestic demand, but also partly of improved competitiveness in the tourism sector. We expect continued deficits in 2018-23 as import volumes pick up in line with higher domestic demand, and as global energy prices rise moderately in the second half of the forecast period. However, these deficits will be much smaller than the average annual deficit of 7.1% of GDP since Greece joined the euro zone in 2001.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Muhammadu Buhari won a second and final four-year presidential term on February 23rd. The policy agenda he campaigned on did not involve considerable reform, only cosmetic improvements to the business environment.
The administration will struggle to tackle high levels of poverty and the country's ethnic and religious divisions. This will create a potent mixture that will lead to frequent violent instability and directly affect key economic sectors.
Policy will be interventionist. Import bans on agricultural and manufacturing goods will be widened to support local industry and farmers, and the Central Bank of Nigeria will maintain an overvalued official naira rate with which to channel cheap US dollars to preferred buyers.
Even though a multiple exchange-rate system will persist, non-official rates will converge and so in reality Nigeria will run a dual exchange-rate regime. As oil prices fall in 2019-20, adjustments to the official rate will have to be made to safeguard foreign-exchange reserves.
Fiscal expenditure will remain dominated by recurrent spending, despite attempts to boost capital investment. Efforts to boost non-oil tax revenue will be constrained by weak bureaucratic capacity and low economic growth.
Constrained by a crippling infrastructure deficit, as well as tight monetary conditions and instability in key agricultural regions, economic growth will be well below levels needed to boost job creation and increase living standards. This will perpetuate instability in a vicious cycle.
Inflation will remain high over the forecast period (2019-23) amid expansionary fiscal policy and high food prices stemming from government efforts to limit imports and support local producers. This in turn will keep credit conditions tight; even with some relaxation of the policy rate (currently at 14%) from 2021, inflation will be running too high for sustained monetary loosening, and credit growth will generally be slow.
The multiple exchange-rate regime will not be dismantled under a Buhari administration; the arrangement is critical for making petrol subsidies affordable and underpins the government's interventionist approach to industrialisation.
Oil prices and exports will fall in 2019-20 but so will imports. Both imports and exports will then expand in 2021-23 but a current-account surplus will be maintained throughout the forecast period.

Nigeria's business environment score will improve slightly but its global and regional rankings will worsen as the administration struggles with the reform process and other countries make more significant improvements.
Country forecast overview: Nigeria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Progress on market-oriented reforms remains slow, given various vested interests and inefficiencies. The upstream oil sector will remain characterised by joint-ventures between the state oil company and multinationals.
2021-23: Improving prospects for the non-oil private sector remains a priority, but progress will be slow.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: An attempt to sell the state's interest in oil joint ventures with multinationals will meet serious challenges (the policy has been around for years), with resistance in the legislature to the permanent loss of a revenue stream.
2021-23: Higher world oil prices and so easing fiscal pressures lessen the need to embark on a divestment programme. Energy companies will anyway be hesitant to increase their stake in a difficult operating environment, especially onshore.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Import bans are widened, but as oil prices decline, the naira weakens anyway as foreign-exchange inflows lessen.
2021-23: A premium between the official and the black-market exchange rates persists.
Taxes
2019-20: Focus intensifies on boosting tax compliance, especially given weak prospects for oil revenue. Value-added tax (VAT) is increased to fund a higher minimum wage, which will see the fiscal cost of the civil service increase markedly.
2021-23: Tax rates for the oil and gas sector increase under new legislation, particularly for offshore oilfields. The need for new consumer taxes is alleviated by higher world oil prices and so hydrocarbons revenue.
Financing
2019-20: Funding for well-planned projects becomes easier to raise domestically once the 2019 elections are concluded, as local capital markets deepen (with greater foreign participation) and the banking sector develops.
2021-23: Credit conditions become easier for businesses as the current-account surplus boosts national savings and investment.
The labour market
2019-20: Employers face major problems, including a shortage of skilled manual workers, restrictive visa regulations and poor health indicators.
2021-23: Employers continue to struggle to find suitably qualified staff.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Government spending on the priority area of infrastructure hits capacity constraints. Although there should be growth in private-sector investment, the government struggles to create an encouraging environment.
2021-23: Expenditure on infrastructure increases, but white elephant projects hold back the productivity of investment.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Nigeria continues to have a vibrant technology sector for an economy at its stage of development, but infrastructure is weak outside urban hubs.
2021-23: Research spending is likely to remain low compared with global averages, but some home-grown technology firms looking to adapt global technology trends to the Nigerian market continue to do well.

Background: Nigeria gained independence in 1960 and the army soon became the dominant political player. Multiparty democracy was restored in 1999. That presidential poll and the next one, in 2003, were both won by a former military ruler turned civilian politician, Olusegun Obasanjo. Mr Obasanjo was unable to change the constitution to allow him to serve a third term in office, so in the 2007 election power passed to his handpicked successor, Umaru Yar'Adua. After Mr Yar'Adua's death in May 2010, his vice-president, Goodluck Jonathan, assumed the presidency and went on to win the 2011 presidential election. Mr Jonathan was defeated by Muhammadu Buhari in the 2015 presidential election and in 2019 Mr Buhari went on to win another term, with a clear lead over his main rival, Atiku Abubakar.
Political structure: Under the constitution adopted in May 1999, a strong executive presidency appoints a Federal Executive Council, comprising government ministers and ministers of state from each of Nigeria's 36 states. The executive is accountable to the bicameral National Assembly. Political parties tend to lack clear ideologies; in practice, personal and ethnic ties dominate the political process. The People's Democratic Party (Mr Jonathan's party) had historically been the only political party to attract nationwide support, but the merger in 2013 of three large opposition parties to form the All Progressives Congress gave them, with Mr Buhari at the helm, the reach that they needed to take power in 2015. Although the 36 state governments enjoy significant autonomy, almost all remain dependent on the federal government for funding.
Policy issues: Successive governments have sought to improve macroeconomic stability and develop the nation's dire infrastructure, with mixed results. Meanwhile, the government is struggling to end insecurity in various parts of the country. These tensions are stoked by the underlying problems of poverty and unemployment. Management of the naira by the authorities is contentious, and currency liberalisation will be postponed whenever foreign-exchange supplies permit.
Taxation: Corporate profits in most non-oil sectors are taxed at 30%. Planned changes to the tax system for the oil and gas sector have been repeatedly delayed, creating uncertainty. Most other taxes are low, reflecting the fact that most revenue comes from the oil sector, with the total tax take very small as a share of GDP. Tax compliance is a time-consuming process.
Foreign trade: Exports are dominated by oil. The slump in oil prices from the second half of 2014 almost wiped out what had historically been a large current-account surplus, although it has partly recovered since. The non-oil export base has been rendered globally uncompetitive by an overvalued exchange rate and massive infrastructure deficiencies.
