Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
An election on February 23rd resulted in a comfortable margin of victory for Muhammadu Buhari, who was running for a second term as president. However, the vote was tarnished by low turnout nationwide. To some extent this can be explained by a week-long, last-minute delay to the polling date, but there was an especially low turnout in the south of the country (where it dropped to only 18% in one state). This affirms a strong sense of apathy in that part of Nigeria and a clear disengagement from federal politics.
Given that the economically vital southern regions have a history of separatist sentiment and militancy, the disconnect between the population there and mainstream Nigerian politics bodes poorly for stability. There are added reasons to expect unrest in the south in particular, with the government likely to concentrate its energy on developments in the north. An Islamist militant group, Boko Haram, is resurgent in the north and north-east, and is utilising new tactics and more sophisticated hardware. Mr Buhari's "zero tolerance" approach to the group was a major reason for strong turnout and support for him in the affected states. As was the case in his last tenure, substantial federal resources are likely to be channelled towards keeping Boko Haram at bay. However, militants in the oil-producing south cite the use of oil earnings for far-flung causes such as combating Boko Haram-rather than for local development-as justification for launching attacks. It is a dilemma that cannot be resolved without reforming the distribution of federal hydrocarbons revenue and possibly the entire oil sector, but Mr Buhari is not an advocate of doing either. So it seems likely that attacks by aggrieved militants on oil infrastructure will continue to be a major security problem, albeit isolated to the south.
Boko Haram will probably be aggressively countered, but in the process the north-east of Nigeria will essentially become a low-level conflict zone. Just to the south of this region, in the agricultural Middle Belt of Nigeria, a more insoluble challenge will be addressing extremely violent clashes between settled farmers and nomads competing for increasingly scarce water and land resources. Formal land titling is a potential answer, but as it would in effect alienate one group from communal holdings in favour of another it would prove too contentious. Ultimately there is no foreseeable end to violence in the Middle Belt. Moreover, in Mr Buhari's first term, it was clear that military engagements in other parts of Nigeria have priority when it comes to deploying the army's thinly spread resources, and the same is likely to be true in his second, leaving the conflict to intensify. Again, the direct security impact will be localised, with little spillover into the administrative capital, Abuja, or the economic capital, Lagos. The entire country will feel the secondary effects, however, in the form of constricted food supply and high consumer prices.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Nigeria's national elections took place on February 23rd, and were marred by violence, delays and voter apathy, but Mr Buhari of the ruling All Progressives Congress (APC) secured 56% of the vote. Participation across the country, at 35%, was well down on the 44% turnout rate in 2015, partly reflecting a delay to the poll but also disengagement with the two main candidates. There was especially low participation in the south-a traditional People's Democratic Party (PDP) stronghold-with voters there evidently feeling alienated by the two main candidates (who are both northern). Mr Abubakar wants to contest the result in court, but the margin of victory for Mr Buhari is too wide for there to be any credible chance of him overturning it. Moreover, although international observers reported shortcomings in the management of the election, it was not deemed to be systemically unfair. The parliamentary election gave the APC a majority in both houses; in theory this should allow for the swift passage of legislation, but Mr Buhari's first term was marked by divisions between the executive and parliament (as had happened to presidents before him), and crucial bills including the national budget were delayed by months. As legislators typically prioritise the interests of their constituents over party and federation in Nigeria, similar tensions could easily reoccur in Mr Buhari's second stint. The next election will be in 2023, and a new APC presidential candidate will stand. Custom dictates that after two terms for a northerner, the next APC and PDP nominees will be from the country's south.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Many of Nigeria's militant groups operate across land and sea borders, and international co-operation will therefore be needed to tackle the threat they pose. Stretched resources, vast territories and porous borders will prevent complete military victories. Relations with the US will be mixed; the administration of Donald Trump is willing to sell Nigeria military hardware, but Mr Trump's disapproval of the trade deficit the US runs with Nigeria (particularly owing to Nigerian import restrictions) could strain ties. Relations with the EU will be largely cordial but subject to tensions over Nigerian migrants seeking to enter Europe and Nigerian efforts to repatriate funds in European banks that were allegedly looted by former rulers.
India will remain important as the largest market for Nigerian oil and become a bigger source of foreign investment. China will also remain a significant source of investment, but actual inflows will fall short of the headline-grabbing pledges made, given an extremely challenging local business environment. Nigeria will remain an important player on the Sub-Saharan African stage given its size, but its domestic challenges tend to keep policymakers inwardly focused.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Economic policy during Mr Buhari's second term is likely to carry over the interventionist policies adopted during his first. Measures to liberalise and unify foreign-exchange markets or move to more market-led pricing in the energy sector will not be a priority and not become formal policy. An overvalued official naira rate is critical for maintaining petrol subsidies, and Mr Buhari will not willingly attempt to dismantle consumer price caps and risk a popular backlash. Although in practice very little foreign exchange is traded at the official rate, the existence of a multiple-exchange-rate system will be off-putting to investors fearing a return of capital controls. Elsewhere, efforts will be made to cleanse and reboot inefficient state owned industries such as the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC)-which dominates all segments of the oil sector-but again no structural reforms (such as full or partial privatisation) will take place. Generally, Mr Buhari's approach will be to make existing entities such as the NNPC become profitable rather than relinquish state control over them entirely, although there has been official talk of reducing the parastatal's stake in joint ventures with multinationals. Even this, however, would leave open questions around fiscal terms and revenue management in the oil sector. Multinationals, the NNPC's powerful union and local politicians (not to mention militant groups) will all pull in different directions. In practice there will be few improvements in the NNPC's performance, with politicians and other members of the political elite working to direct the flow of resources to favour specific geo-ethnic and political constituencies (as well as for illicit personal gain).
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
We expect small fiscal deficits throughout the forecast period. The government wants to diversify its revenue base away from oil, and non-oil revenue will rise through efforts to widen tax coverage (including through consumer taxes) and collect overdue taxes, but from an extremely low base. Instability in many parts of the country will be another impediment to collection. Hydrocarbons earnings will be held back by petrol subsidies (whereby losses incurred by the NNPC's retail arm are deducted from federal revenue), and budgeted revenue levels will be undermined by overambitious oil production targets. For example in 2019 the government expects output of 2.3m barrels/day (b/d)-a level not seen for well over a decade, and one that will be unobtainable given underinvestment, antiquated oil infrastructure and the government's compliance with OPEC output guidelines. Despite a new offshore oilfield coming on stream, total production stood at 1.6m b/d in January. In all, federally retained revenue is not expected to rise above 3.7% of GDP, a ratio only attained in 2023 when oil prices are at their highest within the forecast period.
After some projected expansion in 2018, spending will decline as a proportion of GDP in 2019 with deep cuts to the capital budget. Partly offsetting this will be higher spending on wages and public-sector benefits, including via the roll-out of a new (increased) minimum wage. Generally, flexibility on spending will be restricted by high levels of debt-servicing and pressing security needs. But with oil prices-and so revenue-under pressure and there being considerable political pressure to curb the fiscal deficit, we expect the spending/GDP ratio to dip again in 2020 and only increase materially as elections in 2023 approach. Altogether, we expect an average budget deficit equal to 2.1% of GDP over 2019-23. If the government moves to sells stakes in its upstream oil assets, which will be difficult politically, it would provide a dramatic one-off boost to the public finances.
Long-term public debt sustainability will remain in doubt. Central government debt is low as a proportion of GDP compared with other emerging markets, but it is set against a low revenue base. Debt service already takes up close to one-third of federal government income. A sovereign default is unlikely, but repayment difficulties are possible at state level, where revenue collection is weaker.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
Monetary policy will concentrate on fostering an economic recovery while limiting inflation and maintaining currency stability. However, this will generate contradictory pressures in the early part of the forecast period. The private sector is desperate for cheaper credit, but inflation will remain above the targeted upper limit of 9% set by the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN). On balance, we expect interest rates not to move much in 2019-20, notwithstanding small rate cut by the CBN in March. Rates will then fall in 2021 and stabilise over 2022-23 as economic activity picks up and inflation hovers above-or-around target. However, real interest rates will be too high to support private-sector activity outside of highly profitable ventures.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
The economy will for the most part be mired in a low-growth cycle, although there will be improvements over time. Tight monetary conditions and limited private investment-aggravated by cuts to public capital spending-presage a year of slow growth in 2019. We forecast growth of 2.1%, the lowest rate in the five-year outlook period. Growth will increase in 2020 as election-related uncertainty passes, but only marginally as an expected slowdown in the world economy holds back export-oriented sectors. In 2021-23, as global markets strengthen and external demand picks up, the rate of growth will quicken, although remain well below potential at an annual average of 3.3%.
From a sectoral viewpoint, agriculture will record only lacklustre growth; although boosting food production is a key government objective, weak infrastructure and violent competition for access to land in the fertile Middle Belt will be severe impediments. Industrial production will be curtailed by militancy and labour agitation in the oil sector, and falling oil prices in 2019-20 will hold back investment in infrastructure upgrades. Egina, a new offshore oilfield, will be a new driver of output, but hydrocarbons production is not expected to return to levels prior to the 2015 commodity-price crash. That said, a private refinery coming on stream by 2021 will be a boost to downstream oil activity in the latter years of the forecast period. The manufacturing sector will continue to struggle in the face of cheap goods from abroad, which are often smuggled into the country to bypass import bans. The services sector is less affected by instability and so will be a stronger contributor to growth than industry, but it will nonetheless be held back by protectionism affecting trade, tight credit conditions affecting areas such as real estate and finance, and the struggle in the communications sector to profitably roll out data services beyond urban hubs.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
From a rate of 12.1% in 2018, average inflation will increase to 12.7% in 2019, as pre-election giveaways (including an increase in the minimum wage) and a small devaluation of the naira add to upward price pressures. Inflation will remain elevated at 11.4% on average in 2020 on the back of further currency weakening. Thereafter, as the currency stabilises, inflation will ease over the rest of the forecast period to an average of 8.8% in 2023. Preventing a faster slide will be widening protectionist measures that limit relatively cheap imports from abroad, particularly of food and manufactured goods. Currently 43 items are barred from foreign exchange access, the most recent addition being textiles, and the CBN wants to increase the list to 50 as a means of stimulating non-oil economic activity.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
We expect the multiple-exchange-rate system to persist throughout 2019-23, with an official rate used for government business and a market-determined rate applicable to investors and exporters, which will be broadly in line with retail rates and the parallel market. Such a system allows the government to subsidise sectors deemed important for economic or political reasons, including the NNPC, which budgets for petrol imports at the official rate. For this reason the set-up is not expected to be tampered with. Oil prices, and with them the level of hard-currency earnings, will in large part dictate where the authorities are able to hold the official rate and what the premium is between it and market-sensitive rates. In 2019 lower oil prices will cause the market-determined Nafex rate to drop and the official rate will do likewise from N306.5:US$1 at end-2018 to N319.5:US$1 at end-2019. With oil prices forecast to decline again in 2020 we expect a further fall in the value of the naira, to N337:US$1 at end-2020. As oil prices pick up on average over the rest of the forecast period and import pressures are eased by improved domestic refining capacity, we broadly expect the naira to stabilise, with an average rate of N338.4:US$1 in 2023.
Forecasting the naira
Although The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts both the official and the secondary market rates, it is the official rate that appears in most of our data presentations, as it is the longest-running and best-tracked variable. For example, the current market-determined rate, known as the Nigerian Autonomous Foreign Exchange Rate Fixing (Nafex), has only been in full operation since April 2017, making historical calculations challenging. However, indicators that are converted into US dollars at the official rate are essentially overvalued.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The export profile will move in tandem with oil production trends and world crude prices. In 2019-20 limited output gains will be outweighed by a drop in world crude prices. Only in 2021-23 when prices recover and Nigeria begins to sell refined oil overseas (a new mega-refinery being developed is expected to be export-oriented) will there be any growth in earnings.
As Nigeria imports most of its petrol, lower world crude prices will ease pressure on the import bill in 2019-20. In 2019 there will even be a sharp drop in imports relative to 2018, when there was a one-off surge in capital goods imports. Wider restrictions on foreign-exchange access and a weakening naira will also hold back consumer demand. In 2020 world oil prices will decline further and the naira will continue to depreciate, but slightly stronger economic growth will nonetheless cause imports to edge up that year. As the economy gathers pace in 2021-23, the naira stabilises and world oil (and so petrol) prices rise, imports will then grow faster. Trade-related services imports and profit repatriation in the oil sector will keep the services and primary income balances firmly in deficit. Meanwhile, workers' remittances will remain an important source of hard currency, albeit dipping in 2020 as growth falters in the US (home to a large Nigerian diaspora). Overall, the current-account surplus will broadly track movements in world oil prices, narrowing from 2.3% of GDP in 2019 to 1.1% of GDP in 2020, then widening again to 2.5% of GDP by 2023.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; the source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: IEA average import price
Non-oil commodity prices: IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
EUR 3-month interbank rate: IFS
Domestic data
Population: UN
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics
Balance of payments: IFS and CBN, Annual Report and Statement of Accounts
Inflation: IFS, CBN and Federal Office of Statistics
Exchange rate: IFS; principal rate expressed as naira:US dollar
Interest rate: IFS; year-end lending rate
GDP growth and expenditure breakdown: World Bank, World Tables; 1987 prices
US$ GDP: IFS; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
GDP per head: US dollar GDP divided by population
Oil production: IEA; m barrels/day
Oil price: The Economist Intelligence Unit; dated Brent Blend
FDI: IFS, UNCTAD, World Investment Report and CBN
Total external debt: sum of long- and short-term debt and IMF credits
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding, with an original maturity of more than one year
Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
IMF credits: IFS and country page on website
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges on total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
CBN: Central Bank of Nigeria
IEA: International Energy Agency
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
NPC: National Population Commission
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development

Country Forecast Germany March 2019

https://www.proquest.com/reports/country-forecast-germany-march-2019/docview/2198275760/se-2?accountid=14357

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Germany&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Germany+March+2019&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2019-03-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Germany&amp;rft.issn=09669388&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Germany--highlights: Political outlook
The grand coalition-comprising the centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU), its Bavarian sister party the Christian Social Union (CSU) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD)-that took office in March 2018 will remain in power until the next election, in 2021. Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer, the CDU leader since December 2018, will become more vocal in domestic and international debates, but this will not create frictions with Angela Merkel, who has held the position of chancellor since 2005. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Ms Merkel to resign as chancellor before 2021 and she will work with Ms Kramp-Karrenbauer to ensure a smooth transition of power. A series of state elections taking place this year will confirm a higher degree of political fragmentation, and instability will remain high by German standards in 2019-23 (the forecast period).
Germany--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.31 8.37 7 10 4 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Germany's score in our business environ-ment rankings improves slightly between the historical period (2014-18) and the forecast period-faster improvements elsewhere mean that Germany slips in the global and regional rankings. The main strengths of the business environment are political stability, a highly skilled labour force, openness to trade and investment, and well-developed (if ageing) infrastructure. A strong research and innovation framework is another advantage. Faults include a high tax burden on labour income and on firms, alongside high administrative costs. Germany's open economy is also exposed to a slowdown in global trade flows and rising geopolitical tensions. The economy is comparatively well prepared to face technological changes.
Germany--highlights: Economic outlook
  2018 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023
Real GDP growth (%) 1.5 1.0 1.6 1.7 1.7 1.8
Consumer price inflation (av, %) 1.9 1.6 1.5 1.9 2.0 2.0
Budget balance (% of GDP) 1.8 0.8 0.7 0.5 0.4 0.3
Current-account balance (% of GDP) 7.6 6.7 6.6 6.3 6.4 6.7
3-month Treasury rate (av; %) -0.3 -0.2 0.4 0.9 1.4 1.6
Exchange rate [euro]:US$ (av) 0.85 0.86 0.82 0.82 0.81 0.81
We forecast average annual real GDP growth of 1.6% in 2019-23, driven in large part by consumer spending, in the light of a tightening labour market, solid wage growth and low borrowing costs. Fiscal policy will become slightly more expansionary (although still highly prudent), and public investment and construction activity will support investment. We expect substantial (if gradually declining) current-account surpluses, despite external pressure for Germany to do more to boost domestic demand. The main risks to the short-term outlook are external, with a more protectionist global trade environment, driven mainly by tariff impositions by the US, being the most pronounced. In the longer term the weak demographic outlook will weigh more heavily on economic growth.
Germany--highlights: Demographic outlook
Population (m) 2013 2018 2023
Total 80.8 82.8 82.9
 Male 39.7 40.8 40.9
 Female 41.1 42.0 41.9
Period averages (%)   2014-18 2019-23
Population growth   0.5 0.0
Working-age population growth   0.1 -0.6
Labour force growth   0.8 0.4
Germany's demographic outlook is challenging, even in a European context. Long-standing natural decline, as deaths outnumber births, combined with political constraints on net immigration mean that the population will grow only marginally over the forecast period. The working-age population will start to decline, and the average age will rise, putting pressure on the pensions and healthcare systems, and exacerbating labour shortages. The influx of migrants in 2015 will only partly offset this trend; successfully integrating these newcomers into the labour market will require significant policy efforts.
Germany--highlights: Market opportunities
  2018 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023

Germany will remain the world's fourth-largest economy at market exchange rates in 2023. Germany is the largest consumer market in Europe by population, and market opportunities will be supported by the tight labour market and solid wage growth in the forecast period. The country's changing age profile will do much to shape demand, particularly in the area of leisure services for the large retired population. The consumer market will continue to be characterised by a preference for inexpensive goods for most day-to-day needs and high-quality purchases in special circumstances.
Germany--highlights: Long-term outlook

In the long-term forecast period the economy's growth will be constrained by markedly poor demographics. Real GDP growth will ease from an average of 1.5% in 2019-30 to 1.3% in 2031-50, although on a per-head basis the rate of growth will remain broadly steady. Notwithstanding demographic headwinds, Germany has many attributes that are conducive to sustainable long-term growth, including a highly skilled workforce, stable institutions and openness to innovation. It needs more reform, including of the pension system, progress on which we expect to be slow.

Background: The modern German state was founded in 1870. After the second world war (1939-45) Germany was divided into two parts: a liberal parliamentary democracy in the west and a totalitarian communist regime in the east. On October 3rd 1990, after the end of the Soviet Union's hegemony in central and eastern Europe, Germany was reunified.
Political structure: Germany is a federation of 16 states, or Länder, each of which has its own constitution, government and parliament. The states are primarily responsible for policing and education. The federal parliament comprises the directly elected Bundestag (the lower house) and the Bundesrat (the upper house) of representatives of the state governments. The federal chancellor, the head of the executive, is elected by the Bundestag and can be brought down only by the election of a successor. In March 2018 a grand coalition was once again formed, comprising the centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU), its Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union (CSU), and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD).
Policy issues: Internationally, the government's agenda will include the Brexit negotiations between the EU and the UK; EU reform efforts, in collaboration with the French president, Emmanuel Macron; managing relations with the US president, Donald Trump, especially over trade issues; and shaping the EU's response to Russia, in the wake of the annexation of Crimea in 2014. Domestically, the government aims to ensure a sustainable medium-term budget surplus, increase investment spending, ensure continued progress on its Industry 4.0 agenda and shift away from nuclear energy.
Taxation: The federal corporation tax rate was cut from 25% to 15% in 2008. The effective corporate tax rate, including a municipal trade tax and a solidarity tax, is about 30-33%. The top marginal personal income tax rate is 45%. Social security contributions are shared equally between employers and employees. The main value-added tax (VAT) rate is 19%.
Foreign trade: Export earnings picked up to US$1.4trn in 2017, from US$1.3trn in 2016. Import costs also picked up, to US$1.1trn, from US$1trn. This resulted in a rise in the goods trade surplus, to US$303.5bn; The EU is still the single largest goods export market for Germany, but it has been more successful than most in diversifying its markets and selling into fast-growing emerging markets over the past decade.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
Germany is a federal democracy, with major powers delegated to the 16 states (Länder). In March 2018 the centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU), its Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union (CSU), and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD) reformed their grand coalition following a difficult and protracted coalition-building process. The bicameral parlia-ment comprises the Bundestag (the lower house of parliament), whose members are elected on a system of modified proportional representation, and the Bundesrat (the upper house), which consists of representatives of the 16 state governments. The coalition has a majority in the Bundestag, but not in the Bundesrat.

Political outlook: Political stability
Germany has experienced an unusual degree of political stability in recent years, in a European context, with Angela Merkel, the leader of the centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU), holding the post of chancellor since 2005. However, since late 2017 political instability has increased as the political landscape has become more fragmented. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects significant political change in the years ahead, although German politics will remain highly centrist and driven by consensus.
In the September 2017 federal election the CDU and its smaller Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union (CSU), won the largest share of the vote. The centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD) had its worst result in the post-war period and initially announced that it would go into opposition. However, after no other workable coalition options could be found, a grand coalition of the CDU/CSU and the SPD took office in March 2018, which became the third grand coalition led by Ms Merkel after similar administrations in 2005-09 and 2013-17. One consequence of the two "big-tent" parties repeatedly governing together is that the difference between them has become blurred. This has hurt their public support and has contributed to a reshaping of the political landscape. When Ms Merkel first took on the chancellorship in 2005 the CDU/CSU and the SPD held 73% of the seats in the Bundestag (the lower house of parliament). This share has now fallen to 56%. Parties that take a clear line on migration and openness have benefited most from the fall in support for the mainstream parties-notably the far-right, anti-immigrant Alternative for Germany (AfD), which is the largest opposition party; and the centre-left The Greens, which stand for an open Germany.
At the party conference in December 2018 Ms Merkel chose not to run for re-election as the CDU leader-a role that she had held since 2000. In part, this reflected her view that the CDU would need some time to reinvent itself under a new leader before contesting the 2021 federal election. Ms Merkel's preferred successor and the continuity candidate, Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer, won the nomination, although only by a small margin. Ms Kramp-Karrenbauer was chief minister of the state of Saarland in 2011-18 and became general secretary of the CDU in February 2018, so brings significant experience to the role. Like Ms Merkel, Ms Kramp-Karrenbauer strives for consensus, has a strong religious basis for her values and is broadly centrist in her economic policy positioning. However, she is more socially conservative-she voted against gay marriage and intends to take a tougher stance on migration.
Ms Kramp-Karrenbauer's first challenge is to unite the liberal and conservative wings of the party. Her second is to convince party members that she is not just a "mini-Merkel". A shift towards the right on some issues could open up space for the SPD to define itself on the left, potentially giving some new energy to the political debate in Germany. We expect the government to last a full term, as none of the coalition parties would benefit from an early election. Ms Merkel has said that she intends to serve out her term as chancellor, but we believe that there is a high probability that she will step down early to give Ms Kramp-Karrenbauer the best possible chance of winning the chancellorship in 2021.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
The quality of administration is high, and the implementation of policies that have been passed by the federal parliament is sound. The federal structure of the government means that considerable responsibility falls on the 16 states that constitute the federal republic. An advantage of this is that many issues are decided with the closer democratic involvement of the electorate. States have a strong incentive to improve their own quality of governance, as comparisons with other states are easy to make, although one drawback is that the quality of public services such as education remains heterogeneous across states. Another disadvantage is that co-ordination can be troublesome in policy areas in which the states have a large role. This has been the case in recent years. For instance, although the federal government had allocated additional funds for infrastructure investment, lower governments were often unable to use these for additional investment owing to capacity constraints.
The design of the system also means that the constitutional powers enjoyed by the Bundesrat may, on occasion, limit the ability of the federal government to push through reforms in the face of opposition at state level. However, the upper house does not have the right of veto on all aspects of legislation, and the proportion of laws requiring its approval was reduced in 2006. The last of these changes aimed to reduce the share of legislation requiring Bundesrat approval from about 60% to 35-40%, but the actual impact has been less dramatic. In exchange for this loss of influence over federal legislation, the states now have greater influence over the implementation of federal laws and have gained some additional powers, particularly in education.
Majority governments are the norm in Germany, at both the federal and the state levels. This generally ensures smooth policymaking, as the coalition agreement usually sets out in advance what the government will be working on throughout its term. In the coming years We expect increased pressure on policymaking at the federal level, as the coalition is more fractured than in its previous term. The SPD's wish to differentiate itself more clearly from the CDU, as it performed poorly in opinion polls since the 2017 election, will hamper effective policymaking. Nevertheless, the nomination of Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer as the leader of the CDU could create some space for manoeuvre for the SPD. Ms Kramp-Karrenbauer shares Angela Merkel's centrist stance on the economic agenda, but is more socially conservative. Relations between the governing parties will remain shaky, but government effectiveness will not be severely undermined as Ms Kramp-Karrenbauer's influence in shaping domestic and international debate grows.
Political outlook: Election watch
The next federal election is scheduled for 2021. Elections will be held for the European Parliament and the state parliament of Bremen in May 2019. State elections will also be held in Brandenburg and Saxony in September, and in Thuringia in October-three of the five states that made up the former east Germany. These will be closely watched given the strength of the AfD's support in east Germany, where voters' dissatisfaction with the government's handling of the 2015-16 migration crisis have fed into deeper frustrations about the lack of convergence between the east and the west of the country since reunification.
Political outlook: International relations
The external environment has become a source of uncertainty in recent years. The UK's vote to leave the EU, strains over migration, and the challenges to the bloc posed by Hungary and Poland have put pressure on the European community. Further afield, the actions of Donald Trump, Vladimir Putin and Recep Tayyip Erdogan-the presidents of the US, Russia and Turkey respectively-are undermining the global rules-based order that Germany has always held as the gold standard.
Germany's support for euro zone reform has been lukewarm, but Ms Merkel has supported the idea of creating an EU army, and redesigning security and refugee policy. In the past few months Ms Kramp-Karrenbauer has taken the lead in promoting the CDU's vision for Europe, in an effort to boost her profile at home and abroad. We do not expect Germany's EU stance or influence in shaping the EU debate to change under Ms Kramp-Karrenbauer's potential leadership. The country's position will continue to reflect the broad social German consensus against fiscal transfers within the bloc, as well as Germany's economic dominance.
Relations with the US, traditionally Germany's most important non-EU partner on the global stage, have worsened significantly during Mr Trump's presidency, and will remain strained in the forecast period (2019-23). The US president has publicly criticised Germany for its failure to meet the NATO target of 2% of GDP spending on defence, its reliance on Russian energy and its trade surplus with the US. Following an exchange of tariffs between the US and the EU in May-June 2018, the two factions agreed to start talks on a trade agreement for non-automotive industrial goods. Nevertheless, in February Mr Trump sharpened his rhetoric against the EU and reiterated his threat to raise tariffs on imported European cars. Mr Trump has until mid-May to act on undisclosed findings from the US Department of Commerce on whether imported cars pose a threat to national security. The risk of a collapse in the trade talks is high. Faced with US tariffs, we would expect the EU to respond in kind, albeit staying within the framework of World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules.
Following the annexation of Crimea in 2014, Germany took a decisive line against Russia, breaking with decades of relatively good relations and pushing against the reluctance of many southern and central European countries to impose far-reaching EU sanctions-a position that it has maintained ever since. We expect the EU sanctions to remain in place in the medium term, although pragmatic co-operation between Germany and Russia will continue, especially on energy.

Germany's score in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings increases slightly from 8.31 in the historical period (2014-18) to 8.37 in the forecast period (2019-23). However, owing to larger gains elsewhere, the country falls in the global and regional rankings. Germany was the seventh most attractive business location in the world in 2014-18, but it drops to tenth position in 2019-23, and the country's regional ranking declines from fourth to sixth place among its 17 peers. Strong fundamentals underpin Germany's high score and ranking for the macroeconomic environment, supporting an improvement in financing conditions. Declines in market opportunities and labour market categories reflect the poor demographic outlook and the increasingly acute labour shortages respectively. Overall, most of the scores in our business environment categories are expected to remain broadly stable-an indication of the previous coalition government's unadventurous policy agenda and our expectation that "reform fatigue" will endure in the coming years. This is disappointing given the fiscal space in Germany's public finances, the weaknesses that persist in the tax system and network infrastructure, and the country's demographic challenges.
Political stability will mainly be tested by region-wide issues
Germany's main strengths are its political stability, skilled labour force, openness to foreign trade and investment, and strong research and innovation framework. The political environment is reasonably robust, with a mature democratic system and efficient public administration, but stability will be tested by internal coalition pressures and region-wide issues related to immigration, Brexit, Russia and reform of euro zone structures. The tax regime places a substantial burden on labour income and on companies, alongside high administrative costs. The medium-term phase-out of nuclear power and coal-powered generation raises questions about the cost of renewables and energy supply security.

Business environment outlook: Germany's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The state maintains its involvement in the financial sector, railways and telecommunications. Firms' administrative burden is reasonable, but some areas of weakness remain. Protective regulation across the services sector persists.
2021-23: Limited prospects for reforming regulated service professions. Gradual shift towards increased state intervention.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: The government generally welcomes foreign direct investment, but Germany has lobbied hard to increase scrutiny at the EU level, and takeovers of major German media, infrastructure and finance companies now meet political resistance.
2021-23: Investment from China is increasingly unwelcome, given concerns about intellectual property leakage.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Pressure on German export sector from slowing global demand, ongoing US-China trade war and possible Brexit disruption. Risk of an escalation in trade tensions between the EU and the US. Risk of worsening EU-Russia relations.
2021-23: EU makes further gradual progress on bilateral trade deals. Expected decline in post-Brexit UK-EU crossborder trade.
Taxes
2019-20: Mild fiscal loosening, including targeted tax cuts via phased abolition of "solidarity surcharge", but a comparatively high labour tax burden persists. Deeper than expected economic slowdown could trigger modest discretionary stimulus.
2021-23: Incremental income-tax relief is likely amid pressure to strengthen work incentives for lower-income earners. Modest reform of management of corporate tax. Possible introduction of digital tax.
Financing
2019-20: Highly accommodative monetary policy has lowered banks' funding costs, but pressure on margins persists amid weak profitability and tighter regulation. Possible state-backed merger of struggling Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank.
2021-23: Operating conditions for banks remain challenging. Ongoing efforts to attract financial services firms from the UK.
The labour market
2019-20: Unemployment remains low. Restrictions on temporary employment. Skilled-labour shortages worsen.
2021-23: Limited prospects for reform to address structural challenges arising from ageing demographics and increasing share of migrant workers. Increased provision of childcare facilities supports moderate rise in female participation.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Modest rise in public infrastructure investment. Focus on maintenance of existing road and rail networks. Further delays in opening of flagship airport in Berlin, the capital. Continued calls from energy sector for improvement of power grid.
2021-23: Gradual phase-out of nuclear and coal generation, alongside rising renewables, expected to push up energy prices.
Technological readiness
2019-20: The government prioritises upgrading the country's digital infrastructure and investing in artificial intelligence.
2021-23: Efforts continue on "Industry 4.0", which focuses on upgrading manufacturing prowess through increased use of automation and connected systems. Increasing threat from cybercrime and cyber-espionage.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.6 9.2 6 3 4 3
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The robust economic upswing in recent years was supported by a resilient labour market, weak inflation, solid household finances, highly accommodative monetary policy from the European Central Bank (ECB) and a broad expansion of global demand. The external environment has weakened sharply since mid-2018, however, amid heightened world trade tensions and Brexit risks, softening growth in China and disruption in the automotive sector. These headwinds have contributed to weaker activity across the euro zone and a marked slowdown in Germany, reflecting the significant exposure of its export-oriented economy to world trade flows and fluctuating external demand. Near-term prospects remain weak, but solid fundamentals-healthy public finances, low unemployment, a competitive export sector, modest household debt and attractive financing conditions-will continue to underpin domestic demand. Alongside the country's strong institutional framework, this will sustain Germany's high global ranking for its macroeconomic environment throughout the forecast period.
Weaker global growth will, however, focus attention on structural supply-side challenges. Weak business investment and public infrastructure spending over the past decade, viewed alongside the government's limited reform plans, does not augur well for medium-term productivity and potential growth. Policy will also be tested by ageing demographics and a gradual decline in the working-age population (increasing the risk of skilled labour shortages), emerging strains in parts of the housing market and the disruptive impact of new technologies and shifting consumer demand on Germany's large automotive sector.
A substantial current-account surplus has long implied an inefficient allocation of resources, domestically and within the euro zone. It reflects an unusually large volume of domestic savings (that are mainly invested abroad), driven by fiscal conservatism, low investment and population ageing. An escalation in global trade protectionism represents the most serious risk to growth prospects in the forecast period, with firms also facing uncertainty over a (potentially chaotic) "no-deal" Brexit, weaker Asian demand and a cyclical downturn of the US economy.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.3 8.3 13 13 6 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Protective regulations across the business services sector will persist
Policy towards private enterprise and competition is generally liberal, and will remain so during the forecast period. Strengths include an effectively developed framework for research and innovation, a stable legal code and integrated supply chains across the EU. The competition authority, the Federal Cartel Office, has a solid reputation for being unbiased and efficient. However, Germany fares less well in other areas, with inefficiencies in the corporate tax regime, restricted competition in parts of the services sector and subdued entrepreneurial activity. The country's regulatory framework for companies is reasonable, but lags some of its regional peers. According to the World Bank's Doing Business 2019 study, the administrative processes involved in accessing utilities and credit, obtaining permits, enforcing contracts and resolving insolvency are fairly low. In contrast, the number of procedures and time taken to set up a new business are well above the average for high-income OECD countries, tax administration is often complex and costly, and registration of property can be protracted.
Liberalisation of product markets has progressed gradually, but regulations remain comparatively restrictive in some utilities and transport sectors, retail and business services. There has been negligible domestic reform in these areas and successive governments have resisted efforts to open up the EU services market to greater competition. EU-wide access to the German public procurement market is more restricted, and is less transparent than is the case in the UK and France.
Studies by the OECD and European Commission have showed Germany to have some of the most restrictive regulation in business services among all member states, in sectors including architecture, engineering, legal, accountancy and computer services. Vested interests imply limited prospects for reform, with the government showing little inclination to enact liberalising measures.
State involvement across the economy is moderate. Most domestic post-crisis emergency measures in the financial sector have been rolled back, but the state retains holdings in three recapitalised banks and will continue to oversee the run-off of substantial legacy assets in a Special Fund for Financial Market Stabilisation (SoFFin). A broad framework of state-owned regional and savings banks carries political clout, and restricts competition. The federal government wholly owns the state railway, Deutsche Bahn; holds a 32% share in the former national telecommunications monopolist, Deutsche Telekom; and has a 21% stake in the former postal monopoly, Deutsche Post.
In February 2019 the government proposed a revised national industrial strategy that implied a shift towards greater state intervention in industry sectors, support for "national and regional champions", and protection for firms deemed to be of "strategic importance" to the German economy. The plans reflect rising concern over the ability of EU-based firms to compete with US and Chinese rivals.
Reforms aimed at reducing firms' administrative burdens have been modest in recent years and no major changes are anticipated in 2019-23. A "bureaucracy relief" act in 2016 introduced a "one-in, one-out" rule for new regulations likely to impose costs on companies, and eased record-keeping requirements for start-ups.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.7 8.7 10 11 8 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
FDI policy is fairly liberal, but there will be tighter screening of non-EU inflows
Policy towards foreign direct investment (FDI) is relatively liberal, as in most EU countries, but sentiment towards non-EU inward FDI-particularly from China-is hardening and regulation will be tightened in the forecast period. Subsidies or financial incentives aimed directly at attracting FDI are limited, and focused mainly on research and development (R&D) support. Germany Trade and Invest (GTAI) is the federal body responsible for FDI affairs. A state-owned development bank, KfW, is the main provider of financial support. As in most countries, greenfield FDI is viewed as preferable to foreign acquisitions of domestic companies. Restrictions on hostile takeovers are considerable, whether the acquirer is foreign or domestic. Notice of strategic goals and "acting in concert" is mandatory for large investments. Constraints are more pronounced with respect to acquisitions of major utility companies, reflecting security of energy supply issues. According to data from the UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), in 2017 Germany had the ninth-largest stock of FDI in the world, and the fourth largest in Europe after the UK, Switzerland and the Netherlands.
The government will maintain its right to veto acquisitions of equity stakes above 25% in German companies by non-EU investors if these are deemed not to be in the national interest or pose a risk to national security. The veto has yet to be applied, but could be tested in the coming years amid a growing pushback (at domestic and EU level) against non-EU FDI inflows, particularly from China. A marked increase in such inflows in recent years has raised concerns over the potential transfer of technological knowledge and intellectual property, as well as the sale of strategic assets, especially in the case of investment by Chinese state-owned firms.
FDI rules were further tightened in late 2018, with the new regulation entering into force from 2019. The government can now block direct and indirect foreign investments when it involves at least a 10% stake on German companies working in critical sectors. Media has also been added to the list of covered sectors, which include energy, telecommunications, transport, information technology (IT) security, healthcare, water, food, finance, insurances, and related software and technology.
These moves have mirrored similar moves at EU level, with Germany supportive of European Commission plans to establish a regional framework for screening inward FDI on grounds of national security. A recent global trend has been an increasing share of FDI activity reflecting "corporate reconfigurations"-changes in multinational ownership structures-that often have a minimal impact on output, employment and capital in the host economy. This is expected to continue over the forecast period as firms' tax-planning practices continue to evolve.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
10.0 10.0 1 1 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Trade talks will focus on bilateral deals amid global trade tensions
Germany's foreign trade regime is defined by its EU membership. Free movement of goods, services, capital and persons exists within the EU, and we do not expect any exchange controls. No tariffs or quotas are permitted within the bloc, and the EU has abolished most other non-tariff restrictions. The EU trades with Norway and Iceland under the European Free Trade Association (EFTA), has a range of bilateral agreements with Switzerland and a customs union with Turkey. Only agriculture is excluded from all these arrangements.
The EU will continue to abide by World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, but-continuing the shift of recent years-the bloc's focus will be on bilateral trade deals, as support for progress through the multilateral trade system has frayed amid heightened opposition in many countries (notably the US) to further trade liberalisation. We expect the EU to make gradual progress, but the backdrop will be challenging, given the fall-out from the ongoing US-China trade war, a broader increase in global trade protectionist measures, the significant risk of a disruptive Brexit by the UK, an increased threat of additional US tariffs on imports of EU cars (which would result in a wider trade conflict as the EU defends its interests) and weaker global growth. There is a clear risk of an escalating chain reaction of measures, threatening a more dramatic fraying of the multilateral trade system.
The EU and Japan finalised an economic partnership agreement in July 2018, creating the world's largest free-trade area. The deal came into effect in February 2019; some tariffs will fall to zero this year, but for most measures there will be a lengthy transition phase in the next decade. The EU-Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) will gradually come into force in 2019-23. CETA will eliminate most trade tariffs, simplify border procedures and increase regulatory co-operation. In April 2018 the EU and Mexico agreed in principle to a trade deal that would include a significant reduction of tariffs.
Our core forecast is that the UK and EU will ultimately reach some form of Brexit agreement (paving the way for, most likely, an even more protracted and antagonistic period of negotiations over a future trade deal). However, the UK's increasingly dysfunctional political landscape also implies a clear possibility of a disruptive no-deal Brexit or no Brexit at all. Should the negotiations break down irrevocably, then the UK would leave the EU and revert to WTO trade rules. This would mean a significant increase in tariffs, as well as in non-tariff barriers to trade with the EU. The UK is Germany's fifth-largest export market, with the two countries interconnected by extensive financial, investment and supply-chain linkages (and with Germany also indirectly exposed to the UK's significant ties with the wider EU market). A no-deal Brexit would have a severe impact on UK-EU trade, weighing on business activity across Germany.
Business environment outlook: Taxes

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Tax burden will remain high on labour income and companies
The tax/GDP ratio in Germany has risen slightly over the past decade and stood at 40.5% in 2017 (latest available data), similar to the EU average and moderately below that for the euro zone (41.4%). Direct taxes on personal income and net social security contributions account for a higher than average share of overall tax receipts. A lower proportion of revenue is derived from taxes on corporate income, goods and services (such as value-added tax, VAT), on the environment and on property. There are three personal income tax rates, ranging from 14% to 45%, with the top rate levied on taxable income over EUR265,330. There is also a "solidarity surcharge"-a 5.5% levy on income that has been in effect since 1991 to finance reunification costs. The standard VAT rate is 19%, slightly less than the EU average, with a reduced rate of 7% on certain goods and services.
Despite robust jobs growth in Germany over recent years, the tax system is not that supportive of employment or private investment, with a relatively high tax burden on labour income and on companies. In 2017 the average single worker faced a tax wedge-the difference between workers' take-home pay and what it costs to employ them-of 49.7%, the second highest in the OECD, after Belgium. This high burden, including on low-income workers, acts as a disincentive for second earners and partly accounts for the modest full-time employment rate among women. The effective tax burden on firms is also elevated, even though the headline federal corporation tax rate is just 15%. After including the impact of a local trade tax (Gewerbesteuer) and solidarity surcharge, the effective average corporation tax rate is about 28%, compared with an EU average of about 21%. The country's tax system for firms is quite complex, with fairly high administration costs. Tax treatment favours debt over equity, which could hinder private investment and might partly account for Germany's underdeveloped venture capital market.
The public finances are robust by advanced economy standards, with the general government budget recording a fifth consecutive annual surplus in 2018. The government plans a modest fiscal expansion in 2019-20, mainly via a rise in public investment. With both coalition parties broadly supportive of a cautious fiscal stance, no significant overhaul of tax policy is expected.
The coalition government has agreed a phased abolition of the solidarity surcharge for most lower- and middle-income earners by 2021, which will offer some modest tax relief. Adjustments to social security contributions and welfare benefits in 2019 will have a negligible effect on the labour tax burden. We expect some targeted measures to incentivise business investment, building on recent reforms to the tax framework for start-ups and investment funds. A deeper-than-expected economic slowdown would probably trigger more fiscal intervention, although well-established automatic stabilisers and long-held fiscal conservatism will limit the prospects of a major discretionary fiscal stimulus.
Business environment outlook: Financing

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Support for the financial sector will continue, amid slow reforms
Germany's financial sector was badly hit by the 2008-09 global financial crisis. Officials and regulators were slow to address the failings in the banking system, which had invested heavily in exotic asset-backed securities. In the past decade the underlying resilience of the sector has steadily improved, in response to major balance sheet restructuring and consolidation, and as banks have strengthened their capital and liquidity positions, and asset quality, amid tighter regulation, firmer GDP growth and supportive financing conditions. At end-2018 estimates of Tier 1 capital ratio were slightly above the regional average and the share of non-performing loans was modest. Huge monetary support from the ECB has kept banks' funding costs low and fostered an upturn in private-sector credit growth, but the protracted low-interest-rate environment has weighed heavily on bank profitability, which in Germany is among the weakest in the EU. There has been a modest shift towards commission- and fee-based revenue generation, but the business model of most German banks remains heavily geared towards interest income, leading to consistently low returns on equity. High operating costs, litigation pay-outs, pressure on margins from regulatory requirements and demands for digitisation have spurred large cost-cutting programmes and job losses across the sector, including at the two largest financial institutions, Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank. Amid a weakening economic outlook, more structural adjustments will most likely be required to avert a loss of investor confidence, and doubts will persist about the underlying strength of some state-owned regional lenders (Landesbanken), which faced huge losses during the crisis and remain in a weakened condition. Germany has an extensive network of (mostly non-profit) small local credit co-operatives and public-sector savings banks (owned by local authorities) that aim to service the Mittelstand. These account for the majority of credit institutions and are a major factor as to why retail banking in Germany is less profitable than in most other EU countries.
Private equity and venture capital markets remain relatively small
The credit cycle in Germany-and across the euro zone-firmed in 2015-17 amid improved economic conditions. According to ECB figures, total lending by financial institutions to the German private sector (including to other financial intermediaries) rose by 4.6% in 2017, a decade high, driven by faster growth in unsecured consumer credit and in lending to corporates. However, credit demand softened during the course of 2018, as economic conditions deteriorated, and we expect a period of more subdued lending growth in the coming years.
Internally generated funds account for an above-average share of corporate financing in Germany, reflecting firms' lower reliance on capital markets than in most large advanced economies. Equity capital accounts for the largest share of funding, but is below the EU average. Bank credit was traditionally the preferred financing channel, being comparatively cheap and available at long maturities, but demand has weakened over the past decade amid steady deleveraging. The private equity and venture capital markets are growing, but remain small in an international comparison. Securitisation and use of credit derivatives are common, but the market is less developed than in some other high-income countries.
Brexit-related disruption, regulatory changes and digitalisation costs could lead to additional capital needs for parts of Germany's financial sector. A state-backed merger of the country's two largest financial institutions-Deutsche and Commerzbank-is possible in the coming years, but may not address structural flaws. Brexit would create more opportunities for the expansion of Germany's financial services hub of Frankfurt, as regulatory requirements will mean that London's relative appeal as a financial centre partly diminishes.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
7.0 6.7 13 23 6 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Germany has a comparatively robust labour market, with a high employment rate, a record-low jobless rate (of about 3.2% of the labour force as at January 2019, far below the EU28 average of 6.5%), solid employer-employee relations, a statutory national minimum wage and a well-respected apprenticeship system. The rate of unemployment has fallen steadily in the past decade (from a peak of 11.2% in 2005) and the employment rate has trended higher, to about 80% at end-2018 (among those aged 20-64). Firm labour demand in recent years has been supported by robust cyclical economic growth, which is now weakening, but the impressive headline labour market indicators can also be traced back to the impact of contentious reforms implemented by past governments. Liberalising measures, tighter welfare eligibility, the decentralisation of wage bargaining and a long period of earnings restraint resulted in a strengthening of productivity, jobs growth and competitiveness during the 2000s, when most EU countries experienced a steady increase in labour costs. This policy approach was deeply unpopular with workers in Germany at the time-and constrained household spending-but has since underpinned the consistently high employment rate. Recent evidence would suggest that it has also contributed to lowering the rate at which unemployment generates wage inflation. Despite a record-low jobless rate and increasing labour shortages, average whole-economy earnings growth has remained subdued. Collective wage agreements since early 2018 point to a mild acceleration over the next couple of years, even as labour demand softens. The scope of collective agreements has declined gradually over recent years.
Reforms will be needed to strengthen the incentives for later retirement
There are some other less positive features of the labour market. Although the overall female employment rate is comparatively high (about 76% at end-2018), participation of women in full-time employment is modest, partly owing to limited childcare availability and tax disincentives for second earners. Since 2017 the government has implemented a number of reforms to strengthen childcare provision. About 5m Germans (mainly female) were employed in part-time, low-wage "mini-jobs" at end-2017. Across the economy as a whole, the share of low-skill, low-wage employment has risen steadily over the past decade. There is also a significant gap between the employment and inactivity rates of female EU and non-EU nationals (more so than for men), implying transition issues for those with a migrant background into the labour market, and underused labour resources. The employment prospects (and participation rate) of older workers have improved, but the challenges posed by Germany's ageing population mean that reforms will be needed to strengthen the incentives for later retirement (in contrast to a 2014 pension bill that expanded early retirement options) and improve lifelong learning policies.
Skilled labour shortages have been a topic of debate in Germany for some time, but business surveys suggest that the problem has become more acute over the past few years, with a growing proportion of firms-particularly SMEs-citing a lack of higher-skilled labour as having a negative impact on business operations. Germany's negative demographic trends mean that the situation is only likely to get worse. Inflows of migrant labour will help to some extent and Brexit could be beneficial, as the UK's diminishing status leads to the relocation of employees to Germany and the re-routing of some immigrants who might have otherwise gone to the UK. However, vacancy rates suggest that these arrivals will not be sufficient to meet labour demand. As the political mood is not conducive to greater immigration, the focus may need to shift to removing incentives for early retirement or encouraging higher female full-time employment.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
7.8 8.0 16 13 10 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Infrastructure is solid, but greater capital investment is needed
The quality of network infrastructure has traditionally been a strength of the business environment in Germany, but a lengthy period of subdued public and private capital investment has resulted in a gradual deterioration of standards, constraining progress in digitisation (which lags many of the country's peers) and raising capacity concerns in the energy transition policy (Energiewende) towards renewables. We expect some improvement in the forecast period in response to a moderately stronger trend in public investment, targeted primarily at digital infrastructure and social housing, although some weaknesses will persist. Transport infrastructure is well developed, but spending restraint has contributed to rising congestion and a backlog of repairs. The previous coalition government published a new Federal Transport Infrastructure Plan (FTIP) in 2016, proposing expenditure of EUR270bn on about 1,000 projects up to 2030, with a majority of the intended funds allocated to maintenance of existing road and rail networks. However, the FTIP is more a basic framework for policy than a specific funding plan, with actual implementation dependent on attracting substantial private investment and overcoming regulatory hurdles (such as complex planning rules) and weak co-ordination between federal and local government. Ongoing airport investment will be underpinned by robust passenger demand, but construction of a new flagship airport, Berlin-Brandenburg, has been beset with problems and budget overruns. The scheduled opening has been repeatedly pushed back from 2011 to 2020, with further delays possible. The mobile telecoms and broadband markets are competitive, but Germany lags many of its peers in the provision of high-speed broadband services, with large regional and urban-rural disparities.
The post-Fukushima decision by the government in 2011 to phase out domestic nuclear power by 2022 has driven a steady shift towards renewables, subsidies for which have contributed to high household energy bills. Germany is making progress in expanding renewables generation (particularly solar and windpower), but has been constrained by sluggish power-grid development and a continually high dependence on heavily polluting coal, hampering efforts to meet other climate targets, such as emissions reduction.
In early 2019 a government-appointed commission recommended an exit date of 2038 from coal-fired power generation. The phase-out plans envisage a 25% decline in coal generation by 2022, higher electricity prices, and substantial financial support to coal-producing areas and to power-station operators.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
9.4 9.7 3 1 3 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Investment in artificial intelligence and roll-out of 5G will be a priority
Germany scores highly on a regional and global basis for technological readiness, owing to the scope of its existing digital infrastructure; strong e-commerce and e-business penetration; above-average digital skill levels; a national Industry 4.0 initiative aimed at supporting digital manufacturing; and an effectively developed framework for research and innovation. Weaker aspects are the comparatively slow pace of high-speed broadband roll-out, modest digital adoption by SMEs and a fairly limited scope of e-government services. Total investment in R&D was 3% of GDP in 2017, one of the highest ratios in the EU. R&D intensity has trended steadily higher over the past decade, driven primarily by larger firms in the medium- and high-tech manufacturing sectors (the automotive industry is a major driver). However, Germany was no longer ranked among the "innovation leaders" in the European Commission's "Innovation Scoreboard 2018", falling back into the group of "strong innovators". Germany scored well in terms of business investment and private-public linkages, but lagged its peers in entrepreneurship and financing support. There are pockets of entrepreneurial dynamism, such as Berlin (the capital), but measures of innovative high-growth firms and start-up activity have gradually weakened in recent years. Germany has established a National Cyber Response Centre and since 2011 has updated its official cybersecurity strategy on several occasions. In 2018 the government implemented several new initiatives aimed at safeguarding its digital infra-structure, including a new agency tasked with strengthening key technologies for business operations. According to the Global Cybersecurity Index, published by the International Telecommunications Union (ITU) in 2017, Germany was ranked 24th globally in terms of its commitment and capacity to deal with the rapidly increasing threat from cyber-crime and cyber-espionage.
The government's digital policy is largely a continuation of its predecessor's "Digital Strategy 2025". The four-stage expansion plan comprised an end-2018 target for national high-speed broadband access for all households (unlikely to have been met owing to limited availability in rural and remote areas), with a second stage aiming to provide fibre-optic technology to underserved industrial areas by end-2019. A third stage envisages the deployment of fifth-generation (5G) mobile technology by end-2020, and a final phase aims to have a nationwide gigabit-capable infrastructure network by 2025.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
The presence of the Social Democratic Party (SPD) in the previous government enabled progress on some typically social democratic policy goals, including the introduction of a lower retirement age for some workers and a statutory minimum wage. The current coalition has agreed a substantial fiscal stimulus for 2019. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any large-scale structural reform efforts.
Significant structural challenges will emerge during the 2020s. The poor demo-graphic outlook is a particular problem, with the working-age population heading into decline and the population structure ageing. Social changes will also require policymakers' attention, with crucial questions including how best to integrate large numbers of refugees, and whether the need to combat terrorism should supersede Germany's long-standing aversion to surveillance.
The dominant automotive sector also faces an increasingly uncertain future following the "Dieselgate" emissions-rigging scandal and allegations of cartel behaviour, and given disruptive technological trends in the industry. The government's "Industry 4.0" initiative is intended to ensure that the dominant German manufacturing sector remains at the forefront of advances in robotics, artificial intelligence and the Internet of Things, but Germany will face strong competition from China, South Korea and Japan in the coming decades. Changes will also need to be made in the energy sector, with the government planning to phase out coal-fired power plants by 2038 in order to meet emissions goals.

A balanced federal budget on the national measure-the so-called schwarze Null-has long been the main target of federal government policy, and has been met for the past five years.
The slow process of government formation after the 2017 election meant that the 2018 budget did not include significant changes, and solid revenue growth underpins our fiscal surplus estimate of 1.8% of GDP. We expect the surplus to decline to 0.8% of GDP this year. Under the 2019 budget, expenditure is set to reach an all-time high owing to an increase in defence and welfare funding; this, together with broad tax-relief efforts, means that the budget's fiscal stimulus will be the strongest since 2010.
The coalition's agreement foresees a more expansionary fiscal policy until 2021, but the deep-seated commitment across the political spectrum to the schwarze Null target will ensure that the balance remains in surplus, at an average of 0.5% of GDP in 2020-23. The downward trend in the debt/GDP ratio will persist, bringing it within the 60% EU level this year and to less than 50% by 2023.
Economic forecast: Monetary policy

The European Central Bank (ECB) adopted an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy in response to the European sovereign debt crisis, bringing major policy interest rates down to zero or below and undertaking a quantitative easing (QE) programme that amounted to EUR2.6trn. The bank ended its asset-purchase programme in December 2018, but policy conditions will remain loose in the medium term as the ECB reinvests principal payments from maturing securities and adjusts other existing tools. Economic activity in the euro zone softened in 2018, and headline growth will slow further this year. Together with a more subdued outlook for commodity prices in 2019-20, we expect this to prompt the ECB to hold off on normalising its policy stance this year. We expect a 25-basis-point increase in the main refinancing rate to 0.25% in early 2020 as underlying price pressures build. Policy tightening should then proceed at a gradual pace, and we expect five more rate rises in the 2019-23 forecast period to lift the rate to 2% by end-2023. An increase in the deposit rate, which currently stands at -0.4%, may come sooner, in 2019, easing the pressure on banks' lending margins and supporting profitability. Risks to our outlook stem from the nomination of a new ECB president in late 2019.
