Real GDP growth averaged 2.5% in 2017, the strongest annual expansion since 2011, in line with a pick-up in world trade growth. Growth slowed to 1.5% in 2018, driven primarily by weaker car production in the second half of the year-as the industrial sector scrambled to respond to new European car-emissions tests-and by a less supportive external trade environment.
This year we forecast real GDP growth of 1%. On the one hand, this is the result of muted carry-over effects from the slowdown in the second half of 2018. On the other, it reflects our assessment of weak underlying growth: high-frequency data show that the disruption to production in the automotive sector is now fading, but global economic and political uncertainty continues to weigh on business confidence and export expectations. The composite purchasing managers' index (PMI) recorded a five-year low in December, with respondents citing global market uncertainty and reduced demand from major trading partners (particularly China). The outlook for the export sector is subdued, underpinned by the US-China trade war, the ongoing Brexit process and a projected slowdown in the world's two biggest economies-the US and China.
Nevertheless, domestic economic fundamentals remain strong. The main driver of growth in 2019 will be private consumption as the tight labour market feeds into significant nominal wage increases. Growth in state pensions and low borrowing costs will further support household spending. Investment will also continue to contribute robustly to growth, supported by an increase in public and private investment, driven by capacity constraints, skills shortages, investment in new technologies, additional residential co-nstruction and favourable financing conditions.
In 2020-23 we forecast average annual real GDP growth of 1.7%, supported by still positive domestic conditions. The competitiveness of the manufacturing sector will keep the contribution of external trade to headline growth positive, despite strong import growth. However, we expect the external environment to become more difficult and to act as the main drag on German growth. We also expect a slowdown in the US economy in 2020 to lower demand for manufactured exports in that year. Risks to our economic outlook are on the downside. An escalation of the US-China trade war could lead to greater disruption to global trade volumes. An imposition of new US tariffs on EU automotive exports is not our core forecast, but cannot yet be ruled out; nor can a disorderly UK exit from the EU. A further challenge is that Germany's flagship industry, the automotive sector, is in danger of being disrupted by technological change.
In the longer term the poor demographic outlook will increasingly constrain potential growth as the working-age population declines. The inflow of young migrants in 2015-16 will mitigate the rate at which the population will age and-over the longer term-shrink, but will not change the overall trend.

Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Services account for about 68% of GDP, industry (including construction) for 31% and agriculture the remainder. Manufacturing accounts for about 24% of gross value added-a considerably higher proportion than in most other indus-trialised economies. Moreover, in contrast with many of Germany's peers, manu-facturing's share of gross value added has remained broadly stable over the past two decades. Nevertheless, we expect industry's share of gross value added to edge down slightly by 2023, to about 30%. A decrease in the relative importance of manufacturing is the inevitable result of rising living standards: as people get wealthier they spend a higher proportion of their income on services and a lower pro-portion on manufactured goods. However, it also reflects the changing nature of manufacturing, as even Germany's industrial champions increasingly provide value added through services supplied in conjunction with manufactured products.
Strong industrial sector faces medium-term threats from new technology
Germany's most important manufacturing sectors are automotive, electrical and mechanical engineering, chemicals, and food, drink and tobacco. Germany is the global leader in the production of premium cars, an industry that has gained from robust competition between several domestic companies, ownership structures that have enabled firms to make long-term investment, and a host of innovative supplier companies in the mechanical and electrical engineering sectors. Although many of the industry's main European markets experienced a weak recovery following the 2008-09 global financial crisis, sales in emerging markets such as China and India have been strong. As major producers of capital goods, German firms were able to weather the years following the global financial crisis by profiting from rapid industrialisation in emerging markets. A pick-up in world trade in 2017 underpinned strong manufacturing growth of 3.5% in Germany that year, the fastest in the past six years. The rebound was felt across the euro zone, which supported growth in capital goods production. Nevertheless, the slowdown felt across the euro zone and, to a lesser extent, in the global economy put growth of capital goods production at 1.1% in 2018 and overall manufacturing growth at 1.2%. We expect manufacturing growth to remain modest throughout the forecast period as the Chinese and US economies lose momentum.
Most industries derive competitive advantages from Germany's well-developed system of vocational training, good physical infrastructure and research base, and a tax system that encourages capital investment. German manufacturers will face a more unstable external environment, challenged by a broad shift towards protectionism across the world, but particularly led by the US. Low interest rates will continue to stimulate residential construction, ensuring relatively strong growth in overall construction activity. However, from 2023 onwards we expect larger threats to the dominance of German industry to emerge, particularly to the automotive industry. New technologies, such as electric cars and self-driving cars, could pose challenges the industry's position, especially as it is still dealing with the fallout of the diesel-emissions scandal and the move away from diesel technology, in which it had invested heavily in recent decades.
Financial services activity unlikely to shift from London to Frankfurt
The services sector is the largest component of GDP and comprises a broad range of activities, from retailing to financial services, logistics and healthcare. Services sector growth in Germany was relatively weak in the years after the global financial crisis, held back by subdued growth in household income. However, with the recent strong improvements in the labour market and the concurrent improving outlook for private consumption, services sector activity expanded relatively strongly in 2016-17 and, despite the slowdown in 2018, growth should remain firm in the coming years. One source of uncertainty is the financial services industry. In common with the rest of Europe, German financial services were hit hard by the economic downturn. Although solvency indicators have improved, many German banks remain vulnerable to the effects of any renewed shock. Furthermore, the sector has experienced relatively little reform in recent years compared with regional peers. The weakness of the banking sector has the potential to restrict growth prospects over the forecast period. A possible upside risk is that some financial services activity may move from London to Frankfurt following the UK's departure from the EU. Although some relocations have already been announced, we expect these moves to remain relatively limited, and do not expect Frankfurt to take over London's role as Europe's main financial hub.
Agriculture contributes less than 1% of GDP, one of the lowest proportions in the EU. We expect this share to remain broadly unchanged throughout the forecast period as public- and private-sector investment continues to focus on other sectors of the economy.

In 2018 consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) averaged 1.9%, with global commodity prices providing the main upward impetus. A series of recent collective bargaining agreements is starting to feed into higher wages, but underlying domestic inflationary pressures remain modest for now. Lower global oil prices this year mean that we expect inflation to soften to 1.6%. In 2020-23 we expect the German economy to outperform the euro zone average, which will keep inflation comparatively high within the bloc-albeit in line with the ECB's target of "below, but close to, 2%". We forecast an annual average rate of about 1.9% in 2020-23.

The euro rallied in late 2017 as the region's economic recovery strengthened and expectations of QE tapering increased, and as political risk waned in Europe but rose in the US. After peaking at almost US$1.25:EUR1 in early February 2018, the euro has depreciated gradually. This was a response to the formation of a Eurosceptic government in Italy, which increased political risk in the region, and to monetary tightening in the US. More recently, the euro has hovered around US$1.14:EUR1-weaker than we had anticipated-on the back of softening momentum in the euro zone. We expect it to appreciate gradually throughout 2019 as growth in the bloc picks up later this year and momentum in the US slows, but we have revised down our forecast for 2019 to an average of US$1.16:EUR1 (from US$1.19:EUR1 previously). The euro will continue to appreciate throughout our forecast period, to US$1.22:EUR1 in 2020-21 as monetary policy in the euro zone is tightened gradually, and to US$1.24:EUR1 on average in 2022-23, supported by the large current-account surplus.

Germany's large current-account surplus averaged 8.5% of GDP in 2015-17, underpinned by huge trade surpluses reflecting the competitiveness of its manufacturing sector. This will continue to generate large domestic savings that are mainly invested abroad, leading to a solid primary income surplus. Trade and primary income surpluses will comfortably outweigh small structural deficits on the services and secondary income accounts. We expect the current-account surplus to remain substantial, declining gradually as a share of GDP from 2017 levels, to 6.7% of GDP by 2023 owing to an increasingly disadvan-tageous global trade environment and slowly rising levels of domestic consumption and investment. These large surpluses will continue to provoke criticism-within Europe and globally-of Germany's role in prolonging demand shortfalls in much of the rest of the euro zone.

Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Germany
Stocks and flows
Germany is an attractive destination for foreign investment, but on balance the country is a net exporter of long-term capital. The skills of its workforce, the availability of supplier companies, the quality of the research and innovation framework, and a reliable administrative and legal environment make Germany one of the most attractive destinations in the world for inward foreign direct investment (FDI). However, relative to GDP the stock of such investment is lower than in some other comparatively sized economies. Following a significant increase in inflows during the 1990s, the rate of growth of FDI then slowed, falling below the world average. The global financial crisis then reduced inflows to about one-tenth of previous years' levels at the lowest point, in 2008. Inward foreign investment has since recovered, but outflows have continued to be larger than inflows. In the third quarter of 2018 (latest available data) the inward FDI stock was equivalent to 43% of GDP and net direct investment totalled EUR546.4bn, an all-time high.
Origin and distribution
As is the case in other developed countries, the FDI stock in Germany is increasingly dominated by service providers rather than by manufacturers, although manufacturers remain important, in line with the relatively large size of the manufacturing sector. About three-quarters of Germany's inward FDI stock originates from other EU member states-although this sometimes includes investment from outside the EU that is transferred through countries such as the Netherlands and Luxembourg (the largest and second-largest foreign direct investors in Germany respectively), often for tax reasons. The most important investor from outside the EU is the US, which accounts for 12% of total stock. Authorities and companies have become increasingly hesitant about increasing investment from China (by 2016 it only amounted to 1% of the FDI stock), which often targets mid-sized companies with significant technological knowhow. This is likely to weigh on investment from China in the coming years, as Germany has put its weight behind new investment screening measures at the EU level. Most outward investment is to other EU countries, but investment in Switzerland, the US, Russia and China is also significant.
Determinants
German labour costs are among the highest in the world, but have been made more competitive by a period of falling or stagnant growth in real wages over the past decade. A minimum wage was introduced in 2015, but has not had a significant effect on employment levels, reflecting at least in part the healthy state of the labour market. Regulations such as the right of worker representatives to sit on company boards (up to half of board members) have deterred some foreign investors, but in practice the system of workforce representation in companies often helps company management bodies to communicate their strategies and, where necessary, explain the need for changes in working practice-or even reduced pay in difficult circumstances. The tax environment remains, on balance, a downside. Foreign investors, including a rising number of private equity firms, are attracted by the large number of profitable medium-sized companies specialising in niche markets. Additional strengths are the country's good infrastructure, the generally high quality of the workforce, and strong research and innovation activity.
Impact
Foreign-owned companies employ about 2.5m people in Germany. Many FDI inflows take the form of acquisitions rather than greenfield investment, so that the immediate impact on employment is not clear (and in some cases has initially been negative). In industry, especially manufacturing, the dominance of German firms means that FDI has had only a limited impact. Although manufacturing made up 24% of gross value added in 2016, it represented just 16% of the inward FDI stock in that year (latest available data). Foreign investment in Germany's services sector is likely to have had a larger impact on the domestic economy, boosting productivity via the introduction of new technology and fewer hierarchical organisational structures. Investment by private equity groups has also helped to inject capital and managerial expertise into slow-growing family-owned businesses.
Potential
Germany's skilled workforce and sound infrastructure make it a good location for specialised manufacturing. More generally, the structure of German industry is still relatively fragmented, providing foreign investors with the opportunity to participate in sectoral consolidation and to reap economies of scale through acquisitions. The generational changeover at the helm of many small and medium-sized companies provides opportunities for foreign investors, although in many cases foreign involvement is not appreciated. The still moderate level of property prices-by west European standards-and increasing demand for housing, especially in urban areas, may attract investors into this sector. A poor demographic outlook, with the population expected to go into decline by 2023, will constrain Germany's potential as a consumer market. Regulatory barriers to inward investment are likely to increase in the coming years, as political pressure to protect sensitive industries has increased in recent years and broadened from traditional strategic industries, such as defence, to high-tech industries, driven by the desire not to sell technology to future competitors. This is likely to happen both at the European and the domestic levels, and will increasingly lead to delays in approving projects, and larger numbers of rejections of takeovers.

The population has experienced negative natural change ever since reunification
Germany's population declined in every year between 2002 and 2011, but high levels of net immigration underpinned population growth in subsequent years. The population reached 82.8m in 2018, up from about 80.8m in 2013, boosted in particular by the impact of the migrant crisis in 2015. The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that the rise in the population will moderate in the 2019-23 forecast period, with the total number stabilising at about 82.9m in 2023, before starting to decline.
The population has recorded a natural decline in every year since German reunification, with the death rate higher than the birth rate, and this will continue to be the case in 2019-23. The birth rate plummeted after the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989, especially in East Germany. In 1991 a total of 830,019 births were recorded in Germany, but by 2011 this number had declined to 662,685. More recently, this trend has reversed, with the fertility rate rising to 1.59 children per woman in 2016-the highest figure since 1973-reflecting both policy efforts, such as an expansion in childcare provision and parental benefits, and a higher fertility rate among immigrant communities. The fertility rate decreased marginally in 2017, to 1.57, slightly less than the EU average of 1.59, and well below the replacement rate of 2.1, the rate needed to keep the population size constant in the absence of migration.
The decline in the population in the early 2000s was caused not just by a decrease in the birth rate, but also by negative net immigration. In total, the population contracted by 1%, or about 800,000 people, between 2002 and 2012. However, this trend has now also reversed, with population growth in 2012-18 coming from positive net immigration. Population growth peaked in 2015 during the migrant crisis, when a sharp rise in inflows of migrants and refugees from conflict zones in the Middle East and North Africa were attracted to Germany in particular because of its strong economy and initially welcoming policy stance. However, the sheer volume of arrivals soon proved politically unsustainable, prompting a hardening of the government's position. The influx of migrants slowed in 2016-17, reflecting the closing of the Balkan route into the EU and an agreement between the EU and Turkey to halt migrants crossing illegally to the bloc from Turkey, brokered by Germany. We expect further deals to be agreed with other countries as needed, for instance in North Africa, to ensure that the experience of 2015 is not repeated.
The working-age population will continue to decline
This means that the demographic outlook will remain poor. As in the region more broadly, the population is ageing, with the old-age dependency ratio expected to rise throughout the forecast period and the working-age population already in decline. We expect the share of the population aged 15-64 to fall from 64.8% in 2018 to 62.9% in 2023. Although these shares remain higher than those in France, the UK or Italy, the rate of decline is faster. This is likely to lead to greater pressure on the pensions and healthcare systems. It will also exacerbate labour shortages, given robust economic activity at present in Germany and an increasingly tight labour market-Germany has the second-lowest unemployment rate in the EU. Efforts have already been made to attract more women and older workers into employment, but there will be diminishing returns from these over the forecast period. Policy innovation will also be needed to attract immigrants into the labour market, and in particular to integrate the recent arrivals from the Middle East and North Africa. Although the current economic upswing and a range of integration programmes are helping with this, full labour market integration is likely to be a long process.
Germany has the second-highest number of immigrants in the world, after the US, with more than 16m first- and second-generation immigrants. The largest groups in 2017 were from Turkey (which is double the size of any other group), Poland, Syria, Italy, Romania and Greece. Aside from a large inflow of migrants from the Middle East and the Balkans in 2015-16, the turnaround in net immigration since 2011 reflects a rise in the number of people migrating to Germany from Poland, Romania and Bulgaria, and to a lesser extent from crisis-hit members of the euro zone, such as Italy and Greece. The economic recovery in some of these countries means that these inflows are now easing, but Brexit may result in some financial services staff moving to Germany, while other immigrations who would otherwise have gone to the UK may start to consider Germany as an alternative option.

Germany will remain the fourth-largest economy in the world in 2022
As measured by GDP at current exchange rates, Germany is the fourth-largest economy in the world, behind the US, China and Japan. According to The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecasts, this will still be the case in 2023, with German GDP registering US$4.9trn. This is still significantly larger than the fifth-largest economy in the world on this measure, the UK, which we forecast at US$3.4trn in 2023 (about the same size as the French economy). Germany is the largest economy in Europe, and accounts for just over one-fifth of total EU GDP. On a purchasing power parity (PPP) basis, which adjusts for differences in price levels between countries that are not always captured by market exchange rates, the German economy is the fifth largest in the world, behind India, the US, China and Japan.

Consumer demand will rise moderately over the forecast period
Germany is the largest consumer market in the EU in terms of population size. However, GDP per head is only the sixth-highest level in the EU, and the market for consumer goods is further reduced by an elevated savings rate, a cultural reluctance to buy on credit, the second-highest tax wedge as a percentage of labour costs in the OECD in 2017 (after Belgium), and a low proportion of national income accounted for by wages and salaries. Consumer spending played a relatively modest role in Germany's post-crisis recovery, with private consumption accounting for an average of only 0.1 percentage point of GDP growth in 2007-10, and 0.6 percentage points in 2011-14. However, it has become a more important driver of GDP growth more recently, in line with a strengthening of employment growth, as well as a gradual rise in wages, increases to state pensions and the introduction of a minimum wage in 2015. Collective bargaining arrangements to increase wages in specific industries are now being agreed, and will feed into real earnings growth in 2019-23 (the forecast period). This will support consumer spending; but with real personal disposable income forecast to rise by 1.1% per year in 2019-23 compared with 2% in 2014-18, demand is likely to moderate over the course of our forecast period.
The shift towards domestic-demand-driven growth in recent years is lending support to housing-related areas of the German economy, with a significant pick-up in house price growth since 2010. We expect this firmer trend in housing market activity to continue, and, combined with the rise in the number of single and two-person households, which now comprise three-quarters of the total, this will support sales of white goods. As in many countries, the profile of bricks-and-mortar retailing is changing owing to the strong growth of online shopping and consumers' increasing demand for convenience. E-commerce sales totalled EUR53.4bn in 2018, up by 10% from 2017, according to the German Retail Federation (HDE). Meanwhile, traditional mainstays such as bookshops, consumer electronics stores and household appliance chains are disappearing, and department stores are struggling to remain profitable. Reflecting the high market share of discounters, consumers will retain a strong price focus for staples, including food and clothing, but high-end income gains will also sustain demand for luxury goods.
Population ageing will influence spending patterns
Germany is a mature consumer market, but demographic trends will have an important influence on spending patterns over the next few years. The population is ageing, and, according to Germany Trade and Invest, people older than 50 years now account for more than half of purchasing power. This brings with it a rising demand for age-related services, particularly in the health sector, and for products-for example, in the tourism industry-that cater specifically for the needs of the elderly. Meanwhile, the increasing awareness in the working-age population that the public pension system will not remain as generous as it is at present will boost demand for retirement savings products in the financial services industry.

Long-term outlook: The long-term outlook

Initial conditions: Germany has many attributes that are conducive to sustainable long-term growth, including a highly skilled workforce, good infra-structure and stable institutions. Its economic underperformance prior to the 2008-09 global financial slump was largely the result of deficient con-sumer demand, but also reflected supply-side rigidities in services. The situation in the labour market and wage dynamics indicate that the rebalancing towards consumption-driven growth is set to continue during a multi-year time horizon. The structural shift towards a more services-oriented economy still has further to go in Germany than in many other OECD members, owing to the relatively high share of the manufacturing industry in overall GDP. Growth in services is likely to come from areas connected with the manufacturing sector.
Demographic trends: The Economist Intelligence Unit expects negative demographic trends in the coming decades, with the total population set to shrink by 0.13% per year on average in 2019-50 (the long-term forecast period), and the working-age population set to decline at an even more rapid rate of 0.57% per year. The tightening of conditions for long-term unemployment benefits has increased the incentive to search for employment, and additional measures in the same direction are likely in the long term. The partial reversal of previous plans to raise the retirement age from 65 to 67 between 2012 and 2029 will add to demographic challenges, although we expect some relief to come from increased participation of older workers. Immigration from central and eastern Europe could make a modest contribution to alleviating labour shortages, and further liberalisation of immigration rules for highly skilled workers from non-EU countries is possible. The large-scale immigration from the Middle East and Africa seen in 2015 has provided a temporary boost for the demographic outlook, but fully integrating a significant percentage of the newcomers into productive parts of the economy is likely to be a process that spans decades.
External conditions: As an export-oriented country, Germany benefits from the broadly liberal world trade order. Generally, it suffers less than other developed countries (for example, Italy) from competition from emerging markets, such as China and India, owing to its specialisation in high-technology capital goods. This specialisation will also allow Germany to benefit from strong demand from these countries as they upgrade their capital stock. However, over the longer term German output will come under more pressure as manufacturers in emerging markets become more sophisticated and challenge German producers head on in high-end merchandise goods. Within the EU the liberalisation of trade in services should continue (albeit slowly). A worsening of the global trading environment and increased protectionism represent will have a negative impact on Germany, given its open economy.
Institutions and policy trends: Germany's low growth in the early 2000s focused the minds of politicians and policymakers on the need for economic reforms, many of which were implemented, along with more flexible bargaining about wages and other working conditions. Our expectation is that national and EU initiatives will continue to strengthen competition, but there is a risk that the recent loss of faith in market-based solutions will persist. Under the previous government there were already signs that the reforms that have underpinned strong growth in recent years were being partly reversed. Although the public finances are currently in a healthy state, further reform is needed to make them sustainable in the long term. Not much movement in this direction, for instance via the reform of the pension system, is currently in sight, and we expect policymaking to continue to be slow. This will start posing a drag on growth in the first half of our long-term forecast period.
Long-term performance: Our forecast for the economy's long-term average annual growth rate is 1.4%, with a slowdown from 1.5% in the first half of the forecast period (to 2030), to 1.3% in the second half. A contraction of the working-age population is a major driver of this weakening overall growth rate. Accordingly, the picture looks slightly more favourable on a per-head basis, with growth of real GDP per head averaging 1.5% throughout the forecast period, broadly in line with growth since reunification in 1990. GDP per head in 2050 will therefore register US$145,590, marginally behind Norway and the Netherlands but ahead of Denmark and Finland. GDP per head in the UK and France will remain smaller, at US$107,858 and US$116,459 respectively. In terms of the size of the German economy overall, we expect it to be overtaken by India in the 2030s, making it the fifth largest in the world by 2050. Although productivity growth in Germany will be almost as strong as in the US, the less favourable demographic outlook means that the real economy will go from 22% the size of its US counterpart in 2017 to 18% in 2050.
Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
Germany claims to be a global leader in tackling climate change, and its Energiewende, or energy transition, focuses on expanding renewables generation. This effort has been comparatively successful, with renewables accounting for 40% of the country's power supply in 2018. However, Germany is still dependent on coal, one of the most polluting fossil fuels, which accounted for just over 38% of total power generation in 2018. Against this backdrop. the government decided in January 2019 to phase out coal by 2038 or earlier.
Germany is seeking to cut emissions by 40% from 1990 levels by 2020, 55% by 2030 and by at least 80% by 2050. These ambitious targets have been made more difficult by the 2011 decision to phase out nuclear power by 2022, a low-carbon source of energy that at the time accounted for over 20% of generation. Germany's emissions have fallen over the past decade, but only incrementally, with very modest cuts in emissions in the power sector largely negated by slight increases in other sectors, such as transport and manufacturing, and in the past few years by stronger economic growth.
Efforts to mitigate climate change, including by increasing the share of renewables in the country's energy mix, will remain a government priority over the medium to long term, and The Economist Intelligence Unit expects public support to be maintained-even in the face of rising electricity prices. The government aims to increase the share of renewables in the energy mix, to 65% by 2030. Germany's high technological level and self-perception as a global leader in this area will support progress in reducing emissions, and we are cautiously optimistic about the long-term outlook, even if the 2020 target is likely to be missed.
The country's exposure to the impact of climate change, meanwhile, will remain comparatively low, given its geographical position-with limited coastal areas-and temperate climate. We expect the government to remain willing and able to provide the infrastructure upgrades necessary in the face of more extreme weather patterns in the future. However, the country's heavy reliance on exports, which we expect to reach about 51% of GDP by 2023, and on imports means that supply-chain risk may increase as other countries on which it depends are affected. This year we have for the first time explicitly incorporated the impact of climate change on long-term growth in our model, and we find that the German economy will be 1% smaller in 2050 than it would have been without this hit to growth.
Technological developments
Technological advancements will have a significant effect on Germany over the long term for a number of reasons. First, the share of manufacturing in GDP is much higher in Germany than in most other developed European countries, with industry accounting for just over 30% of the economy. According to the OECD, along with agriculture, manufacturing is the industry most exposed to automation globally. In general, the OECD found that jobs in Germany (as in central and eastern Europe, and Japan) were easier to automate than those in the UK, US, Nordic countries and the Netherlands.
Second, Germany is typically strong at research and development (R&D), and innovation, which could make a transition to higher automation rates both more likely and quicker. In 2017 Germany spent 3% of GDP on R&D, among the highest levels in the bloc, but slightly behind Denmark, Sweden and Austria. In 2017 a total of 33,425 patents were filed in Germany, the fourth-highest level in the world after the US, Japan and China, according to the European Patent Office.
Third, Germany is already starting from a strong position. Of the countries looked at in the 2018 report by the International Federation of Robotics, Germany had the highest density of industrial robots in the manufacturing industry in Europe, and the third highest in the world after South Korea and Singapore. Germany's ratio of 322 industrial robots per 10,000 workers has exceeded Japan's since 2017. Excluding the automotive sector, Germany (191) is outpaced by Japan (225) and followed by Sweden (180) on this measure.
Germany is already working to increase automation and data exchange in manufacturing technologies as part of its Industry 4.0 strategy, and efforts to embed new technologies across the industrial sector will continue over the long term. This is likely to be disruptive for the automotive sector in particular, as e-mobility gains pace and autonomous vehicles are further developed, and as diesel technologies are gradually phased out. It is also likely to prove difficult for the Mittelstand, the often family-owned small and medium-sized enterprises found across the country that are central to Germany's manufacturing prowess, as they may struggle to acquire the digital skills needed to compete with new challengers. Efforts to make these firms more resilient to digital disruption will gain pace in 2019-50. Although the country will not supplant the US as a leader in innovation, adoption of new technology will be consistently strong.

Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2014-18) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2019-23). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2014-18. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2019-23 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2014-18 ranges are then used to derive 2019-23 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2019-23, not to the likely situation in 2023 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2016 or 2021). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Liberal Party, led by the prime minister, Justin Trudeau, to remain in power after the October 2019 election, but fallout from the controversy over alleged political interference in a criminal corruption case means that the result will be tighter than previously envisaged.
The renegotiation of the North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA) has reduced trade uncertainty, although the new agreement has yet to be ratified. Trade policy will remain a risk during the administration of the US president, Donald Trump, owing to Canada's reliance on the US, its key export market.
The federal budget will remain in deficit in 2019-23, as higher receipts from the planned carbon tax, the legalisation of cannabis and other sources will be more than offset by increased spending on infrastructure and other measures.
The Bank of Canada (BoC, the central bank) lifted the policy rate three times in 2018, to 1.75%. In 2019 we expect one more rise, of 25 basis points, although continued weak economic data could see the bank keep rates on hold. Modest tightening will resume in 2021 and continue for the rest of the forecast period.
Consumer price inflation will ease to 1.7% in 2019, from 2.2% in 2018, reflecting generally lower oil prices. Inflationary pressures will ease further in 2020, in line with a weaker economy, before picking up again from 2021 as economic growth regains some momentum.
We forecast that real GDP growth will slow from 1.8% in 2018 to 1.6% in 2019 and to 1.5% in 2020 as private consumption growth moderates and an economic slowdown in the US dampens export demand. Real GDP growth will average 2% per year in 2021-23.

Canada's score improves slightly in 2019-23, pushing the country up to seventh place in our global business environment rankings. The best features of the business environment are political stability and openness to trade, although tax policy and the labour market will remain constraints.
Country forecast overview: Canada's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The government revises the Canada Business Corporations Act to introduce provisions on board gender diversity, annual election of directors, single election of directors and shareholder empowerment.
2021-23: Progress on increasing competition in certain sectors, such as telecommunications and dairy, will be uneven.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: The government will continue to welcome foreign investment but will sometimes reject foreign takeovers owing to national security considerations. Chinese investment and takeover bids will come under particular scrutiny.
2021-23: Foreign investment is likely to rise in value terms as resource nationalism in the oil and gas sector eases.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Canada, Mexico and the US ratify the revised North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA), now called the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), which retains the essence of the original treaty.
2021-23: Canada continues to diversify its trade ties. Free-trade talks with China resume.
Taxes
2019-20: The government provides benefits and tax breaks to improve business competitiveness compared with the US.
2021-23: The government introduces reporting mechanisms for multinational enterprises to reduce tax avoidance.
Financing
2019-20: The Bank of Canada (the central bank) develops a system-wide framework to measure stress in banking, insurance and investment funds.
2021-23: The government completes its update of financial legislation, including the Bank Act, the Co-operative Credit Associations Act, the Insurance Companies Act, and the Trust and Loan Companies Act.
The labour market
2019-20: Canada will enact policies to streamline processes and increase quotas to expedite the hiring of foreign talent by companies.
2021-23: The government further encourages the entry of skilled workers and professionals by raising its immigration target.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Construction of oil pipelines from Alberta progresses slowly, as the projects face opposition from environmental groups.
2021-23: After years of uncertainty, pipelines to carry energy resources from Alberta come on stream.
Technological readiness
2019-20: The technology sector benefits from workers moving from the US, especially those on that country's H1B visas, for whom the political climate becomes more difficult.
2021-23: Expertise in artificial intelligence takes root, particularly in the academic centres of Toronto and Montreal.

Background: The Canadian economy was the ninth-largest in the world in 2017 (measured in US dollars at market exchange rates). It is highly integrated with the US economy, which absorbs 76% of its goods exports and is the source of about 51% of its imported goods. The US exerts a powerful economic and cultural influence on Canada. Fifty-eight per cent of Canadians say that English is their mother tongue, just over 21% say French and just under 21% have another language as their first. The majority of French-speakers live in Quebec, Canada's second most-populous province. Canada's unity is sometimes called into question, but support for sovereignty is currently muted in Quebec. Neither of the main parties in contention to lead the provincial government after the 2018 election is seeking an independence referendum.
Political structure: Canada is formally a constitutional monarchy, with the governor-general (always of Canadian nationality and appointed in Ottawa) acting as the representative of the British crown. In practice, the Canadian House of Commons is sovereign. Canada is a federation of ten provinces, each with substantial powers, and three territories. At the federal level are the Commons, the main seat of legislative power, and the non-elected Senate, which plays only a marginal role. The Liberal Party heads a majority government since winning the general election in 2015.
Policy issues: The federal government must balance the assistance that it is providing to the fossil fuel industry through approving new oil pipelines with the need to maintain its green credentials. The government will increase its spending on infrastructure significantly, including through its Canada Infrastructure Bank.
Taxation: The federal corporate income tax rate is 15%. Provincial governments charge corporate tax at rates between 2% and 16%. As at 2018 the top federal income-tax rate, on taxable income above C$205,842 (US$154,200), was 33%.
Foreign trade: The US absorbs about three-quarters of Canadian exports, so the health of its economy is crucial for Canada. Canada's trade deficit was US$19.2bn in 2017 and the current-account deficit was US$46.4bn (2.8% of GDP).

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
The Liberal Party, led by Justin Trudeau, has shifted Canadian politics to the left since it won a majority at the 2015 election. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects challenges to policy initiatives and friction with provincial administrations to intensify ahead of the next federal election, due in October 2019. The unfolding controversy over alleged political interference in a criminal corruption case also risks tarnishing Mr Trudeau's political brand.
The political scandal is rooted in the surprise demotion in January of Jody Wilson-Raybould, the former justice minister and attorney-general, to the veterans' affairs portfolio. Mr Trudeau gave no reason for shifting the respected indigenous leader. However, in early February a national newspaper published unproven allegations that she had been put under pressure by the prime minister's office to abandon the criminal prosecution for fraud of SNC-Lavalin, a large Montreal-based construction and engineering firm, in favour of a deferred prosecution agreement (DPA). This would have let the company off with a fine, and with no ban on bidding for federal contracts. She refused to intervene and the company faces the prospect of a trial.
Ms Wilson-Raybould resigned from the cabinet on February 12th, a day after Mr Trudeau said that her continued presence on the front bench was proof that no one had put her under pressure. This was followed by the resignation of Mr Trudeau's principal secretary and close confidante, Gerald Butts, in a move aimed at fending off further attacks from the main opposition Conservative Party and the New Democratic Party (NDP). Mr Butts and Mr Trudeau have denied any wrongdoing. However, Ms Wilson-Raybould has since testified that Mr Trudeau had asked her in September 2018 to help to find a solution for SNC-Lavalin, because, without a DPA, he feared that many jobs would be lost in his home province of Quebec. Ms Wilson-Raybould claimed that the pressure continued until late last year despite her cautioning him against interfering politically with her role as attorney-general.
In a further setback for Mr Trudeau, a second cabinet minister, Jane Philpott, resigned on March 4th, stating that she had lost confidence in the government's handling of the affair. Mr Trudeau has rejected calls for his resignation by the Conservative leader, Andrew Scheer. However, the controversy is likely to result in further political fallout for the government and give added momentum to the Conservatives in the lead-up to the federal election.
Friction between the federal and provincial governments will intensify ahead of the election. The nationalisation in 2018 of the Trans Mountain pipeline expansion project, which is fundamentally opposed by the provincial government in British Columbia (BC), has raised questions over federal jurisdiction. The Trudeau administration also plans to impose a carbon tax in four provinces-Saskatchewan, Manitoba, Ontario and New Brunswick-that do not have pricing plans meeting federal standards. However, broad agreement on 75:25 cannabis tax revenue-sharing between provincial administrations and the federal government, which came into effect in October, together with the renegotiation of the North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA), which ended a period of heightened trade uncertainty, should help to limit tensions.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Political fallout from the SNC-Lavalin affair saw the Conservatives edge ahead of the Liberals in opinion polls in February, for the first time since July 2018. However, we still expect the Liberal Party to form the government after the federal election due by October 2019. This reflects its recent successes on international trade policy, the legalisation of cannabis and decrying Saudi actions towards human rights, as well as the advantages of incumbency. Since the October 2015 general election, the opposition parties have been in transition. The Conservatives have an experienced shadow cabinet and are building momentum under Mr Scheer. The party will focus on the government's perceived vulnerabilities, namely taxes and government spending. The Conservatives also contend that the Liberals have lost control of the border by allowing 40,000 people to walk across from the US over the past two years and claim asylum. The left-leaning NDP will be boosted by the election to parliament of its leader, Jagmeet Singh, in a by-election on February 25th. However, the NDP trails well behind the two larger parties in terms of fundraising ahead of the election. The Conservatives are in the best shape in this regard.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Under the Liberals, Canadian foreign policy emphasises multilateralism over unilateralism, engagement over isolation, mitigating the effects of climate change and upholding human rights. This is in clear contrast to the policies pursued by Donald Trump's administration in the US. As a result, bilateral relations with the US will be strained during the remainder of the Trump administration, and Canada will continue to look elsewhere for support. This shift was illustrated by the addition of "trade diversification" to the mandate of the international trade minister in a recent cabinet reshuffle. Nonetheless, Canada will seek to preserve relations with the US, its most important diplomatic and economic partner by far. Where possible, Canada will attempt to circumvent the White House by strengthening its ties to other levels of US government.
The successful negotiation of the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), which will replace NAFTA and preserve the trilateral arrangement, mitigates significant trade risk for Canada. The revised deal maintains most of the substance of the earlier US-Mexico deal. In particular, the USMCA retains the Chapter 19 dispute-resolution mechanism, which Canada relies on to protect some of its industries (primarily lumber) from potential US anti-dumping measures. The new deal grants the US greater access to the Canadian market for dairy, poultry and eggs (these sectors are also managed by the government to ensure sufficiently high prices for farmers). This concession is broadly similar to what Canada had offered during negotiations for the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal, which the US withdrew from in 2017. In another move that should ease regional trade tension, Canada negotiated an exemption from any future tariffs that the US might impose on automotive imports. The new agreement was signed in November 2018 but is awaiting ratification by the three governments.
The implementation of the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) is expected to provide enhanced access to key Asian markets over the forecast period. A trade deal signed with the EU in 2016 has removed 98% of the EU tariff lines. With full implementation, the figure is set to rise to 99%. The government also intends to conclude a free-trade agreement with the UK after Brexit.
China was a key target for the government's trade diversification policy until December, when Meng Wanzhou, a senior executive of Huawei, a Chinese telecommunications firm, was detained in Canada at the request of US authorities. On March 1st the government announced that it would proceed with hearings on her extradition. Bitter exchanges between Canada and China since her arrest have cast a chill on bilateral relations. We expect this to persist throughout 2019, preventing progress on exploratory free-trade talks.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Canada will continue supporting domestic industries that are negatively affected by US trade protectionism. In the 2018 autumn fiscal update, the finance minister, Bill Morneau, announced measures to increase the competitiveness of Canadian businesses after the introduction of tax cuts in the US at the start of 2018. These included a tax break on capital expenditure in manufacturing. Additional measures are possible in the 2019/20 federal budget, which will be tabled on March 19th. Environmental policy will also be important in the remainder of the parliamentary term. Government support for the fossil fuel industry is crucial for economic growth in the short to medium term but appears incompatible with the federal government's green credentials. The Liberal Party will continue to seek a balance between these two objectives to preserve its voter base. On the one hand, the government has rolled out a national carbon tax of C$20/tonne (US$15.1/tonne) in provinces that do not have an equivalent carbon pricing programme in place by January 1st 2019. The federal tax will rise to C$50/tonne by 2022. However, the consensus on taxing carbon emissions seems to be weakening as opposition mounts. On the other hand, the government is set to approve the construction of the controversial Trans Mountain Expansion pipeline, designed to enable higher volumes of crude oil from Alberta to be transported to a port in BC. Additional major investments are being undertaken to develop Canada's natural resources.
Policymakers will continue to keep a close eye on the property market, which remains a key risk owing to recent monetary policy tightening and overleveraged Canadian households. Following the imposition of macroprudential measures from the federal government to tighten mortgage-lending requirements since 2016, the market appears to be rebalancing as the quality of new mortgage lending improves. Price growth has slowed markedly, although trends vary across the country.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
The government is committed to a programme of infrastructure spending that will entail a series of budget deficits, but this will be counterbalanced by increased receipts due to the expected introduction of a cap-and-trade system and greater tax income as a result of cannabis legalisation. However, lower average oil prices in 2019-20 compared with 2018 will weigh on plans to reduce the fiscal deficit, as increased government support will be expected to shore up the economy and government receipts are likely to undershoot official projections.
In the 2018/19 budget Mr Morneau announced a series of narrower deficits over the next five years. We estimate that the fiscal deficit stood at 1.2% of GDP in 2018, and expect it to expand slightly, to 1.4%, in 2019 as the government looks to support the fossil fuels industry through rebates and additional incentives amid a softer price environment. In 2020 the government will respond to an economic slowdown with additional fiscal spending, which will push the deficit up to 1.6% of GDP; however, we expect the slowdown to be short-lived. The government will look to narrow the deficit in the longer term, and we expect it to fall gradually, to 1% of GDP by 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The Bank of Canada (BoC, the central bank) lifted its policy rate by 125 basis points between July 2017 and October 2018, in response to rising inflation and tightening monetary policy in the US. However, the BoC has proceeded more cautiously than the Federal Reserve (Fed, the US central bank), and the Canadian policy rate has remained below its US equivalent-an unusual situation. The BoC had been on course to raise its policy rate, currently 1.75%, to what it considers to be a more normal range of between 2.5% and 3.5%, but kept monetary tightening on hold at its December and January meetings, owing in part to lower energy prices, which have pushed down the headline inflation rate. However, the concern is that prolonging the period of low interest rates will encourage households to increase their borrowing, adding to near-record levels of household debt as a proportion of disposable income.
Given the benign outlook for inflation and softer real GDP growth, we now expect that the BoC will lift rates by only 25 basis points in 2019 (we previously forecast that it would increase rates by 50 basis points this year). Moreover, several factors could prevent the BoC from moving altogether, including weak household spending growth, a deteriorating housing market and signs of weaker economic momentum in the US. The BoC will keep rates on hold in 2020, when the US enters a cyclical slowdown, which, because of the two countries' interlinkages, will cause the Canadian economy to slow. Modest tightening will resume in 2021 and continue for the remainder of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
Real GDP growth slowed to 1.8% in 2018, from 3% in 2017. This reflected weaker growth in most GDP components, notably private consumption and business investment, although export growth picked up. The pace of economic expansion slowed sharply in the final three months of last year, and this weaker starting-point has led us to revise down slightly our forecast for real GDP growth in 2019 to 1.6% (from 1.7% previously). Monetary tightening and high household debt levels will dampen private consumption growth this year, and export growth is also expected to moderate, as a result of softer economic expansion in the US, Canada's key export market.
Much of 2018 was characterised by the escalating trade dispute with the US. The renegotiation of NAFTA reduces one of the key downside risks to our forecast, although the agreement has yet to be ratified, and the steel and aluminium tariffs imposed on Canada by the US in 2018 remain in place for now. Other risks to the economic outlook include a renewed drop in global oil prices, which would act as a drag on economic activity.
Real GDP growth will slow further in 2020, to 1.5% (previously 1.6%), as the US enters a cyclical downturn. Economic expansion in Canada is expected to pick up again in 2021, and real GDP growth will average 2.1% per year in 2022-23. This will be supported by continued government spending on infrastructure and stronger export growth, driven by recovering demand in the US and enhanced trade ties with the EU and CPTPP members.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Rising oil prices until October 2018 and the increasingly protectionist trade policy of the US added to price pressures for much of 2018, when the headline rate of consumer price inflation picked up to an average of 2.2%. The headline inflation rate fell back to 1.4% year on year in January, below the BoC's 2% target rate, owing to lower petrol prices, although core inflation was steady at 1.9%. We expect the headline inflation rate to average a benign 1.7% in 2019, reflecting a modest tightening of monetary policy by the central bank, slowing export demand and generally lower oil prices. The mild economic slowdown in 2020 will lead to a further easing in the inflation rate next year, before it picks up again from 2021 as the economy strengthens.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
Tightening monetary policy, a broader improvement in the global economy and the draining of the surplus in the oil market lent support to the Canadian dollar in the first half of 2018. More recently, falling oil prices have weighed on the currency. We expect the Canadian dollar to depreciate further against its US counterpart, from a full-year average of C$1.30:US$1 in 2018 to an average of C$1.36:US$1 in 2019-2020, reflecting weaker global oil prices, softer economic growth and a more dovish approach from the BoC, which we now expect will lift its policy rate by only 25 basis points in 2019, if at all. A pick-up in growth from 2021, and the resumption of monetary tightening, will underpin an appreciation in the Canadian dollar over the remainder of the forecast period, with the currency forecast to average C$1.28:US$1 in 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The exchange rate, commodity prices and the health of the US economy will continue to shape the outlook for the current account, which we expect will remain in deficit in 2019-23. The impact of softer global oil prices in 2019-20 will be offset by slowing domestic demand and, therefore, import growth. As a result, the merchandise trade deficit and the shortfall on the current account will remain broadly stable as a proportion of GDP, with the latter averaging 2.9% of GDP during this period. The CPTPP, the effects of which will first be felt at the start of the next decade, will result in higher trade volumes between Canada and Pacific nations. We expect that this will help to narrow the current-account deficit to 2.5% of GDP in 2023.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
In June 2018 Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected as president for a second term in snap presidential and parliamentary elections, in which his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a coalition majority with the right-wing Nationalist Action Party (MHP). Mr Erdogan and the AKP will remain in power throughout the forecast period (2019-23) and probably beyond.
Following the 2018 elections, an executive presidency has replaced the former parliamentary system of government. The new system provides few checks on the president's powers, raising the risk of discretionary policymaking.
Since the failed coup in July 2016 there has been a deterioration in Turkey's relations with its Western allies. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a rupture to be avoided, but tensions will remain high and relations could sour quickly.
Turkey's relationship with the US will continue to be tense. Points of contention include Turkey's perceived pivot towards Iran and Russia and, from Turkey's perspective, the lack of support from the US after the failed coup. A Turkish military intervention against Kurds in Syria would lead to a further deterioration in relations between the US and Turkey.
Turkey's relationship with the EU will remain transactional. Turkey will not make progress with accession talks and is unlikely to manage to renegotiate the terms of its customs union with the EU.
The government's focus on domestic power struggles, economic growth and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate.
We forecast a slowdown in real GDP growth, from 7.3% in 2017 to an average of about 3.6% per year in 2019-23, reflecting the impact of the August 2018 currency crisis, higher domestic and international interest rates, a persist-ently difficult business environment and global trade tensions.
The lira will depreciate in nominal terms against the US dollar during the forecast period, to about TL6.4:US$1 at end-2023, as a result of negative foreign investor sentiment, high inflation and the large current-account deficit.
As a result of the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar in 2018 (which will boost competitiveness), we forecast that the current-account deficit will shrink in 2019-23, to an annual average of about 3.9% of GDP. Turkey will struggle to meet its high external financing needs throughout the forecast period.

Turkey's score deteriorates only slightly in 2019-23, but in the global rankings the country falls by 11 places, to 59th. The failed coup in 2016 and the government's response have increased the level of uncertainty about the direction of economic policy. Shortcomings include a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Political instability and adverse market conditions will delay further privatisation deals.
2021-23: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in several sectors.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but macroeconomic instability and concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2021-23: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Capital controls are not considered, despite the scale of the currency collapse. Political tensions resulting in tit-for-tat tariffs and US sanctions will disrupt Turkish-US trade and relations.
2021-23: Negotiations with the EU to update the customs union are likely to be protracted, given poor Turkish-EU relations.
Taxes
2019-20: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Tax rises introduced in 2018 to curb the widening of the budget deficit reduce company profits.
2021-23: Income tax base becomes broader as exemptions and exceptions are reduced.
Financing
2019-20: Asset quality likely to deteriorate on the back of financial market turmoil in 2018. Central Bank of Turkey to lower rates gradually as inflation moderates in 2019. Risk of the US imposing fines or sanctions on some Turkish banks.
2021-23: Lending growth to pick up again as banking system regains strength. Continued reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2019-20: Relatively high labour costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment.
2021-23: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2019-20: First phase of third airport in Istanbul becomes operational. Slower progress made on other projects.
2021-23: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. Other major urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks might persist.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Spending on research and development remains moderate, at about 1% of GDP, holding back efforts to move the economy up the value-added ladder.
2021-23: Turkey's young population spurs further rapid digital transformation of the banking sector.
