Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West. The country became a member of the Council of Europe in 1949 and NATO in 1952, and signed an association agreement with the then European Community in 1963. A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but a coup attempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey currently has a presidential system of government, with parliament elected for a five-year term. To win seats, parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the AKP leader, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who was re-elected as president for a second term in June 2018. Following his re-election a presidential system of government was introduced and the post of prime minister was abolished.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability and stabilising the lira following the August 2018 currency crisis are Turkey's biggest policy challenges. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and tightening global liquidity conditions require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy tight to attract adequate capital inflows and slow the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar. The Kurdish issue, which has blocked economic development in the south east, is one of Turkey's most pressing policy challenges, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015, and there has been a resurgence in violence. Politicisation of the judiciary since the coup attempt has undermined its independence. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The corporation tax rate was raised from 20% to 22 in 2018. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Reducing tax evasion was one of the elements of previous IMF programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2018 goods exports totalled an estimated US$175bn and imports about US$216bn, creating an estimated trade deficit of about US$41.6bn and a current-account deficit in the region of US$27.6bn (or 3.6% of estimated GDP). The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
In June 2018 Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected for a second term in the first round of a snap presidential election. On the same day his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a parliamentary coalition majority with its right-wing ally, the Nationalist Action Party (MHP). The election process appeared mostly free, but largely unfair. Opposition candidates received little or no media coverage; the pro-Kurdish Peoples' Democratic Party (HDP) candidate, Selahattin Demirtas, had to campaign from prison; and the government restrained freedom of speech and freedom of association. Mr Erdogan secured a majority of the vote after a high turnout. Results published by opposition observers were similar to those announced by the government.
Mr Erdogan's re-election concluded Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. This move was initiated with a constitutional referendum in April 2017, which the government narrowly won. The new system grants the president wide-ranging executive powers-including the selection of most of the officials in the judiciary-and will greatly weaken parliament. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the AKP and Mr Erdogan, who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in July 2016, to remain in power until 2023, and probably beyond.
Mr Erdogan will continue to restrict political dissent and stifle the opposition. Despite allowing the state of emergency to expire on July 18th 2018, parliament passed a security law on July 25th that imposes stringent barriers on freedoms.
Security risk remains high, as Turkey appears vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and the Islamic State (IS). Neither the government nor the PKK is interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will return to 1990s levels. The fact that the ruling coalition is made up of the AKP and the MHP will hinder attempts to resolve the Kurdish issue, as the nationalist-minded MHP is pushing for hawkish policies aimed at constraining and delegitimising the HDP.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Parliamentary and presidential elections were held in June 2018 (they had originally been scheduled for late 2019). Mr Erdogan was re-elected as president in the first round, securing 52.6% of the vote with a turnout of 86.2%. In the parliamentary election the AKP lost its absolute majority (although it secured a coalition majority alongside its partner, the MHP), as the HDP managed to poll more than the 10% threshold needed to enter parliament.
Local elections are planned for the end of March this year. In order to raise levels of support for the AKP ahead of the elections, the government has implemented a number of expansionary fiscal measures. We continue to expect the AKP to emerge unscathed from the local elections, retaining control of the two largest cities-Istanbul and Ankara, the capital.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Domestic political and security issues will continue to shape Turkey's actions in the foreign-policy sphere. Although not our core forecast, there is a risk of a rupture in the country's ties with its traditional Western allies. Many factors have contributed to the deterioration in relations, including a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey after the failed coup; US military backing for PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurdish groups (although this may change in 2019); Turkey's forging of closer relations with China, Russia and Iran; tensions with Cyprus about the delimitation of the two countries' exclusive economic zones in the Mediterranean; and US sanctions on Turkish officials due to Turkey's detention of Andrew Brunson, a US pastor, on terrorism charges (sanctions were lifted after Mr Brunson was released in October 2018).
Turkey's relations with the EU and the US are likely to remain antagonistic and transactional rather than strategic. However, we expect Turkey and its Western allies to avoid a breakdown in relations, as Turkey and the EU have a common interest in handling refugee inflows from Syria and Iraq. However, EU-Turkey relations would deteriorate quickly if the EU was to suspend Turkey's moribund accession negotiations, or if Turkey re-imposed the death penalty, closed the Incirlik air base to NATO forces or withdrew from NATO (none of which are our core forecast).
Turkey's military operations in Syria seek to block the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds affiliated with the PKK, but risk fuelling the conflict with the PKK in south-east Turkey. In December 2018 the US announced that it would withdraw troops from Syria. For Turkey, the US withdrawal represents an invitation to press ahead with plans to extend its border zone within Syria eastwards. Turkey controls most of the territory across the border region from the Mediterranean to the Euphrates River. The country is also planning another military operation against Kurdish forces to the east of the Euphrates, although Mr Erdogan has delayed the offensive for fear of US retaliation. With a Turkish offensive in the pipeline, the Kurds are likely to step up negotiations with the Syrian regime on a political settlement in order to avoid a situation in which they could be surrounded by enemies and without US support.
Turkey is also preoccupied with the situation in Idlib, a rebel-held city in northern Syria. An agreement between Turkey, Russia and Iran in September 2018 forestalled a long-anticipated regime offensive against Idlib, which is controlled by Islamist rebel groups, the most powerful of which is Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS). The agreement centres on the creation of a buffer zone around Idlib, in which Turkish forces are deployed as monitors. Turkey has undertaken to integrate HTS with other opposition groups under Turkey's direct influence and to foster the creation of an autonomous local government; Russia has agreed to forestall any major offensive against the Idlib area, in which an estimated 3m people live. However, the situation on the ground remains highly precarious and could quickly embroil Turkey in yet another diplomatic struggle with its traditional western allies, which consider HTS a terror organisation, or Russia.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
The government's past focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. Nonetheless, Turkey's economy has shown resilience during previous bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing to its solid public finances, its well-capitalised banking sector, and its dynamic and diversified private sector.
The heavily pro-growth approach to economic policymaking that Mr Erdogan has espoused enthusiastically throughout the past decade will persist during our forecast period (2019-23) at the expense of inflation control and fiscal discipline. This approach will continue to have a significant effect on, for example, monetary policy, macroprudential regulation, public-private capital investments and social spending. Shortcomings such as cronyism and corruption, skills mismatches (a major factor behind the high unemployment rate), and tax evasion are unlikely to be addressed in 2019-23, as propping up economic growth-partly to avoid social unrest-will remain the priority.
In the case of a severe economic or banking crisis (not our core forecast), Turkey's options would remain limited, as Gulf Co-operation Council (GCC) countries appear unwilling to offer financial support. This is because Turkey is forging closer ties with Iran, a country with which Saudi Arabia has tensions. Turkey's ties with Saudi Arabia deteriorated (from an already low base) after Jamal Khashoggi, a Saudi journalist, was murdered in the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, Turkey's largest city, in October 2018. Furthermore, any potential IMF programme would include a level of foreign involvement that the government would be likely to view as unacceptable, and that would run counter to Mr Erdogan's nationalist, anti-Western rhetoric. There is little prospect of EU financial assistance, not least because there would be no support for this among EU member states. Only China appears able at present to offer a financial lifeline to Turkey. Such assistance could come as part of China's Belt and Road Initiative, which seeks to boost transport infrastructure between Asia and Europe to foster trade, as well as connectivity.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
The public finances have traditionally been one of the Turkish economy's most reassuring aspects. Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios reflect the positive impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past.
Despite several tax rises in 2018 and official promises of budgetary tightening, higher government spending on defence, security, infrastructure, public employ-ment and social benefits caused the deficit to widen in 2018-to an estimated 1.9% of GDP, from 1.5% in 2017.
In 2019-23 we expect a cautious approach to on-balance-sheet fiscal policy. This, alongside a recovering economy, will cause the deficit to narrow gradually, from a forecast 2.3% in 2019 to 1.6% of GDP in 2023.
We expect the central government debt/GDP ratio to have remained broadly stable, at an estimated 28.6% of GDP in 2018 (from 28.3% in 2017), despite economic turmoil following the August currency crisis and various government handouts ahead of the June 2018 elections. The ratio will decline slightly, to 25.8% by end-2023 as macroeconomic conditions normalise and the budget deficit shrinks.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
In September 2018 the Central Bank of Turkey's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) raised its main policy rate, the one-week repo (repurchase agreement) lending rate, to 24%, from 17.75% previously. The MPC's decision was a response to the lira's sharp depreciation against the US dollar in August, as well as to the record rise in annual consumer price inflation. The average cost of central bank funding is likely to be above the main policy rate, however. The bank retains the option of providing some of its funding for the banking system at its overnight lending rates, which are 1.5-3% higher than the one-week repo rate.
At its meeting on March 6th the MPC kept its one-week repo lending rate unchanged, at 24%. We expect the central bank to keep monetary policy tight in the first half of 2019. From mid-2019 to 2020 the central bank will gradually lower its policy rate in response to declining inflationary pressures and a normalisation of financial market conditions. In 2021-23 we believe that the central bank will continue to miss its inflation target of 5%. This reflects the government's continued pro-growth stance; it will put pressure on the central bank to keep nominal rates below what would credibly be required to lower inflation to the 5% target.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
Real GDP growth accelerated sharply in 2017, to 7.3% (from 3.3% in 2016), supported by government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit, improved export competitiveness and a pick-up in global demand. However, the surge in economic growth exacerbated internal and external imbalances. These imbalances-coupled with heightened policy unpredictability, foreign investors' concerns regarding the independence of the central bank, reliance on short-term capital inflows, a rising interest rate environment in advanced economies and a diplomatic spat with the US-contributed to the lira losing about 40% of its value against the US dollar in January-August 2018. The sharp depreciation of the lira caused consumer price inflation to accelerate from already high rates, increased input costs for corporations and raised the debt-servicing costs of foreign-currency-denominated liabilities. Higher domestic interest rates and rising risk premiums further dent the economic outlook.
High-frequency indicators for December 2018 (latest available data) suggest that the economy stalled in the wake of the currency crisis. After quarterly growth of 0.3% in the second quarter of 2018, GDP contracted by 1.6% in the third quarter. We expect negative quarterly growth readings in the last quarter of 2018 and the first quarter of 2019, with activity starting to pick up in the second quarter of 2019. As a result, we believe that growth decelerated to 3.1% in 2018 and that GDP will grow only slightly in 2019, by 1.1% (mainly owing to base effects).
In 2020 we expect growth to rebound to 5% as the economy recovers and spare capacity is depleted. In 2021-23 economic growth will average about 3.9% per year, in line with the economy's forecast potential growth rate. There are substantial downside risks to our forecasts; these growth profiles do not reflect the possible impact of a severe banking crisis (not our core scenario), although we expect non-performing loans to rise and credit availability to be impaired in the coming quarters.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
In full-year 2018 the currency crisis and rising global commodity prices drove inflation higher, to 16.3% (from 11.1% in 2017). In 2019 inflation will remain elevated in the first half of the year and then moderate gradually on the back of a limited depreciation of the lira (against the US dollar), a decline in global oil prices and the emergence of spare capacity in the economy. Accommodative fiscal policies in response to the economic weakness in the final months of 2018 will prevent inflation from declining faster than would otherwise be the case. On average, we forecast inflation of 15.5% in 2019-only marginally lower than the 2018 rate.
The moderating trend in inflation will continue in 2020, with an average inflation rate of 9.1% as global oil prices continue to decline (owing to a slowdown in the global economy, with the US entering a technical recession) and the exchange rate depreciates slightly (in nominal terms) against the US dollar. In 2021-23 we expect inflation to stabilise at an annual average of about 7.2%-still more than the central bank's medium-term target of 5%. Economic growth in these years will be close to the economy's potential growth rate (limiting upward inflationary pressures).
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
In 2018 the lira depreciated by 24.5% on average against the US dollar (in nominal terms). The lira depreciated significantly in January-August, with the exchange rate briefly reaching a low point of TL7.2:US$1 on August 13th. After a substantial recovery from September, the lira remained broadly stable against the US dollar for the remainder of the year. This was owing to the decrease in tensions between the US and Turkey, the sharp reduction in the current-account deficit (a direct result of the currency depreciation) and the tight monetary policy stance of the central bank.
We forecast that the lira will continue to depreciate in the coming quarters against the dollar, albeit at a much more moderate pace than in 2018. A normalising domestic economic situation will support the exchange rate. However, there will be an increase in global risk aversion as the effects of the US-China bilateral trade war are fully felt and the cooling of the global economy causes expectations of a recession in some advanced economies to build. Consequently, we expect an average exchange rate of TL5.7:US$1 in 2019.
In 2020 we expect the exchange rate to remain broadly stable as the economy starts to grow more markedly and as global risk aversion does not increase further. A widening current-account deficit will keep downward pressures on the value of the currency. Thereafter still elevated inflation and a significant current-account deficit (although not as large as that in 2017) will result in a gradual depreciation of the lira against the US dollar in nominal terms, to TL6.4:US$1 by the end of 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The current-account deficit as a share of GDP narrowed in 2018, to an estimated 3.6%, from 5.6% in 2017, as the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar depressed imports (owing to a deceleration in domestic demand) and boosted export competitiveness.
In 2019-23 we expect an average annual current-account deficit of 3.9% of GDP. The slightly higher deficit reflects an increase in economic growth momentum in these years. However, the deficit remains contained (by historical standards) owing to significant gains in competitiveness from the 2018 currency crisis that will boost exports and limit import growth throughout the medium term.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The head of the ruling regime, Nicolás Maduro, and his party, the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), are under intense political and economic pressure. Under The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast, we expect regime pragmatists to oust Mr Maduro and form a government with Juan Guaidó, the opposition leader who has declared himself interim president and who is openly offering regime pragmatists a series of benefits (amnesty, international financing, a transitional government, lifting of sanctions) that Mr Maduro can no longer credibly promise. There is a risk that the existing regime will retain cohesion and cling to power beyond 2019 if it finds financing to meet its debt obligations and boost dwindling oil production.
Following years-long economic collapse, GDP will continue to contract in 2019-20. High inflation has led to a collapse in private consumption, and difficult operating conditions have hurt investment. Following a change in policy under a new government, we expect economic growth to resume in 2021.
The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. Following our forecast transition this year, a new government will stabilise the economy, but the wholesale rethink of the institutional framework needed to restore investment and confidence is unlikely.
The recession that began in 2014 has evolved into a hyperinflationary crisis and will continue to deepen in the short term. The economy will not return to growth until 2021-assuming that a new government takes power and implements reforms. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, reinforcing our forecasts of only a weak recovery.
US dollar measurements of Venezuela's market size provide an overly positive picture of the economy, given the marked overvaluation of the fixed exchange rate. In reality, recession and extremely high inflation (driven by shortages of foreign exchange and basic goods) will continue to restrict purchasing power. After 2020, under a new government, we expect purchasing power and the business environment to improve.

Venezuela is in 82nd position globally in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings for 2019-23, the worst position in our ranking. This reflects the highly heterodox macroeconomic policies of an authoritarian government, a lack of legal security and weak institutions.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Start of rollback of interventionist measures like price controls, but political-instability concerns slow liberalisation. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and undermine free competition.
2021-23: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Regulation by new government protecting property rights introduced in an attempt at attracting investment.
2021-23: Despite efforts, actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2019-20: Currency controls are made less opaque but restrictions on the private sector's access to foreign currency remain in place.
2021-23: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2019-20: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2021-23: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2019-20: Inflation remains high and concerns about economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2021-23: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2019-20: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. The current freeze on redundancies is fazed-out
2021-23: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Underinvestment in the water network and electricity grid ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2021-23: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued water and electricity rationing.
Technological readiness
2019-20: E-government services remain almost non-existent and deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment.
2021-23: Limited regulator capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has plummeted as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices has plunged the country into a massive economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded republican institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and side-lining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy mired in a years-long economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyper-inflation. At the same time, mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign-exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Using IMF data, The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$21.1bn in 2017 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages. We estimate the current-account surplus at 2.3% of GDP that year.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
The civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), is under huge economic and political pressure. The Economist Intelligence Unit continues to expect that a national unity government composed of opposition and regime "pragmatists" will form a transitional administration later in in 2019. The transition process, however, remains extremely uncertain, and we expect the entire forecast period (2019-23) to be characterised by political instability.
On January 23rd the president of the opposition-controlled National Assembly, Juan Guaidó, declared himself interim president, days after Mr Maduro started a controversial new term, and was swiftly recognised by most Western nations as the legitimate president of Venezuela. Although Mr Guaidó's recent attempts at bringing humanitarian aid into the country largely failed, he has nonetheless re-energised a disillusioned population, allowing him to convoke massive demonstrations, sowing concerns among regime members of country-wide unrest at a time when dissatisfaction within the military's lower ranks is at an all-time high. More crucially, Mr Guaidó secured US sanctions on oil trade conducted by PDVSA, the state-owned oil company. Prior to this the US was the destination of around 40% of Venezuelan exports, PDVSA's largest cash-paying client, and a key source of production inputs. All of this translates to a severe blow to the patronage flows underpinning the regime's internal stability.
Mr Guaidó is presenting his leadership as a path out of the current political and economic quagmire for dissatisfied regime members. He has repeatedly called for the military to depose Mr Maduro, offering the lifting of oil sanctions, the arrival of international aid and financing, and amnesty for defectors. Overall, considering that the regime's raison d'etre is the enrichment of its members, which Mr Maduro can no longer guarantee, we expect that pragmatists within the regime will eventually side-line or expel "hardliners" in exchange for influence in Mr Guaidó's more prosperous government.
Although a Guaidó-led transition government is our baseline forecast, questions remain. At present it is unclear how much power the opposition would have in a power-sharing transitional government. Once in place, such an administration would face considerable hurdles. If the opposition cannot deliver on its promises quickly enough, the government could well collapse. Even if short-term stability is secured, political stability will remain at risk, given the challenging tasks ahead. These include securing debt relief; rebuilding the rule of law; and attracting tens of billions of dollars in foreign investment (not only in oil but in all sectors of the economy). Through all this, the opposition would need to be careful to not upset its partners. Most of the opposition's economic rationalisation plans require reforms that eliminate the economy's distortions, closing the avenues for corruption and enrichment that regime members have used for years.
Three key assumptions underpin our baseline view. Firstly, and foremost, that regime pragmatists have enough power to overpower hardliners who would rather rule a ruined country than share a prosperous one. Years of economic malaise and failed dialogues have been insufficient to prompt regime change in itself, and, as showcased when it blocked the entry of humanitarian aid on February 23rd, the military-a key powerbroker-remains behind Mr Maduro despite repeated rumours to the contrary. Secondly, that regime members deem Mr Guaidó's amnesty and transitional government offers credible. Risks to this assumption include a deep-seated distrust of the opposition and fear of being prosecuted outside of Venezuela (a credible fear given accusations of drug- and weapon-trafficking levied at regime members). The third assumption underpinning our forecast for a unity government is a continued lack of hard-currency to sustain the patronage system. The main risk to this assumption comes from the possibility that Russia or China, erstwhile financiers, would bail out the regime. This is not our baseline forecast, but Venezuela's oil wealth remains a draw-especially if sold off at low prices by a bankrupt regime. Another risk to our assumptions around the regime's access to hard currency centres on transnational crime and the informal export of precious metals, and whether these enterprises could be enough to make up the lost revenue from oil exports.
Given the strong risks to our baseline view, there are several alternate scenarios for Venezuela's political environment, with varying probabilities. Our main alternate scenarios are (in order of likelihood): although Mr Maduro's days seem numbered, a continuation of the PSUV's authoritarian rule could continue with more political repression, emigration, economic isolation and support from the likes of China; a complete collapse of the regime followed by a transitional government that does not include current regime members (decisive US military intervention would increase this scenario's chances); or prolonged chaos-including, possibly, armed conflict-if divisions within the regime become clearer but no faction gains outright control of the state apparatus across the country. All of these outcomes, like our baseline forecast, would be characterised by extremely high levels of political instability.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
The opposition's recently announced plans for a transitional government call for the renovation of all electoral authorities and for elections within 12 months of the transitional government's formation. As we currently expect such a government to coalesce within 2019, we expect elections at some point in 2020. International assistance in organising the elections would be necessary and forthcoming.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Mr Guaidó has marshalled hitherto unexpected levels of support from the international community. Most governments in the Americas, under the banner of the Lima Group, have recognised Mr Guaidó. A similar stance, but stressing the need for immediate elections, has been adopted by most of Europe. The US is Mr Guaidó's most committed champion, instituting crippling oil sanctions and openly calling for the military to accept Mr Guaidó in place of Mr Maduro. We had expected US sanctions on oil to be progressive, but instead, the hawkish US policy team instituted full sanctions directly. This introduces risks of a military intervention. We currently do not foresee large-scale military action, in part because such an initiative currently lacks international legitimacy. However, the US administration has sunk considerable political capital into Mr Guaidó and smaller-scale interventions, such as targeted bombings, have become a possibility, especially given that the US no longer has substantial economic sanctions to throw at the regime, although such action is not included in our baseline forecasts.
Russia and China seem unwilling to provide the necessary financing-amounting to tens of billions of dollars per year-to stabilise the economy and PDVSA. Mr Maduro has openly courted the two countries, but with little apparent success in actual investment. Neither country seems willing to antagonise the US too much, as they are both at sensitive points in their relations with the US. Russia is dealing with sanctions, while China is involved in difficult trade negotiations. Instead, we believe that both Russia and China will be willing to work with a successor government in an attempt at protecting their current investments in Venezuela.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Our expectation of a change of government later in 2019 implies huge changes to policymaking as a new administration works to end hyperinflation, restructure public debt, and rebuild institutions to restore confidence and promote investment. Until then, we foresee no fundamental change in policy by the Maduro regime, which remains technically unable and politically unwilling to undertake the deep and wide-ranging policy and institutional changes needed. Monetisation of large public deficits, coupled with mismanagement of the state-dominated oil industry, has led to hyperinflation and shortages of foreign currency, basic goods and industrial inputs. The regime's latest plan to tackle these issues, launched in late August, was self-defeating, and the government has not curbed the monetisation of public deficits. As such, imbalances will persist and foreign exchange will continue to be rationed.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect that more orthodox economic policies will be implemented under the transition and successor governments. However, the pace and depth of the adjustment will be constrained by uncertainty over the stability of any new administration, and whether this takes precedence over the likely demands for reform from multilateral and bilateral lenders. Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and multilaterals (totalling US$19bn in 2019-22) and the restructuring of the government's debt obligations. This in itself will be a huge task for any administration. At the same time, PDVSA will need wholesale reform to open itself to the foreign finance needed to increase output, a process that will require considerable political capital.
Pockets of resistance are likely to exist. Internal stability within the PSUV is a major risk to our forecast, as the success of any government will depend on PSUV pragmatists fending off more radical party members. These hardliners would oppose international assistance, foreign investment and policy reforms on both ideological and personal grounds (as many regime insiders profit from the state's indirect and direct control of the economy).
Outside of these areas, we do not expect much success in rolling back the PSUV's strong interventionist bent in the economy. Thus, we expect limited real investment inflows, the vast majority going into the oil sector, which will restrict economic recovery and fuel continued unrest.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
Authorities have not published complete official data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We estimate that the fiscal deficit is well into double figures as a percentage of GDP. The government relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency.
High inflation and the overvalued official exchange rate make debt/GDP ratios misleading indicators of fiscal stability. Considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) understates the true size of total public liabilities. Most sovereign and state-owned bonds (including PDVSA's) are in arrears. Bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy changes or a change in government. The exceptions to arrears are debts that threaten Citgo (PDVSA's US subsidiary) and leased facilities in the Caribbean. So far, Venezuela has taken a defensive stance, treating each claim individually and stalling as much as possible before complying when seizures seem imminent. Given PDVSA's extremely strained financial situation and the lack of further sources of financing, the strategy does not seem sustainable.
In this uncertain context, Citgo is in limbo. Following the January 28th sanctions, the US government considers Citgo to be under Mr Guaidó's purview, but it is unclear how much power Mr Guaidó will have over the company. The regime now has little incentive to defend Citgo from creditors, and it is also it is unclear if creditors could even claim it. PDVSA's strained financial situation means that the risk of default and seizure on Citgo, its Caribbean facilities and even shipments will remain high in the short term. Stalling tactics (including partial compliance with payments) will continue.
Under our baseline forecast, we expect a restructuring with external creditors in 2020. Owing to the need to maintain political stability, we do not expect the closure of the various handout programmes in operation, nor the complete removal of utility subsidies or the reformation of inefficient state-owned firms. Therefore, we expect public expenditure to be hard to reduce; the deficit will be substantial throughout the 2019-23 period.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The government's financing needs will continue to force the Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank) to print money. Money supply (M2) continues to grow rapidly, expanding by 75% month on month at end-January. We expect a new administration to place a much greater emphasis on tackling hyper-inflation and expect a substantial monetary adjustment in the context of a macroeconomic stabilisation plan. The introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) in such a context is highly likely.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 15% in 2018, we expect further contractions in 2019-20. A forecast recovery in 2021-23 rests on the assumption of a political transition that, supported by international assistance, produces a credible macroeconomic programme with improved management of oil wealth. However, reform will be limited in scope by a weak government, and we expect only a partial rebound in real GDP, following a decline of around 50% in 2013-20.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2019, reflecting the effect on real wages of hyperinflation, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will also contract, reflecting difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange. Our forecast for a recovery in investment later in the forecast period assumes a political transition and a pick-up in oil investment.
We expect oil output to bottom out at 950,000 barrels/day (b/d) in mid-2019, kept from going lower by PDVSA's joint-venture partners. But until US sanctions on oil are lifted, margins will be smaller, as PDVSA has lost access to its closest and better-paying market. Under our baseline forecast of openness to foreign investment under a new government from 2019, production will start to recover in 2020 but will end the forecast period (2023) well below 2m b/d, the average output in 2017.
Export volumes will only start to recover in 2020, as an increase in domestic demand, which has been artificially constrained, will initially absorb the increase in oil output. For the same reason, import demand will rise sharply in 2019.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Decimated domestic supply, severe limits on imports and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official data have not been published since 2015, but the opposition-led National Assembly estimated that monthly inflation was 142% in December. In the context of a macroeconomic stabilisation plan later in 2019, we expect much tighter monetary policy and lower inflation. However, supply bottlenecks and bouts of inflationary pressure are likely.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
Under our current baseline forecast of a political transition later in 2019, the introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) amid deep imbalances and as a means to try to tackle hyperinflation is highly likely. The exact nature and implementation of such moves are hard to foresee, but our baseline forecast includes the continuation of some currency controls for the duration of the forecast period.
Since the start of 2018, the government has repeatedly devalued the currency and promised liberalisation of exchange controls. The official rate is determined by an auction process, but the government-which monopolises the country's exports-does not supply the system with foreign exchange, making the system unsustainable and access to foreign exchange practically impossible. In early March, following a string of devaluations in January, the official rate stood at BsS3,300:US$1 to the black-market rate of over BsS3,700:US$1.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
We expect a current-account surplus of US$526m in 2019. The surplus is buoyed by non-payment of interest on bonded debt ("savings" in excess of US$5bn in 2019 alone). Our export data, which are based on IMF data, may overstate receipts, as some exports are actually payments in-kind for loans, the repayment of which may not be included in their totality under forecast interest repayments (we have excluded repayments to Chinese lenders to maintain consistency with the World Bank's data on which our debt forecasts are based).
By 2020, with a new government in power, we expect that-following debt renegotiation-external financing will be restored. Although we expect exports to grow as oil production increases, we also expect a surge in imports, as Venezuela's own productive base has been decimated and imports have been compressed to artificially low levels. In addition, the government will be complying with its debt obligations, meaning that the restructured debt will actually result in increased outflows in interest payments. These factors will erode the current-account surplus to a deficit of 2.3% of GDP in 2023.
We currently expect that a new administration will secure enough finance to stabilise the balance-of-payments dynamics. However, there are considerable risks to this rosy outlook. In addition to assuming the installation of a pragmatic transition administration capable of retaining power, it hinges on substantial finance from the IMF, the quick implementation of a successful macroeconomic stabilisation package, the fast resolution of a debt renegotiation process in 2019-20, substantial inflows of financial and real investment into the economy in 2020-23, and a fast recovery in oil output after years of underinvestment and mismanagement.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
BCV: Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Muhammadu Buhari won a second and final four-year presidential term on February 23rd. The policy agenda he campaigned on did not involve considerable reform, only cosmetic improvements to the business environment.
The administration will struggle to tackle high levels of poverty and the country's ethnic and religious divisions. This will create a potent mixture that will lead to frequent violent instability and directly affect key economic sectors.
Policy will be interventionist. Import bans on agricultural and manufacturing goods will be widened to support local industry and farmers, and the Central Bank of Nigeria will maintain an overvalued official naira rate with which to channel cheap US dollars to preferred buyers.
Even though a multiple exchange-rate system will persist, non-official rates will converge and so in reality Nigeria will run a dual exchange-rate regime. As oil prices fall in 2019-20, adjustments to the official rate will have to be made to safeguard foreign-exchange reserves.
Fiscal expenditure will remain dominated by recurrent spending, despite attempts to boost capital investment. Efforts to boost non-oil tax revenue will be constrained by weak bureaucratic capacity and low economic growth.
Constrained by a crippling infrastructure deficit, as well as tight monetary conditions and instability in key agricultural regions, economic growth will be well below levels needed to boost job creation and increase living standards. This will perpetuate instability in a vicious cycle.
Inflation will remain high over the forecast period (2019-23) amid expansionary fiscal policy and high food prices stemming from government efforts to limit imports and support local producers. This in turn will keep credit conditions tight; even with some relaxation of the policy rate (currently at 14%) from 2021, inflation will be running too high for sustained monetary loosening, and credit growth will generally be slow.
The multiple exchange-rate regime will not be dismantled under a Buhari administration; the arrangement is critical for making petrol subsidies affordable and underpins the government's interventionist approach to industrialisation.
Oil prices and exports will fall in 2019-20 but so will imports. Both imports and exports will then expand in 2021-23 but a current account surplus will be maintained throughout the forecast period.

Nigeria's business environment score will improve slightly but its global and regional rankings will worsen as the administration struggles with the reform process and other countries make more significant improvements.
Country forecast overview: Nigeria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Progress on market-oriented reforms remains slow, given various vested interests and inefficiencies. The upstream oil sector will remain characterised by joint-ventures between the state oil company and multinationals.
2021-23: Improving prospects for the non-oil private sector remains a priority, but progress will be slow.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Confusion over oil sector reform creates ongoing uncertainty for investors. The government favours local companies in oil sector deals.
2021-23: Clearer policy lines help to stem the trend of lower investment in the oil and gas sectors, but mistrust between the numerous stakeholders prevents any major upturn in foreign direct investment.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Import bans are widened, but as oil prices decline, the naira weakens anyway as foreign-exchange inflows lessen.
2021-23: A premium between the official and the black-market exchange rates persists.
Taxes
2019-20: Focus intensifies on boosting tax compliance, especially given weak prospects for oil revenue. Retroactive measures become a possibility, although the business community would fight these.
2021-23: Tax rates for the oil and gas sector increase under new legislation. Efforts to increase value-added tax (VAT) and to move more of the informal economy into the formal sector mean non-oil collection also improves.
Financing
2019-20: Funding for well-planned projects becomes easier to raise domestically once the 2019 elections are concluded, as local capital markets deepen (with greater foreign participation) and the banking sector develops.
2021-23: Credit conditions become easier for businesses as the current-account surplus boosts national savings and investment.
The labour market
2019-20: Employers face major problems, including a shortage of skilled manual workers, restrictive visa regulations and poor health indicators.
2021-23: Employers continue to struggle to find suitably qualified staff.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Government spending on the priority area of infrastructure hits capacity constraints. Although there should be growth in private-sector investment, the government struggles to create an encouraging environment.
2021-23: Expenditure on infrastructure increases, but white elephant projects hold back the productivity of investment.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Nigeria continues to have a vibrant technology sector for an economy at its stage of development, but infrastructure is weak outside urban hubs.
2021-23: Research spending is likely to remain low compared with global averages, but some home-grown technology firms looking to adapt global technology trends to the Nigerian market continue to do well.

Background: Nigeria gained independence in 1960 and the army soon became the dominant political player. Multiparty democracy was restored in 1999. That presidential poll and the next one, in 2003, were both won by a former military ruler turned civilian politician, Olusegun Obasanjo. Mr Obasanjo was unable to change the constitution to allow him to serve a third term in office, so in the 2007 election power passed to his handpicked successor, Umaru Yar'Adua. After Mr Yar'Adua's death in May 2010, his vice-president, Goodluck Jonathan, assumed the presidency and went on to win the 2011 presidential election. Mr Jonathan was defeated by Muhammadu Buhari in the 2015 presidential election and in 2019 Mr Buhari went on to win another term, with a clear lead over his main rival, Atiku Abubakar.
Political structure: Under the constitution adopted in May 1999, a strong executive presidency appoints a Federal Executive Council, comprising government ministers and ministers of state from each of Nigeria's 36 states. The executive is accountable to the bicameral National Assembly. Political parties tend to lack clear ideologies; in practice, personal and ethnic ties dominate the political process. The People's Democratic Party (Mr Jonathan's party) had historically been the only political party to attract nationwide support, but the merger in 2013 of three large opposition parties to form the All Progressives Congress gave them, with Mr Buhari at the helm, the reach that they needed to take power in 2015. Although the 36 state governments enjoy significant autonomy, almost all remain dependent on the federal government for funding.
Policy issues: Successive governments have sought to improve macroeconomic stability and develop the nation's dire infrastructure, with mixed results. Meanwhile, the government is struggling to end insecurity in various parts of the country. These tensions are stoked by the underlying problems of poverty and unemployment. Management of the naira by the authorities is contentious, and currency liberalisation will be postponed whenever foreign-exchange supplies permit.
Taxation: Corporate profits in most non-oil sectors are taxed at 30%. Planned changes to the tax system for the oil and gas sector have been repeatedly delayed, creating uncertainty. Most other taxes are low, reflecting the fact that most revenue comes from the oil sector, with the total tax take very small as a share of GDP. Tax compliance is a time-consuming process.
Foreign trade: Exports are dominated by oil. The slump in oil prices from the second half of 2014 almost wiped out what had historically been a large current-account surplus, although it has partly recovered since. The non-oil export base has been rendered globally uncompetitive by an overvalued exchange rate and massive infrastructure deficiencies.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
An election on February 23rd resulted in a comfortable margin of victory for Muhammadu Buhari, who was running for a second term as president. However, the vote was tarnished by low turnout nationwide. To some extent this can be explained by a week-long, last-minute delay to the polling date, leading to a low turnout (which dropped to only 18% in one state) in the south of the country. This affirms a strong sense of apathy in that part of Nigeria and a clear disconnect from national politics.
Given that the economically-vital southern regions have a history of separatist sentiment and militancy, the disconnect between the population there and mainstream Nigerian politics bodes poorly for stability. There are added reasons to expect unrest in the south in particular. An Islamist militant group, Boko Haram, is resurgent in the north and north-east, and is utilising new tactics and more sophisticated hardware. Mr Buhari's "zero-tolerance" approach to the group was a major reason for strong turnout and support for him in the affected regions, and as was the case in his last tenure, substantial federal resources are likely to be channelled towards keeping Boko Haram at bay. However, militants in the oil-producing south cite the use of fiscal resources for far-flung causes such as combating Boko Haram-rather than for local development-as justification for launching attacks. It is a dilemma that cannot be resolved without reforming the distribution of federal hydrocarbons revenue and possibly the entire oil sector, but Mr Buhari is not an advocate of doing either. So it seems likely that attacks by aggrieved militants on oil infrastructure will continue to be a major security problem, albeit isolated to the south.
Boko Haram will probably be aggressively countered, but in the process the north-east of Nigeria will essentially be made a low-level conflict zone. Just to the south of this region, in the Middle Belt of Nigeria, a more insoluble challenge will be addressing extremely violent clashes between settled farmers and nomads competing for increasingly scarce water and land resources. There will also be an ethno-religious aspect to this conflict, with the majority of farmers being Christian, from a variety of small minority groups and the herders predominantly being Muslim and Fulani. Formal land titling is a potential answer, but as it would in effect alienate one group from communal holdings in favour of another, it would prove too contentious. Ultimately there is no foreseeable end to the violence. Moreover, in Mr Buhari's first term, it was clear that military engagements in other parts of Nigeria have priority when it comes to deploying the army's thinly spread resources, and the same is likely to be true in his second-leaving the conflict to intensify. Again, the direct security impact will be localised, with little spillover into the administrative capital, Abuja, or the economic capital, Lagos, so overall stability will not be compromised. The entire country will feel the secondary effects, however, in the form of constricted food supply and high consumer prices.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Nigeria's national elections took place on February 23rd, and were marred by violence, delays and voter apathy, but Mr Buhari of the ruling All Progressives Congress (APC) secured 56% of the vote. Participation across the country at 35% was well down on the 44% turnout rate in 2015, partly reflecting a delay to the poll but also disengagement with the two main candidates, both of whom represented an elite that has dominated politics for decades. Mr Buhari's sweeping victory can, nonetheless, be attributed to his clean reputation; his main rival, Atiku Abubakar of the opposition, People's Democratic Party (PDP), has in the past battled with serious (unproven) corruption allegations. Mr Buhari's triumph also hinged on particularly low turnout in the south-a traditional PDP stronghold-with voters there evidently feeling alienated by the two main candidates (who are both northern). Mr Abubakar wants to contest the result in court, but the margin of victory for Mr Buhari is too wide for there to be any credible chance of him overturning it. Although international observers reported shortcomings in the management of the election, it was not deemed to be systemically unfair. Results from the legislative election are still to be released, but early signs are for an APC majority in both houses.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Many of Nigeria's militant groups operate across land and sea borders, and international co-operation will therefore be needed to tackle the threat they pose. Stretched resources, vast territories and porous borders will prevent complete military victories. Relations with the US will be mixed; the administration of Donald Trump is willing to sell Nigeria military hardware, but Mr Trump's disapproval of the trade deficit the US runs with Nigeria (particularly owing to Nigerian trade barriers on agricultural imports) could strain relations. Ties with the EU will be largely cordial but subject to tensions over the large numbers of Nigerian migrants seeking to enter Europe and Nigerian efforts to repatriate funds in European banks that were allegedly looted by former rulers.
India will remain important as the largest market for Nigerian oil and become a bigger source of foreign investment. China will also remain a significant source of investment, but actual inflows will total only a small proportion of the headline-grabbing pledges made, given an extremely challenging local business environment. Nigeria will remain an important player on the Sub-Saharan African stage given its size, but its domestic challenges tend to keep policymakers inwardly focused. Relations with South Africa will be cordial, but Africa's two largest economies will continue to compete for political, economic and cultural influence.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Economic policy during Mr Buhari's second term is likely to carry over the interventionist policies adopted during his first. Measures to liberalise and unify foreign-exchange markets or move to more market-led pricing in the energy sector will not be a priority and not become formal policy. An overvalued official naira rate is critical for maintaining petrol subsidies, and Mr Buhari will not willingly attempt to dismantle consumer price caps and risk a popular backlash. Although in practice very little foreign exchange is traded at the official rate, the existence of a multiple-exchange-rate system will be off-putting to investors fearing a return of capital controls. Elsewhere, efforts will be made to cleanse and reboot inefficient state owned industries such as the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC)-which dominates all segments of the oil sector-but again no structural reforms (such as full or partial privatisation) will take place. Generally, Mr Buhari's approach will be to make existing entities such as the NNPC become profitable rather than relinquish state control over them entirely. This, however, leaves open questions around fiscal terms and revenue management in the oil sector. Multinationals, the NNPC's powerful union and local politicians (not to mention various militant groups) will all pull in different directions. In practice there will be few improvements in the NNPC's performance, with politicians and other members of the political elite working to direct the flow of resources to favour specific geo-ethnic and political constituencies (as well as for illicit personal gain).
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
We expect small fiscal deficits throughout the forecast period. The government wants to diversify its revenue base away from oil, and non-oil revenue will rise through efforts to widen tax coverage and collect overdue taxes, but from an extremely low base. Petrol subsidies (whereby losses from below-cost prices are taken by the NNPC's distribution arm) and instability in many parts of the country will also be an impediment to revenue collection. More importantly, oil production targets budgeted for by the government are repeatedly overambitious; for example in 2019 the government expects output of 2.3m barrels/day (b/d)-a level not seen for well over a decade, and one that will be unobtainable given underinvestment and antiquated oil infrastructure. Despite a new offshore oilfield coming onstream, total production stood at 1.6m b/d in January. Total revenue is not expected to rise above 3.4% of GDP, a ratio only attained in 2023 when oil prices are at their highest within the forecast period.
After some projected expansion in 2018, spending will decline as a proportion of GDP in 2019 with deep cuts to the capital budget. Partly offsetting this will be a rise in populist recurrent spending on wages and public-sector benefits. Generally, flexibility on spending will be restricted by high levels of debt-servicing and pressing security needs. But with oil prices-and so revenue-under pressure and there being considerable political pressure to curb the fiscal deficit, we expect the spending/GDP ratio to dip again in 2020 and only begin to increase materially as elections in 2023 approach. Altogether, we expect an average budget deficit equal to 2.2% of GDP over 2019-23.
Long-term public debt sustainability will remain in doubt. Central government debt is low as a proportion of GDP compared with other emerging markets, but it is set against a low revenue base. Debt service already takes up close to one-third of federal government income, and yields on government securities are increasing as global monetary conditions tighten and foreign investors repatriate capital. A federal government default is unlikely, but repayment difficulties are possible at state level, where revenue collection is even weaker.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
Monetary policy will concentrate on fostering an economic recovery while limiting inflation and maintaining currency stability. However, this will generate contradictory pressures in the early part of the forecast period. The private sector is desperate for cheaper credit, but inflation will remain above the targeted upper limit of 9% set by the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN). On balance, we expect interest rates not to move much in 2019-20. Rates will then fall in 2021 and stabilise over 2022-23 as economic activity picks up and inflation hovers above or around target. However, real interest rates will be too high to support private-sector activity outside of highly profitable ventures.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
The economy will for the most part be mired in a low-growth cycle, although there will be improvements over time. Tight monetary conditions and limited private investment aggravated by cuts to public capital spending in the national budget presage a year of slow growth in 2019, while falling annual average world oil prices and a weakening naira will hold back consumer and business confidence. We forecast growth of 1.9%; this is the lowest annual rate of growth in our five-year outlook period. Growth will increase in 2020 as election-related uncertainty passes, but only moderately-as an expected slowdown in the world economy holds back export-oriented sectors. In 2021-23, as global markets strengthen and external demand picks up, the rate of growth will quicken, although remain well below potential at an annual average of 3.3%.
From a sectoral viewpoint, agriculture will record only lacklustre growth; although boosting food production is a key government objective, weak infrastructure and violent competition for access to land in the fertile Middle Belt will be severe impediments. Industrial production will be curtailed by militancy and labour agitation in the oil sector, and falling oil prices in 2019-20 will hold back investment in infrastructure upgrades. Egina, a new offshore oilfield, will be a key driver of output growth, but hydrocarbons production is not expected to return to levels prior to the 2015 commodity-price crash. That said, a private refinery coming on stream by 2021 will be a boost to downstream oil activity in the latter years of the forecast period. The manufacturing sector will continue to struggle in the face of cheap goods from abroad, which are often smuggled into the country to bypass import bans. The services sector is less affected by instability and so will be a stronger contributor to growth than industry, but it will nonetheless be held back by trade protectionism (which will increase), tight credit conditions (particularly affecting areas such as real estate and finance), and the struggle in the communications sector to profitably roll out data services beyond urban hubs.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
From a rate of 12.1% in 2018, average inflation will increase to 14% in 2019, as the naira enters a period of managed depreciation and pre-election giveaways (including an increase in the minimum wage) add to upward price pressures. Inflation will remain elevated at 13.5% in 2020 on the back of further currency weakening. Thereafter, as the currency stabilises, inflation will steadily ease over the rest of the forecast period to an average of 8.8% in 2023. Preventing a faster slide will be protectionist measures that limit relatively cheap imports from abroad, particularly of food. These bans are set to widen.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
We expect the multiple-exchange-rate system to persist throughout 2019-23, with an official rate used for government business and a market-determined rate applicable to investors and exporters, which will be broadly in line with retail rates and the parallel market. Such a system allows the government to subsidise sectors deemed important for economic or political reasons, including petroleum imports. For this reason the set-up is not expected to be tampered with. Oil prices, and with them the level of hard-currency earnings, will in large part dictate where the authorities are able to hold the official rate and what the premium is between the official and the market rates. In 2019 lower oil prices, reduced hard-currency inflows around the election and the cumulative impact of real appreciation over recent years will cause the official rate to drop from N306.5:US$1 at end-2018 to N325.9:US$1 at end-2019. With oil prices forecast to decline again in 2020 we expect a further fall in the value of the naira, to N362.2:US$1 at end-2020. This is almost aligned with the current market-determined Nafex rate, although some spread is still expected as the Nafex rate also depreciates. As oil prices pick up on average over the rest of the forecast period and import pressures are eased by improved domestic refining capacity, we broadly expect the naira to stabilise, with an average rate of N365:US$1 in 2023.
Forecasting the naira
Although The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts both the official and the secondary market rates, it is the official rate that appears in most of our data presentations, as it is the longest-running and best-tracked variable. For example, the current market-determined rate, known as the Nigerian Autonomous Foreign Exchange Rate Fixing (Nafex), has only been in full operation since April 2017, making historical calculations challenging. However, indicators that are converted into US dollars at the official rate are essentially overvalued.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The export profile will move in tandem with oil production trends and world crude prices. In 2019-20 our expectation for limited output gains will be outweighed by a drop in world crude prices. Only in 2021-23 when prices recover and Nigeria begins to export refined oil (a new mega-refinery being developed is expected to be export-oriented) will there be any growth in earnings, although it will be fairly sharp.
As Nigeria is a fuel importer, lower world crude prices will also ease pressure on the import bill in 2019-20. In 2019 there will be a sharp drop in imports relative to 2018, when there was a one-off surge in capital goods entering the country; weaker economic growth, cuts in public investment, lower world oil (and so petrol) prices and depreciation of the naira will also be contributing factors. In 2020 the naira will continue to depreciate, limiting consumer demand, but slightly stronger economic growth will nonetheless stabilise imports that year. As the economy gathers pace in 2021-23 and the naira stabilises, imports will then grow with reasonable strength, albeit with less need for fuel imports as a new refinery comes on stream. Trade-related services imports and profit repatriation in the oil sector will keep the services and primary income balances firmly in deficit. Meanwhile, workers' remittances will remain an important source of hard currency, albeit dipping in 2020 as growth falters in the US (home to a large Nigerian diaspora). Overall, the current-account surplus will broadly track movements in world oil prices, narrowing from 2.6% of GDP in 2019 to 1% of GDP in 2020, then widening again to 2.5% of GDP by 2023.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; the source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: IEA average import price
Non-oil commodity prices: IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
EUR 3-month interbank rate: IFS
Domestic data
Population: UN
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics
Balance of payments: IFS and CBN, Annual Report and Statement of Accounts
Inflation: IFS, CBN and Federal Office of Statistics
Exchange rate: IFS; principal rate expressed as naira:US dollar
Interest rate: IFS; year-end lending rate
GDP growth and expenditure breakdown: World Bank, World Tables; 1987 prices
US$ GDP: IFS; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
GDP per head: US dollar GDP divided by population
Oil production: IEA; m barrels/day
Oil price: The Economist Intelligence Unit; dated Brent Blend
FDI: IFS, UNCTAD, World Investment Report and CBN
Total external debt: sum of long- and short-term debt and IMF credits
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding, with an original maturity of more than one year
Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
IMF credits: IFS and country page on website
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges on total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
CBN: Central Bank of Nigeria
IEA: International Energy Agency
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
NPC: National Population Commission
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development

Full text: Greece--highlights: Political outlook
The government, led by Alexis Tsipras of the Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), is likely to hobble along for a few more months following the departure of the nationalist Independent Greeks (AE) in protest against the Macedonia name change deal. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Greek parliament's ratification of the deal ahead of a busy electoral cycle to increase political instability, further weakening Greece's governance and its commitment to political and economic reform. Polls point to a victory for the main opposition party, the centre-right New Democracy (ND), but forming a government may prove difficult. Domestic political instability has limited Greece's influence in the EU and the Balkans. Recent government efforts to restore influence are fraught with difficulty, as domestic pre-election tension is likely to condition foreign policy decisions.
Greece--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.62 6.23 55 50 18 17

Greece's business environment will improve moderately in the forecast period (2019-23) with progress in almost all categories, bar political stability. Greece rises five places to 50th in the global ranking and one place in the regional ranking to 17th. Greece will remain subject to sub-optimal fiscal and other policy conditions beyond the end of the forecast period. These will constrain economic growth, and Greece's debt burden will remain onerous.
Greece--highlights: Economic outlook

Exchange rate [euro]:US$ (av) 0.8 0.9 0.8 0.8 0.8 0.8
With a general election looming in 2019, the Syriza government opted to exit Greece's third economic adjustment programmes in August 2018 without a precautionary credit line. However, the government will still be subject to severe policy constraints during the forecast period and beyond, until its huge government debt is substantially reduced. General government debt was an estimated 185% of GDP at end-2018, and also almost entirely owed to official creditors (the EU and the IMF), making another debt write-down, as happened in 2012, highly unlikely. In the short term Greece should have sufficient funds to meet its financing needs, but it will need to re-establish itself in the debt markets before its cash buffer runs out, which could prove challenging. Grexit is not a short- or medium-term risk; however, given that it is unlikely to improve competitiveness inside the euro zone or to grow its way out of its huge debt burden, Grexit is a possibility in the long term. We expect real growth of 2.1% in 2018 and an average of 2% in 2019-23.
Greece--highlights: Demographic outlook

Period averages (%)   2014-18 2019-23
Population growth   -0.3 -0.2
Working-age population growth   -0.5 -0.5

The population will shrink by an average of 0.2% per year over the five-year forecast period, declining to 11m by 2023. Greece will experience a change in its demographic composition as a result of low fertility rates, longer life expectancy and a rising proportion of the total population aged 65 or over. Population ageing will prove a burden on already heavily indebted social services, particularly the pension and healthcare systems. The working-age population will decline at a faster pace than the population. Moderately higher participation rates (reflecting a rise in the effective retirement age, an increase in the number of women in work and immigration) will limit the decline in the labour force.

Greece--highlights: Long-term outlook

We expect real GDP to grow at 1.8% per year on average in 2019-30 (2.1% per head). Over 2031-50 average annual GDP growth is forecast to be 0.9% (1.3% per head). Labour productivity growth is expected to average 1.7% per year over the entire long-term forecast period. Scope for a further rise in labour force participation rates will be reduced, and we expect a decline in the working-age population. We expect the labour force to be fairly stable during 2019-30, but to decline dramatically in 2031-50. We believe that there is a greater than even chance that Greece will leave the euro area over the long term.
