Background: After 400 years of Ottoman rule Greece emerged as a sovereign state in 1830. A devastating civil war followed the retreat of German occupying forces in 1944. A military junta ruled the country from 1967 to 1974, but since then a democracy has been in place. In 1981 Greece joined the European Economic Community, now the EU. It became a member of the economic and monetary union (EMU) in 2001, but its public finances became unsustainable, resulting in a sovereign debt crisis in 2009-10. Greece's public debt has put its continued membership of the EMU into question.
Political structure: Greece is a parliamentary republic, with deputies elected for four-year terms. The prime minister and the government hold executive powers. The president is elected by the 300-member parliament for a five-year term. The government requires the support of parliament to hold office. Since the 2010 crisis the traditional party system has broken down. Voters blamed the parties that ruled Greece after the return of democracy in the mid-1970s-New Democracy (ND) and the Panhellenic Socialist Movement (Pasok)-for causing the crisis, which led to the imposition of painful austerity by the country's external creditors. The result has been political fragmentation and the rise of populist parties such as the left-wing Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), which came to power in 2015, and far-right parties such as the neo-fascist Golden Dawn (XA).
Policy issues: The ND-Pasok government of 2012-14, like its two predecessors, imposed draconian austerity packages. It also enacted fiscal and some structural economic reforms to meet the conditions of two EU-IMF bail-out packages, totalling EUR240bn. Implementation proved difficult and ultimately brought down the government. After a seven-month confrontation with Greece's creditors, the Syriza-led government negotiated a new three-year European Stability Mechanism (ESM) programme in August 2015. In 2012 Greece restructured its public debt, reducing the value of private-sector creditors' holdings by EUR107bn. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any further debt write-down. Now that Greece has exited the programme, it is subject to an "enhanced supervision" monitoring regime by its euro zone creditors.
Taxation: The tax rate on corporate profits is 28% and on distributed dividends is 10%. The top marginal personal income tax rate is 45% for income of more than EUR40,000. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at rates of 24%, 13% and 6%.
Foreign trade: In 2018 goods exports (fob) were worth EUR32.4bn and imports (fob) amounted to EUR54.9bn. The current account registered a deficit of EUR5.3bn, equivalent to an estimated 2.9% of GDP.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza) won 35.5% of the vote in the snap September 2015 election and secured 145 seats in Greece's 300-seat parliament (including the 50 bonus seats awarded to the winning party). The Independent Greeks (AE) passed the 3% threshold that secured entry to parliament and elected ten members of parliament (MPs). The two parties formed a government, with a slim majority of five seats, but the coalition collapsed in January 2019 when AE withdrew its support because of the Macedonia name change deal. The prime minister and Syriza party leader, Alexis Tsipras, now heads a minority administration, which had to rely on the help of a few members of the opposition and AE defectors to win a vote of confidence and get the Macedonia agreement through parliament. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect the government to survive more than a few months, leading to a pre-term election before the end of the parliamentary term in October 2019.

Political outlook: Political stability
Political instability has intensified owing to the agreement with Macedonia to change that country's name to the Republic of North Macedonia, which the Greek parliament ratified on January 25th. This is likely to lead to a further weakening of the country's governance and its commitment to political and economic reform ahead of Greece's busy 2019 electoral cycle. Local and European Parliament elections are scheduled for May, and the general election is due by October, but we expect the general election to be called early, possibly in conjunction with the elections in May. In early January the small, right-wing nationalist AE dropped out of the coalition govern-ment in protest against the Macedonia name change deal. The government is led by the prime minister, Mr Tsipras, of Syriza. Syriza has just 145 seats in the 300-seat parliament, but, with the help of members of the opposition and AE defectors, the government survived a vote of confidence on January 16th and managed to get the Macedonia agreement through parliament. We expect the Syriza minority government to attempt to pass legislation aimed at boosting its electoral support in the coming months, but it is unlikely to survive more than a few months.
In August 2018, after eight years of austerity and unpopular reforms under three economic adjustment programmes, Greece exited the third bail-out programme signed by the Syriza-led government in 2015. During his period in power Mr Tsipras has lost much popular support and will struggle to revive his party's political fortunes before the next election. We remain sceptical that real GDP growth will rise much higher than 2% during the 2019-23 forecast period, and expect that failure to implement other structural reforms agreed with Greece's international creditors could lead to delays in the implementation of the debt-relief measures agreed with Greece's EU creditors.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
Greece scores poorly in relation to other developed economies on political and institutional effectiveness, as a result of the high levels of corruption, patronage and inefficiency affecting the government and the legal system. Under the terms of its financial assistance package, which expired in August 2018, the Greek authorities committed to implementing a far-reaching reform of the public administration, judiciary and society more broadly. However, progress in many areas has fallen short of expectations, and implementation of reforms remains an issue. There is also a risk of backsliding on some reforms now that Greece has exited the economic adjustment programme.
Political effectiveness has been sorely lacking since the start of the bail-out era in 2010, as successive governments have sought to implement fiscal and structural reforms in the face of political and societal resistance. Weak governments and an inefficient bureaucracy have fallen short in fully implementing bail-out policies, despite many having been legislated.
The establishment of a modern state and public administration has been one of the four pillars of the reform agenda under the bail-out programme. The main priorities have been to control the size and cost of the public sector and at the same time increase the efficiency of the public sector in the delivery of essential public goods and services. Reforms aimed to strengthen the institutional and operational independence of major institutions, such as revenue administration and the Hellenic Statistical Authority (ELSTAT, the national statistics office), as well as improve the efficiency of the judicial system and tackle corruption. The first post-programme review published by the European Commission in November 2018 noted that the size of the public sector in Greece had shrunk considerably and was broadly on par with levels in other euro area member states. However, in the second review, published in late February 2019, the Commission warned that the number of public servants increased slightly in 2018, driven mainly by a sharp increase of temporary staff. It warned that avoiding a return to pre-crisis practices of excessive levels of public-sector hiring would be a major challenge as the attrition rule of one new entry for every three exits was adjusted to 1:1 in 2019-22.
The reviews highlight that there has been uneven progress in areas such as depoliticisation of the public administration through renewal of the top management and the implementation of new selection procedures to all levels of senior management, including the replacement of political appointees. The Commission also noted mixed progress in efforts to increase the efficiency of the judicial system, which is needed to enhance the business environment and revive investment. Greece's judicial system remains burdened by an excessive backlog of cases, especially tax cases (appealing tax decisions can take up to 12 years). The sector is subject to frequent strikes by the courts and the Bar Association.
In terms of the anti-corruption agenda, the authorities have repeatedly amended the legal framework for the funding of political parties to bring it into line with European best practice.
Overall, progress in modernising the public administration and tackling ingrained patronage and corruption has been slow. We expect some further improvement in these areas during the 2019-23 forecast period, as reflected in the improved score from 4.9 to 5.5 in the political effectiveness category of the business environment rankings, but Greece will continue to lag most of its peers in the EU.
Political outlook: Election watch
Syriza trails the centre-right New Democracy (ND), led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis, in opinion polls; the gap has exceeded 10 percentage points for some time. ND's lead may narrow during the election campaign, as Mr Tsipras is a formidable campaigner and there is little overt enthusiasm for Mr Mitsotakis or his party. However, given widespread popular disaffection with the Syriza government, which is likely to have increased owing to the Macedonia name change deal, the election-due by October 2019-is ND's to lose. If, as we expect, ND wins the largest share of the vote, it would benefit from the 50-seat bonus rule for the winning party. Even so, it would probably have to secure the support of at least one other party to muster a parliamentary majority.
Political outlook: International relations
Domestic political instability and protracted economic and financial crises have limited Greece's influence in the EU and in the Balkans. Recent govern-ment efforts to restore influence, including the Macedonia name change deal and talks on closer co-operation with the US, are fraught with difficulty, as domestic pre-election tension is likely to condition foreign policy decisions. Ratification of the name change agreement aims to end Greece's opposition to Macedonia's accession to NATO and its application for EU membership, but the leader of ND has said that if elected, his government would seek to renegotiate the deal.
Elections in Greece and Turkey in 2019 will fuel further tensions between the two countries. However, we believe that both sides will seek to prevent their historical enmity from escalating into military hostility. Points of contention include long-standing territorial disputes in the Aegean Sea, and the Greek courts' rejection of Turkey's extradition request for Turkish soldiers who fled to Greece on the night of the July 2016 failed coup in Turkey. Turkey's release in August 2018 of two Greek soldiers arrested in March of that year while on patrol in the border area of Evros has eased tensions slightly.

The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Greece's business environment to improve moderately in the forecast period (2019-23). We expect progress in almost all categories, bar political stability. Greece's overall score improves from 5.62 in the historical period (2014-18) to 6.23, rising five places to 50th in the global ranking. It moves up one place from the bottom of the regional ranking to 17th-above Turkey, which suffered a severe currency crisis in 2018.
The Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza) government no longer has a stable parliamentary majority following the withdrawal of its junior coalition partner, the Independent Greeks, in January 2019 and is trailing badly in opinion polls ahead of a series of elections due to be held in 2019. Syriza is hoping that the decision to exit the third bail-out programme, when it expired in August 2018, without a precautionary credit line will revive its electoral prospects. However, policy conditionality will persist well beyond the forecast period. By exiting the programme Greece has also lost access to EU financial support, and the sovereign has not as yet re-established itself fully in the debt markets.
Eight years of bail-out policies have largely failed to reverse Greece's economic decline-although a modest recovery is under way-and have instead discredited the political system and undermined social stability. There is no political or societal consensus in favour of more reforms, although paradoxic-ally there is a majority in favour of continued euro zone membership. This indicates only that fear, along with anger, have become the prevailing motifs in Greek society, which is not a sound basis for addressing the serious and deep-seated structural problems that are preventing a return to sustainable growth and competitiveness.

Business environment outlook: Greece's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The country's privatisation agency (under new management) gains momentum, unblocking some delayed deals.
2021-23: Efforts to valorise public property through concession management and long-leasehold development agreements.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: The Investment Incentives Law of 2016 offers more tax relief and fewer subsidies, and focuses predominantly on small firms. Plans to cut down on bureaucracy make modest progress.
2021-23: "Fast-track" legislation could become more important if the economy normalises. It will cover "strategic" investments in energy, tourism, transport, communications and health.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Remaining capital controls introduced in June 2015 are eliminated. Capital buffer of about EUR26bn sufficient to cover almost two years of the government's medium- and long-term financing needs.
2021-23: There is a significant risk of Greece leaving the euro zone in the long term if growth continues to disappoint. Grexit would probably result in the reintroduction of foreign-exchange controls and possibly restrictions on trade.
Taxes
2019-20: Extensive efforts to widen the tax base. Government pledges to pursue aggressive tax collection, but implementation is difficult. Indirect taxes increase. Mandatory introduction of electronic point of sale terminals helps.
2021-23: Limited progress in cutting corporate income tax or value-added tax (VAT). Measures to tackle tax evasion stepped up. Independence of tax authority remains in doubt.
Financing
2019-20: Liquidity tight. Uncertainty constrains lending capacity. Pressure to reduce non-performing loans (NPLs) intensifies, but foreign interest picks up. A moratorium on foreclosures is lifted for the majority of debtors.
2021-23: The need to increase provisions for still high NPLs hampers lending. More Greek bank foreign subsidiaries are sold off.
The labour market
2019-20: Labour market reforms now mostly passed, but implementation is problematic. Unemployment remains high.
2021-23: EU funded job-creation schemes, particularly for youth, raise employment, but create few productive jobs.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Energy infrastructure comes to the fore as Trans-Adriatic Pipeline (TAP) nears completion. Privatisations pick up pace.
2021-23: Technical assistance from the EU helps absorption of European funds to revive infrastructure investment.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Greece rolls out high-speed internet, at a slow pace. The private sector adopts electronic payments by law.
2021-23: Significant financial and technical assistance from the EU, but Greece remains a laggard.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Expected improvement in macroeconomic stability subject to risks
The score for the macroeconomic environment improves, but macroeconomic stability will remain in question after Greece's exit from the third economic adjustment programme in August 2018. Unemployment remains high (18.5% in November 2018); households are highly indebted; the banking system is burdened with bad loans; the stock of public debt is the highest in the euro zone (as a share of GDP); the public sector is still inefficient, despite gradual reforms; recent competitive gains for Greek goods exports could be reversed; and labour market and demographic trends are not conducive to growth.
The government insists that it has made a "clean exit" from the bail-out programme, but policy conditionality will persist, including a significant primary budget surplus target equivalent to 3.5% of GDP annually in 2019-22, declining to 2.2% from 2023. In addition, post-programme debt relief is conditional on continued reform implementation. The government may find the post-programme transition to be more problematic than it expects, as the financial markets could turn less positive on Greek sovereign debt as time goes on as they pay more attention to Greece's political and policy risk dynamics. Greece is unlikely to be granted another debt write-down, and although the short-term repayment schedule is manageable, the size of the debt pile will weigh on investor sentiment. This might require Greece to request further financial assistance from the European Stability Mechanism (ESM) at some point in the medium term. Although Grexit is not a risk in the short or medium term, given the political and economic uncertainties facing Greece and the wider region, it could be a risk in the long run.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.3 6.3 36 40 16 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Efforts to promote competition are under way, but face headwinds
Greece has made uneven progress since its first bail-out programme in 2010 in opening up closed product markets, enhancing competition and privatising state-owned companies. Under the third Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) reached with the European Commission in 2015 the government committed to undertake ambitious reforms, particularly in the professions, and to revive privatisation plans. Resisted by groups that have enjoyed preferential status, these plans have only been partially implemented.
Selling off public assets was an important feature of Greece's bail-out programmes, but the privatisation process has been plagued with problems, and proceeds have been disappointing; sales brought in only EUR3.9bn in 2011-15. The third economic adjustment programme foresaw privatisation proceeds of EUR3.3bn by end-2018, rising to EUR14.2bn by end-2022. In 2016 cash receipts amounted to just one-fifth of the envisaged EUR2.5bn, but the process has picked up pace. Proceeds more than tripled to EUR1.7bn in 2017, and came close to the government's target of EUR2.7bn in 2018.
Privatisation plans have been subject to delay, but have started to pick up pace
Delays in launching the Hellenic Corporation of Assets and Participations (EESYP), the new privatisation and investment fund, are starting to be overcome. The EESYP, the profits of which will be used to pay down public debt and boost investment in the economy, finally launched a strategic plan on the develop-ment, sale or restructuring of its assets in April 2018, and the Hellenic Republic Asset Development Fund (TAIPED), now its subsidiary, continues with its disinvestment responsibilities. Implementation of the plan is likely to be drawn out, however, and the lingering transition and additional administrative delays could affect various privatisation projects.
The government's privatisation programme (which, under the enhanced surveillance by the Commission, is updated every six months on a continuous basis) has made uneven progress. The government's projections of EUR1.5bn in revenue from the sale of state assets in 2019, most of which is budgeted to occur at the end of this year (after the election deadline), are optimistic.
As at early 2019 there was still a lack of progress on the tendering of concessions to operate the Egnatia highway, owing to delays partly attributable to the Ministry of Infrastructure, but progress had been made on tendering some regional ports. There have been continued delays in the sale by Public Power Corporation of some of its lignite coal-generating assets. The sale for development of Hellinikon, the site of the former airport, had seemed to be moving forward last year, but has once again been affected by delays.
The long-delayed sale of a 66% stake in the Hellenic Gas Transmission System Operator (DESFA, which is 31% owned by TAIPED and 35% by Hellenic Petroleum, HELPE) to an international consortium comprising Snam (60%), Enagás (20%) and Fluxys (20%) was completed at the end of 2018. The conclusion of the DESFA process could unlock the process for the privatisation of the commercial division of the Public Gas Corporation (DEPA) and HELPE. The two remaining bidders for HELPE, Glencore-Carlyle and Vitol-Sonatrach, are expected to submit binding offers in early March 2019.
In March 2014 the government passed an omnibus act comprising further competitiveness-enhancing measures, resulting from a competitiveness review undertaken by the OECD. The legislation was passed, but implementation was watered down by a score of administrative measures. The third economic adjustment programme included further such measures, especially for beverages and petroleum products. Some of these were legislated at the end of 2016, but implementation is likely to continue to face resistance.
Laws put in place in 2011 and 2012 abolished restrictive practices in more than 150 professions, but they have not been fully applied. Implementation of the law has in many cases been left to professional groups, which have used their influence to maintain restrictive practices. In most liberalised professions, the growth rate has not exceeded 3%. Legislation has been passed to open network industries, but it is ponderous, and implementation will be slow.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.1 6.0 65 59 18 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Attracting foreign direct investment is high on government's agenda
The government's foreign direct investment (FDI) policy aims to counteract a process of disinvestment since 2010. However, FDI is hindered by complex and unevenly enforced legislation, obstructive bureaucracy and frequent changes in tax law. The third bail-out programme included policies to speed up company registration, "fast-track" investment (by facilitating approvals and relaxing regulation) and simplify export rules. Progress has been slow.
The fast track legislation covers investments that are deemed to be strategic. Priorities include industry, energy, tourism, transport, communication, health and waste management. The fast track process provides for approval in one month by the Interministerial Committee for Strategic Investments (DESE) and facilitation of licensing and permitting applications (against payment of fees) within two months by the Ministry of Development's Enterprise Greece agency (formerly Invest in Greece). However, the process has not gone smoothly in all cases, and as at end-February 2019 only 15 had been approved, although four more were reported to have been submitted in the first two months of 2019.
Investors will be offered more tax breaks and fewer cash subsidies
The investment incentives law (which provides for tax breaks and grants to promote regional development) involves the National Fund for Entrepreneurship and Development (ETEAN), which operates in conjunction with commercial banks to provide financing for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). However, given the exceptionally high incidence of non-performing loans (NPLs) and the difficulty faced by banks in foreclosure, available funding is scant. ETEAN is supplemented by the development ministry with EU-led community support framework funding, as well as by Information Society, the government's technological consultancy arm. The result has often been confusing for SMEs, which have to invest a substantial amount of time in chasing up funding. The government had announced its intention to replace ETEAN with a national development bank, but plans have stalled.
In June 2016 the government passed Law 4399, termed the New Development Law (NDL). This sets out the complete regulatory framework on state aid for private investment plans. The reform is modelled on the EU's General Block Exemption framework, so as to ensure compliance with EU standards on the distribution of state aid. It includes some transitional provisions for investment plans submitted under previous laws.
The NDL has sector-specific priorities. Assistance packages include tax exemptions, grants, leasing subsidies, new employment cost subsidies, stabilisation of income tax rates and business risk financing via an equity fund. To have access to these incentives, businesses in eligible sectors must meet minimum investment thresholds; these depend on business size, with lower thresholds applying to smaller companies.
In April 2013 an "investor ombudsman" service was set up to examine deadlocked investments and liaise with the relevant branch(es) of the public administration to remove stumbling blocks. The ombudsman, which is part of Enterprise Greece is available for investments in excess of EUR2m. The ombudsman reported an 86% resolution rate for 2017 (latest available data), but did not report on the volume of cases. Enterprise Greece also runs a "golden visa" programme, which grants investors residence permits when investing in the country.

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The Greek authorities imposed exchange and capital controls to stem a flight of cash from its banks in June 2015, at the height of a debt crisis. The restrictions contravened the rules of the common currency, but the Commission issued a special dispensation in this instance, on the grounds of maintaining the stability of the Greek financial system. The restrictions have been gradually relaxed in line with the timeline agreed in the bail-out programme, but as at end-February 2019 some remained in place, despite government promises in September 2018 that they would be removed completely in the coming months. The easing of controls that took effect on October 1st 2018 allowed unlimited cash withdrawals from credit institutions in Greece. In addition, supporting crossborder business activities, the limit on the amount of funds that can be transferred abroad was also increased, and the limit on the repatriation of capital gains and dividends was raised to 100% of the invested funds in Greece per year.
As long as Greece remains a member of the EU (and the euro area) over the forecast period, the country's foreign trade and exchange policy (with the proviso of capital controls) will be that of the EU. Trade policy will be determined by the EU's commitments to the World Trade Organisation (WTO) and its dispute arbitration procedures. Greece is so far largely unaffected (directly) by the latest global pick-up in tariffs.
Within the EU no tariffs or quotas are permitted, and the bloc has succeeded in abolishing most other non-tariff trade restrictions, such as health regulation that favours domestically produced goods. The EU has a customs union with Turkey, includes Norway and Iceland in the European Economic Area, and has a range of bilateral agreements enabling free trade and other economic exchange with Switzerland. Negotiations related to the UK's decision to withdraw from the EU have run into difficulty. We expect a new trade agreement between the UK and the EU to be reached before the UK's full departure from the bloc, but the risk of a "no-deal" exit has risen considerably since late 2018.
Agriculture is excluded from all of these arrangements. Outside agriculture, trade with non-EU countries is mostly subject to moderate customs duties. The EU takes a liberal approach to trade in industrial goods. Average unweighted tariffs on these goods from "most-favoured nations" are 4%.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.1 5.5 67 67 17 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Efforts are being made to reduce tax evasion
Improvement of tax collection is a major policy focus. Some progress has been made since 2015. Government revenue declined sharply during the crisis, but it rose as a share of GDP under the bail-out programme in 2010-18 (by about 6 percentage points to an estimated 47.6% last year), despite declining incomes during most of that period. Most of the increase came from improved collection of direct and indirect taxes and social security contributions, but also higher tax rates (the 2018 budget included increases in social security contributions, tax rates for medium-sized and large properties, value-added tax (VAT) rates on most Aegean islands, and a new hotel stay levy).
However, the overhaul of the tax administration has been painfully slow and, according to the Commission's second post-programme review, further action is needed to strengthen institutional and operational capacity. The Independent Agency for Public Revenue (IAPR) only became operational on January 1st 2017 as an autonomous revenue agency, following a series of ineffective prior reforms. With significant technical support from the Commission and the IMF, the IAPR has begun to shift from building its institutional capacity to enhancing its operational capacity and efficiency, by adopting modern collection and audit tools. Tax collection rose by a solid 8.5% in 2018 to EUR5.6bn, and the use of electronic payments has become much more widespread-rising by 24% to EUR31bn in 2018. Overdue tax debts have also been reduced significantly.
Tax cuts unlikely until public debt is reduced to sustainable levels
Given the size of the public debt, the overall tax burden is unlikely to be reduced substantially during the forecast period, despite political promises of tax cuts. Greece's statutory corporate income tax (CIT) rate is one of the highest in the EU, at 28% in 2019 (down from 29% in 2018), and, in addition, companies pay a fixed annual levy of EUR650 irrespective of profitability. The system is also complex, adding to the administrative burden of compliance. The average tax burden on labour is also high, with an implicit tax rate on employed labour of 43.3% in 2017, compared with the EU average of 36.3%, according to Eurostat.
Under the enhanced surveillance regime, further reform of the tax administration will remain a priority, but curbing political influence in the tax sphere is likely to become more difficult now that Greece has exited the bail-out programme. Efforts to improve the efficiency of the justice system have had mixed results, which suggests that progress towards reducing the backlog of tax appeal cases is also likely to be slow. There are plans to set a threshold on the amounts that can be appealed in order to limit court applications, and also to increase the size of deposits that plaintiffs must make against the eventuality that the court rules against them. The Ministry of Finance is establishing debt management units in all larger tax offices, concentrating on debts past due that can be paid through the negotiation of instalment plans. All tax obligations must in future be settled through bank transfers coupled with tax identification measures; the use of cheques and cash has been abolished to prevent corruption of inspectors.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.5 6.6 50 42 18 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Banking sector expected to undergo consolidation
Greek banks went through a difficult time in 2010-14, and 2015 was even worse, culminating in a month-long bank holiday from June 28th and the imposition of capital controls, following accelerating capital flight in December 2014-June 2015. In 2012 rising NPLs and the 53.5% haircut on private-sector sovereign debt holdings (a 79% reduction in net present value) resulted in state-funded recapitalisation, followed by a new round of capital increases in 2014, which were privately funded. The stakes of the Hellenic Financial Stability Fund (HFSF) in the systemic banks, as reported in its latest filing, in September 2018, were as follows: Eurobank Egrasias, 2.38%; National Bank of Greece, 40.39%; Alpha Bank, 10.96%; and Piraeus Bank, 26.42%.
In May 2018 the European Central Bank (ECB), the euro zone's banking watchdog, released the stress test results for the four "systemic" Greek banks. The testing was based on a baseline scenario that assumed annual average real GDP growth rates of 2.4% in 2018-20, and an adverse scenario that assumed a return to recession in 2018-19 and negligible growth in 2020. There are no official "pass rates", but unofficially a capitalisation rate of 5.5% or better under an adverse growth scenario is considered acceptable. All of the Greek banks met this benchmark, but they did not do so by a large margin owing mainly to the large NPL burden that continues to weigh on the Greek banking system, accounting for about 47% of total loans. High NPLs have constrained banks' ability to attract equity investors.
Domestic deposits at Greek banks remain well below pre-crisis levels after falling by 30% in 2009-12 and by another 25% in the first half of 2015. After stabalising as a result of capital controls in 2015-17, they began to increase gradually again towards the end of 2017. Bank credit to the private sector will remain constrained; it contracted in the 27 consecutive quarters to end-2017. The decline in total volume has been less than that for deposits, as many loans have been restructured to prevent default.
Greek banks will remain under pressure to reduce NPLs on banks' balance sheets, but progress will be constrained by weak bank profitability. According to the Commission's second post-programme review, the pace of NPL reduction so far has been in line with supervisory targets, but an acceleration is needed to meet the NPL targets for 2019 and future years through insolvency reforms related to the insolvency framework, the enforceability of collateral through electronic online auctions, the out-of-court debt workout mechanism and the activation of a secondary market for NPLs. The Commission warns that the process is likely to become more onerous if the proposed prudential backstop is implemented, this would force banks to hold more capital against the risk of new loans turning sour.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.9 6.1 49 43 16 14
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Labour market gradually becoming more flexible, but progress is slow
Greece's labour market has been one of the least flexible in the euro area. However, this began to change in 2010. In addition to allowing more redundancies, reforms should enable company-level collective agreements to prevail over those at the sectoral and occupational levels. Another law provided for flexible working time, including part-time shift work. Greater flexibility regarding redundancies was introduced and redundancy compen-sation was reduced. The government, under pressure from creditors to liberalise the market and after losing a precedent-setting case at the European Court of Justice, abolished in May 2017 the discretionary right of the labour minister to approve collective dismissals in the private sector. Labour market liberalisation and economic recovery, but also emigration of mainly young Greeks, has helped to reduce the unemployment rate, which was 18.5% in November 2018, down from a crisis peak of 27.9% in July 2013.
The rise of unemployment was accompanied by sharp wage cuts. In 2010-12 public-sector wages were cut three times, and in 2012 the government slashed the minimum wage for over-25-year-olds by 22% to EUR586 per month (14 annual payments) and for under 25s by 32% to EUR511. The minimum wage remained unchanged until February 1st 2019, when a single rate was restored and increased by 10.9% to EUR650 per month (still 14 annual payments). The minimum wage is expected to remain at this level until about mid-2020.
Statutory pension age increased, and likely to rise further
Primary (pillar one) pensions in the public and private sectors were reformed in 2011. In 2015 new legislation introduced penalties for early retirement in an attempt to address loopholes that let people collect pension benefits at an average age of 57-58. In May 2016 a new way of calculating pensions was introduced. It reduced auxiliary pensions, partially stopped the payment of a special social solidarity allowance for low-income pensioners (EKAS), cut high-end pensions and widower pensions, and increased insurance contributions for employers, employees and farmers. Starting in 2017, contri-butions were further increased for freelancers and civil servants. The private sector is now almost exclusively served by a single fund that came about from the merger of eight smaller ones in 2017. The statutory pension age is 67, and the number of years of contributions necessary to secure a full pension is 40. The minimum pension eligibility age is 62.
The minimum wage increase at the beginning of 2019 was long overdue. It should help to reduce poverty and income inequality, as well as supporting household demand in the near term. However, the size of the increase-a committee of experts recommended an increase in the range of 5-10%-could have potentially negative effects on economic growth and competitiveness as well as on youth unemployment, which is the highest by far in the EU at 39.1%. Because of the previously lower level, the increase in the minimum wage for workers under 25 works out at about 27%. This is only partly offset by a 6.7-percentage-point cut in employers' social security contributions for workers under 25 years of age, bringing the increase in the labour costs for workers under the age of 25 down to a still hefty 20%, potentially hindering youth employment.
From 2021 the statutory pension age and the minimum pension eligibility ages, of 67 and 62, will be revised every three years, in line with life expectancy. In the future pensions will be based on full earnings history, and accrual rates will be reduced so that the replacement ratio will drop from about 80% to 64%.
The Greek government may in the future years regret the decision (approved by the Commission) not to include previously agreed pension cuts in the draft 2019 budget, because they were deemed unnecessary to meet the government's primary budget surplus target of 3.5% of GDP this year. The cuts were designed to reduce the difference between the higher pension levels of those drawing their pensions before the 2016 reform and those drawing them after.
According to the OECD's Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) 2015 test scores (latest available), 27.3% of Greek 15-year-olds were "low achievers", compared with 15.9% for the EU and 16.8% for the OECD. At the same time persistently high youth unemployment has led more than 400,000 young educated Greeks to seek work abroad. With a labour force of 4.7m, the negative effect on Greece's labour market is significant.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.0 7.3 38 26 17 14
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Major deficiencies in infrastructure will remain
The poor quality of Greece's transport and communications networks is holding back the country's international trade and investment potential. Delays to plans to improve infrastructure arise for a variety of reasons, including scarcity of funds, despite the availability of EU monies, administrative complexity and political opposition at local and national level. The main gaps include the need to upgrade the existing rail network, improve interconnections between domestic and international transport links, overhaul the coastal shipping network to improve the accessibility of islands and reduce over-reliance on the port of Piraeus, and promote multi-modal freight transport by improving rail connections to Trans-European Transport Network ports such as Thessaloniki. Because of a lack of investment, Greece has lagged well behind most of the rest of the EU in the move to fast broadband in terms of both the availability of higher speeds and coverage.
A motorway (Pathe) runs between Athens, the capital, and Thessaloniki, on the east coast of the mainland, and a highway-standard link (Egnatia) runs across the north from the port of Igoumenitsa to the Turkish border. However, nine uplinks from Egnatia to the Balkans remain uncompleted. The tendering of a long-term concession for Egnatia and three of its uplinks was part of Greece's commitments under the 2015 bail-out programme, but as at end-February 2019 the tender had not been completed.
The government created a special purpose vehicle (SVP) called Hellenic Motorways, where the state allocated its concession rights from five concession toll roads contracted by the government in the early 2000s. As the recent economic downturn stalled projects, the government renegotiated the concession contracts in 2013, with the Commission approving related funding of EUR2.97bn. The works were concluded in 2017.
Public funding for infrastructure projects will be scarce
The government wants to couple management concessions for infrastructure projects such as the railway system, ports and airports with development financing. In August 2016 a Chinese logistics company, Cosco, which in 2010 won a EUR5bn, 35-year concession to manage two of three piers at the main container depot at Piraeus, paid EUR280.5m to acquire a majority stake in the third pier and promised to invest a further EUR350m within the next decade. Of this, EUR294m is expected in five years, allowing Cosco to exercise a right to up its stake to two-thirds for an additional consideration of EUR88m. In March 2018 a 67% stake in the Thessaloniki port authority was sold to a consortium of international and domestic companies for EUR232m upfront plus a portion of revenue annually. The buyers also agreed to undertake investments of EUR180m over the next seven years.
In April 2017 Germany's Fraport entered a 40-year concession to manage 14 regional airports. It paid EUR1.2bn upfront and will pay both an annual flat fee of EUR23m and a portion of operating profits. It has also undertaken to invest EUR330m in the airports by 2020. In December 2018 the European competition authorities approved an agreement, valued at EUR600m, to extend the concession for Athens International Airport for 20 years (from 2026 onwards) to the current concessionaire.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.5 5.5 49 57 17 18
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Our technological readiness ranking, introduced as part of an upgrade to our rankings in 2018, aims to show how future-oriented the business environment is-the extent to which it is digitally connected, open to innovation and prepared for technological disruption. Greece scores poorly and shows no improvement between the historical and forecast periods, which results in a drop of eight places to 57th in the world in the global rankings.
Our Inclusive Internet Index ranks Greece 30th out of 86 countries and second to last in the EU. The index ranks countries on four different axes: availability, readiness, affordability and relevance. Greece ranks last in the region on the first two criteria and performs well only on the last (relevance), for which it is 11th in the EU and 20th globally owing to top marks for availability of local content.
In June 2017 Greece's telecom regulator approved a two-year roll-out plan for very-high-bit-rate digital subscriber line (VDSL) vectoring technology that will, when completed, considerably improve high-speed internet availability in Greece. However, the plan is facing delays and is being amended on a rolling basis. The government's targets are also unrealistic. For instance, by 2020 it aims to provide internet access of more than 30 Megabits per second (Mbps) to all Greeks (it was as low as 9.9% in June 2017) and a connection with a speed of more than 100 Mbps to at least 50% of households.
In the World Economic Forum Global Competitiveness Report 2018, Greece ranks 57th out of 140 countries for ICT adoption and 44th for innovation capability. In the EU's Digital Economy and Society Index (DESI) Greece ranked 27th out of 28 in 2018, falling one place from 2017. In the UN's E-Government Survey 2018, Greece ranked 35rd out of 193 countries for e-government development-up from 43rd in 2016.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
With a general election looming in 2019, the Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza) government opted to exit Greece's third economic adjustment programmes in August 2018 without a precautionary credit line. However, the government will still be subject to severe policy constraints during the forecast period and beyond, until its huge government debt is substantially reduced. General government debt was an estimated 185% of GDP at end-2018, and also almost entirely owed to official creditors (the EU and the IMF), making another debt write-down, as happened in 2012, highly unlikely. Economic policy and performance will be subject to an "enhanced surveillance" regime, which is a more exacting system of post-programme monitoring than those applied to other former bail-out countries. The implementation of further debt-relief measures agreed with Greece's EU creditors in June 2018 will be conditional on quarterly reviews of the state of the economy and of the government's adherence to its commitments, the most pressing of which include tackling Greek banks' heavy burden of non-performing loans, reviving the government's privatisation programme, removing remaining capital controls and clearing state arrears to the private sector. As these reviews will be published (the last review was on February 27th), transgression by Greece would adversely affect market access.
In June 2018 Greece's official creditors agreed to close the final review of the third bail-out programme, paving the way for a disbursement of EUR15bn, which was released in August. Of this, EUR3.3bn was earmarked to repay more expensive IMF debt, and the balance to create a buffer for Greece to use while it builds up market access. The total buffer, estimated at EUR26bn, should be sufficient to cover almost two years of the country's financing needs, to end-2020. This is more onerous than a precautionary credit line would have been, as Greece will be accruing interest on money that it does not currently need. However, intense political pressure not to invite further policy conditionality led the government to choose the more expensive option.
The debt-relief measures also agreed in June include a ten-year grace period and a ten-year maturity extension on EUR96bn of its loans (provided by the European Financial Stability Facility). Greece will also get a reduction in the interest rates (for EUR130.9bn worth of loans), and a return of profits from the securities market programme and from the Agreement on Net Financial Assets, which comprises the official sector holders of Greek debt-the European Central Bank (ECB) and national central banks of euro area countries. The value of the return is estimated to be about EUR5bn in total in 2018-22. In response, Greece has committed to long-term fiscal prudence. It must achieve annual primary budget surpluses (budget balance minus interest payments) of 3.5% of GDP in 2018-22 and 2.2% thereafter, until 2060.
In the short term Greece should have sufficient funds to meet its financing needs, but it will need to have re-established itself in the debt markets before its cash buffer runs out. After a three-year absence Greece has tapped the financial markets four times since July 2017, most recently with a new bench-mark five-year bond issuance worth EUR2.5bn in late January 2019; however, without the backstop of an official credit line borrowing from the markets is still costly relative to its official debt. The yield on the January 2019 issue was 3.6%-about 340 basis points above German government bonds of a similar maturity. Amid rising domestic political instability ahead of the next general election in Greece, as well as and growing global economic and financial uncertainty, further issuance will be challenging.
In the medium and long term, the political and, arguably, the economic price of meeting high annual primary surplus targets may become unbearable. During the past two years Greece has exceeded its annual primary surplus targets, but at the expense of economic growth, which has been disappointing. Meeting such targets will remain a constraint on growth, as will other negative factors such as poor demographics and a weak business environment. Grexit is not a short- or medium-term risk; however, given that Greece is unlikely to improve competitiveness inside the euro zone or to grow its way out of its huge debt burden, Grexit will represent a possibility in the long term.

After almost a decade of austerity Greece recorded an overall budget surplus of 0.8% of GDP and a primary surplus of 3.9% in 2017, exceeding the bail-out programme target of 1.75%. From 2018, however, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects fiscal performance to deteriorate gradually, with the budget balance returning to moderately widening headline deficits and primary surpluses falling well short of the official target of 3.5% of GDP for 2018-22, reflecting constraints on revenue collection, a relaxation of spending restraint and only modest economic growth. Although the primary surplus target will decline to 2.2% of GDP from 2023, it will still be difficult to achieve.
The restructuring of government debt owed to the private sector cut the debt/GDP ratio to 159.4% at end-2012, from 171.9% in 2011. However, large primary surpluses in 2016-17 were insufficient to arrest the growth of gross consolidated government debt. We expect that, without a debt write-down and assuming moderate nominal medium-term GDP growth rates, the public debt/GDP ratio will still be more than 175% at the end of 2023.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy
Interest rates
(%)
  2018 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023
Commercial banks' prime rate (av) 5.0 5.1 5.6 6.2 6.7 6.8
Long-term interest rate (av) 4.2 4.6 5.8 7.0 7.5 7.5
The ECB adopted an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy in response to the European sovereign debt crisis, bringing major policy interest rates down to zero or below and undertaking a quantitative easing (QE) programme that amounted to EUR2.6trn. The bank ended its asset-purchase programme in December 2018, but policy conditions will nevertheless remain loose in the medium term as the ECB reinvests principal payments from maturing securities and adjusts other existing tools. Economic activity in the euro zone softened in 2018, and headline growth will slow further this year. Together with a more subdued outlook for commodity prices in 2019-20, we expect this to prompt the ECB to hold off on normalising its policy stance this year. We expect a 25-basis-point increase in the main refinancing rate to 0.25% in early 2020 as underlying price pressures build. Policy tightening should then proceed at a gradual pace, and we expect five more rate rises over the forecast period to lift the rate to 2% by end-2023. An increase in the deposit rate, which currently stands at -0.4%, may come sooner, in 2019, easing the pressure on banks' lending margins and supporting profitability. Risks to our outlook stem from the nomination of a new ECB president in late 2019.

Compared with 2007 levels, real GDP has shrunk by more than one-quarter, government consumption by almost one-quarter, household consumption by one-fifth and gross fixed investment by almost two-thirds. The recovery, which began at the start of 2017, is fragile and vulnerable to domestic and external developments. After real GDP growth of 1.4% in 2017, we estimate growth of 2.1% in 2018. In 2019-23 real GDP growth will remain constrained at an average of 2%. The risks to our forecast are balanced: upside risks include continued strong tourism performance if capacity constraints are addressed; downside risks include the frailty of the banking sector and political instability.
Our estimate for 2018 real GDP growth is a disappointing rate of expansion in the context of the slump of the past decade. We expect a combination of more-and higher-taxes, higher social security payments, debt repayments and spending cuts to put pressure on household disposable income. Although we expect a modest acceleration in household spending in 2018-23, this will be from a low base and will be constrained by large primary surplus targets (of 3.5% of GDP per year up to 2022 and 2.2% in 2023), continued high unemploy-ment and insipid lending growth.
Quarterly gross fixed investment has been volatile in recent years but recorded strong full-year growth in 2016-17, albeit from a low base. However, reflecting base effects and a loss of momentum, investment contracted by an average of 6.3% year on year in the first three quarters of 2018. Despite an expected modest quarter-on-quarter increase in the final three months of 2018, we now expect a full-year contraction of 7.5%, followed by average annual growth of 5.2% in 2019-23, leaving fixed investment still about 50% below its 2007 peak. Under-investment during the crisis and the depletion of Greece's capital stock are likely to restrict growth potential in the medium term.
Greece's external trade will be constrained by its relatively uncompetitive goods exports. In the medium term we expect tourism to continue to support services export growth, contributing to annual average growth of exports of goods and services of 8.3% in 2018 and 4.5% in 2019-23.
How the economy performs in the next five years (and beyond) will determine if the country remains in the euro zone. Although risks have abated since the height of the financial crisis, we believe that there is a risk that Greece will exit the euro zone in the long term, given the difficulties that it will face in attaining rapid growth while meeting large primary surplus targets and in restoring competitiveness without a currency devaluation. Greece's exit from the euro zone (not our core scenario) would lead to a sovereign default and severe recession in the first few years, but the economy would then recover, assuming a responsible fiscal policy guided by the necessity to achieve a primary surplus.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Greece's economy is driven by services, particularly shipping and tourism, and the related real estate sector, as well as financial services. The industrial sector has contracted sharply and accounts for about 12% of GDP, the third-lowest level in the EU, with manufacturing focused on food-processing. Real estate accounts for about 20% of GDP, reflecting the predominance of tourism, a sector in which Greece has a huge comparative advantage. The financial sector has been through a difficult eight years, suffering from weak profitability, a huge depletion of assets, deleveraging and a major asset quality problem; NPLs were about 43% of total loans at end-2018. The sector's growth prospects will be strongly correlated with political stability and continued reform progress now that the third economic adjustment programme has ended (in August 2018).
Greece's shipping industry employs 250,000 people and makes an important contribution to the country's GDP. Demand for shipping declined dramatically from mid-2008 to early 2009, primarily owing to sharp reductions in cargoes of commodities such as iron ore and coal. After reaching a peak of 11,793 in May 2008, the Baltic Dry Index (BDI, which measures the demand for shipping capacity against the supply of dry bulk carriers) plummeted to just over 650 in December 2008, before recovering slowly from 2010 onwards. However, decelerating demand growth in major emerging markets and excess supply in the industry resulted in a slump to an all-time low of 290 points in February 2016 as a result of falling demand from the economic slowdown in China, and other emerging markets such as Brazil relying on industrial production, as well as lingering excess supply problems. In 2017, however, the BDI registered an impressive improvement, ending the year at 1,366 points, driven by Chinese demand for the import of commodities, mainly coal and iron ore. The index rose steadily in 2018 to reach 1,400 in mid-December, driven by solid growth in demand and slow growth of the fleet, but has since plummeted again to about 650, reflecting concerns about international trade tensions and slowing global economic growth.
We estimate that the pace of world trade growth slowed in 2018, to 4.4%, from 5.4% in 2017. In 2019-20 it will slow further to average 3.1% per year, before picking up to an annual average of 4% in 2021-23. This should be sufficient to underpin growth in shipping as long as shipping companies can manage oversupply problems. The health of the Chinese economy is the biggest risk to the global economy and to world trade prospects. We expect average annual real GDP growth in China of 6.6% in 2018 to slow to an average of 6.2% per year in 2019-20 and 5.3% in 2021-23.
Tourism will be main driver of growth in services
The tourism sector plays a major role in the Greek economy. It contributes about 7.5% to GDP directly and almost 20% indirectly. Employment in the sector is about 11.5% of total employment directly and 23.5% including related sectors. In terms of foreign-currency earnings based on the balance of payments, travel credits amounted to EUR16.1bn-or an estimated 8.2% of GDP-in 2018, compared with about 2% in France, 5% in Spain and 8% in Portugal. Last year was another record year for tourism in Greece, with just over 30m arrivals, compared with about 27m in 2017 and 25m in 2016.
Greece's tourism sector has been one of a few bright spots during the country's near-decade-long economic depression, and the boom shows no signs of slowing. Following strong performances in 2017 and 2018, the medium-term outlook for the sector remains strong, owing to high European demand, competitive pricing and instability in some rival tourism destinations, although the collapse of the Turkish lira in 2018 has made Turkey a much cheaper destination. These factors imply that the sector is reasonably well positioned to cope with a new tourism tax and the end of reduced value-added tax (VAT) rates for most Aegean islands, which came into force in January 2018. We expect tourism to continue to make a strong contribution to overall economic growth.

After averaging 1.1% in 2017, driven by higher global energy prices, Greece's annual consumer price inflation rate (seasonally adjusted, EU harmonised) dipped sharply at the start of 2018. After a moderate acceleration in May-October, it eased to an average of 0.8% in the final two months of the year, as oil prices plunged from about US$80/barrel in October to just under US$60/b in December. The economy has returned to growth, but significant slack in the labour market, subdued domestic demand and recent decreases in global oil prices will dampen inflationary pressures. We expect inflation to pick up only modestly, from an average of 0.8% in 2018-19 to 1% in 2020 and 1.5% per year in 2021-23 as domestic demand growth accelerates.

The euro rallied in late 2017 as the region's economic recovery strengthened and expectations of QE tapering increased, and as political risk waned in Europe but rose in the US. After peaking at almost US$1.25:EUR1 in early February 2018, the euro has depreciated gradually. This was a response to the formation of a populist, Eurosceptic government in Italy, which increased political risk in the region, and to monetary tightening in the US. More recently, the euro has hovered around US$1.14:EUR1-at lower levels than we had anticipated-on the back of softening momentum in the euro zone. We expect it to appreciate gradually throughout 2019 as growth in the bloc picks up again in the second half of the year and momentum in the US slows, but we have revised down our forecast for 2019 to an average of US$1.16:EUR1 (from US$1.19:EUR1 previously). The euro will continue to appreciate throughout our forecast period-to US$1.22:EUR1 in 2020-21 as monetary policy in the euro zone is tightened gradually, and to US$1.24:EUR1 on average in 2022-23, supported by the large current-account surplus.

The economic crisis helped to reduce Greece's current-account deficit, which shrank primarily as a result of a compression of imports due to contracting domestic demand, but also partly of improved competitiveness in the tourism sector. We expect continued deficits in 2018-23 as import volumes pick up in line with higher domestic demand, and as global energy prices rise moderately in the second half of the forecast period. However, these deficits will be much smaller than the average annual deficit of 7.1% of GDP since Greece joined the euro zone in 2001.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Greece
Stocks and flows
Greece is a small host of inward foreign direct investment (FDI) compared with other EU countries. Stocks and inflows are well below those of many of the central and east European countries that joined the EU in 2004. FDI outflows have in some years exceeded inflows. Most inflows have been for the acquisition of existing companies either through privatisation sales or joint ventures with local partners. There has been significant disinvestment since the advent of the crisis, particularly in the retail and banking sectors; according to data from the IMF (based on data by the Bank of Greece, the central bank), the stock of FDI fell from a peak of US$55.1bn (17.3% of GDP) in 2007 to US$25.6bn (10.8% of GDP) in 2014. The stock has since risen, to US$37.5bn (18.5% of GDP) at the end of 2017 (latest available data). This is far below the levels of new EU member states in the former communist Balkans, Bulgaria (US$47.4bn; 81.5% of GDP) and Romania (US$98.1bn; 46.3% of GDP).
Greek companies' FDI stock abroad was US$51.7bn (17.9% of GDP) at end-2011. Much of this outward investment was in the Balkan region, although Greek companies have also looked further afield, to invest in North Africa, Turkey and, in a few cases, the US. The outward stock had declined to US$24.3bn by end-2017, equivalent to 12% of GDP, as a result of retrenchment by Greek companies and banks.
With FDI inflows drying up after the onset of the economic crisis and outflows falling less sharply, net negative FDI flows were registered in 2010-11. In 2012-13 net inflows turned positive, but this was mainly the result of inflows from foreign banks recapitalising subsidiaries before divestment. Net inflows turned negative again in 2014-15, amid acute political and economic uncertainty. In 2016-18, after Greece signed a third economic adjustment programme in August 2015, there was a pick-up in FDI inflows and positive net investment to an estimated US$4.4bn and US$3.8bn respectively last year-the third consecutive year of positive net investment.
Origin and distribution
Historically, the US was a major source of FDI for Greece in heavy industries such as refining and chemicals. However, since Greece entered the common market, EU countries, particularly Germany, the Netherlands, and Luxembourg (because of its status as a financial hub for special-purpose entities (SPEs) created by multinationals for inward and outward FDI) have become the main investors, primarily in financial services and telecommunications, as these sectors have been liberalised. Retrenchment in Europe has led to a search for funding from Middle Eastern sovereign funds (Dubai and Qatar) and pursuit of investment from China, particularly through the China Development Bank. A number of Chinese transport and logistics companies have made large investments in Greece with a view to creating a gateway into the EU for Chinese manufactures.
Determinants
Factors that have traditionally held back greater levels of inward direct investment include Greece's geographical remoteness from core EU markets; its small domestic market; excessive product and market regulation; underdeveloped transport and communications infrastructure; a reluctance to allow companies in so-called strategic sectors to be majority foreign-owned; widespread red tape and corruption; and an unstable tax regime. Political factors have sometimes come into play, such as Greece's historically tense relations with Turkey.
Impact
The share of FDI inflows in gross fixed investment in Greece is well below the EU average. Increased foreign participation in privatised or part-privatised companies would boost productivity. In April 2016 Greece sold a majority stake in Piraeus Port Authority, the state-owned company that controls Pier I and the port's cruise, passenger and car terminal operations, to China's Cosco. The sale opens the way for the site to become a major multimodal transhipment hub in the Mediterranean and the most important sea trade gateway into Europe, potentially bringing significant benefits to the economy.
Potential
Greece holds relatively few attractions for FDI in the short term for investors, with the exception of investors specialising in distressed assets. The payoff from structural reforms in terms of increased competitiveness will take years to materialise fully and could yet be reversed in the medium term now that Greece has exited its EU-backed economic adjustment programme. In the medium term the country will offer opportunities for investment in renewable energy and greenfield new technology ventures if red tape continues to be reduced and the reduction in labour costs is maintained. The Economist Intelligence Unit projects average annual FDI inflows of about US$3bn in 2019-23.

Age structure set to change dramatically over long term
According to UN projections, the population will decline slowly in the coming five years, by an average of 0.2% per year in 2019-23. However, life expectancy is increasing, and in 2018 it was estimated to average 81.2 years-broadly in line with the EU28 average of 80.9 (2017). The population structure by age bears all the hallmarks of the demographic ageing process, with a decline in the working-age population and a rise in the elderly population (65 years and older). The proportion of people aged over 65 has been increasing steadily, from 19.2% in 2013 to an estimated 20.6% in 2018, and is forecast to rise to 22.3% in 2023.
The economic impact of an ageing population will be exacerbated to some degree by the continued decline in the working-age population during the forecast period (2019-23), which means that the old-age dependency ratio (the ratio of people aged above 65 to the working-age population) will rise compared with the previous five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that the population of people of working age will decrease by an average of 0.5% per year during 2019-23. The labour force will also decline by 0.2% over the forecast period as a result of young, skilled workers leaving Greece to seek employment opportunities elsewhere and the arrival of fewer economic migrants; this contraction of the labour force is set to happen despite moderately increased participation rates due to a rise in the effective retirement age and an increase in the number of women in work. The labour force participation rate for women is much lower than that for men and one of the lowest in the EU. The gender gap (the difference between the employment rates of men and women of working age (20-64) in Greece was 19.7 percentage points in 2017 (Eurostat), compared with an EU28 average of 11.5 percentage points. The narrowest gap (1 percentage point) was in Lithuania and the widest in Malta (24.1 percentage points). According to the Hellenic Statistical Authority (ELSTAT, the national statistics office), in November 2018 the unemployment rate for males was 14.3%, compared with 23.7% for females. We expect to see a gradual increase in the employment rate for women over the medium and long term.
According to Eurostat, the foreign population of Greece as at January 1st 2018 was 816,100-equivalent to 7.6% of the total population. Of these, 2% of the total population were EU-born and 5.6% were born outside the EU. In June 2015 parliament approved a controversial law granting Greek citizenship to second-generation immigrants. The law is estimated to have affected up to 200,000 people, including those who arrived in the early 1990s as part of the mass exodus from eastern Europe after the fall of communism in 1989. Prior to the new law, children born to migrants to Greece received a "maternity clinic certificate", not a birth certificate, leaving them without proper legal status. As they were not Greek nationals, they were not entitled to the same rights-such as travelling, working and studying within the EU-as EU citizens.
The migrant influx via Turkey and Greece into Europe in 2015-16 posed big challenges for the authorities. About 800,000 migrants arrived in Greece in 2015, according to the office of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees. Of these, about 60% were of Syrian origin, 24% came from Afghanistan and 8% were from Iraq. The closure of the western Balkan migrant route in February 2016 led to about 55,000 migrants becoming trapped in Greece. In March 2016 the Turkey-EU joint action plan stemmed the influx into Greece of migrants arriving from Turkey. However, Greece is vulnerable to another migration upsurge given its extensive and porous land and sea border.
Immigration has become contentious issue
In 2009 a Panhellenic Socialist Movement (Pasok) government passed legislation regarding permanent residence and working rights, in keeping with EU regulations. The law provides complex rules designed to allow non-EU persons legally resident in the country for five years to acquire permanent resident status. Since 2006 all immigration has been linked to employment criteria. A special committee determines available jobs, and these are posted at consulates abroad. Persons wishing to take employment in Greece have to acquire a work permit through the consulate in their home country before arriving. Persons arriving in the country on student or tourist permits are not allowed to change their status and take employment. Those seeking to establish themselves in Greece as self-employed or as entrepreneurs have to fulfil detailed criteria demonstrating their relevant experience and supply evidence of having sufficient funds to support themselves so that they do not become dependent on the state.

Greece is a small, fragmented market of about 11m people, about 12% of whom live on its many islands. As a result, distribution is a problem, which is exacerbated when the population is swollen by large numbers of tourists in the high season. Restrictions will continue to affect the movement of commercial visitors to and from non-EU countries, particularly as Greece is a signatory to the Schengen Agreement, which places tough controls on external borders. Greece has been in the front line of recent mass migration into Europe-mainly from the Middle East and North Africa-that accelerated in 2015. Road and rail development should gradually improve access between Greece and its Balkan neighbours in the coming years, enhancing the country's role as a distribution centre for the southern Balkans, as will development of the ports of Thessaloniki, Kavala and Alexandroupolis.
Market opportunities to pick up but consumer spending power constrained
Over the forecast period (2019-23) market opportunities in Greece will be constrained by consumers' limited spending power. Further budget spending constraints, driven by the need to attain large primary surplus targets, still high unemployment, high taxes, only a partial recovery in wage levels and tight credit conditions will make consumers cautious about spending over the forecast period. GDP per head (at market exchange rates) was an estimated US$19,467 in 2018-well below the EU average. This is forecast to rise to US$23,365 by 2023. This primarily reflects a continued projected recovery in GDP, from a low base, following the prolonged economic crisis after 2007, but also a shrinking population. The booming tourism (and associated real estate) sector, which attracted a record 30m tourists in 2018, (almost triple the population of Greece itself), will continue to boost market opportunities, despite the disappointing projected growth performance of the wider Greek economy.
The after-effects of the depression in 2008-13, the truncated recovery in 2014 and the renewed economic downturn in 2015-16 have reshaped market opportunities considerably. A previous rapid increase in one-person households will decelerate sharply, as the number of single people able to afford their own household will not continue to rise. This will have negative follow-through effects on demand in various consumer goods markets, such as white goods, consumer electronics and furniture. Other consumer durables that relied on a buoyant, debt-fuelled economy for sales growth are also likely to suffer, as low consumer confidence will mean that households will show restraint with regard to big-ticket purchases in the forecast period. Internal migration to the cities will continue, but at a slower rate than previously, as young people abandon farming because of falling EU subsidies and the hope of better employment opportunities in the big cities: Athens (the capital), Thessaloniki and Larissa.

Demand for healthcare and communication services will rise
Food, beverages and tobacco, together with housing, household fuel, and household goods and services, absorbed about 45.8% of consumer expenditure in 2018 and will account for about the same in 2023. Demand for housing and household goods and services will fall slightly as a percentage of GDP compared with other items over the forecast period, in line with the broadly stagnant number of households over the next five years. Non-essential spending will generally also be held back by increased saving efforts by the population, as well as debt-reduction moves. Greater spending power among the immigrant community and population ageing will have important influences on consumption patterns during the forecast period, providing support to demand for communication and healthcare services.

Long-term outlook: The long-term outlook
