The negative effect of ageing will become more pronounced over time
The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that real GDP growth will reach an annual average of 1.3% in 2019-50. We expect annual growth to average 1.8% in 2019-30, slowing to 0.9% in 2031-50. This trajectory reflects the greater negative effect of demographic trends in 2031-50 compared with 2019-30, especially the contraction in the working-age population, which becomes more significant as time goes on. Reasonable total factor productivity and capital stock growth will support a continued economic expansion in 2019-50, offsetting the negative contribution of labour to GDP growth from 2030.
Initial conditions: Several factors will hold back potential long-term GDP growth in Greece. The economy has a number of deep structural flaws that will continue to hinder growth in 2019-30 and 2031-50. In particular, a decline of just under 65% in real fixed investment in 2008-18 will undermine the economy's ability to generate growth over the longer term. Agricultural products, renewable energy, tourism and shipping will remain the principal exports in the long term, but the success of these and other industries will depend on the restoration of competitiveness to the economy inside the euro zone (we are sceptical that a return to competitiveness and catch-up growth can be accomplished as long as Greece retains the euro, hence our forecast that "Grexit" is more likely than not over the long term). A marked deterioration in the demographic profile will result in diminishing opportunities to increase labour utilisation.
Demographic trends: The demographic profile becomes increasingly unfavourable in 2019-50. The working-age population will decline steadily throughout the same period, despite increased immigration. Life expectancy is high, reflecting good living conditions and health standards (at least until recently). The birth rate is set to remain below the replacement level; since 2012 the crude death rate has exceeded the crude birth rate every year. The number of people aged 65 and over will increase from 2.3m now to 2.7m by 2030 and 3.5m by 2050. The number of people of working age will decline from 7.3m to 6.8m and 5.2m over the same periods.
Transport links to neighbours should improve
External conditions: Greece is geographically remote from the EU market, although less so since the EU's expansion to include Bulgaria and Romania in January 2007. Greece will continue with infrastructure projects to improve transport links with the southern Balkan states of Albania, Macedonia and Bulgaria (in part subsidised by the EU). Provided that the Balkan region can improve political and economic stability, better transport links with the countries to the north is expected to help to attract some investment from foreign companies wishing to establish a base in south-east Europe from a more established Western market. We believe that there is a greater than even chance that Greece will leave the euro area over the long term as currency devaluation becomes the preferred method to restore competitiveness. However, even if Greece were to leave the euro area, it would remain a member of the EU.
Greek and EU relations with Turkey will also influence Greece's long-term economic prospects. Relations between Greece and Turkey had been improving since mid-1999, but took a turn for the worse in 2016-18 over the Cyprus question and Greece's failure to extradite alleged coup plotters to Turkey. Relations are set to remain volatile and we do not expect progress in the dispute over Cyprus. The EU opened membership negotiations with Turkey in October 2005. Some large EU member states, such as Germany and France, stalled the talks on technical grounds. Following a deal over migration between the EU and Turkey in April 2016, the stalled negotiation process is meant to get under way once again. Our forecast is that Turkey will not join the EU as it is currently shaped. Even so, we expect trade and investment relations between Greece and Turkey to remain broadly positive.
Political stability will be imperilled by public distrust of all political parties
Institutions and policy trends: Greece has a well-established parliamentary democracy. However, political stability will be undermined by weak govern-ment and the continued erosion of public trust in the mainstream political parties and in Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), which has proved to be a disappointment for many of those who propelled it to power in 2015. A renewed migration surge into Europe along the Balkan route as a result of war and state breakdown in the Middle East could potentially threaten social stability. Institutional effectiveness should improve moderately in 2019-50, but progress will be constrained by pervasive corruption and bureaucratic resistance to change.
Structural reforms to boost competitiveness will be inconsistent and will make a difference only over the longer term. We expect that red tape will be reduced moderately and that the tax system will become more efficient. Labour law has been changed to ease the hiring and firing of workers and to give priority to labour agreements at the company level. In the longer term high public debt and the cost of supporting an ageing population will leave little room for a cut in the overall burden of taxes and social security contributions.
Long-term performance: We expect real GDP to grow at 1.8% per year on average in 2019-30 (2.1% per head). Over 2031-50 average annual GDP growth is forecast to be 0.9% (1.3% per head). Labour productivity growth is expected to average 1.7% per year over the entire long-term forecast period. Scope for a further rise in labour force participation rates will be reduced, and we expect a decline in the working-age population. We expect the labour force to be fairly stable during 2019-30, expanding by 0.06%, but to decline dramatically in 2031-50, by 0.99%, or 0.60% on average in 2019-50.
Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
Climate change is predicted to have significant negative effects on the natural ecosystems of Greece and on many important economic sectors over the long term; for example, it will affect biodiversity, species and habitat, agriculture, forestry, fisheries, tourism, transport, activities in coastal areas and the built environment in urban centres, mainly owing to increased temperature, drought, extreme weather events and rising sea levels. According to specific climate change studies pertaining to Greece, the effects will lead to reductions in productivity, capital losses and additional costs arising from damage repair. According to the Bank of Greece (the central bank), under an inaction ("business as usual") scenario, Greek GDP could fall by an annual 2% by 2050 and 6% by 2100. It states that the total cumulative cost to the Greek economy could reach about EUR700bn (at constant prices of 2008) by 2100. According to our long-term economic model by 2050, climate change will subtract 3.45% from forecast real GDP.
There is thus a clear necessity for the adoption of mitigation and adaptation policies. For example, the tourism and shipping sectors are of vital importance for Greece. The focus is on "Blue Growth", which is a long-term strategy to support integrated sustainable growth in the marine and maritime sectors. The Mediterranean region, where Greece is situated, is bordered by more than 20 countries and a large part of the Mediterranean Sea remains outside national jurisdiction. As a result, co-operation on issues such as climate change and the environment is vital in order to manage maritime activities, tackle climate impacts, protect the marine environment and fight pollution in the Mediterranean Sea region.
Greece adopted its first National Climate Change Programme in 1995; the second was adopted in 2002 and revised in 2007. All three iterations placed great emphasis on achieving a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by changing the fuel mix to include a higher percentage of natural gas and renewable energy sources; improving energy efficiency and conservation in all sectors; making structural changes in agriculture and transport; reducing emissions in waste management; and expanding research and development efforts. In 2016 Greece adopted the National Strategy for Adapting to Climate Change (ESPKA) through Law 4414/2016. According to the strategy, mitigation policies and adaptation should be adopted in all fields, but especially in those of energy, clean technology, industry, biodiversity, agriculture, tourism and transport. The Ministry of Environment and Energy is responsible for identifying potential climate change impacts, planning and co-ordinating adaptation measures and policies, and preparing a national adaptation strategy
Demographic and productivity headwinds
The UN's long-term population projections for Greece, which The Economist Intelligence Unit uses in its long-term growth forecasts, assume a decline in the overall population from an estimated 11.14m in 2018 to 10.78m in 2030 and 9.98m in 2050. Falling fertility rates and continued outward emigration will result in a rapidly shrinking and ageing population. Greece's working-age population is projected to fall from an estimated 7.28m in 2018 to 6.79m in 2030 and to 5.23m in 2050; that is a decline of 28.8% over the 2019-50 period. This is one of the steepest declines in the euro area. We forecast a slightly slower decline in the labour force, of 17.4%, from 4.72m in 2018 to 3.90m in 2050; this assumes an increase in the labour participation rate in the coming decades as the retirement age is raised and more women enter the labour force.
Such adverse demographic projections would imply a severely negative effect on long-term real GDP growth rates. This is especially worrying given Greece's poor historical track record when it comes to productivity growth. To achieve even the modest average annual long-term real GDP growth rate of 1.3% that we forecast for 2019-50 will require significant improvements in employment, labour participation and productivity growth rates, such that Greece has not achieved in recent decades. Over the past 45 years Greece's total factor productivity growth averaged 0.2% per year, and since joining the euro zone in 2001 it has turned negative.
A rebound in investment is likely given the low levels to which it has sunk over the past decade, but this positive effect will not persist over decades. Once the capital stock is replenished, the boost to growth will dissipate and the negative effects of poor demographics and productivity will reassert themselves. The emphasis must therefore be on policies to raise employment rates and boost total factor productivity to avert the disaster of negative average growth rates over the long term. However, the empirical evidence suggests that even the most comprehensive structural reform programme aimed at transforming productivity and the labour market may not deliver the sort of pay-off in terms of growth that is needed.

Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2014-18) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2019-23). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2014-18. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2019-23 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2014-18 ranges are then used to derive 2019-23 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2019-23, not to the likely situation in 2023 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2016 or 2021). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Turkey&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Turkey+February+2019+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2019-02-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Turkey&amp;rft.issn=09668632&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
In June 2018 Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected as president for a second term in snap presidential and parliamentary elections, in which his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a coalition majority with the right-wing Nationalist Action Party (MHP). The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Mr Erdogan and the AKP to remain in power throughout the forecast period (2019-23), and probably beyond.
Following the June 2018 elections, an executive presidency has replaced the former parliamentary system of government. The new system provides few checks on the president's powers, raising the risk of discretionary policymaking.
Since the failed coup in July 2016 there has been a marked deterioration in Turkey's relations with its Western allies. We expect a rupture to be avoided, but tensions will remain high and relations could sour quickly.
Turkey's relationship with the US will continue to be tense. Points of contention include Turkey's perceived pivot towards Iran and Russia and, from Turkey's perspective, the lack of support from the US after the failed coup. A Turkish military intervention against Kurds in Syria would lead to a further deterioration in relations between the US and Turkey.
Turkey's relationship with the EU will remain transactional. Turkey will not make progress with accession talks and is unlikely to manage to renegotiate the terms of its customs union with the EU.
The government's focus on domestic power struggles, economic growth and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate.
We forecast a slowdown in real GDP growth, from 7.3% in 2017 to an average of about 3.6% per year in 2019-23, reflecting the impact of the recent currency crisis, higher interest rates, a difficult business environment and trade tensions.
The lira will depreciate in nominal terms against the US dollar during the forecast period, to about TL6.3:US$1 at end-2023, as a result of negative foreign investor sentiment, high inflation and the large current-account deficit.
As a result of the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar in 2018 (which will boost competitiveness), we forecast that the current-account deficit will shrink in 2019-23, to an annual average of about 3.9% of GDP. Turkey will struggle to meet its high external financing needs throughout the forecast period.

Turkey's score deteriorates only slightly in 2019-23, but in the global rankings the country falls by 11 places, to 59th. The failed coup in 2016 and the government's response have increased the level of uncertainty about the direction of economic policy. Shortcomings include a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Political instability and adverse market conditions will delay further privatisation deals.
2021-23: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in several sectors.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but macroeconomic instability and concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2021-23: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Capital controls are not considered, despite the scale of the currency collapse. Political tensions resulting in tit-for-tat tariffs and US sanctions will disrupt Turkish-US trade and relations.
2021-23: Negotiations with the EU to update the customs union are likely to be protracted, given poor Turkish-EU relations.
Taxes
2019-20: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Tax rises introduced in 2018 to curb the widening of the budget deficit reduce company profits.
2021-23: Income tax base becomes broader as exemptions and exceptions are reduced.
Financing
2019-20: Asset quality likely to deteriorate on the back of financial market turmoil in 2018. Central Bank of Turkey to lower rates gradually as inflation moderates in 2019. Risk of the US imposing fines or sanctions on some Turkish banks.
2021-23: Lending growth to pick up again as banking system regains strength. Continued reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2019-20: Relatively high labour costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment.
2021-23: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2019-20: First phase of third airport in Istanbul becomes operational. Slower progress made on other projects.
2021-23: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. Other major urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks might persist.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Spending on research and development remains moderate, at about 1% of GDP, holding back efforts to move the economy up the value-added ladder.
2021-23: Turkey's young population spurs further rapid digital transformation of the banking sector.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West. The country became a member of the Council of Europe in 1949 and NATO in 1952, and signed an association agreement with the then European Community in 1963. A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but a coup attempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey currently has a presidential system of government, with parliament elected for a five-year term. To win seats, parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the AKP leader, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who was re-elected as president for a second term in June 2018. Following his re-election a presidential system of government was introduced and the post of prime minister was abolished.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability and stabilising the lira following the August 2018 currency crisis are Turkey's biggest policy challenges. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and tightening global liquidity conditions require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy tight to attract adequate capital inflows and slow the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar. The Kurdish issue, which has blocked economic development in the south east, is one of Turkey's most pressing policy challenges, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015, and there has been a resurgence in violence. Politicisation of the judiciary since the coup attempt has undermined its independence. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The corporation tax rate has been raised in 2018, from 20% to 22%. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Reducing tax evasion was one of the elements of previous IMF programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2018 goods exports totalled an estimated US$175bn and imports about US$216bn, creating an estimated trade deficit of about US$41.3bn and a current-account deficit in the region of US$28bn (or 3.6% of GDP). The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
In June 2018 Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected for a second term in the first round of a snap presidential election. On the same day his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a parliamentary coalition majority with its right-wing ally, the Nationalist Action Party (MHP). The election process appeared mostly free, but largely unfair. Opposition candidates received little or no media coverage; the pro-Kurdish Peoples' Democratic Party (HDP) candidate, Selahattin Demirtas, had to campaign from prison; and the government restrained freedom of speech and freedom of association. Mr Erdogan secured a majority of the vote after a high turnout. Results published by opposition observers were similar to those announced by the government.
Mr Erdogan's re-election concluded Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. This move was initiated with a constitutional referendum in April 2017, which the government narrowly won. The new system grants the president wide-ranging executive powers-including the selection of most of the officials in the judiciary-and will greatly weaken parliament. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the AKP and Mr Erdogan, who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in July 2016, to remain in power until 2023, and probably beyond.
Mr Erdogan will continue to restrict political dissent and stifle the opposition. Despite allowing the state of emergency to expire on July 18th 2018, parliament passed a security law on July 25th that imposes stringent barriers on freedoms.
Security risk remains high, as Turkey appears vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and the Islamic State (IS). Neither the government nor the PKK is interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will return to 1990s levels. The fact that the ruling coalition is made up of the AKP and the MHP will hinder attempts to resolve the Kurdish issue, as the nationalist-minded MHP is pushing for hawkish policies aimed at constraining and delegitimising the HDP.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Parliamentary and presidential elections were held in June 2018 (they had originally been scheduled for late 2019). Mr Erdogan was re-elected as president in the first round, securing 52.6% of the vote with a turnout of 86.2%. In the parliamentary election the AKP lost its absolute majority (although it secured a coalition majority alongside its partner, the MHP), as the HDP managed to poll more than the 10% threshold needed to enter parliament.
Local elections are planned for the end of March this year. In order to raise levels of support for the AKP ahead of the elections, the government has implemented a number of expansionary fiscal measures. We continue to expect the AKP to emerge unscathed from the local elections, retaining control of the two largest cities-Istanbul and the capital, Ankara.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Domestic political and security issues will continue to shape Turkey's actions in the foreign-policy sphere. Although not our core forecast, there is a risk of a rupture in the country's ties with its traditional Western allies. Many factors have contributed to the deterioration in relations, including a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey after the failed coup; US military backing for PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurdish groups (although this may change in 2019); Turkey's forging of closer relations with China, Russia and Iran; tensions with Cyprus about the delimitation of the two countries' exclusive economic zones in the Mediterranean; and US sanctions on Turkish officials due to Turkey's detention of Andrew Brunson, a US pastor, on terrorism charges (sanctions were lifted after Mr Brunson was released in October).
Turkey's relations with the EU and the US are likely to remain antagonistic and transactional rather than strategic. However, we expect Turkey and its Western allies to avoid a breakdown in relations, as Turkey, and the EU, have a common interest in handling refugee inflows from Syria and Iraq. However, EU-Turkey relations would deteriorate quickly if the EU was to suspend Turkey's moribund accession negotiations, or if Turkey re-imposed the death penalty, closed the Incirlik air base to NATO forces or withdrew from NATO (none of which are our core forecast).
Turkey's military operations in Syria seek to block the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds affiliated with the PKK, but risk fuelling the conflict with the PKK in south-east Turkey. In December 2018 the US announced that it would withdraw troops from Syria. For Turkey, the US withdrawal represents an invitation to press ahead with plans to extend its border zone within Syria eastwards. Turkey controls most of the territory across the border region from the Mediterranean to the Euphrates River. The country is also planning another military operation against Kurdish forces to the east of the Euphrates, although Mr Erdogan has delayed the offensive for fear of US retaliation. With a Turkish offensive in the pipeline, the Kurds are likely to step up negotiations with the Syrian regime on a political settlement in order to avoid a situation in which they could be surrounded by enemies and without US support.
Turkey is also preoccupied with the situation in Idlib, a rebel-held city in northern Syria. An agreement between Turkey, Russia and Iran in September 2018 forestalled a long-anticipated regime offensive against Idlib, which is controlled by Islamist rebel groups, the most powerful of which is Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS). The agreement centres around the creation of a buffer zone around Idlib, in which Turkish forces are deployed as monitors. HTS has refused to endorse the agreement, but has stopped short of violating it. Turkey is seeking to persuade core factions of HTS to integrate with the other rebel groups and to reaffirm their rejection of the global jihadi mission of al-Qaida. If integration occurs, a significant block of Turkish-allied rebel groups could potentially be involved in the negotiations for a political settlement. The success of Turkey's machinations in Idlib is far from guaranteed, and it remains unlikely that HTS will give up its long-standing cause and join Turkish forces.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
The government's past focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. Nonetheless, Turkey's economy has shown resilience during previous bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing to its solid public finances, its well-capitalised banking sector, and its dynamic and diversified private sector.
The heavily pro-growth approach to economic policymaking that Mr Erdogan has espoused enthusiastically throughout the past decade will persist during our forecast period (2019-23), at the expense of inflation control and fiscal discipline. This approach will continue to have a significant effect on, for example, monetary policy, macroprudential regulation, public-private capital investments and social spending. Shortcomings such as cronyism and corruption, skills mismatches (a major factor behind the high unemployment rate), and tax evasion are unlikely to be addressed in 2019-23, as propping up economic growth-partly to avoid social unrest-will remain the priority.
In the case of a severe economic or banking crisis (not our core forecast), Turkey's options would remain limited, as Gulf Co-operation Council (GCC) countries appear unwilling to offer financial support. This is because Turkey is forging closer ties with Iran, a country with which Saudi Arabia has tensions with. Turkey's ties with Saudi Arabia deteriorated (from an already low base) after Jamal Khashoggi, a Saudi journalist, was murdered in the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, Turkey's largest city, in October 2018. Furthermore, any potential IMF programme would include a level of foreign involvement that the government would be likely to view as unacceptable, and that would run counter to Mr Erdogan's nationalist, anti-Western rhetoric. There is little prospect of EU financial assistance, not least because there would be no consensus on this issue among EU member states. Only China, therefore, appears able at present to offer a financial lifeline to Turkey. Such assistance could come as part of China's Belt and Road Initiative, which seeks to boost transport infrastructure between Asia and Europe to foster trade, as well as connectivity.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
The public finances have traditionally been one of the Turkish economy's most reassuring aspects. Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios reflect the positive impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past.
Despite several tax rises in 2018 and official promises of budgetary tightening, higher government spending on defence, security, infrastructure, public employment and social benefits caused the deficit to widen in 2018-to an estimated 1.9% of GDP, from 1.5% in 2017.
In 2019-23 we expect a cautious approach to on-balance-sheet fiscal policy. This, alongside a recovering economy, will cause the deficit to narrow gradually, from a forecast 2.3% in 2019 to 1.6% of GDP in 2023.
We expect the central government debt/GDP ratio to have remained broadly stable, at 28.6% of GDP in 2018 (from 28.3% in 2017), despite economic turmoil following the August currency crisis and various government handouts ahead of the June 2018 elections. The ratio will decline slightly, to 25.8% by end-2023 as macroeconomic conditions normalise and the budget deficit shrinks.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
In September 2018 the Central Bank of Turkey's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) raised its main policy rate, the one-week repo (repurchase agreement) lending rate, to 24%, from 17.75% previously. The MPC's decision was a response to the lira's sharp depreciation against the US dollar in August, as well as to the record rise in annual consumer price inflation. The average cost of central bank funding is likely to be above the main policy rate, however. The bank retains the option of providing some of its funding for the banking system at its overnight lending rates, which are 1.5-3% higher than the one-week repo rate.
We expect the central bank to keep monetary policy tight in the first half of 2019. From mid-2019 to 2020 the central bank will gradually lower its policy rate in response to declining inflationary pressures and a normalisation of financial market conditions. In 2021-23 we believe that it will miss its inflation target of 5%. This reflects the government's continued pro-growth stance; it will put pressure on the bank to keep nominal rates below what would credibly be required to lower inflation to the 5% target.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
Real GDP growth accelerated sharply in 2017, to 7.3% (from 3.3% in 2016), supported by government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit, improved export competitiveness and a pick-up in global demand. However, the surge in economic growth exacerbated internal and external imbalances. These imbalances-coupled with heightened policy unpredictability, foreign investors' concerns regarding the independence of the central bank, reliance on short-term capital inflows, a rising interest rate environment in advanced economies and a diplomatic spat with the US-contributed to the lira losing about 40% of its value against the US dollar in January-August 2018. The sharp depreciation of the lira caused consumer price inflation to accelerate from already high rates, increased input costs for corporations and raised the debt-servicing costs of foreign-currency-denominated liabilities. Higher domestic interest rates and rising risk premiums further dent the economic outlook.
High-frequency indicators for October-December 2018 (latest available data) suggest that the economy stalled in the wake of the currency crisis. After quarterly growth of 0.3% in the second quarter of 2018, GDP contracted in the third quarter, by 1.6%. We expect negative quarterly growth readings in the last quarter of 2018 and the first quarter of 2019, with activity starting to pick up in the second quarter of 2019. As a result, we believe that growth decelerated to 3.1% in 2018 and that GDP will grow only slightly in 2019, by 1.1% (mainly owing to base effects).
In 2020 we expect growth to rebound to 5% as the economy recovers and spare capacity is depleted. In 2021-23 economic growth will average about 3.9% per year, in line with the economy's forecast potential growth rate. There are substantial downside risks to our forecasts; these growth profiles do not reflect the possible impact of a severe banking crisis (not our core scenario), although we expect non-performing loans to rise and credit availability to be impaired in the coming quarters.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
In full-year 2018 the currency crisis and rising global commodity prices have driven inflation higher, to 16.3% (from 11.1% in 2017). In 2019 inflation will remain elevated in the first half of the year and then moderate gradually on the back of a limited depreciation of the lira (against the US dollar), a decline in global oil prices and the emergence of spare capacity in the economy. Accommodative fiscal policies in response to the economic weakness in the final months of 2018 will prevent inflation from declining faster than otherwise. On average, we forecast inflation of 15.5% in 2019-only marginally lower than the 2018 rate.
The moderating trend in inflation will continue in 2020, with an average inflation rate of 9.1% as global oil prices continue to decline (owing to a slowdown in the global economy, with the US entering a technical recession) and the exchange rate depreciates slightly (in nominal terms) against the US dollar. In 2021-23 we expect inflation to stabilise at an annual average of about 7.2%-still more than the central bank's medium-term target of 5%. Economic growth in these years will be close to the economy's potential growth rate (limiting upward inflationary pressures).
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
In 2018 the lira depreciated by 24.5% on average against the US dollar (in nominal terms). The lira depreciated significantly in January-August, with the exchange rate briefly reaching a low point of TL7.2:US$1 on August 13th. After a substantial recovery from September, the lira remained broadly stable against the US dollar for the remainder of the year. This was owing to the decrease in tensions between the US and Turkey, the sharp reduction in the current-account deficit (a direct result of the currency depreciation) and the tight monetary policy stance of the central bank.
In the first weeks of 2019 the lira exchange rate has remained at about TL5.30:US$1. We forecast that the lira will continue to depreciate in the coming quarters against the dollar, albeit at a much more moderate pace than in 2018. A normalising economic and financial domestic situation will support the exchange rate. However, there will be an increase in global risk aversion as the effects of the US-China bilateral trade war are fully felt and the cooling of the global economy causes expectations of a recession in some advanced economies to build. Consequently, we expect an average exchange rate of TL5.66:US$1 in 2019.
In 2020 we expect the exchange rate to remain broadly stable as the economy starts to grow more markedly and as global risk aversion does not increase further. A widening current-account deficit will keep downward pressures on the value of the currency. Thereafter, in 2021-23 still elevated inflation and a significant current-account deficit (although not as large as that in 2017) will result in a gradual depreciation of the lira against the US dollar in nominal terms, to TL6.3:US$1 by the end of 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The current-account deficit as a share of GDP narrowed in 2018, to an estimated 3.6%, from 5.6% in 2017, as the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar depressed imports (owing to a deceleration in domestic demand) and boosted export competitiveness.
In 2019-23 we expect an average annual current-account deficit of 3.9% of GDP. The slightly higher deficit reflects an increase in economic growth momentum in these years. However, it remains contained (by historical standards) owing to significant gains in competitiveness from the 2018 currency crisis that will boost exports and limit import growth throughout the medium term.

[...]we expect limited real investment inflows, the vast majority going into the oil sector, which will restrict economic recovery and fuel continued unrest. Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The head of the ruling regime, Nicolás Maduro, and his party, the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), are under intense political and economic pressure. Under The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast, we expect regime pragmatists to oust Mr Maduro and form a government with Juan Guaidó, the opposition leader who has declared himself interim president and who is openly offering regime pragmatists a series of benefits (amnesty, international financing, a transitional government, lifting of sanctions) that Mr Maduro can no longer credibly promise. There is a risk that the existing regime will retain cohesion and cling to power beyond 2019 if it finds financing to meet its debt obligations and boost dwindling oil production.
Following years-long economic collapse, GDP will continue to contract in 2019-20. High inflation has led to a collapse in private consumption, and difficult operating conditions have hurt investment. Following a change in policy under a new government, we expect economic growth to resume in 2021.
The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. Following our forecast transition this year, a new government will stabilise the economy, but the wholesale rethink of the institutional framework needed to restore investment and confidence is unlikely.
The recession that began in 2014 has evolved into a hyperinflationary crisis and will continue to deepen in the short term. The economy will not return to growth until 2021-assuming that a new government takes power and implements reforms. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, reinforcing our forecasts of only a weak recovery.
US dollar measurements of Venezuela's market size provide an overly positive picture of the economy, given the marked overvaluation of the fixed exchange rate. In reality, recession and extremely high inflation (driven by shortages of foreign exchange and basic goods) will continue to restrict purchasing power. After 2020, under a new government, we expect purchasing power and the business environment to improve.

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Venezuela is in 82nd position globally in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings for 2019-23, the worst position in our ranking. This reflects the highly heterodox macroeconomic policies of an authoritarian government, a lack of legal security and weak institutions.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Start of rollback of interventionist measures like price controls, but political-instability concerns slow liberalisation. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and undermine free competition.
2021-23: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Regulation by new government protecting property rights introduced in an attempt at attracting investment.
2021-23: Despite efforts, actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2019-20: Currency controls are made less opaque but restrictions on the private sector's access to foreign currency remain in place.
2021-23: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2019-20: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2021-23: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2019-20: Inflation remains high and concerns about economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2021-23: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2019-20: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. The current freeze on redundancies is fazed-out
2021-23: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Underinvestment in the water network and electricity grid ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2021-23: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued water and electricity rationing.
Technological readiness
2019-20: E-government services remain almost non-existent and deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment.
2021-23: Limited regulator capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has plummeted as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices has plunged the country into a massive economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded republican institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and side-lining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy mired in a years-long economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. At the same time, mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign-exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Using IMF data, The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$21.1bn in 2017 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages. We estimate the current-account surplus at 2.3% of GDP that year.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
The civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), is under huge economic and political pressure. The Economist Intelligence Unit continues to expect that a national unity government composed of opposition and regime "pragmatists" will form a transitional administration in 2019. The transition process, however, remains extremely uncertain, and we expect the entire forecast period (2019-23) to be characterised by political instability.
On January 23rd the president of the opposition-controlled National Assembly, Juan Guaidó, declared himself interim president, days after Mr Maduro started a controversial new term, and was swiftly recognised by many nations as the legitimate president of Venezuela. Mr Guaidó's move has re-energised a disillusioned population, allowing him to convoke massive demonstrations, sowing concerns among regime members of country-wide unrest at a time when dissatisfaction within the military's lower ranks is at an all-time high. More crucially, Mr Guaidó secured US sanctions on oil trade conducted by PDVSA, the state-owned oil company. The US previously imported some 500,000 barrels/day (b/d), around half of all Venezuelan exports, and was PDVSA's largest cash-paying client. In addition, it was a key source of diluents required to process Venezuela's extra-heavy crude. We expect that PDVSA will be able to re-direct part of its production and find new sources of diluents, limiting the overall drop in output. However, the exports will have lower profit margins, meaning a severe blow to the patronage flows underpinning the regime's internal stability.
Mr Guaidó is presenting his leadership as a path to a relatively easy way out of the current political and economic quagmire for dissatisfied regime members. He has repeatedly called for the military to depose Mr Maduro, offering the lifting of oil sanctions, the arrival of international aid and financing, and amnesty for defectors. Overall, considering that the regime's raison d'etre is the enrichment of its members, which Mr Maduro can no longer guarantee, we expect that pragmatists within the regime will eventually side-line or expel hardliners in exchange for influence in Mr Guaidó's more prosperous government.
Although a Guaidó-led transition government is our baseline forecast, questions remain. At present it is unclear how much power the opposition would have in a power-sharing transitional government. Once in place, such an administration would face considerable hurdles. If the opposition cannot deliver on its promises quickly enough, the government could well collapse. Even if short-term stability is secured, political stability will remain at risk, given the challenging tasks ahead. These include securing debt relief; rebuilding the rule of law; and attracting tens of billions of dollars in foreign investment (not only in oil but in all sectors of the economy). Through all this, the opposition would need to be careful to not upset its partners. Most of the opposition's economic rationalisation plans require reforms that eliminate the economy's distortions, closing the avenues for corruption and enrichment that regime members have used for years.
Three key assumptions underpin our baseline view. Firstly, and foremost, that regime pragmatists have enough power to overpower hardliners who would rather rule a ruined country than share a prosperous one. Years of economic malaise and failed dialogues have been insufficient to prompt regime change in itself, and the military-a key powerbroker-remains behind Mr Maduro despite repeated rumours to the contrary. Secondly, that regime members deem Mr Guaidó's amnesty and transitional government offers credible. Risks to this assumption include a deep-seated distrust of the opposition and fear of being prosecuted outside of Venezuela (a credible fear given accusations of drug- and weapon trafficking levied at regime members). The third assumption underpinning our forecast for a unity government is a continued lack of hard-currency to sustain the patronage system. The main risk to this assumption comes from the possibility that Russia or China, erstwhile financiers, would bail out the regime. This is not our baseline forecast, but Venezuela's oil wealth remains a draw-especially if sold off at low prices by a bankrupt regime. Another risk to our assumptions around the regime's access to hard currency centres on transnational crime and the informal export of precious metals, and whether these enterprises could be enough to make up the lost revenue from oil exports.
Given the strong risks to our baseline view, there are several alternate scenarios for Venezuela's political environment, with varying probabilities. Our main alternate scenarios are (in order of likelihood): although Mr Maduro's days seem numbered, a continuation of the PSUV's authoritarian rule could continue with more political repression, emigration, economic isolation and support from the likes of China; a complete collapse of the regime followed by a transitional government that does not include current regime members (decisive US military intervention would increase this scenario's chances); or prolonged chaos-including, possibly, armed conflict-if divisions within the regime become clearer but no faction gains outright control of the state apparatus across the country. All of these outcomes, like our baseline forecast, would be characterised by extremely high levels of political instability.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
The opposition's recently announced plans for a transitional government call for the renovation of all electoral authorities and for elections within 12 months of the transitional government's formation. As we currently expect such a government to coalesce within 2019, we expect elections at some point in 2020. International assistance in organising the elections would be necessary and forthcoming.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Mr Guaidó has marshalled hitherto unexpected levels of support from the international community. Most governments in the Americas, under the banner of the Lima Group, have recognised Mr Guaidó. A similar stance, but stressing the need for immediate elections, has been adopted by most of Europe. The US is Mr Guaidó's most committed champion, instituting crippling oil sanctions and openly calling for the military to accept Mr Guaidó in place of Mr Maduro. We had expected US sanctions on oil to be progressive, but instead, the hawkish US policy team instituted full sanctions directly. This introduces risks of a military intervention. We currently do not foresee large-scale military action but smaller-scale interventions, such as targeted bombings, have become a possibility, especially given that the US no longer has substantial economic sanctions to throw at the regime, although such action is not included in our baseline forecasts.
Russia and China seem unwilling to provide the necessary financing-amounting to tens of billions of dollars per year-to stabilise the economy and PDVSA. Mr Maduro has openly courted the two countries, but with little apparent success in actual investment. Neither country seems willing to antagonise the US too much, as they are both at sensitive points in their relations with the US. Russia is dealing with sanctions, while China is involved in difficult trade negotiations. Instead, we believe both Russia and China will be willing to work with a successor government in an attempt at protecting their current investments in Venezuela.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Our expectation of a change of government in 2019 implies huge changes to economic policymaking as a new administration works to end hyperinflation, restructure public debt, and rebuild institutions to help restore confidence in rule of law and promote investment. But until then we foresee no fundamental change in policy by the Maduro regime, which remains technically unable and politically unwilling to undertake the deep and wide-ranging policy and institutional changes needed. Monetisation of large public deficits, coupled with mismanagement of the state-dominated oil industry, has led to hyperinflation and shortages of foreign currency, basic goods and industrial inputs. The regime's latest plan to tackle these issues, launched in late August, was self-defeating, and the PSUV government has not complied with the cornerstone promise of abolishing the monetisation of public deficits. As such, imbalances will persist and foreign exchange will continue to be rationed.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect that more orthodox economic policies will be implemented under the transition and successor governments. However, the pace and depth of the adjustment will be constrained by uncertainty over the stability of any new administration, and whether this takes precedence over the likely demands for reform from multilateral and bilateral lenders. Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and multilaterals (totalling US$19bn in 2019-22) and the restructuring of the government's debt obligations. This in itself will be a huge task for any administration. At the same time, PDVSA will need wholesale reform to open itself to the foreign finance needed to increase output, a process that will require considerable political capital.
Pockets of resistance are likely to exist. Internal stability within the PSUV is a major risk to our forecast, as the success of any government will depend on PSUV pragmatists fending off more radical party members. These hardliners would oppose international assistance, foreign investment and policy reforms on both ideological and personal grounds (as many regime insiders profit from the state's indirect and direct control of the economy).
Outside of these areas, we do not expect much success in rolling back the PSUV's strong interventionist bent in the economy. Thus, we expect limited real investment inflows, the vast majority going into the oil sector, which will restrict economic recovery and fuel continued unrest.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
Authorities have not published complete official data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We estimate that the fiscal deficit is well into double figures as a percentage of GDP. The government relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency.
High inflation and the overvalued official exchange rate make debt/GDP ratios misleading indicators of fiscal stability. Considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) understates the true size of total public liabilities. Most sovereign and state-owned bonds (including PDVSA's) are in arrears. Bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy changes or a change in government. The exceptions to arrears are debts that threaten Citgo (PDVSA's US subsidiary) and leased facilities in the Caribbean. So far, Venezuela has taken a defensive stance, treating each claim individually and stalling as much as possible before complying when seizures seem imminent. Given PDVSA's extremely strained financial situation and the lack of further sources of financing, the strategy does not seem sustainable.
In this uncertain context, Citgo is in limbo. Following the January 28th sanctions, the US government considers Citgo to be under Mr Guaidó's purview, but it is unclear how much power Mr Guaidó will have over the company. The regime now has little incentive to defend Citgo from creditors, and it is also it is unclear if creditors could even claim it. PDVSA's strained financial situation means that the risk of default and seizure on Citgo, its Caribbean facilities and even shipments will remain high in the short term. Stalling tactics (including partial compliance with payments) will continue.
Under our baseline forecast, we expect a restructuring with external creditors in 2020. Owing to the need to maintain political stability, we do not expect the closure of the various handout programmes in operation, nor the complete removal of utility subsidies or the reformation of inefficient state-owned firms. Therefore, we expect public expenditure to be hard to reduce; the deficit will be substantial throughout the 2019-23 period.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The government's financing needs will continue to force the Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank) to print money. Money supply (M2) continues to grow rapidly, expanding by 75% month on month at end-January. We expect a new administration to place a much greater emphasis on tackling hyperinflation and expect a substantial monetary adjustment in the context of a macroeconomic stabilisation plan. The introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) in such a context is highly likely.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 15% in 2018, we expect further contractions in 2019-20. A forecast recovery in 2021-23 rests on the assumption of a political transition that, supported by international assistance, produces a credible macroeconomic programme with improved management of oil wealth. However, reform will be limited in scope by a weak government, and we expect only a partial rebound in real GDP, following a decline of around 50% in 2013-20.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2019, reflecting the effect on real wages of hyperinflation, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will also contract, reflecting difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange. Our forecast for a recovery in investment later in the forecast period assumes a political transition and a pick-up in oil investment.
We expect oil output to bottom out at 950,000 b/d in mid-2019, kept from going lower by PDVSA's joint-venture partners. But until US sanctions on oil are lifted, margins will be smaller, as PDVSA has lost access to its closest and better-paying market. Under our baseline forecast of openness to foreign investment under a new government from 2019, production will start to recover in 2020 but will end the forecast period (2023) well below 2m b/d, the average output in 2017.
Export volumes will only start to recover in 2020, as an increase in domestic demand, which has been artificially constrained, will initially absorb the increase in oil output. For the same reason, import demand will rise sharply in 2019.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Decimated domestic supply, severe limits on imports and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official data have not been published since 2015, but the opposition-led National Assembly estimated that monthly inflation was 142% in December. In the context of a macroeconomic stabilisation plan in 2019, we expect much tighter monetary policy and lower inflation. However, supply bottlenecks and bouts of inflationary pressure are likely.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
Under our current baseline forecast, the introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) amid deep imbalances and as a means to try to tackle hyperinflation is possible in 2019. The exact nature and implementation of such moves are hard to foresee, but our baseline forecast includes the continuation of some currency controls for the duration of the forecast period.
Since the start of 2018, the government has repeatedly devaluated the currency and promised liberalisation of exchange controls. The official rate is determined by an auction process, but the government-which monopolises the country's exports-does not supply the system with foreign-exchange, making the system unsustainable and access to foreign exchange practically impossible. In early February, following a string of devaluations, the official rate stood at BsS3200:US$1, roughly in line with the black market rate.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
We expect a current-account surplus of US$600m in 2019. The surplus is buoyed by non-payment of interest on bonded debt ("savings" in excess of US$5bn in 2019 alone). Our export data, which are based on IMF data, may overstate receipts, as some exports are actually payments in-kind for loans, the repayment of which may not be included in their totality under forecast interest repayments (we have excluded repayments to Chinese lenders to maintain consistency with the World Bank's data on which our debt forecasts are based).
By 2020, with a new government in power, we expect that-following debt renegotiation-external financing will be restored. Although we expect exports to grow as oil production increases, we also expect a surge in imports, as Venezuela's own productive base has been decimated and imports have been compressed to artificially low levels. In addition, the government will be complying with its debt obligations, meaning that the restructured debt will actually result in increased outflows in interest payments. These factors will erode the current-account surplus to a deficit of 2.1% of GDP in 2023.
We currently expect that a new administration will secure enough finance to stabilise the balance-of-payments dynamics. However, there are considerable risks to this rosy outlook. In addition to assuming the installation of a pragmatic transition administration capable of retaining power, it hinges on substantial finance from the IMF, the quick implementation of a successful macroeconomic stabilisation package, the fast resolution of a debt renegotiation process in 2019-20, substantial inflows of financial and real investment into the economy in 2020-23, and a fast recovery in oil output after years of underinvestment and mismanagement.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
BCV: Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics
