Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The government, led by Alexis Tsipras of the Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), is likely to hobble along for just a few more months following the departure of the nationalist Independent Greeks (AE) from the coalition regarding the Macedonia name change deal, which the Greek parliament ratified on January 25th. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects political instability to increase ahead of a busy electoral cycle in 2019, further weakening Greece's governance and its commitment to political and economic reform.
We forecast that an early election will be held before the end of the parliamentary term in October 2019, possibly in conjunction with the European Parliament and the local elections in May. We expect the centre-right New Democracy (ND) to win the most seats and to form a government. However, it would probably have to secure the support of at least one other party to muster a parliamentary majority.
Greece will remain subject to strict policy conditionality in the medium term, until its debt to its international creditors is substantially reduced. Protests are likely to continue as the government strives to meet ambitious annual primary surplus budget targets of 3.5% of GDP until 2022 and 2.2% from 2023, as agreed with Greece's international creditors. Mr Tsipras's promises to lower taxes and reverse spending cuts could cause tensions with the EU and investors.
Greece is facing its biggest macroeconomic challenge now that it has exited the bail-out programme and no longer has access to official borrowing at preferential interest rates. However, Greece will not face short-term financing difficulties, as it will have sufficient funds to cover its debt repayments until the end of 2020. A Greek exit from the euro zone represents a risk over the long term.
We expect that real GDP growth will pick up from 1.4% in 2017 to a moderate 2% per year on average in 2018-23. Public debt is forecast to continue to exceed 175% of GDP in 2023. Meeting large primary surplus targets and restoring competitiveness will prove to be difficult.
Inflation is forecast to rise only slightly, from 0.8% in 2018 to 0.9% in 2019 and 1% in 2020, reflecting moderate domestic demand growth and lower global energy prices. In 2021-23 we expect oil prices to rise again, pushing up inflation to 1.5% per year. We expect still moderate current-account deficits in 2018-23.

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Greece's score recovers modestly in our forecast period (2019-23), from a low base. The main areas of improvement are expected to be in the macroeconomic environment, as a result of efforts to improve policy towards foreign investment, private enterprise and competition, and the labour market.
Country forecast overview: Greece's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The country's privatisation agency (under new management) gains momentum, unblocking some delayed deals.
2021-23: Efforts to valorise public property through concession management and long-leasehold development agreements.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: The Investment Incentives Law of 2016 offers more tax relief and fewer subsidies, and focuses predominantly on small firms. Plans to cut down on bureaucracy make little progress.
2021-23: "Fast-track" legislation could become more important if the economy normalises. It will cover "strategic" investments in energy, tourism, transport, communications and health.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Remaining capital controls introduced in June 2015 are eliminated. Capital buffer of about EUR26bn sufficient to cover almost two years of the government's medium- and long-term financing needs.
2021-23: There is a significant risk of Greece leaving the euro zone in the long term if growth continues to disappoint. Grexit would probably result in the reintroduction of foreign-exchange controls and possibly restrictions on trade.
Taxes
2019-20: Extensive efforts to widen the tax base. Government pledges to pursue aggressive tax collection, but implementation is difficult. Indirect taxes increase. Mandatory introduction of electronic point of sale terminals helps.
2021-23: Limited progress in cutting corporate income tax or value-added tax (VAT). Measures to tackle tax evasion stepped up. Independence of tax authority remains in doubt.
Financing
2019-20: Liquidity tight. Uncertainty constrains lending capacity. Steps to reduce non-performing loans (NPLs) are slow, but foreign interest picks up. A moratorium on foreclosures is lifted for the majority of debtors.
2021-23: The need to increase provisions for still high NPLs hampers lending. More Greek bank foreign subsidiaries are sold off.
The labour market
2019-20: Labour market reforms now mostly passed, but implementation is problematic. Unemployment remains high.
2021-23: EU funded job-creation schemes, particularly for youth, raise employment, but create few productive jobs.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Energy infrastructure comes to the fore as Trans-Adriatic Pipeline (TAP) nears completion. Privatisations pick up pace.
2021-23: Technical assistance from the EU helps absorption of European funds to revive infrastructure investment.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Greece rolls out high-speed internet, at a slow pace. The private sector adopts electronic payments by law.
2021-23: Significant financial and technical assistance from the EU, but Greece remains a laggard.

Background: After 400 years of Ottoman rule Greece emerged as a sovereign state in 1830. A devastating civil war followed the retreat of German occupying forces in 1944. A military junta ruled the country from 1967 to 1974, but since then a democracy has been in place. In 1981 Greece joined the European Economic Community, now the EU. It became a member of the economic and monetary union (EMU) in 2001, but its public finances became unsustainable, resulting in a sovereign debt crisis in 2009-10. Greece's public debt has put its continued membership of the EMU into question.
Political structure: Greece is a parliamentary republic, with deputies elected for four-year terms. The prime minister and the government hold executive powers. The president is elected by the 300-member parliament for a five-year term. The government requires the support of parliament to hold office. Since the 2010 crisis the traditional party system has broken down. Voters blamed the parties that ruled Greece after the return of democracy in the mid-1970s-New Democracy (ND) and the Panhellenic Socialist Movement (Pasok)-for causing the crisis, which led to the imposition of painful austerity by the country's external creditors. The result has been political fragmentation and the rise of populist parties such as the left-wing Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), which came to power in 2015, and far-right parties such as the neo-fascist Golden Dawn (XA).
Policy issues: The ND-Pasok government of 2012-14, like its two predecessors, imposed draconian austerity packages. It also enacted fiscal and some structural economic reforms to meet the conditions of two EU-IMF bail-out packages, totalling EUR240bn. Implementation proved difficult and ultimately brought down the government. After a seven-month confrontation with Greece's creditors, the Syriza-led government negotiated a new three-year European Stability Mechanism (ESM) programme in August 2015. In 2012 Greece restructured its public debt, reducing the value of private-sector creditors' holdings by EUR107bn. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any further debt write-down. Now that Greece has exited the programme, it is subject to an "enhanced supervision" monitoring regime by its euro zone creditors.
Taxation: The tax rate on corporate profits is 29% and on distributed dividends is 10%. The top marginal personal income tax rate is 45% for income of more than EUR40,000. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at rates of 24%, 13% and 6%.
Foreign trade: In 2017 goods exports (fob) were worth EUR28bn and imports (fob) amounted to EUR47.9bn. The current account registered a deficit of EUR3.2bn, equivalent to 1.8% of GDP.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
Political instability has intensified owing to the agreement with Macedonia to change that country's name to the Republic of North Macedonia, which the Greek parliament ratified on January 25th. This is likely to lead to a further weakening of the country's governance and its commitment to political and economic reform ahead of Greece's busy 2019 electoral cycle. Local and European Parliament elections are scheduled for May, and the general election is due by October, but The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the general election to be called early, possibly in conjunction with the elections in May. In early January the small, right-wing nationalist Independent Greeks (AE) dropped out of the coalition government in protest against the Macedonia name change deal. The government is led by the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, of the Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza). Syriza has just 145 seats in the 300-seat parliament, but, with the help of members of the opposition and AE defectors, the government survived a vote of confidence on January 16th and managed get the Macedonia agreement through parliament. We expect the Syriza minority government to attempt to pass legislation aimed at boosting its electoral support in the coming months, but it is unlikely to survive more than a few months.
In August 2018, after eight years of austerity and unpopular reforms under three economic adjustment programmes, Greece exited the third bail-out programme signed by the Syriza-led government in 2015. During his period in power Mr Tsipras has lost much popular support and will struggle to revive his party's political fortunes before the next election, although Syriza may receive a boost in popularity, as the European Commission has accepted the government's plan to cancel agreed pension cuts in 2019 on the grounds that the cuts will not be needed to achieve the country's fiscal targets (a 3.5% primary surplus in 2018-22). We remain sceptical that real GDP growth will rise much higher than 2% during the 2019-23 forecast period, and expect that failure to implement other structural reforms agreed with Greece's international creditors could lead to delays in the implementation of the debt-relief measures agreed with Greece's EU creditors.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Syriza trails the centre-right New Democracy (ND), led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis, in opinion polls; the gap has exceeded 10 percentage points for some time. ND's lead may narrow during the election campaign, as Mr Tsipras is a formidable campaigner and there is little overt enthusiasm for Mr Mitsotakis or his party. However, given widespread popular disaffection with the Syriza government, which is likely to have increased owing to the Macedonia name change deal, the election-due by October 2019-is ND's to lose. If, as we expect, ND wins the largest share of the vote, it would benefit from the 50-seat bonus rule for the winning party. Even so, it would probably have to secure the support of at least one other party to muster a parliamentary majority.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Domestic political instability and protracted economic and financial crises have limited Greece's influence in the EU and the Balkans region. Recent government efforts to restore influence, including the Macedonia name change deal and talks on closer co-operation with the US, are fraught with difficulty, as domestic pre-election tension is likely to condition foreign policy decisions. Ratification of the name change agreement aims to end Greece's opposition to Macedonia's accession to NATO and its application for EU membership, but the leader of ND has said that if elected his government would seek to renegotiate the deal.
Tensions between Greece and Turkey have been threatening to boil over, increasing the risk of military hostility, particularly in the Aegean Sea. However, we believe that both sides will seek to avoid clashes. Points of contention-such as historical territorial disputes in the Aegean Sea, and the Greek courts' rejection of Turkey's extradition request for Turkish soldiers who fled to Greece on the night of the July 2016 failed coup in Turkey-have fuelled distrust. Turkey's release in August of two Greek soldiers arrested in March 2018 while on patrol in the border area of Evros has eased tensions slightly.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Despite exiting the third economic adjustment programmes in August 2018 without a precautionary credit line, the government will still be subject to huge policy constraints during the forecast period and beyond. General government debt is huge, at an estimated 184% of GDP in 2018, and also almost entirely owed to official creditors (the EU and the IMF), making another debt write-down, as happened in 2012, highly unlikely.
In June 2018 Greece's official creditors agreed to close the final review of the third bail-out programme, paving the way for a disbursement of EUR15bn, which was released in August. Of this, EUR3.3bn was earmarked to repay more expensive IMF debt, and the balance to create a buffer for Greece to use while it builds up market access. The total buffer, estimated at EUR26bn, should be sufficient to cover almost two years of the country's financing needs, to end-2020. This is more onerous than a precautionary credit line would have been, as Greece will be accruing interest on money that it does not currently need. However, intense political pressure not to invite further policy conditionality led the government to choose the more expensive option.
In June EU creditors also agreed to further debt relief for Greece, which was granted a ten-year grace period and a ten-year maturity extension on EUR96bn of its loans (provided by the European Financial Stability Facility). It will also get a reduction in the interest rates (for EUR130.9bn worth of loans), and a return of profits from the securities market programme and from the Agreement on Net Financial Assets, which comprises the official sector holders of Greek debt-the European Central Bank (ECB) and national central banks of euro area countries. The value of the return is estimated to be about EUR5bn in total in 2018-22.
In response, Greece has committed to long-term fiscal prudence. It must achieve annual primary budget surpluses of 3.5% of GDP in 2018-22 and 2.2% thereafter, until 2060. It will also be subject to an "enhanced surveillance" regime, which is a more exacting system of post-programme monitoring than those applied to other former bail-out countries. The implementation of the debt-relief measures will be subject to quarterly reviews of the state of the economy and of the government's adherence to its commitments. As these reviews will be published, transgression by Greece would adversely affect market access.
After a three-year absence Greece has returned to the financial markets three times since July 2017. However, after its exit from the bail-out programme in August, it will do so without the backstop of an official credit line. Recent emerging-market turbulence and investor risk aversion highlight the difficulties that Greece could face in the future on the international capital markets. Greece should have sufficient funds to meet its financing needs in the short term. In the medium and long term, however, the political and, arguably, the economic price of meeting high annual primary surplus targets may become unbearable. During the past two years Greece has exceeded its annual primary surplus targets, but at the expense of economic growth, which has been disappointing. Meeting such targets will remain a constraint on growth, as will other negative factors such as poor demographics and a weak business environment. Grexit is not a short- or medium-term risk; however, given that Greece is unlikely to improve competitiveness inside the euro zone or to grow its way out of its huge debt burden, Grexit will represent a possibility in the long term.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
Greece recorded an overall budget surplus of 0.8% of GDP and a primary surplus (budget balance minus interest payments) of 3.9% in 2017, exceeding the bail-out programme target of 1.75%. From 2018 we expect fiscal performance to deteriorate gradually, with the budget balance returning to moderately widening headline deficits and primary surpluses falling well short of the official target of 3.5% of GDP for 2018-22, reflecting constraints on revenue collection, a relaxation of spending restraint and only modest economic growth. Although the primary surplus target will decline to 2.2% of GDP from 2023, it will still be difficult to achieve, owing to the fact that debt repayments will become much more onerous from that year on.
The restructuring of government debt owed to the private sector cut the debt/GDP ratio to 159.4% at end-2012, from 171.9% in 2011. However, large primary surpluses in 2016-17 were insufficient to arrest the growth of gross consolidated government debt. We expect that, without a debt write-down and assuming moderate nominal medium-term GDP growth rates, the public debt/GDP ratio will still be more than 180% at the end of 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The ECB has been pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a quantitative easing (QE) programme that concluded at the end of 2018 with about EUR2.6trn of government and corporate bonds added to the bank's balance sheet. Economic activity has softened, but higher commodity prices and evidence of building domestic price pressure in parts of the euro zone should mean that sufficient inflationary pressures will begin to emerge on the policy horizon in 2019-20. In response, we expect the ECB to take steps towards normalising its policy stance, with an increase of 25 basis points in the main refinancing rate to 0.25% in early 2020, followed by five more rises that will lift the main refinancing rate to 2% by end-2023. An increase in the deposit rate, which currently stands at -0.4%, may come sooner, in 2019.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
Compared with 2007 levels, real GDP has shrunk by more than one-quarter, government consumption by almost one-quarter, household consumption by one-fifth and gross fixed investment by almost two-thirds. The recovery, which began at the start of 2017, is fragile and vulnerable to domestic and external developments. After real GDP growth of 1.4% in 2017, we estimate growth of 2.1% in 2018. In 2019-23 real GDP growth will remain constrained at an average of 2%. The risks to our forecast are balanced: upside risks include continued strong tourism performance if capacity constraints are addressed; downside risks include the frailty of the banking sector and political instability.
Our estimate for 2018 real GDP growth is a disappointing rate of expansion in the context of the slump of the past decade. We expect a combination of more-and higher-taxes, higher social security payments, debt repayments and spending cuts to put pressure on household disposable income. Although we expect a modest acceleration in household spending in 2018-23, this will be from a low base and will be constrained by large primary surplus targets (of 3.5% of GDP per year up to 2022 and 2.2% in 2023), continued high unemployment and insipid lending growth.
Quarterly gross fixed investment has been volatile in recent years, but recorded strong full-year growth in 2016-17, albeit from a low base. However, reflecting base effects and a loss of momentum, investment contracted by an average of 6.3% year on year in the first three quarters of 2018. Despite an expected modest quarter-on-quarter increase in the final three months of 2018, we now expect a full-year contraction of 7.5%, followed by average annual growth of 5.2% in 2019-23, leaving fixed investment still about 50% below its 2007 peak. Underinvestment during the crisis and the depletion of Greece's capital stock are likely to restrict growth potential in the medium term.
Greece's external trade will be constrained by its relatively uncompetitive goods exports. In the medium term we expect tourism to continue to support services export growth, contributing to annual average growth of exports of goods and services of 8.2% in 2018 and 3.9% in 2019-23.
Greece will face its biggest macroeconomic challenge now that it no longer has access to official external financing at preferential rates. How the economy performs in the next five years (and beyond) will determine if the country remains in the euro zone. Although risks have abated since the height of the financial crisis, we believe that there is a risk that Greece will exit the euro zone in the long term, given the difficulties that it will face in attaining rapid growth while meeting large primary surplus targets and in restoring competitiveness without a currency devaluation. Greece's exit from the euro zone (not our core scenario) would lead to a sovereign default and severe recession in the first few years, but the economy would then recover, assuming a responsible fiscal policy guided by the necessity to achieve a primary surplus.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
After averaging 1.1% in 2017, driven by higher global energy prices, Greece's annual consumer price inflation rate (seasonally adjusted, EU harmonised) dipped sharply at the start of 2018. After a moderate acceleration in May-October, it eased to an average of 0.8% in the final two months of the year, as oil prices plunged from about US$80/barrel in October to just under US$60/b in December. The economy has returned to growth, but significant slack in the labour market, subdued domestic demand and recent decreases in global oil prices will dampen inflationary pressures. We expect that inflation will pick up only modestly, from an average of 0.8% in 2018 to 0.9% in 2019, 1% in 2020 and 1.5% per year in 2021-23 as domestic demand growth accelerates.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
The euro rallied in late 2017 as the region's economic recovery strengthened and expectations of QE tapering increased, and as political risk waned in Europe but rose in the US. It peaked at almost US$1.25:EUR1 at the beginning of February 2018, but had weakened to US$1.16:EUR1 by late May in response to the formation of a populist, Eurosceptic government in Italy. We expect the euro to remain under pressure from political risk in Italy and monetary tightening in the US, but forecast a moderate strengthening against the US dollar from the second half of 2019, on the assumption that the region's recovery will continue while growth momentum in the US slows. We forecast an average of US$1.19:EUR1 in 2019 and then US$1.22:EUR1 in 2020-21 as monetary policy in the euro zone is gradually tightened. The euro will also receive structural support from a large current-account surplus, and we expect it to appreciate to US$1.24:EUR1 on average in 2022-23.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
Greece's current-account deficit has narrowed since the start of the economic crisis. This mainly reflects the compression of imports owing to contracting domestic demand, but is also partly the result of improved competitiveness in the tourism sector. The current-account deficit widened from 0.8% of GDP in 2015 to an average of 1.7% of GDP per year in 2016-17, according to the Bank of Greece (the central bank). We expect continued deficits in 2018-23 as import volumes pick up in line with higher domestic demand, and as global energy prices rise moderately in the second half of the forecast period. However, these deficits will be much smaller than the average annual deficit of 7% of GDP since Greece joined the euro zone in 2001.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Manoeuvring ahead of the presidential and legislative elections in 2019 will create tensions and distract from efforts to contain security threats and the implementation of much-needed economic reform.
The administration will struggle to tackle high levels of poverty and the country's ethnic and religious divisions. This will create a potent mixture that will lead to frequent violent instability and directly affect key economic sectors.
The 2019 elections will be a close contest between the ruling All Progressives Congress and the People's Democratic Party (PDP). We expect that the PDP candidate, Atiku Abubakar, will win, but that the next administration will face the same divisions as the current one.
Policy reform in the oil sector will become central to economic policy, and some meaningful attempts to privatise the upstream industry will be made. Progress will be slow, however, because of the scale of the endeavour and resistance from powerful interest groups.
Although not expected to be fully floated, the official naira exchange rate will be allowed to depreciate in 2019-20 as oil prices drop and the central bank becomes less interventionist.
Fiscal expenditure will remain dominated by recurrent spending, despite attempts to boost capital investment. Efforts to boost non-oil tax revenue will be constrained by weak bureaucratic capacity and low economic growth.
Constrained by a crippling infrastructure deficit, as well as tight monetary conditions and instability in key agricultural regions, economic growth will be well below levels needed to boost job creation and increase living standards. This will perpetuate instability in a vicious cycle.
Inflation will remain high over the forecast period (2019-23) amid expansionary fiscal policy and high food prices stemming from government efforts to limit imports and support local producers.
The current account will record surpluses throughout the forecast period, with some output gains in the oil sector and supportive world oil prices. The difficult business environment will restrict the development of non-oil exports.

Nigeria's business environment score will improve slightly but its global and regional rankings will worsen as the administration struggles with the reform process and other countries make more significant improvements.
Country forecast overview: Nigeria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Progress on market-oriented reforms remains slow, given various vested interests and inefficiencies. Atiku Abubakar of the People's Democratic Party presses for deregulation, but the legislature is unlikely to be amenable.
2021-23: Improving prospects for the non-oil private sector remains a priority, but progress will be slow.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Confusion over oil sector reform creates ongoing uncertainty for investors. The government favours local companies in oil sector deals.
2021-23: Clearer policy lines help to stem the trend of lower investment in the oil and gas sectors, but mistrust between the numerous stakeholders prevents any major upturn in foreign direct investment.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Political upheaval around the 2019 elections delays reforms that would make trading across borders easier.
2021-23: A premium between the official and the black-market exchange rates persists.
Taxes
2019-20: Focus intensifies on boosting tax compliance, especially given weak prospects for oil revenue. Retroactive measures become a possibility, although the business community would fight these.
2021-23: Tax rates for the oil and gas sector increase under new legislation. Efforts to increase value-added tax (VAT) and to move more of the informal economy into the formal sector see non-oil collection also improve.
Financing
2019-20: Funding for well-planned projects becomes easier to raise domestically once the 2019 elections are concluded, as local capital markets deepen (with greater foreign participation) and the banking sector develops.
2021-23: Credit conditions become easier for businesses as the current-account surplus boosts national savings and investment.
The labour market
2019-20: Employers face major problems, including a shortage of skilled manual workers, restrictive visa regulations and poor health indicators.
2021-23: Employers continue to struggle to find suitably qualified staff.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Government spending on the priority area of infrastructure hits capacity constraints. Although there should be growth in private-sector investment, the government struggles to create an encouraging environment.
2021-23: Expenditure on infrastructure increases, but white elephant projects hold back the productivity of investment.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Nigeria continues to have a vibrant technology sector for an economy at its stage of development, but infrastructure is weak outside urban hubs.
2021-23: Research spending is likely to remain low compared with global averages, but some home-grown technology firms looking to adapt global technology trends to the Nigerian market continue to do well.

Background: Nigeria gained independence in 1960 and the army soon became the dominant political player. Multiparty democracy was restored in 1999. That presidential poll and the next one, in 2003, were both won by a former military ruler turned civilian politician, Olusegun Obasanjo. Mr Obasanjo was unable to change the constitution to allow him to serve a third term in office, so in the 2007 election power passed to his handpicked successor, Umaru Yar'Adua. After Mr Yar'Adua's death in May 2010, his vice-president, Goodluck Jonathan, assumed the presidency and went on to win the 2011 presidential election. Mr Jonathan was defeated by Muhammadu Buhari in the 2015 presidential election-the first time an incumbent had been defeated at the ballot box and an important step forward for the country's democracy.
Political structure: Under the constitution adopted in May 1999, a strong executive presidency appoints a Federal Executive Council, comprising government ministers and ministers of state from each of Nigeria's 36 states. The executive is accountable to the bicameral National Assembly. Political parties tend to lack clear ideologies; in practice, personal and ethnic ties dominate the political process. The People's Democratic Party (Mr Jonathan's party) had historically been the only political party to attract nationwide support, but the merger in 2013 of three large opposition parties to form the All Progressives Congress gave them, with Mr Buhari at the helm, the reach that they needed to take power in 2015. Although the 36 state governments enjoy significant autonomy, almost all remain dependent on the federal government for funding.
Policy issues: Successive governments have sought to improve macroeconomic stability and develop the nation's dire infrastructure, with mixed results. Meanwhile, the government is struggling to end insecurity in various parts of the country. These tensions are stoked by the underlying problems of poverty and unemployment. Management of the naira by the authorities is contentious, and currency liberalisation will be postponed whenever foreign-exchange supplies permit.
Taxation: Corporate profits in most non-oil sectors are taxed at 30%. Planned changes to the tax system for the oil and gas sector have been repeatedly delayed, creating uncertainty. Most other taxes are low, reflecting the fact that most revenue comes from the oil sector, with the total tax take very small as a share of GDP. Tax compliance is a time-consuming process.
Foreign trade: Exports are dominated by oil. The slump in oil prices from the second half of 2014 almost wiped out what had historically been a large current-account surplus, although a positive trade balance has since resumed. The non-oil export base has been rendered globally uncompetitive by massive infrastructure deficiencies.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
Nigeria is heading into a hotly contested general election on February 16th against a concerning backdrop. The chief justice, Walter Onnoghen, has been suspended without constitutional procedure being followed and will now be unable to adjudicate on any electoral disputes that arise from the vote. As the presidential race is going to be extremely tight and the opposition are convinced it will be rigged, this presents a real problem, especially if the incumbent, Muhammadu Buhari, wins. The opposition see the timing of Mr Onnoghen's suspension as wholly political, alleging that Mr Buhari wanted to install a sympathiser in his place. So if an electoral dispute did occur and the new chief justice, Ibrahim Tanko Mohammed, ruled in favour of the incumbent, the opposition now have grounds for discrediting such a decision. Mass protests and even a political crisis could follow. Presaging how stark the risks to stability could be, a militant group in the country's south (where Mr Onnoghen comes from) have already warned that they will step up attacks on critical infrastructure in protest. Another alarming sign has come from government accusations that the main opposition party, the People's Democratic Party (PDP), is fomenting unrest in the country's north by actively supporting Boko Haram, an Islamist terrorist organisation. Unsubstantiated claims like these will only work to build tensions before the poll.
The baseline forecast of The Economist Intelligence Unit is that the main opposition candidate, Atiku Abubakar, will win the presidency outright, thereby obviating instability that could follow an electoral dispute. Nonetheless, a different electoral outcome now contains a severe downside risk to political stability, which will anyway be under severe strain. Even assuming that the election passes peacefully, the new government will be faced with the same insoluble security problems as the outgoing administration. A concerted effort is needed to eliminate Boko Haram in the north-east and bring an end to clashes between settled farmers and pastoralists in central Nigeria. Militancy in the oil-producing Niger Delta is another ever-present threat. Nigeria's overstretched military will be unable to decisively end violence in these regions, with meagre federal government resources being stretched too thin. It will also prove hard to create economic opportunities for local populations; poverty, rising unemploy-ment and competition for natural resources are at the root of much of the instability. Parliamentary rifts will be another hold-up to finding a permanent solution. Both of Nigeria's main parties, the ruling All Progressives Congress (APC) and the PDP, lack any clear ideology, and most legislators prioritise their constituents' needs over party. As different regions have competing interests and vastly different priorities, the collective resolve needed to bring permanent peace to unstable parts of Nigeria will be lacking.
Speculation over the threat of a military coup or a civil war is likely to surface periodically but the military has been depoliticised since the junta stepped aside in 1999. Meanwhile, there is little appetite beyond extremist agitators for a return to civil war, given memories of how disastrous the 1967-70 conflict was for the country. Nonetheless, as the country's leadership struggles to shift Nigeria onto a more sustainable path to economic development, the risks to stability will intensify as more and more Nigerians question what they have to lose from pushing for violent change.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Presidential and legislative elections are due in February 2019. Mr Buhari is the APC's presidential candidate, and his main challenger is Mr Abubakar from the PDP. Both candidates are from northern Nigeria, where Mr Buhari's support base lies, presaging a fierce contest there. With the vote likely to be split in the north, Mr Abubakar will find it easier to garner support from the country's south, which has traditionally been a PDP stronghold. This gives Mr Abubakar an edge, as does popular frustration over a sharp rise in joblessness and poverty (two of the biggest concerns of voters) on Mr Buhari's watch. Growing instability in north-eastern and central Nigeria also denies the incumbent much in the way of achievements to boast of while in office; he was given a clear mandate in 2015 to restore law and order. Nonetheless, strong incumbency advantages in Nigeria imply that it will be a very tight race. If Mr Abubakar loses-a distinct downside risk to our forecast-there may be a rejection of the result by the PDP, which is convinced the election will be rigged.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Many of Nigeria's militant groups operate across land and sea borders, and international co-operation will therefore be needed to tackle the threat they pose. Stretched resources, vast territories and porous borders will prevent complete military victories. Relations with the US will be mixed; the administration of Donald Trump is willing to sell Nigeria military hardware, but Mr Trump's disapproval of the trade deficit the US runs with Nigeria (particularly owing to Nigerian trade barriers on agricultural imports) could strain relations. Ties with the EU will be largely cordial but subject to tensions over the large numbers of Nigerian migrants seeking to enter Europe and Nigerian efforts to repatriate funds in European banks that were allegedly looted by former rulers.
India will remain important as the largest market for Nigerian oil and become a bigger source of foreign investment. China will remain a significant source of investment, but actual inflows will total only a small proportion of the headline-grabbing pledges made given an extremely challenging local business environment. Nigeria will remain an important player on the Sub-Saharan African stage given its size, but its domestic challenges will tend to keep policymakers inwardly focused. Relations with South Africa will remain strained. Africa's two largest economies will continue to compete for political, economic and cultural influence.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Over the forecast period efforts to open up the economy will be made but progress will be haphazard. Mr Abubakar advocates a pro-business and free-market reform agenda, with his flagship proposal being to privatise the state oil company, the National Nigerian Petroleum Corporation (NNPC) which dominates both the upstream and downstream oil sectors. The loss of a federal government stake in the oil sector-from which it derives most of its revenue-would then be compensated-for by higher taxes. It is not yet clear whether the divestment would be wholesale, or if the NNPC's various subsidiaries would be sold separately. The latter is a more likely policy; getting private investors interested in buying and recapitalising Nigeria's oil refineries would require the deregulation of pump prices-which are fixed below cost-recovery-as would ending the NNPC's role as a petroleum distributor. Not only would ending petrol subsidies unleash inflation, but it could lead to widespread riots; for many Nigerians cheap petrol is the only visible contribution that the federal government makes to daily life. Having established reform of the NNPC as the linchpin of his campaign, we expect Mr Abubakar to make some determined moves to privatise the corporation, although in practice these will be limited to its upstream operations. However, completion of that task is unlikely within the outlook period. The NNPC has a daunting trade union and its opaque setup has long been a vehicle for patronage, meaning the legislation needed to overhaul the sector will contend with powerful vested interests and be extremely slow to pass.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
We expect small fiscal deficits throughout the forecast period. The government wants to diversify its revenue base away from oil, and non-oil revenue will rise through efforts to widen tax coverage and collect overdue taxes, but from an extremely low base. Petrol subsidies (whereby losses from below-cost prices are taken by the NNPC's distribution arm) and instability in many parts of the country will also be an impediment to revenue collection. More importantly, oil production targets budgeted for by the government are repeatedly over-ambitious; for example in 2019 the government expects output of 2.3m barrels/day-a level not seen for well over a decade, and one that will be unobtainable given underinvestment and antiquated oil infrastructure. Total revenue is not expected to rise above 3.4% of GDP, a ratio only attained in 2023 when oil prices are at their highest within the forecast period.
After some projected expansion in 2018, spending will decline as a proportion of GDP in 2019 with deep cuts to the capital budget. Partly offsetting this will be a rise in populist recurrent spending on wages and public-sector benefits. Generally, flexibility on spending will be restricted by high levels of debt-servicing and pressing security needs. But with oil prices-and so revenue-under pressure and there being considerable political pressure to curb the fiscal deficit, we expect the spending/GDP ratio to dip again in 2020 and only begin to increase materially as elections in 2023 approach. Altogether, we expect an average budget deficit equal to 1.9% of GDP over 2019-23.
Long-term public debt sustainability will remain in doubt. Central government debt is low as a proportion of GDP compared with other emerging markets, but it is set against a low revenue base. Debt service already takes up close to one-third of federal government income, and yields on government securities are increasing as global monetary conditions tighten and foreign investors repatriate capital. A federal government default is unlikely, but repayment difficulties are possible at state level, where revenue collection is even weaker.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
Monetary policy will concentrate on bolstering economic recovery while limiting inflation and maintaining currency stability. However, this will generate contradictory pressures in the early part of the forecast period. The private sector is desperate for cheaper credit, but inflation will remain above the targeted upper limit of 9% set by the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN). On balance, we expect interest rates not to move much in 2019-20. Rates will then fall in 2021 and stabilise over 2022-23 as economic activity picks up and inflation hovers above or around target. However, real interest rates will be too high to support private-sector activity outside of highly profitable ventures.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
The economy will for the most part be mired in a low-growth cycle, although there will be improvements over time. In 2019 what are expected to be fiercely contested elections in February, as well as falling oil prices, will hold back business and consumer confidence. High local borrowing costs will likewise hold back investment, and with cuts to public capital spending as well we forecast a growth rate of 1.9%; this is the lowest annual rate of growth in our five-year outlook period. Growth will increase in 2020 as election-related uncertainty passes, but only moderately-as an expected slowdown in the world economy holds back export-oriented sectors. In 2021-23, as global markets strengthen and external demand picks up, the rate of growth will quicken to an annual average of 3.3%. This is well below potential, with numerous factors holding the economy back.
From a sectoral viewpoint, agriculture will record only lacklustre growth; although boosting food production is a key government objective, weak infrastructure and violent competition for access to land in the fertile Middle Belt will be severe impediments. Industrial production will be curtailed by militancy and labour agitation in the oil sector, and falling oil prices in 2019-20 will hold back investment in infrastructure upgrades. Hydrocarbons production is therefore not expected to return to levels prior to the 2015 commodity-price crash, although a new, private refinery coming on stream by 2021 will be a boost in the latter years of the forecast period. The manufacturing sector will continue to struggle in the face of cheap goods from abroad, which are often smuggled into the country to bypass import bans. The services sector is less affected by instability and so will be a stronger contributor to growth than industry, but it will nonetheless be held back by trade protectionism, tight credit conditions (particularly affecting areas such as real estate and finance), and the struggle in the communications sector to profitably roll out data services beyond urban hubs.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
From a rate of 12.1% in 2018, average inflation will increase to 14% in 2019, as the naira enters a period of managed depreciation and pre-election giveaways (including an increase in the minimum wage) add to upward price pressures. Inflation will remain elevated at 13.5% in 2020 on the back of further currency weakening. Thereafter, as the currency stabilises, inflation will steadily ease over the rest of the forecast period to an average of 8.8% in 2023. Preventing a faster slide will be protectionist measures that limit relatively cheap imports from abroad, particularly of food. If Mr Abubakar goes ahead with proposals to fully float the naira and liberalise pump prices, inflation would exceed these forecasts by a considerable margin. (Nigeria is heavily dependent on imports, and consumer prices are highly sensitive to currency movements.)
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
We expect the multiple-exchange-rate system to persist throughout 2019-23, with an official rate used for government business and a market-determined rate applicable to investors and exporters (with various other rates in between). Such a system allows the government to subsidise sectors deemed important for economic or political reasons, including petroleum imports. For this reason the setup is not expected to be tampered with. Oil prices, and with them the level of hard-currency earnings, will in large part dictate where the authorities are able to hold the official rate and what the premium is between the official and the market rates. In 2019 lower oil prices, reduced hard-currency inflows around the election and the cumulative impact of real appreciation over recent years will cause the official rate to drop from an estimated average of N305.6:US$1 in 2018 to N319:US$1. With oil prices forecast to decline again in 2020 we expect a further fall in the value of the naira, to an average of N362.4:US$1. This is almost aligned with the current market-determined (Nafex) rate, although some spread is still expected as the Nafex rate also depreciates. As oil prices pick up on average over the rest of the forecast period and import pressures are eased by improved domestic refining capacity, we expect the naira to stabilise, with an average rate of N365:US$1 in 2023.
Forecasting the naira
Although The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts both the official and the secondary market rates, it is the official rate that appears in most of our data presentations, as it is the longest-running and best-tracked variable. For example, the current market-determined rate, known as the Nigerian Autonomous Foreign Exchange Rate Fixing (Nafex), has only been in full operation since April 2017, making historical calculations challenging. However, indicators that are converted into US dollars at the official rate are essentially overvalued.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The export profile will move in tandem with oil production trends and world crude prices. In 2019-20 our expectation for limited output gains will be outweighed by a drop in world crude prices. Only in 2021-23 when prices recover and Nigeria begins to export refined oil will there be any growth in earnings, which will be fairly sharp.
As Nigeria is a fuel importer, lower world crude prices will also ease pressure on the import bill in 2019-20. In 2019 there will be a sharp drop in imports relative to 2018, when there was a one-off surge in capital goods entering the country. Weaker economic growth, lower world oil (and so petrol) prices and depreciation of the naira will also be contributing factors. In 2020 the naira will continue to depreciate, limiting consumer demand, but slightly stronger economic growth will nonetheless stabilise imports that year. As the economy gathers pace in 2021-23 and the naira stabilises, imports will then grow with reasonable strength, albeit with less need for fuel imports as a new refinery comes on stream. Trade-related services imports and profit repatriation for the oil sector will keep the services and primary income balances firmly in deficit. Meanwhile, workers' remittances will remain an important source of hard currency, albeit dipping in 2020 as growth falters in the US (home to a large Nigerian diaspora). Overall, the current-account surplus will broadly track movements in world oil prices, narrowing from 4% of GDP in 2019 to 2.2% of GDP in 2020, then widening again to 3.6% of GDP by 2022 before retreating again to 3.1% of GDP in 2023.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; the source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: IEA average import price
Non-oil commodity prices: IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
EUR 3-month interbank rate: IFS
Domestic data
Population: UN
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics
Balance of payments: IFS and CBN, Annual Report and Statement of Accounts
Inflation: IFS, CBN and Federal Office of Statistics
Exchange rate: IFS; principal rate expressed as naira:US dollar
Interest rate: IFS; year-end lending rate
GDP growth and expenditure breakdown: World Bank, World Tables; 1987 prices
US$ GDP: IFS; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
GDP per head: US dollar GDP divided by population
Oil production: IEA; m barrels/day
Oil price: The Economist Intelligence Unit; dated Brent Blend
FDI: IFS, UNCTAD, World Investment Report and CBN
Total external debt: sum of long- and short-term debt and IMF credits
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding, with an original maturity of more than one year
Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
IMF credits: IFS and country page on website
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges on total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
CBN: Central Bank of Nigeria
IEA: International Energy Agency
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
NPC: National Population Commission
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development

Country Forecast Venezuela January 2019 Updater

https://www.proquest.com/reports/country-forecast-venezuela-january-2019-updater/docview/2169135787/se-2?accountid=14357

Abstract: In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly. Outside of these areas, we do not expect much success in rolling back the PSUV's strong interventionist bent in the economy. [...]we expect limited real investment inflows, the vast majority going into the oil sector, which will restrict economic recovery and fuel continued unrest. Owing to the need to maintain political stability, we do not expect the closure of the various handout programmes in operation, nor the complete removal of utility subsidies or the reformation of inefficient state-owned firms. [...]we expect public expenditure to be hard to reduce; the deficit will be substantial throughout the 2019-23 period. The exact nature and implementation of such moves are hard to foresee, but our baseline forecast includes the continuation of some currency controls for the duration of the forecast period. Since the start of the year the government has devalued the official exchange rate by over 99%, but exchange controls remain.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Venezuela&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Venezuela+January+2019+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2019-01-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Venezuela&amp;rft.issn=09669574&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Economic collapse and the erosion of the patronage scheme supporting the president, Nicolás Maduro, have put the ruling regime's internal cohesion in jeopardy. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a traumatic rift that will end in regime pragmatists allowing opposition participation in a "mixed administration" as a way to remain in power from 2019 onwards. There is a risk that the existing regime will retain cohesion and cling to power beyond 2019 if it finds financing to meet its debt obligations and boost dwindling oil production.
Following years-long economic collapse, GDP will continue to contract in 2019-20. High inflation has led to a collapse in private consumption, and difficult operating conditions have hurt investment. Following a change in policy under a new government, we expect economic growth to resume in 2021.
The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. Following our forecast transition this year, a new government will stabilise the economy, but the wholesale rethink of the institutional framework needed to restore investment and confidence is unlikely.
Worsening shortages of consumer goods and hyperinflation will continue to depress private consumption, and an increasingly difficult operating environment will accentuate a fall in fixed investment. The recession that began in 2014 will continue to deepen despite a partial recovery in oil prices as oil output slumps, and the economy will not return to growth until 2021-assuming that a new government takes power and implements reforms. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, reinforcing our forecasts of only a weak recovery.
US dollar measurements of Venezuela's market size provide an overly positive picture of the economy, given the marked overvaluation of the fixed exchange rate. In reality, recession and extremely high inflation (driven by shortages of foreign exchange and basic goods) will continue to restrict purchasing power. After 2020, under a new government, we expect purchasing power and the business environment to improve.

Venezuela is in 82nd position globally in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings for 2019-23, the worst position in our ranking. This reflects the highly heterodox macroeconomic policies of an authoritarian government, a lack of legal security and weak institutions.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Start of roll-back of interventionist measures like price controls, but political-instability concerns slow liberalisation. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and undermine free competition.
2021-23: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Regulation by new government protecting property rights introduced in an attempt at attracting investment.
2021-23: Despite efforts, actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2019-20: Currency controls are made less opaque but restrictions on the private sector's access to foreign currency remain in place.
2021-23: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2019-20: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2021-23: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2019-20: Inflation remains high and concerns about economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2021-23: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2019-20: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. The current freeze on redundancies is fazed-out
2021-23: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Underinvestment in the water network and electricity grid ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2021-23: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued water and electricity rationing.
Technological readiness
2019-20: E-government services remain almost non-existent and deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment.
2021-23: Limited regulator capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has plummeted as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices has plunged the country into a massive economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded republican institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy mired in a years-long economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. At the same time, mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign-exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The VAT rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Using IMF data, The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$21.1bn in 2017 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages. We estimate the current-account surplus at 2.3% of GDP that year.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
Despite an extremely severe economic crisis, the government headed by the president, Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), retains its hold on power. Regardless, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the worsening economic conditions to trigger a chaotic political situation, with a "mixed administration" with nominal opposition participation the most likely outcome. We expect this to happen in 2019, but the process is highly uncertain. We expect the forecast period to be characterised by political instability
The opposition, owing to a history of infighting and ineffectiveness, is incapable of channelling the populace's dissatisfaction with the government. Opposition parties, which consider Mr Maduro illegitimate, are currently split on whether to negotiate with the government or rebuff dialogue in the hopes of forcing an internal fracture in the regime. In any case, the regime's years-long campaign of harassment and disfranchisement has made opposition parties powerless in practice and vulnerable to retaliation.
Regardless, economic crisis and civilian unrest have made the government dependent on the military to remain in power. The integrity of the civic-military alliance running the country is sustained via opportunities for corruption (afforded by large state-owned companies, foreign-exchange controls and subsidised imports) and the tacit approval of transnational organised crime (as evidenced by indictments abroad of regime leaders). Regime factions are primarily based on personal and patronage ties, resulting in a variety of civic-military factions coexisting within the regime. Outside of potential outright criminal income, the resources maintaining this patronage network come from export revenue generated by PDVSA, the state-owned oil company.
However, this patronage network has suffered significantly as mismanagement and underinvestment at PDVSA have taken their toll on oil revenue and output. (Production is currently at around 1.2m barrels/day-b/d-down from 2.5m b/d when Mr Maduro took office.) With the current administration patently unable to demonstrate the technical competence or the foreign financing needed to turn PDVSA around, we judge the status quo unsustainable. We currently expect an internal fracture of the regime in 2019 but, regardless of the timing, what happens next is hard to predict.
Given that the regime's raison d'etre is the enrichment of its members, stabilisation of PDVSA and the economy would take priority under a new government. We expect regime pragmatists to seek assistance from Western governments and multilateral organisations. To gain international legitimacy and secure financing, these pragmatists would allow nominal opposition participation in a mixed administration. Given past behaviour, there should be plenty of opposition figures willing to participate. This administration would nonetheless face pockets of resistance in places such as the judiciary, the Constituent Assembly (the country's de facto legislature), and the radicalised supporters of the PSUV known as colectivos. Political stability through the forecast period will be limited.
Three key assumptions underpin our baseline view. A crucial assumption is that, given economic conditions, Mr Maduro cannot sustain regime cohesion indefinitely. Risks to this assumption include the possibility of new disputes with the opposition that bolster internal regime unity, along with the regular purges within the regime's ranks that help to maintain Mr Maduro's grip on power. A second assumption is that Russia and China-erstwhile financiers-will not provide substantial funding to the current administration (or to a PSUV-only successor administration). We base this view on the regime's inability to repay already expired loans and the fact that it has received limited Chinese or Russian aid since 2015. The main risk here is that Venezuela's oil wealth, however, remains a draw-especially if sold off at low prices by a bankrupt regime. A significant third assumption underpinning our forecast is the need to restore macroeconomic stability and steady resource flows through the patronage system, which has become so urgent as to allow pragmatists to accept Western-demanded democratic and macroeconomic reforms. Here again, there are risks to our assumptions: democratic reform would be likely to involve judicial retribution on a number of current regime leaders, while macroeconomic reform would eliminate the economy's distortions, closing avenues for corruption and enrichment.
As such, there are strong risks to our baseline view, and there is a strong possibility of alternate scenarios. These include: a PSUV-only administration securing enough Chinese financing; a permanently impoverished nation led by an outright military government (or one with civilian figureheads); or-as an outside possibility-prolonged chaos, if regime cohesion fails but no faction gains clear control of the state apparatus across the country.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
We do not expect free and fair elections in the short term. The past two elections (presidential in May and municipal in December) saw most of the opposition proscribed and only some parties are participating (a source of infighting). Based on our political assumptions, an electoral timetable may be announced, as international financing would almost certainly come with demands for democratic reforms.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Most regional governments, under the banner of the Lima Group, have denounced the Venezuelan government, as has the EU. They publicly consider Mr Maduro to be illegitimate since he won his term in irregular elections in May. They agree on this with Venezuela's opposition but-perhaps wary of destabilising the nation-have no concrete plan of action on how to dislodge the head of the regime. The US has put individual sanctions on most regime leaders, including potential successors to Mr Maduro. This limits the field of negotiating partners in the event of an internal fracture of the regime, but sanctions are reversible. US country-level sanctions block Venezuela from refinancing its debts, compounding the regime's financial woes. Despite the hawkish US foreign policy personnel, sanctions on the oil trade (the US is PDVSA's largest cash-paying market and a key source of production inputs) and military intervention are not part of our baseline assumptions.
Russia and China seem unwilling to provide the necessary financing-amounting to tens of billions of dollars per year-to stabilise the economy and PDVSA. The regime openly courts the two countries, but with little apparent success in actual investment.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Monetisation of large public deficits, coupled with mismanagement of the state-dominated oil industry, has led to hyperinflation and shortages of foreign currency, basic goods and industrial inputs. The government remains technically unable and politically unwilling to undertake the deep and wide-ranging policy and institutional changes needed. Its latest economic plan, launched in late August, was self-defeating, and the government has not complied with the cornerstone promise of abolishing the monetisation of public deficits. As such, imbalances will persist and foreign exchange will continue to be rationed.
Economic policy will remain interventionist in the short term, deepening the economic crisis that underpins our baseline forecast for political change. Furthermore, outside of promising a hard-to-implement reduction in fuel subsidies, the plan had little focus on PDVSA's falling output; production at PDVSA remains a crucial factor in supporting the economy amid a collapse in the non-oil sector.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect that more orthodox economic policies will be implemented under a new government. However, the pace and depth of the adjustment will be constrained by uncertainty over the stability of any new regime, and whether this takes precedence over the likely demands for reform from multilateral and bilateral lenders. Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and multilaterals (totalling US$19bn in 2019-22) and the restructuring of the government's debt obligations. This in itself will be a huge task for any administration. At the same time, PDVSA will need wholesale reform to open itself to the foreign finance needed to increase output, a process that will require considerable political capital.
Pockets of resistance are likely to exist. Internal stability within the PSUV is a major risk to our forecast, as the success of a mixed administration would depend on PSUV pragmatists fending off more radical party members. These members would oppose international assistance, foreign investment and policy reforms on both ideological and personal grounds (as many regime insiders profit from the state's indirect and direct control of the economy).
Outside of these areas, we do not expect much success in rolling back the PSUV's strong interventionist bent in the economy. Thus, we expect limited real investment inflows, the vast majority going into the oil sector, which will restrict economic recovery and fuel continued unrest.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
Authorities have not published complete official data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We estimate that the fiscal deficit is well into double figures as a percentage of GDP. The government relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency.
High inflation and the overvalued official exchange rate make debt/GDP ratios misleading indicators of fiscal stability. Considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) understates the true size of total public liabilities. Most sovereign and state-owned bonds (including PDVSA's) are in arrears. Bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy changes or a change in leadership. The exceptions to arrears are debts that threaten Citgo (PDVSA's US subsidiary) and leased facilities in the Caribbean. Both facilitate PDVSA's capacity to export oil and import production inputs. So far, Venezuela has taken a defensive stance, treating each claim individually and stalling as much as possible before complying when seizures seem imminent. Given PDVSA's strained financial situation and the lack of further sources of financing, the strategy does not seem sustainable.
Citgo, itself indebted and posted as collateral for loans and bonds, could have its fate be resolved by a prolonged judicial process in the US. We believe that, if forced to choose, the government would prioritise its Caribbean assets over Citgo, as the former are key for PDVSA's capacity to export, while import-export trade with Citgo could be re-routed to other US companies. However, it is unclear when the government may have to choose or if would have the capacity to do so. PDVSA's strained financial situation means that the risk of default and seizure will remain high in the short term. Stalling tactics (including partial compliance with payments) will continue.
Under our baseline forecast, we expect a restructuring with external creditors in 2020. Owing to the need to maintain political stability, we do not expect the closure of the various handout programmes in operation, nor the complete removal of utility subsidies or the reformation of inefficient state-owned firms. Therefore, we expect public expenditure to be hard to reduce; the deficit will be substantial throughout the 2019-23 period.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The government's financing needs will continue to force the Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank) to print money. Money supply (M2) continues to grow rapidly, expanding by 111% month on month at end-December. We expect a new administration to place a much greater emphasis on tackling hyperinflation and expect a substantial monetary adjustment in the context of a macroeconomic stabilisation plan. The introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) in such a context is highly likely.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 15% in 2018, we expect further contractions in 2019-20. A forecast recovery in 2021-23 rests on the assumption of a political transition that, supported by IMF assistance, produces a credible macroeconomic programme with improved management of oil wealth. However, reform will be limited in scope by a weak government, and we expect only a partial rebound in real GDP, following a decline of around 50% in 2013-20.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2019, reflecting the effect on real wages of hyperinflation, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will also contract, reflecting difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange. Our forecast for a recovery in investment later in the forecast period assumes a political transition and a pick-up in oil investment.
We expect oil output to bottom out at 1m b/d in mid-2019, kept from going lower by PDVSA's joint-venture partners. Under our baseline forecast of openness to foreign investment under a new government from 2019, production will start to recover in the second half of 2020 but will remain well below 2m b/d, the average output in 2017, even at the end of our forecast period.
Export volumes will only start to recover in 2020, as an increase in domestic demand, which has been artificially constrained, will initially absorb the increase in oil output. For the same reason, import demand will rise sharply in 2019.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Decimated domestic supply, severe limits on imports and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official data have not been published since 2015, but the opposition-led National Assembly estimated that monthly inflation was 144% (702,521% year on year) in November. In the context of a macroeconomic stabilisation plan in 2019, we expect much tighter monetary policy and lower inflation.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
Under our current baseline forecast, the introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) amid deep imbalances and as a means to try to tackle hyperinflation is possible in 2019. The exact nature and implementation of such moves are hard to foresee, but our baseline forecast includes the continuation of some currency controls for the duration of the forecast period.
Since the start of the year the government has devalued the official exchange rate by over 99%, but exchange controls remain. The official rate is determined by an auction process, but the government-which monopolises the country's exports-does not supply the system with foreign-exchange, making the system unsustainable and access to foreign exchange practically impossible. In early January the black-market exchange rate was around BsS981:US$1; the official rate stood at BsS700:US$1.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
We expect a current-account surplus of US$2.7bn in 2019. The surplus is buoyed by non-payment of interest on bonded debt ("savings" in excess of US$5bn in 2019 alone). Our export data, which are based on IMF data, may overstate receipts, as some exports are actually payments in-kind for loans, the repayment of which may not be included in their totality under forecast interest repayments (we have excluded repayments to Chinese lenders to maintain consistency with the World Bank's data on which our debt forecasts are based).
By 2020, with a new government in power, we expect that-following debt renegotiation-external financing will be restored. Although we expect exports to grow as oil production increases, we also expect a surge in imports, as Venezuela's own productive base has been decimated and imports have been compressed to artificially low levels. In addition, the government will be complying with its debt obligations, meaning that the restructured debt will actually result in increased outflows in interest payments. These factors will erode the current-account surplus from 3.7% of GDP in 2020 to a deficit of 1.8% by 2023.
We currently expect that the new administration will secure sufficient finance to stabilise the balance-of-payments dynamics. However, there are considerable risks to this rosy outlook. In addition to assuming the installation of a pragmatic mixed administration capable of retaining power, it hinges on substantial finance from the IMF, the quick implementation of a successful macroeconomic stabilisation package, the fast resolution of a debt renegotiation process in 2019-20, substantial inflows of financial and real investment into the economy in 2020-23, and a fast recovery in oil output after years of underinvestment and mismanagement.

Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
