Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
In June 2018 Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected as president for a second term in snap presidential and parliamentary elections, in which his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a coalition majority with the right-wing Nationalist Action Party (MHP).
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Mr Erdogan and the AKP to remain in power throughout the forecast period (2019-23), and probably beyond.
Following the June 2018 elections, an executive presidency has replaced the former parliamentary system of government. The new system provides few checks on the president's powers, raising the risk of discretionary policymaking.
Since the failed coup in July 2016 there has been a marked deterioration in Turkey's relations with its Western allies. We expect a rupture to be avoided, but tensions will remain high and relations could sour quickly.
Turkey's relationship with the US will remain tense. Points of contention include Turkey's perceived pivot towards Iran and Russia and, from Turkey's perspective, the lack of support from the US after the failed coup. A Turkish military intervention against Kurds in Syria would lead to a further deterioration in relations between the US and Turkey.
Turkey's relationship with the EU will remain transactional. Turkey will not make progress with accession talks and is unlikely to manage to renegotiate the terms of its customs union with the EU.
The government's focus on domestic power struggles, economic growth and foreign-policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate.
We forecast a slowdown in real GDP growth, from 7.3% in 2017 to an average of 3.6% per year in 2019-23, reflecting the impact of the recent currency crisis, higher interest rates, a difficult business environment and trade tensions.
The lira will depreciate in nominal terms against the US dollar during the forecast period, to about TL6.2:US$1 at end-2023, as a result of negative foreign investor sentiment, high inflation and the large current-account deficit.
As a result of the recent sharp depreciation of the lira against the US dollar (which will boost competitiveness), we forecast that the current-account deficit will shrink in 2019-23, to an annual average of 3.5% of GDP. Turkey will struggle to meet its high external financing needs throughout the forecast period.

Turkey's score deteriorates only slightly in 2019-23, but in the global rankings the country falls by 11 places, to 59th. The failed coup in 2016 and the government's response have increased the level of uncertainty about the direction of economic policy. Shortcomings include a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Political instability and adverse market conditions will delay further privatisation deals.
2021-23: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in several sectors.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but macroeconomic instability and concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2021-23: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Capital controls are not considered, despite the scale of the currency collapse. Political tensions resulting in tit-for-tat tariffs and US sanctions will disrupt Turkish-US trade and relations.
2021-23: Negotiations with the EU to update the customs union are likely to be protracted, given poor Turkish-EU relations.
Taxes
2019-20: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Tax rises introduced in 2018 to curb the widening of the budget deficit reduce company profits.
2021-23: Income tax base becomes broader as exemptions and exceptions are reduced.
Financing
2019-20: Asset quality likely to deteriorate on the back of financial market turmoil in 2018. Central Bank of Turkey to lower rates gradually as inflation moderates in 2019. Risk of the US imposing fines or sanctions on some Turkish banks.
2021-23: Lending growth to pick up again as banking system regains strength. Continued reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2019-20: Relatively high labour costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment.
2021-23: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2019-20: First phase of third airport in Istanbul becomes operational. Slower progress made on other projects.
2021-23: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. Other major urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks might persist.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Spending on research and development remains moderate, at about 1% of GDP, holding back efforts to move the economy up the value-added ladder.
2021-23: Turkey's young population spurs further rapid digital transformation of the banking sector.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West. The country became a member of the Council of Europe in 1949 and NATO in 1952, and signed an association agreement with the then European Community in 1963. A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but a coup attempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey currently has a presidential system of government, with parliament elected for a five-year term. To win seats, parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the AKP leader, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who was re-elected as president for a second term in June 2018. Following his re-election a presidential system of government was introduced and the post of prime minister was abolished.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability and stabilising the lira following the August 2018 currency crisis are Turkey's biggest policy challenges. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and tightening global liquidity conditions require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy tight to attract adequate capital inflows and slow the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar. The Kurdish issue, which has blocked economic development in the south east, is one of Turkey's most pressing policy challenges, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015, and there has been a resurgence in violence. Politicisation of the judiciary since the coup attempt has undermined its independence. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The corporation tax rate has been raised in 2018, from 20% to 22%. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Reducing tax evasion was one of the elements of previous IMF programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2017 goods exports came to US$166bn and imports to US$225bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$59bn and a current-account deficit of US$47.4bn (or 5.6% of GDP). The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
In June 2018 Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected for a second term in the first round of a snap presidential election. On the same day his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a parliamentary coalition majority with its right-wing ally, the Nationalist Action Party (MHP). The election process appeared mostly free, but largely unfair. Opposition candidates received little or no media coverage; the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP) candidate, Selahattin Demirtas, had to campaign from prison; and the government restrained freedom of speech and freedom of association. Mr Erdogan secured a majority of the vote after a high turnout. Results published by opposition observers were similar to those announced by the government.
Mr Erdogan's re-election concluded Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. This move was initiated with a constitutional referendum in April 2017, which the government narrowly won. The new system grants the president wide-ranging executive powers-including the selection of most of the officials in the judiciary-and will greatly weaken parliament. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the AKP and Mr Erdogan, who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in July 2016, to remain in power until 2023, and probably beyond.
Mr Erdogan will continue to restrict political dissent and stifle the opposition. Despite allowing the state of emergency to expire on July 18th 2018, parliament passed a security law on July 25th that imposes stringent barriers on freedoms.
Security risk remains high, as Turkey appears vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and Islamic State (IS). Neither the govern-ment nor the PKK is interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will return to 1990s levels. The fact that the ruling coalition is made up of the AKP and the MHP will hinder attempts to resolve the Kurdish issue, as the nationalist-minded MHP is pushing for hawkish policies aimed at constraining and delegitimising the HDP.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Parliamentary and presidential elections were held in June 2018 (they had originally been scheduled for late 2019). Mr Erdogan was re-elected as president in the first round, securing 52.6% of the vote with a turnout of 86.2%. In the parliamentary election the AKP lost its absolute majority (although it secured a coalition majority alongside its partner, the MHP), as the HDP managed to poll more than the 10% threshold needed to enter parliament.
Local elections are planned for the end of March this year. In order to raise levels of support for the AKP ahead of the elections, the government has implemented a number of expansionary fiscal measures. We continue to expect the AKP to emerge unscathed from the local elections, retaining control of the two largest cities-Istanbul and the capital, Ankara.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Domestic political and security issues will continue to shape Turkey's actions in the foreign-policy sphere. Although not our core forecast, there is a risk of a rupture in the country's ties with its traditional Western allies. Many factors have contributed to the deterioration in relations, including a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey after the failed coup; US military backing for PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurdish groups (although this may change in 2019); Turkey's forging of closer relations with China, Russia and Iran; tensions with Cyprus over the delimitation of the two countries' exclusive economic zones in the Mediterranean; and US sanctions on Turkish officials due to Turkey's detention of Andrew Brunson, a US pastor, on terrorism charges (sanctions were lifted after Mr Brunson was released in October).
Turkey's relations with the EU and the US are likely to remain antagonistic and transactional rather than strategic. However, we expect Turkey and its Western allies to avoid a breakdown in relations, as Turkey and the EU have a common interest in handling refugee inflows from Syria and Iraq. However, EU-Turkey relations would deteriorate quickly if the EU were to suspend Turkey's moribund accession negotiations, or if Turkey re-imposed the death penalty, closed the Incirlik air base to NATO forces or withdrew from NATO (none of which are our core forecast).
Turkey's military operations in Syria seek to block the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds affiliated with the PKK but risk fuelling the conflict with the PKK in south-east Turkey. In December 2018 the US announced that it would withdraw troops from Syria. For Turkey, the US withdrawal represents an invitation to press ahead with plans to extend its border zone within Syria eastwards. Turkey controls most of the territory across the border region from the Mediterranean to the Euphrates River. The country is also planning another military operation against Kurdish forces to the east of the Euphrates, although Mr Erdogan has delayed the offensive for fear of US retaliation. With a Turkish offensive in the pipeline, the Kurds are likely to step up negotiations with the Syrian regime on a political settlement in order to avoid a situation where they could be surrounded by enemies and without US support.
Turkey is also preoccupied with the situation in Idlib, a rebel-held city in northern Syria. An agreement between Turkey, Russia and Iran in September 2018 forestalled a long-anticipated regime offensive against Idlib, which is controlled by Islamist rebel groups, the most powerful of which is Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS). The agreement centres around the creation of a buffer zone around Idlib in which Turkish forces are deployed as monitors. HTS has refused to endorse the agreement, but has stopped short of violating it. Turkey is seeking to persuade core factions of HTS to integrate with the other rebel groups and to reaffirm their rejection of the global jihadi mission of al-Qaida. If integration takes place, a significant block of Turkish-allied rebel groups could potentially be involved in the negotiations for a political settlement. The success of Turkey's machinations in Idlib is far from guaranteed, and it remains unlikely that HTS will give up its long-standing cause and join Turkish forces.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
The government's past focus on domestic power struggles and foreign-policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. Nonetheless, Turkey's economy has shown resilience during previous bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing to its solid public finances, its well-capitalised banking sector and its dynamic and diversified private sector.
In the aftermath of the failed coup in July 2016 a highly accommodative policy stance has exacerbated fiscal and external imbalances. This, together with heightened political uncertainty, the tightening of global liquidity conditions and tensions with the US, led to a currency crisis in August 2018. The heavily pro-growth approach to economic policymaking that Mr Erdogan has espoused enthusiastically over the past decade will persist over our forecast period (2019-23), at the expense of inflation control and fiscal discipline. This approach will continue to have a significant effect on, for example, monetary policy, macroprudential regulation, public-private capital investments and social spending. Shortcomings such as cronyism and corruption, skills mismatches (a major factor behind the high unemployment rate), and tax evasion are unlikely to be addressed in 2019-23, as propping up economic growth-partly to avoid social unrest-will remain the priority.
In the case of a severe economic or banking crisis (not our core forecast), Turkey's options would remain limited, as Gulf Co-operation Council (GCC) countries appear unwilling to offer financial support. This is because Turkey is forging closer ties with Iran, a country with which Saudi Arabia is at odds. In addition, Turkey's ties with Saudi Arabia deteriorated (from an already low base) after Jamal Khashoggi, a Saudi journalist, was murdered in the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, Turkey's largest city, in October 2018. Furthermore, any potential IMF programme would include a level of foreign involvement that the government would be likely to view as unacceptable, and that would run counter to Mr Erdogan's nationalist, anti-Western rhetoric. There is also little prospect of EU financial assistance, not least because there would be no consensus on this issue among EU member states. Only China, therefore, appears able at present to offer a financial lifeline to Turkey. Such assistance could come as part of China's Belt and Road Initiative, which seeks to boost transport infrastructure between Asia and Europe to foster trade and connectivity.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
The public finances have traditionally been one of the Turkish economy's most reassuring aspects. Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios reflect the positive impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past.
Despite a series of tax rises in 2018 and official promises of budgetary tightening, higher government spending on defence, security, infrastructure, public employment and social benefits will have caused the deficit to widen in 2018, to an estimated 1.9% of GDP, from 1.5% in 2017.
In 2019-23 we expect a cautious approach to on-balance-sheet fiscal policy. This, alongside a recovering economy, will cause the deficit to narrow gradually, from 2.2% in 2019 to 1.5% of GDP in 2023.
We expect the central government debt/GDP ratio to have remained broadly stable, at 28% of GDP at end-2018 (from 28.3% at end-2017), despite economic turmoil following the August currency crisis and various government handouts ahead of the June 2018 elections. The ratio will decline slightly, to 25.3% by end-2023 as macroeconomic conditions normalise and the budget deficit shrinks.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
In September 2018 the Central Bank of Turkey's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) raised its main policy rate, the one-week repo (repurchase agreement) lending rate, to 24%, from 17.75% previously. The MPC's decision was a response to the lira's sharp depreciation against the US dollar in August, as well as to the record rise in annual consumer price inflation. The average cost of central bank funding is likely to be above the main policy rate, however. The bank retains the option of providing some of its funding for the banking system at its overnight lending rates, which are 1.5-3% higher than the one-week repo rate.
We expect the central bank to keep monetary policy tight in the first half of 2019. From mid-2019 to 2020 the central bank will gradually lower its policy rate in response to declining inflationary pressures and a normalisation of financial market conditions. In 2021-23 we believe that it will miss its inflation target of 5%. This reflects the government's continued pro-growth stance; it will put pressure on the bank to keep nominal rates below what would credibly be required to lower inflation to the 5% target.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
Real GDP growth accelerated sharply in 2017, to 7.3% (from 3.3% in 2016), supported by government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit, improved export competitiveness and a pick-up in global demand. However, the surge in economic growth has exacerbated internal and external imbalances. These imbalances-coupled with heightened policy unpredictability, foreign investors' concerns regarding the independence of the central bank, reliance on short-term capital inflows, a rising interest rate environment in advanced economies and a diplomatic spat with the US-contributed to the lira losing about 40% of its value against the US dollar in January-August 2018. The sharp depreciation of the lira caused consumer price inflation to accelerate from already high rates, increased input costs for corporations and raised the debt-servicing costs of foreign-currency-denominated liabilities. Higher domestic interest rates and rising risk premiums further dent the economic outlook.
High-frequency indicators for October-November 2018 (latest available data) suggest that the economy stalled in the wake of the currency crisis. After quarterly growth of 0.3% in the second quarter of 2018, GDP contracted in the third quarter, by 1.6%. We expect negative quarterly growth readings in the last quarter of 2018 and the first quarter of 2019, with activity starting to pick up in the second quarter of 2019. As a result, we believe that growth decelerated to 3.1% in 2018 and that GDP will grow only slightly in 2019, by 1% (mainly owing to base effects).
In 2020 we expect full-year growth to rebound to 4.9% as the economy recovers and spare capacity is depleted. In 2021-23 economic growth will average about 4%, in line with the economy's forecast potential growth rate. There are substantial downside risks to our forecasts; these growth profiles do not reflect the possible impact of a severe banking crisis (not our core scenario), although we expect non-performing loans to rise and credit availability to be impaired in the coming quarters.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
In full-year 2018 the currency crisis and rising global commodity prices have driven inflation higher, to a peak of 16.4% (from 11.1% in 2017). In 2019 inflation will remain elevated in the first half of the year and then moderate gradually on the back of a broadly stable lira (against the US dollar), a limited increase in global oil prices and the emergence of spare capacity in the economy. On average, we forecast inflation of 15.2% in 2019-only marginally below the 2018 rate.
The moderating trend in inflation will continue in 2020, with an average inflation rate of 9.1% as global oil prices decline and the exchange rate depreciates only slightly (in nominal terms) against the US dollar. In 2021-23 we expect inflation to stabilise at an average of 7.1%-still above the central bank's medium-term target of 5%. Economic growth in these years will be close to the economy's potential growth rate (limiting upward inflationary pressures).
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
In 2018 the lira depreciated by 24.5% against the US dollar (in nominal terms). The lira depreciated significantly in January-August, with the exchange rate briefly reaching a low point of TL7.2:US$1 on August 13th. After a substantial recovery from September, the lira remained broadly stable against the US dollar in the remainder of the year. This was due to the decrease in tensions between the US and Turkey, the sharp reduction in the current-account deficit (a direct result of the currency depreciation) and the tight monetary policy stance of the central bank, which reassured foreign investors of the bank's independence.
In 2019 we forecast that the lira will continue to depreciate on average against the US dollar, albeit at a much more moderate pace than in 2018. A normalising economic and financial domestic situation will support the exchange rate. However, there will be an increase in global risk aversion as the effects of the US-China bilateral trade war are fully felt, the cooling of the global economy causes expectations of a recession in some advanced economies to build and central banks in advanced economies tighten their monetary policy stances. As a result, we expect an average exchange rate of TL5.6:US$1 in 2019.
In 2020 we expect the exchange rate to remain broadly stable as the economy starts to grow more markedly after an expected slump in 2018-19. Thereafter in 2021-23 we expect a gradual depreciation of the lira against the US dollar in nominal terms, to TL6.2:US$1 by the end of 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The current-account deficit as a share of GDP narrowed in 2018, to an estimated 4.5%, from 5.6% in 2017, as the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar depressed imports (owing to a deceleration in domestic demand) and boosted export competitiveness.
In 2019-23 we expect a smaller average annual current-account deficit of 3.5% of GDP. Significant gains in competitiveness from past lira depreciation, which moderated inflation, and the emergence of spare capacity will result in a boost to exports and a compression in imports over the medium term.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
Global data
OECD growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP growth and components: Turkstat
Population: UN Population database and Economist Intelligence Unit interpolation
Consumer prices: IMF, IFS; Turkstat
Industrial production: derived from OECD, Main Economic Indicators
Exchange rates and interest rates: IMF, IFS
External trade and balance of payments: IMF, IFS; Central Bank of Turkey; Turkstat
Central government financial balance: IMF, IFS; Turkish Treasury
Foreign direct investment: IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report; Central Bank of Turkey
Abbreviations
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
Turkstat: Turkish Statistical Institute
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Manoeuvring ahead of the presidential and legislative elections in 2019 will create tensions and distract from efforts to contain security threats and the implementation of much-needed economic reform.
The administration will struggle to tackle high levels of poverty and the country's ethnic and religious divisions. This will create a potent mixture that will lead to frequent violent instability and directly affect key economic sectors.
The 2019 elections will be a close contest between the ruling All Progressives Congress and the People's Democratic Party (PDP). We expect that the PDP candidate, Atiku Abubakar, will win, but that the next administration will face the same divisions as the current one.
Policy reform-particularly in the vital oil industry-will be slow as a result of divisions in the political elite between advocates of tough, unpopular market reforms and those who pander to nationalistic and pro-subsidy interest groups.
Inertia over key economic reforms will at times actively decelerate growth. The Central Bank of Nigeria will not act completely independently, and the overall policy agenda will be pulled in differing directions by various powerful interest groups.
Fiscal expenditure will remain dominated by recurrent spending, despite attempts to boost capital investment. Efforts to boost non-oil tax revenue will be constrained by weak bureaucratic capacity and low economic growth.
Constrained by a crippling infrastructure deficit, economic growth will be well below levels needed to boost job creation and increase living standards.
Inflation will remain high over the forecast period (2019-23) amid expansionary fiscal policy and high food prices stemming from government efforts to limit imports and support local producers.
The authorities will continue to intervene in the foreign-exchange market, although the naira will nonetheless depreciate in 2019-21. Higher oil prices will then lessen the need for manipulation and the naira will stabilise in 2022-23.
The current account will record surpluses throughout the forecast period, with some output gains in the oil sector and supportive world oil prices. The difficult business environment will restrict the development of non-oil exports.

Nigeria's business environment score will improve slightly but its global and regional rankings will worsen as the administration struggles with the reform process and other countries make more significant improvements.
Country forecast overview: Nigeria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Progress on market-oriented reforms remains slow, given various vested interests and inefficiencies. Atiku Abubakar of the People's Democratic Party presses for deregulation, but the legislature is unlikely to be amenable.
2021-23: Improving prospects for the non-oil private sector remains a priority, but progress will be slow.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Confusion over oil sector reform creates ongoing uncertainty for investors. The government favours local companies in oil sector deals.
2021-23: Clearer policy lines help to stem the trend of lower investment in the oil and gas sectors, but mistrust between the numerous stakeholders prevents any major upturn in foreign direct investment.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Political upheaval around the 2019 elections delays reforms that would make trading across borders easier.
2021-23: A premium between the official and the black-market exchange rates persists.
Taxes
2019-20: Focus intensifies on boosting tax compliance, especially given weak prospects for oil revenue. Retroactive measures become a possibility, although the business community would fight these.
2021-23: Tax rates for the oil and gas sector increase under new legislation. Efforts to increase value-added tax (VAT) and to move more of the informal economy into the formal sector see non-oil collection also improve.
Financing
2019-20: Funding for well-planned projects becomes easier to raise domestically once the 2019 elections are concluded, as local capital markets deepen (with greater foreign participation) and the banking sector develops.
2021-23: Credit conditions become easier for businesses as the current-account surplus boosts national savings and investment.
The labour market
2019-20: Employers face major problems, including a shortage of skilled manual workers, restrictive visa regulations and poor health indicators.
2021-23: Employers continue to struggle to find suitably qualified staff.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Government spending on the priority area of infrastructure hits capacity constraints. Although there should be growth in private-sector investment, the government struggles to create an encouraging environment.
2021-23: Expenditure on infrastructure increases, but white elephant projects hold back the productivity of investment.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Nigeria continues to have a vibrant technology sector for an economy at its stage of development, but infrastructure is weak outside urban hubs.
2021-23: Research spending is likely to remain low compared with global averages, but some home-grown technology firms looking to adapt global technology trends to the Nigerian market continue to do well.

Background: Nigeria gained independence in 1960 and the army soon became the dominant political player. Multiparty democracy was restored in 1999. That presidential poll and the next one, in 2003, were both won by a former military ruler turned civilian politician, Olusegun Obasanjo. Mr Obasanjo was unable to change the constitution to allow him to serve a third term in office, so in the 2007 election power passed to his handpicked successor, Umaru Yar'Adua. After Mr Yar'Adua's death in May 2010, his vice-president, Goodluck Jonathan, assumed the presidency and went on to win the 2011 presidential election. Mr Jonathan was defeated by Muhammadu Buhari in the 2015 presidential election-the first time an incumbent had been defeated at the ballot box and an important step forward for the country's democracy.
Political structure: Under the constitution adopted in May 1999, a strong executive presidency appoints a Federal Executive Council, comprising government ministers and ministers of state from each of Nigeria's 36 states. The executive is accountable to the bicameral National Assembly. Political parties tend to lack clear ideologies; in practice, personal and ethnic ties dominate the political process. The People's Democratic Party (Mr Jonathan's party) had historically been the only political party to attract nationwide support, but the merger in 2013 of three large opposition parties to form the All Progressives Congress gave them, with Mr Buhari at the helm, the reach that they needed to take power in 2015. Although the 36 state governments enjoy significant autonomy, almost all remain dependent on the federal government for funding.
Policy issues: Successive governments have sought to improve macroeconomic stability and develop the nation's dire infrastructure, with mixed results. Meanwhile, the government is struggling to end insecurity in various parts of the country. These tensions are stoked by the underlying problems of poverty and unemployment. Management of the naira by the authorities is contentious, and currency liberalisation will be postponed whenever foreign-exchange supplies permit.
Taxation: Corporate profits in most non-oil sectors are taxed at 30%. Planned changes to the tax system for the oil and gas sector have been repeatedly delayed, creating uncertainty. Most other taxes are low, reflecting the fact that most revenue comes from the oil sector, with the total tax take very small as a share of GDP. Tax compliance is a time-consuming process.
Foreign trade: Exports are dominated by oil. The slump in oil prices from the second half of 2014 almost wiped out what had historically been a large current-account surplus. The non-oil export base has been rendered globally uncompetitive by an overvalued exchange rate and massive infrastructure deficiencies.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts severe outbreaks of instability, given slow progress on tackling numerous security and societal challenges at a time of economic difficulty. A concerted effort is needed to eliminate the Islamist terrorist organisation Boko Haram in the north-east and bring an end to conflict between settled farmers and pastoralists in central Nigeria. Both of these problems are increasing in terms of the devastation being caused. Ahead of elections in February 2019 policymakers will be distracted, and the polls themselves will be a time of high risk, with possible disputation of the results. This is more likely if the opposition People's Democratic Party (PDP) lose the presidency, with many of its cadres sure that the vote will be rigged. However, our baseline forecast is that the president, Muhammadu Buhari, will lose power, and that the next government will be led by Atiku Abubakar of the PDP. Even if the election passes peacefully the new government will be faced with the same insoluble security problems as the outgoing administration. Boko Haram is resurgent, militancy in the oil-producing Niger Delta is an omnipresent threat, and clashes between herders and farmers are becoming more intense as a result of increasing competition for scarce water and land. Nigeria's overstretched military will be unable to decisively end violence in either region, with meagre federal government resources being stretched too thin. It will also prove hard to create economic opportunities for local populations; poverty and rising unemployment are at the root of much of the instability.
Parliamentary rifts will be another problem. Both of Nigeria's main parties, the ruling All Progressives Congress (APC) and the PDP, lack any clear ideology, and most legislators prioritise their constituents' needs over party. As different regions have competing interests and vastly different priorities, the collective resolve needed to bring permanent peace to unstable parts of Nigeria will be lacking.
Our central forecast is, however, that the 2019 elections will be completed without a widespread breakdown in order, with Nigeria's democracy proving robust enough to endure once again. However, major unrest in a localised form will continue as comprehensive solutions prove too complex and politically costly to implement. Speculation over the threat of a military coup or a civil war is likely to surface periodically but we consider a widespread breakdown of security to be unlikely; the military has become more professional and has been depoliticised since the junta stepped aside in 1999. Meanwhile, there is little appetite beyond extremist agitators for a return to civil war, given memories of how disastrous the 1967-70 conflict was for the country. Nonetheless, as the country's leadership struggles to shift Nigeria onto a more sustainable path to economic development, the risks to stability will intensify as more and more Nigerians question what they have to lose from pushing for violent change.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Presidential and legislative elections are due in February 2019. Mr Buhari is the APC's presidential candidate, and his main challenger is Mr Abubakar-who was confirmed as the PDP's candidate in early October after winning overwhelming backing from party members. Launching his election campaign on November 19th, Mr Abubakar has pledged to reinvigorate the economy with pro-market reforms. Both candidates are from northern Nigeria, where Mr Buhari's support base lies, presaging a fierce contest there. With the vote likely to be split in the north, Mr Abubakar will find it easier to garner support from the country's south, which has traditionally been a PDP stronghold. This gives Mr Abubakar an edge, as does popular frustration over the rise in joblessness and poverty (two of the biggest concerns of voters) on Mr Buhari's watch. Growing instability in north-eastern and central Nigeria also denies the incumbent much in the way of achievements to boast of while in office; he was given a clear mandate in 2015 to restore law and order. Nonetheless, strong incumbency advantages in Nigeria imply that it will be a very tight race. If Mr Abubakar loses-a distinct downside risk to our forecast-there may be a rejection of the result by the PDP, which is convinced the election will be rigged. In this scenario, a state of national paralysis could arise, with severe national security implications.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Many of Nigeria's militant groups operate across land and sea borders, and international co-operation will therefore be needed to tackle the threat they pose. Stretched resources, vast territories and porous borders will prevent complete military victories. Relations with the US will be mixed; the administration of Donald Trump is willing to sell Nigeria military hardware, but Mr Trump's disapproval of the trade deficit the US runs with Nigeria (particularly owing to Nigerian trade barriers on agricultural imports) could strain relations. Ties with the EU will be largely cordial but subject to tensions over the large numbers of Nigerian migrants seeking to enter Europe and Nigerian efforts to repatriate funds in European banks that were allegedly looted by former rulers.
India will remain important as the largest market for Nigerian oil and become a bigger source of foreign investment. China will remain a significant source of investment, but actual inflows will total only a small proportion of the headline-grabbing pledges made given an extremely challenging local business environment.
Nigeria will remain an important player on the Sub-Saharan African stage given its size, but its domestic challenges will tend to keep policymakers inwardly focused. Relations with South Africa will remain strained. Africa's two largest economies will continue to compete for political, economic and cultural influence.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Mr Abubakar advocates a pro-business and free-market reform agenda, with more private participation in public services, as well as liberalisation of the oil sector and the exchange rate. His ability to pass wide-ranging economic policy reforms will depend to some extent on the composition of the legislature after the election, but even if it is dominated by the PDP, overhauling Nigeria's currency regime (and thereby unleashing a temporary inflationary spike and upsetting those who benefit from an overvalued exchange rate) or dissociating the federal government from the hydrocarbons sector-from which it gets most of its revenue-would be a momentous battle. Putting the downstream oil sector in private hands, as Mr Abubakar has posited, would also mean lifting price controls. (For many Nigerians, price controls are the only visible way that the federal government impinges on their daily lives.) Assuming the state retains much of its interest in the oil sector, related issues will still need to be resolved, including fiscal terms and revenue management. Oil companies, workers and local politicians (not to mention various militant groups) will all pull in different directions. However, there is a distinct upside risk that progress on free-market reform will be more rapid than under our baseline forecast. Mr Buhari has been ideologically disposed towards state intervention in the economy, meaning there was little cause for him to overhaul the status quo. A more concerted effort to open up the economy to investment by Mr Abubakar could produce positive results.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
Fiscal policy will centre on attempting to diversify sources of revenue away from oil while directing more expenditure to pro-poor activities and infrastructure investment. Non-oil revenue will rise because of efforts to widen tax coverage and collect overdue taxes, but from an extremely low base. Instability in many parts of the country will also be an impediment. More importantly, oil production targets budgeted for by the government are repeatedly overambitious; for example in 2019 the government expects output of 2.3m barrels/day-a level not seen for well over a decade, and one that will be unobtainable given antiquated oil infrastructure. Total revenue is not expected to rise above 3.4% of GDP, a ratio only attained in 2023 when oil prices are at their highest within the forecast period.
After some projected expansion in 2018, spending will decline as a proportion of GDP in 2019 with deep cuts to the capital budget. Partly offsetting this will be a rise in populist recurrent spending on wages and public-sector benefits. Generally, flexibility on spending will be restricted by high levels of debt-servicing and a costly petrol subsidy, as well as pressing security needs. But with oil prices-and so revenue-under pressure and there being considerable political pressure to curb the fiscal deficit, we expect the spending/GDP ratio to dip again in 2020 and only begin to increase materially as elections in 2023 approach. Altogether we expect an average budget deficit equal to 2% of GDP over 2019-23.
Although higher oil prices will give some reprieve, longer-term public debt sustainability will remain in doubt. Central government debt is low as a proportion of GDP compared with other emerging markets, but it is set against a low revenue base. Debt service already takes up close to one-third of federal government income, and yields on government securities are increasing as global monetary conditions tighten and foreign investors repatriate capital. A federal government default is unlikely, but repayment difficulties are possible at state level, where revenue collection is even weaker.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
Monetary policy will concentrate on bolstering economic recovery while limiting inflation and maintaining currency stability. However, this will generate contradictory pressures in the early part of the forecast period. The private sector is desperate for cheaper credit, but inflation will remain above the targeted upper limit of 9% set by the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN). On balance, interest rates will not move much in 2019, but they will dip in 2020 as the wider global economy slows and the monetary authorities attempt to stimulate activity, with Nigeria following suit. Rates will then stabilise in 2021-23 as economic activity picks up and inflation remains above target. However, real interest rates will be too high to support private-sector activity outside of highly profitable ventures. The CBN also faces an issue over its independence. Mr Abubakar has expressed concern about state interference in the CBN's affairs, but it remains to be seen if independence would be made secure under his presidency.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
The economy will for the most part be mired in a low-growth cycle, although there will be improvements over time. In 2019 what are expected to be fiercely contested elections in February will hold back business and consumer confidence. Although markets are likely to approve of Mr Abubakar's economic reform agenda-meaning the disruption is likely to be short-lived-high local borrowing costs will hold back investment ,and we forecast a growth rate of 1.9%; this is the lowest annual rate of growth in our five-year outlook period. Growth will increase in 2020 as uncertainty passes, but only moderately-as an expected slowdown in the world economy holds back export-oriented sectors. In 2021-23, as global markets strengthen and external demand picks up, the rate of growth will quicken to an annual average of 3%. This is well below potential, with numerous factors holding the economy back.
In terms of sectoral growth, agriculture will record only lacklustre growth; although boosting food production is a key government objective, weak infrastructure and violent competition for access to land in the fertile Middle Belt will be huge impediments. Industrial production will be severely curtailed by militancy and labour agitation in the oil sector, holding back production even when prices are relatively high. An infrastructure deficit and a legacy of chronic underinvestment will also constrain hydrocarbons production, which is not expected to return to levels prior to the 2015 commodity-price crash. The manufacturing sector will continue to struggle in the face of cheap goods from abroad, which are often smuggled into the country to bypass import bans. The services sector is less affected by instability and so will be a stronger contributor to growth than industry, but it will nonetheless be held back by trade protectionism and tight credit conditions (particularly affecting areas such as real estate and finance), as well as the struggle in the communications sector to profitably roll out data services beyond urban hubs.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
From an estimated rate of 11.2% in 2018, average inflation will increase to 13.8% in 2019, as the naira enters a period of managed depreciation and pre-election giveaways (including a substantial increase in the minimum wage) add to upward price pressures. Inflation will edge up further, to 14.2% in 2020, on the back of a weakening currency. Thereafter, with only a modest depreciation in 2021 followed by currency stability, inflation will ease to a still-high average of 9.7% in 2023. Preventing a faster slide will be protectionist measures that limit relatively cheap imports from abroad, particularly of food. If Mr Abubakar goes ahead with an unofficial proposal to fully float the naira, inflation would exceed these forecasts by a considerable margin. (Nigeria is heavily dependent on imports, and consumer prices are highly sensitive to currency movements.)
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
We expect the multiple-exchange-rate system to persist throughout 2019-23, with a notable differential between the official rate used for government business and the market-determined rate applicable to investors and exporters (with various other rates in between). Such a system allows the government to subsidise sectors deemed important for economic or political reasons. Oil prices, and with them the level of hard-currency earnings, will in large part dictate where the authorities are able to hold the official rate and what the premium is between the official and the market rates. In 2019 political events (such as the magnitude of instability that accompanies the election period) will also have an impact, and jitters will cause the official rate to drop from an estimated average of N305.6:US$1 in 2018 to N316.3:US$1. A widening spread between the official and parallel rate supports this view. With oil prices forecast to decline in 2020, and with a cumulative real appreciation in previous years, we expect a further fall in the value of the naira, to an average of N355.8:US$1. As oil prices pick up on average over the rest of the forecast period, we expect the naira to receive greater support, with an average rate of N377.9:US$1 in 2023.
Forecasting the naira
Although The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts both the official and the secondary market rates, it is the official rate that appears in most of our data presentations, as it is the longest-running and best-tracked variable. For example, the current market-determined rate, known as the Nigerian Autonomous Foreign Exchange Rate Fixing (Nafex), has only been in full operation since April 2017, making historical calculations challenging. However, indicators that are converted into US dollars at the official rate are essentially overvalued.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The export profile will move in tandem with oil production trends and world crude prices. With some oil export volume gains expected in 2019 (as a key pipeline that disrupted exports in 2018 resumes operations) and reasonably flat world oil prices, export earnings will increase. Exports will then dip in 2020 in line with a drop in world oil prices, before strengthening in 2021-22 as oil prices recover. In 2023 prices will dip but output will rise slightly, thereby supporting a further modest rise in export earnings. After a one-off surge in capital imports in 2018, imports will contract in 2019 to levels more consistent with the (weak) short-term demand outlook. From there will follow steady import growth led by an economic recovery, with the rate of increase especially fast in 2022-23 as the naira stabilises. Trade-related services imports and profit repatriation will pick up, in line with faster economic growth and increased oil-sector activity. Meanwhile, workers' remittances will remain an important source of hard currency, albeit dipping in 2020 as growth falters in the US (home to a large Nigerian diaspora). Overall, the current-account surplus will broadly track movements in world oil prices, narrowing from 4.1% of GDP in 2019 to 2.8% of GDP in 2020, then widening again to 3.6% of GDP by 2022 before retreating again to 3.4% of GDP in 2023.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; the source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: IEA average import price
Non-oil commodity prices: IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
EUR 3-month interbank rate: IFS
Domestic data
Population: UN
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics
Balance of payments: IFS and CBN, Annual Report and Statement of Accounts
Inflation: IFS, CBN and Federal Office of Statistics
Exchange rate: IFS; principal rate expressed as naira:US dollar
Interest rate: IFS; year-end lending rate
GDP growth and expenditure breakdown: World Bank, World Tables; 1987 prices
US$ GDP: IFS; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
GDP per head: US dollar GDP divided by population
Oil production: IEA; m barrels/day
Oil price: The Economist Intelligence Unit; dated Brent Blend
FDI: IFS, UNCTAD, World Investment Report and CBN
Total external debt: sum of long- and short-term debt and IMF credits
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding, with an original maturity of more than one year
Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
IMF credits: IFS and country page on website
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges on total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
CBN: Central Bank of Nigeria
IEA: International Energy Agency
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
NPC: National Population Commission
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development

Abstract: Fact sheet Annual data 2017a Historical averages (%) 2013-17 Population (m) 11.2 Population growth -0.4 GDP (US$ bn; market exchange rate) 202.9 Real GDP growth -0.4 GDP (US$ bn; purchasing power parity) 300.3 Real domestic demand growth -0.5 GDP per head (US$; market exchange rate) 18,185 Inflation -0.7 GDP per head (US$; purchasing power parity) 26,911 Current-account balance (% of GDP) -1.6 Exchange rate (av) [euro]:US$ 0.9 FDI inflows (% of GDP) 1.2 a Actual. The government requires the support of parliament to hold office. Since the 2010 crisis, the traditional party system has broken down. The coalition government-comprising Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza, the party of the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras) and the small, right-wing nationalist Independent Greeks (AE)-that took office in September 2015 has only a slim majority in the 300-seat parliament. Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The government-comprising Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza, the party of the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras) and the small, right-wing Independent Greeks (AE)-has a two-seat majority in the 300-seat parliament. It is vulnerable to further defections, especially regarding the implementation of further austerity measures and the Macedonia name-change agreement reached in June 2018.
The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that an early election will be held before the end of the parliamentary term in October 2019, possibly in conjunction with the European Parliament and the local elections in May 2019. We expect the centre-right New Democracy (ND) to win the most seats and to form a government. However, it would probably have to secure the support of at least one other party to muster a parliamentary majority.
Greece will remain subject to strict policy conditionality in the medium term, until its debt to its international creditors is substantially reduced. Protests are likely to continue as the government strives to meet ambitious annual primary surplus budget targets of 3.5% of GDP until 2022 and 2.2% from 2023, as agreed with Greece's creditors. Mr Tsipras's promises to lower tax and reverse spending cuts could cause tensions with the country's international creditors and investors.
Greece is facing its biggest macroeconomic challenge now that it has exited the bail-out programme and no longer has access to official borrowing at preferential interest rates. However, Greece does not face short-term financing difficulties, as it will have sufficient funds to cover its debt repayments until the end of 2020. A Greek exit from the euro zone represents a risk over the long term.
We expect that real GDP growth will pick up from 1.4% in 2017 to a moderate 2% per year on average in 2018-23. Public debt is forecast to continue to exceed 175% of GDP in 2023. Meeting large primary surplus targets and restoring competitiveness will prove to be difficult.
We estimate that annual average inflation will ease, from 1.1% in 2017 to 0.8% in 2018, before rising to an annual average of 1% in 2019 and about 1.5% in 2020-23), reflecting a moderate pick-up in domestic demand and higher energy prices. This will result in still moderate current-account deficits in 2018-23.

Greece's score recovers modestly in our forecast period, from a low base. The main areas of improvement are expected in the macroeconomic environment, as a result of efforts to improve policy towards foreign investment, private enterprise and competition, and the labour market.
Country forecast overview: Greece's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The country's privatisation agency (under new management) gains momentum, unblocking some delayed deals.
2021-23: Efforts to valorise public property through concession management and long-leasehold development agreements.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: The Investment Incentives Law of 2016 offers more tax relief and fewer subsidies, and focuses predominantly on small firms. Plans to cut down on bureaucracy make little progress.
2021-23: "Fast-track" legislation could become more important if the economy normalises. It will cover "strategic" investments in energy, tourism, transport, communications and health.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Remaining capital controls introduced in June 2015 are eliminated. Capital buffer of about EUR26bn sufficient to cover almost two years of the government's financing needs.
2021-23: There is a significant risk of Greece leaving the euro zone in the long term if growth continues to disappoint. Grexit would probably result in the reintroduction of exchange controls and possibly restrictions on trade.
Taxes
2019-20: Extensive efforts to widen the tax base. Government pledges to pursue aggressive tax collection, but implementation is difficult. Indirect taxes increase. Mandatory introduction of electronic point of sale terminals helps.
2021-23: Limited progress in cutting corporate income tax or value-added tax (VAT). Measures to tackle tax evasion stepped up. Independence of tax authority remains in doubt.
Financing
2019-20: Liquidity tight. Uncertainty constrains lending capacity. Steps to reduce non-performing loans (NPLs) are slow, but foreign interest picks up. A moratorium on foreclosures is lifted for the majority of debtors.
2021-23: The need to increase provisions for still high NPLs hampers lending. More Greek bank foreign subsidiaries are sold off.
The labour market
2019-20: Labour market reforms now mostly passed, but implementation is problematic. Unemployment remains high.
2021-23: EU funded job-creation schemes, particularly for youth, raise employment, but create few productive jobs.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Energy infrastructure comes to the fore as Trans-Adriatic Pipeline (TAP) nears completion. Privatisations pick up pace.
2021-23: Technical assistance from the EU helps absorption of European funds to revive infrastructure investment.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Greece rolls out high-speed internet, at a slow pace. The private sector adopts electronic payments by law.
2021-23: Significant financial and technical assistance from the EU, but Greece remains a laggard.

Background: After 400 years of Ottoman rule Greece emerged as a sovereign state in 1830. A devastating civil war followed the retreat of German occupying forces in 1944. A military junta ruled the country from 1967 to 1974, but since then a democracy has been in place. In 1981 Greece joined the European Economic Community, now the EU. It became a member of the economic and monetary union (EMU) in 2001, but its public finances became unsustainable, resulting in a sovereign debt crisis in 2009-10. Greece's public debt has put its continued membership of the EMU into question.
Political structure: Greece is a parliamentary republic, with deputies elected for four-year terms. The prime minister and the government hold executive powers. The president is elected by the 300-member parliament for a five-year term. The government requires the support of parliament to hold office. Since the 2010 crisis, the traditional party system has broken down. Voters have blamed the parties that ruled Greece after the return of democracy in the mid-1970s-New Democracy (ND) and the Panhellenic Socialist Movement (Pasok)-for causing the crisis, which led to the imposition of painful austerity by the country's external creditors. The result has been political fragmentation and the rise of populist parties such as the left-wing Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), which came to power in 2015, and far-right parties such as the neo-fascist Golden Dawn (XA).
Policy issues: The ND-Pasok government of 2012-14, like its two predecessors, imposed draconian austerity packages. It also enacted fiscal and some structural economic reforms to meet the conditions of two EU-IMF bail-out packages, totalling EUR240bn. Implementation proved difficult and ultimately brought down the government. After a seven-month confrontation with Greece's creditors, the Syriza-led government negotiated a new three-year European Stability Mechanism (ESM) programme in August 2015. In 2012 Greece restructured its public debt, reducing the value of private-sector creditors' holdings by EUR107bn. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any further debt write-down. Now that Greece has exited the programme, it is subject to an "enhanced supervision" monitoring regime by its euro zone creditors.
Taxation: The tax rate on corporate profits is 29% and on distributed dividends is 10%. The top marginal personal income tax rate is 45% for income of more than EUR40,000. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at rates of 24%, 13% and 6%.
Foreign trade: In 2017 goods exports (fob) were worth EUR28bn and imports (fob) amounted to EUR47.9bn. The current account registered a deficit of EUR3.2bn, equivalent to 1.8% of GDP.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
Instability is set to increase during the busy electoral cycle in 2019, further weakening Greece's governance and its commitment to political and economic reform. Local and European Parliament elections are due to be held in late May, and national legislative elections are due by October, but The Economist Intelligence Unit expects it to be called early, possibly in conjunction with the elections in May. The coalition government-comprising Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza, the party of the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras) and the small, right-wing nationalist Independent Greeks (AE)-that took office in September 2015 has only a slim majority in the 300-seat parliament. Moreover, tensions within the coalition persist about a range of issues, including the continued implementation of austerity measures and the Macedonia name issue. Two members of the AE defected in protest against the agreement reached with Macedonia to end the 27-year name dispute in June, leaving the government with a majority of just two seats.
In a consultative referendum held on September 30th Macedonians voted overwhelmingly in favour of changing their country's official name from the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (its constitutional name is the Republic of Macedonia) to Severna Makedonija (North Macedonia). Despite the low turnout of well below 50% at the referendum, the agreement is now in its final stage of approval by the Macedonian parliament. However, the Syriza-led coalition government may struggle to ratify the deal if it is brought before the Greek parliament in early 2019, as is currently envisaged. The AE, which is now reduced to seven seats, has said that it will oppose the agreement.
In August 2018, after eight years of austerity and unpopular reforms under three economic adjustment programmes, Greece exited the third bail-out programme signed by the Syriza-led government in 2015. During this period in power, Mr Tsipras has lost much popular support and will struggle to revive his party's political fortunes before the next election, although it may receive a boost in popularity after the European Commission accepted the government's plan to cancel agreed pension cuts in 2019 on the grounds that they will not be needed in order to achieve the country's fiscal targets (a 3.5% primary surplus in 2018-22). We remain sceptical that real GDP growth will rise much higher than 2% during the 2019-23 forecast period, and expect that failure to implement other structural reforms agreed with Greece's international creditors could lead to delays in the implementation of the debt relief measures agreed with Greece's EU creditors.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Syriza trails in opinion polls behind the centre-right New Democracy (ND), led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis; the gap has exceeded 10 percentage points for some time. ND's lead may narrow during the election campaign, as Mr Tsipras is a formidable campaigner and there is little overt enthusiasm for Mr Mitsotakis or his party. However, given widespread popular disaffection with the Syriza government, the election-due by October 2019-is ND's to lose. If, as we expect, ND wins the largest share of the vote, it would benefit from the 50-seat bonus rule for the winning party. Even so, it would probably have to secure the support of at least one other party to muster a parliamentary majority.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Domestic political instability, and protracted economic and financial crisis, have limited Greece's influence in the EU and the Balkans region. Recent efforts to restore influence, including the Macedonian name-change agreement with Macedonia and talks on closer co-operation with the US, are fraught with difficulty as domestic pre-election tension is likely to condition foreign policy decisions. The Macedonia agreement remains a major source of tension within the Syriza-led coalition government. If the Macedonian parliament gives final approval to the related constitutional changes, as we expect, and the Greek parliament fails to ratify agreement, the decision could seriously damage Greece's relations with its Western allies, who strongly support the agreement in order to end Greece's opposition to Macedonia's accession to NATO and to its application for EU membership.
Tensions between Greece and Turkey have been threatening to boil over, increasing the risk of military hostility, particularly in the Aegean Sea. However, we believe that both sides will seek to avoid clashes. Points of contention-such as historical territorial disputes in the Aegean Sea and the Greek courts' rejection of Turkey's extradition request for Turkish soldiers who fled to Greece on the night of the July 2016 failed coup in Turkey-have fuelled distrust. Turkey's release in August of two Greek soldiers arrested in March 2018 while on patrol in the border area of Evros has eased tensions slightly.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Despite exiting the third economic adjustment programmes in August 2018 without a precautionary credit line, the government will still be subject to huge policy constraints during the forecast period and beyond. General government debt is huge, at an estimated 185% of GDP in 2018 and also almost entirely owed to official creditors (the EU and the IMF), making another debt write-down, as happened in 2012, highly unlikely.
In June Greece's official creditors agreed to close the final review of the third bail-out programme, paving the way for a disbursement of EUR15bn, which was released in August. Of this, EUR3.3bn was earmarked to repay more expensive IMF debt, and the balance to create a buffer for Greece to use while it builds up market access. The total buffer, estimated at EUR26bn, should be sufficient to cover almost two years of the country's financing needs to end-2020. This is more onerous than a precautionary credit line would have been, as Greece will be accruing interest on money that it does not currently need. However, intense political pressure not to invite further policy conditionality led the government to choose the more expensive option.
In June EU creditors also agreed to further debt relief for Greece, which was granted a ten-year grace period and a ten-year maturity extension on EUR96bn of its loans (provided by the European Financial Stability Facility). It will also get a reduction in the interest rates (for loans of EUR130.9bn), and a return of profits from the securities market programme and from the Agreement on Net Financial Assets, which comprises the official sector holders of Greek debt-the European Central Bank (ECB) and national central banks of euro area countries. The value of the return is estimated to be about EUR5bn in total in 2018-22.
In response, Greece has committed to long-term fiscal prudence. It must achieve annual primary budget surpluses of 3.5% of GDP in 2018-22 and 2.2% thereafter, until 2060. It will also be subject to an "enhanced surveillance" regime, which is a more exacting system of post-programme monitoring than those applied to other former bail-out countries. The debt-relief measures will be subject to quarterly reviews of the state of the economy and of the government's adherence to its commitments. As these reviews will be published, transgression by Greece would adversely affect market access.
After a three-year absence Greece has returned to the financial markets three times since July 2017. However, after its exit from the bail-out programme in August, it will do so without the backstop of an official credit line. Recent emerging-market turbulence and investor risk aversion highlight the difficulties that Greece could face in the future on the international capital markets. Greece should have sufficient funds to meet its financing needs in the short term. In the medium and long term, however, the political and, arguably, the economic price of meeting high annual primary surplus targets may become unbearable. During the past two years Greece has exceeded its annual primary surplus targets, but at the expense of economic growth, which has been disappointing. Meeting such targets will remain a constraint on growth, alongside other negative factors, such as poor demographics and a weak business environment. Grexit is not a short- or medium-term risk; however, given that Greece is unlikely to improve competitiveness inside the euro zone or to grow its way out of its huge debt burden, it will represent a possibility in the long term.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
Greece recorded an overall budget surplus of 0.8% of GDP and a primary surplus (budget balance minus interest payments) of 3.9% in 2017, exceeding the bail-out programme target of 1.75%. From 2018 we expect fiscal performance to deteriorate gradually, with the budget balance returning to moderately widening headline deficits and primary surpluses falling well short of the official target of 3.5% of GDP for 2018-22, reflecting constraints on revenue collection, a relaxation of spending restraint and only modest economic growth. Although the primary surplus target will decline to 2.2% of GDP from 2023, it will still be difficult to achieve, owing to the fact that debt repayments become much more onerous from that year on.
The restructuring of government debt owed to the private sector cut the debt/GDP ratio to 159.4% at end-2012, from 171.9% in 2011. However, large primary surpluses in 2016-17 were insufficient to arrest the growth of gross consolidated government debt. We expect that, without a debt write-down and assuming moderate nominal medium-term GDP growth rates, the public debt/GDP ratio will still be more than 170% at the end of 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The ECB is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a quantitative easing (QE) programme that ran at EUR30bn per month in January-September 2018. The programme is running at EUR15bn per month in October-December before coming to an end. Economic activity in the euro zone has softened this year, but the ECB's view of the outlook remains fairly positive. Rising commodity prices and evidence of building domestic price pressure in some parts of the euro zone should mean that sufficient inflationary pressures will begin to emerge on the policy horizon in 2019-20. In response, we expect the ECB to take steps towards normalising its policy stance, with an increase of 25 basis points in the main refinancing rate to 0.25% in early 2020, followed by five more rises that will lift the rate to 2% by end-2023. An increase in the deposit rate, which currently stands at -0.4%, may come sooner, in 2019, easing the pressure on banks' lending margins and supporting profitability.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
Compared with 2007 levels, real GDP has shrunk by more than one-quarter, government consumption by almost one-quarter, household consumption by one-fifth and gross fixed investment by almost two-thirds. The recovery, which began at the start of 2017, is fragile and vulnerable to domestic and external developments. After real GDP growth of 1.4% in 2017, we estimate growth of 2.1% in 2018. In 2019-23 real GDP growth will remain constrained at an average of 1.9%. The risks to our forecast are balanced. Upside risks include a continued strong tourism performance, if capacity constraints are addressed. Downside risks include the frailty of the banking sector and political instability.
Our estimate for 2018 real GDP growth is a disappointing rate of expansion in the context of the slump of the past decade. We expect a combination of more-and higher-taxes, higher social security payments, debt repayments and spending cuts to put pressure on household disposable income. Although we expect a modest acceleration in household spending in 2018-23, this will be from a low base and will be constrained by large primary surplus targets of 3.5% of GDP per year up to 2022 and 2.2% in 2023, continued high unemployment and insipid lending growth.
Quarterly gross fixed investment has been volatile in recent years, but recorded strong full-year growth in 2016-17, albeit from a low base. However, reflecting base effects and a loss of momentum, investment contracted by an average of 6.2% year on year in the first three quarters of 2018. Despite an expected modest quarter-on-quarter increase in the final three months of 2018, we now expect a full-year contraction of 7.5%, followed by average annual growth of 5.2% in 2019-23, leaving fixed investment still about 50% below its 2007 peak. Underinvestment during the crisis, and the depletion of Greece's capital stock, are likely to restrict growth potential in the medium term.
Greece's external trade will be constrained by its relatively uncompetitive goods exports. In the medium term we expect tourism to continue to support services export growth, contributing to annual average growth of exports of goods and services of 8.2% in 2018, and 4.2% in 2019-23.
Greece will face its biggest macroeconomic challenge now that it no longer has access to official external financing at preferential rates. How the economy performs in the next five years (and beyond) will determine whether the country will remain in the euro zone. Although risks have abated since the height of the financial crisis, we believe that there is a risk that Greece will exit the euro zone in the long term, given the difficulties that it will face in attaining rapid growth while meeting large primary surplus targets and in restoring competitiveness without a currency devaluation. Greece's exiting of the euro zone (not our core scenario) would lead to a sovereign default and severe recession in the first few years, but the economy would then recover, assuming a responsible fiscal policy guided by the necessity to achieve a primary surplus.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
After averaging 1.1% in 2017, driven by higher global energy prices, Greece's annual consumer price inflation rate (seasonally adjusted, EU harmonised) dipped sharply at the start of 2018, before increasing moderately in May-October. The economy has returned to growth, but significant slack in the labour market, subdued domestic demand and recent decreases in global oil prices will dampen inflationary pressures. We expect that inflation will pick up only modestly, from an estimated average of 0.8% in 2018 to 1% in 2019 and 1.5% per year in 2020-23 as the pace of domestic demand growth quickens.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
The euro rallied in late 2017 as the region's economic recovery strengthened and expectations of QE tapering increased, and as political risk waned in Europe but rose in the US. It peaked at almost US$1.25:EUR1 at the beginning of February 2018, but had weakened to US$1.16:EUR1 by late May in response to the formation of a populist, Eurosceptic government in Italy, and remained close to that level in June-July before weakening to US$1.13:EUR1 in mid-August. The euro recovered some value in September-October, but weakened again in November-December to US$1.13-1.14:EUR1, and will remain under pressure from political risk in Italy and monetary tightening in the US. We expect it to begin strengthening against the US dollar from the second half of 2019, on the assumption that the region's recovery will continue while growth momentum in the US slows. We forecast an average of US$1.19:EUR1 in 2019 and then US$1.22:EUR1 in 2020-21 as monetary policy in the euro zone is gradually tightened. The euro will also receive structural support from a large current-account surplus, and we expect it to appreciate to US$1.24:EUR1 on average in 2022-23.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
Greece's current-account deficit has narrowed since the start of the economic crisis. This mainly reflects the compression of imports owing to contracting domestic demand, but is also partly the result of improved competitiveness in the tourism sector. The current-account deficit widened from 0.8% of GDP in 2015 to an average of 1.8% of GDP per year in 2016-17, according to the Bank of Greece (the central bank). We expect continued deficits in 2018-23 as import volumes pick up in line with higher domestic demand and moderately higher global energy prices, but these deficits will be much smaller than the average annual deficit of 7% of GDP since Greece joined the euro zone in 2001.
