Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Following a snap general election in June 2017, in which the Conservative Party lost its parliamentary majority, the prime minister, Theresa May, formed a minority government based on a "confidence and supply" agreement with the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) of Northern Ireland. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect the government to last a full five-year term, as it will face domestic and external challenges during the Brexit process.
Mrs May will continue to face difficulties in reconciling opposing factions in her cabinet that have different views about negotiating the UK's future relationship with the EU. Divisions in the cabinet and on the Conservative backbenches over Brexit have intensified, and there is a high risk that the withdrawal agreement will be rejected in the UK parliament. Our baseline forecast is that it will be narrowly approved (either in a first or a second vote) in order to avoid a "cliff-edge" Brexit in March 2019, which would cause severe disruption.
Talks on the future UK-EU trading relationship will take place throughout 2019-20. If no trade deal is reached by July 2020, we expect the transition period, during which the UK will maintain access to the single market, to be extended from 2020. The UK and the EU have committed to negotiating a free-trade area with deep regulatory and customs co-operation. However, the details of the future relationship will depend on the outcome of complex negotiations. We expect a trade agreement to be implemented during 2021, but possibly later.
The economy was resilient following the Brexit vote, growing by 1.8% in 2016 and 1.7% in 2017, but lost momentum in 2018, as rising inflation and uncertainty surrounding the negotiations dampened domestic demand. We forecast that inflation will ease in 2019, supporting real household incomes and consumer spending, and allowing real GDP growth to recover slightly, to 1.5%. Brexit-related uncertainty will remain high but should recede in 2020-23, when we expect real GDP growth to average 1.7%.
The government's budget deficit has narrowed from 4.2% of GDP in 2015 to an estimated 1.3% of GDP in 2018. After some fiscal easing in 2019, we expect a gradual contraction in the deficit from 2020, reaching 0.5% by 2023. The Bank of England (BoE, the central bank) has started to raise interest rates again, after doing so in November 2017 for the first time in a decade. We expect the next 25-basis-point increase, to 1%, in the second quarter of 2019.

The UK's business environment score improves in the 2019-23 forecast period compared with 2014-18, lifting the UK by two places in the global ranking and by one place in the regional ranking. Brexit introduces policy uncertainty, but the county's strengths-a pro-business policy stance, a welcoming attitude to foreign investment, and flexible labour and product markets-will continue.
Country forecast overview: United Kingdom's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Government retains large stake in the Royal Bank of Scotland. Public support for energy and renationalisation of the rail sector.
2021-23: Shake-up of regulatory and competition frameworks after Brexit. Continued state support underpins house prices.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Reduced foreign investor activity. Government "assurances" encourage investment in automotive sector.
2021-23: Infrastructure plans offer investment opportunities. Likely changes in tax policies to bolster inward investment.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: UK formally leaves EU, but likely transitional agreement to end-2020 implies that status quo arrangements will largely continue. Tensions over Irish border. Talks begin on UK-EU free-trade agreement. Modest risk of "no deal" and hard Brexit.
2021-23: Expected decline in UK-EU crossborder trade. Some new UK-EU trading arrangement possibly phased in.
Taxes
2019-20: Gradual rise in personal income tax allowance, but also in total tax burden. Modest changes to business rates.
2021-23: Planned cut in corporation tax rate, to 17%. Ongoing efforts to reduce revenue lost to growing tax avoidance and evasion. Possible changes to the value-added tax (VAT) framework if the UK leaves the EU's VAT regime after 2020.
Financing
2019-20: Monetary policy is tightened gradually, but remains highly accommodative. "Ring-fencing" bank reforms and ongoing capital strengthening (ahead of 2019 deadlines). Steady growth in alternative forms of debt financing.
2021-23: Expected loss of "passporting" rights and restrictions on EU services trade. Modest decline in City of London's status.
The labour market
2019-20: Firms defer some hiring decisions amid Brexit uncertainty. Phased increase in compulsory national living wage.
2021-23: Some restrictions on free movement of labour from EU, but likely to be flexible in response to business concerns.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Modest rise in spending on housing, roads and digital infrastructure. Crossrail service in London begins operation.
2021-23: Construction of high-speed rail link between London and the north of England. EU-funded investment falls.
Technological readiness
2019-20: High e-commerce penetration and strong research base, but UK research and development (R&D) spending below EU average and limited provision of e-government services. Continued high threat from cybercrime and cyber-espionage.
2021-23: Possible weakening of research and innovation framework owing to exit from-or more restricted access to-EU structural programmes (such as Horizon 2020) and project financing schemes. Modest rise in public R&D spending.

Background: The end of the second world war coincided with the decline of the UK as an imperial power. Residual links with former colonial territories, close relations with the US and a separate sense of identity delayed UK membership of the European Community (now the EU) until 1973. Successive governments have resisted closer EU integration. In a referendum in June 2016 the UK electorate voted to leave the EU. The future contours of the UK's relationship with the EU are uncertain, but a diminution of UK influence in the region looks inevitable.
Political structure: The UK is a constitutional monarchy. The head of state is Queen Elizabeth II. Parliament has an elected House of Commons (the lower house, 650 seats) and a non-elected House of Lords (the upper house, non-fixed membership of about 800). The snap general election in June 2017 produced a minority centre-right Conservative Party government, dependent on the support of Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) for a working majority. The main opposition Labour Party gained 30 seats at the 2017 election, but its ability to compete with the Conservatives will be undermined when the government redraws constituency boundaries, which are currently favourable to Labour.
Policy issues: UK economic policy has yet to return to normal after the financial crisis. The monetary stance is being tightened, but remains exceptionally loose by historical standards. Real GDP growth slowed modestly in 2016-17 compared with 2015. The fallout from the Brexit vote will dominate the policy agenda; The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to focus efforts on negotiating the terms of its departure from the EU and on reducing the damaging effect on the economy of the uncertainty created by the vote. This has led to a shift in the UK's monetary and fiscal policy mix, with fiscal policies becoming more significant. Fiscal policy will be eased slightly in 2019, but deficit reduction remains a medium-term priority for the government. Managing Brexit has forced policymakers to address structural deficiencies in the UK, such as weak productivity.
Taxation: The headline rate of corporation tax has been steadily reduced, from 28% in 2010 to 19% since April 2018. There are three bands of personal income tax, set at 20%, 40% and 45% (the 45% rate came into effect in April 2013, replacing the 50% rate that was introduced in 2010). The standard rate of value-added tax (VAT) is 20% (raised from 17.5% in 2011). Excise duties on tobacco and alcohol are among the highest in Europe.
Foreign trade: In 2017 exports of goods totalled US$436.4bn and imports amounted to US$613bn, resulting in a trade deficit of US$176.6bn. The services surplus rose to US$147.5bn. The overall current-account deficit narrowed in absolute terms, to US$98.4bn, from US$140.3bn in 2016, and fell sharply as a share of GDP, from 5.3% to 3.7%.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
Following an early general election in June 2017, the Conservative Party formed a working government based on a "confidence and supply" arrangement with the Northern Ireland-based Democratic Unionist Party (DUP). The government is politically fragile and, amid domestic and external challenges, is unlikely to last a full term to 2022. The biggest challenge for the prime minister, Theresa May, is to reconcile opposing factions in the cabinet that have different views about negotiating the UK's future relationship with the EU.
Divisions in the cabinet and on the Conservative backbenches reflect deep-seated discontent with the direction in which Mrs May is taking the Brexit negotiations. These divisions will come to a head on December 11th, when members of parliament (MPs) will debate and hold a "meaningful vote" on the draft withdrawal agreement reached by UK and EU negotiators in mid-November. The contents of the deal have already triggered ministerial resignations; the relatively unknown Stephen Barclay has replaced Dominic Raab as Brexit secretary, and Amber Rudd has replaced Esther McVey as secretary of state for work and pensions.
Most Conservative MPs intending to reject the withdrawal deal in December believe that it surrenders an unacceptable degree of sovereignty to the EU. A major area of concern is the backstop arrangement to avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland, as a result of the UK's decision to leave the EU customs union. If a trading arrangement that removes the border is not found, the backstop would keep the UK in a single customs territory with the EU. This includes "level-playing field" requirements that keep the UK aligned to a broad range of rules and standards to prevent it from gaining a competitive advantage. Crucially, however, the UK would not be able to unilaterally withdraw from the arrangement. The DUP plans to vote against the withdrawal agreement because the backstop arrangement also keeps Northern Ireland aligned to a limited set of single-market rules, tying it more closely to the EU than to the UK. The opposition Labour Party has declared its intention to vote against the withdrawal agreement on the grounds that it fails the party's six "tests" against which it measures the Brexit deal. Pro-EU MPs may vote against the deal, as they favour the possibility of calling a second referendum on EU membership.
Mrs May has launched a campaign to get the deal through parliament, but the parliamentary arithmetic is not in her favour. The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast is that she will eventually get the deal approved-potentially in a second vote after some amendments-owing to a lack of alternative options that can guarantee an orderly UK withdrawal when the Article 50 window closes at the end of March 2019. The EU has stated that negotiations on the terms of withdrawal are closed, and may not extend the Article 50 window. A second referendum might lead to a decision to revoke Article 50, but would be politically divisive. In addition, many MPs will be wary of voting against the deal and triggering a general election, in which they could lose their seats.
Nevertheless, downside risks to our forecast are high and contingency plans for a "no-deal" Brexit have been ramped up. The political pressure on Mrs May has also increased significantly. She has avoided, for now, a no-confidence vote. Should this happen, we expect her to survive it in the short term, but if the withdrawal agreement is rejected, Mrs May would lose all authority and would probably be ousted. In this scenario, either the existing government under new leadership or a new government formed following a general election may seek to renegotiate the withdrawal agreement and/or call a second referendum.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
The next general election is scheduled for May 2022. Assuming that parliament approves the UK's withdrawal deal with the EU in late-2018, the Conservative-led government is likely to hold in the short term. Neither the Conservatives nor the DUP wants another election-they are allies on matters of sovereignty and the EU, and the DUP is committed to preventing the Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, from coming to power, given his past association with Northern Ireland's main nationalist party, Sinn Fein. However, the arrangement is fragile, and political deadlock over the direction of Brexit negotiations could lead to an early election.
Since April most opinion polls have placed the Conservatives ahead of Labour by a few percentage points, but this lead could easily collapse during the course of an election campaign. The outcome of the next election will be largely determined by how well the Conservatives are perceived to have handled the Brexit negotiations.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
The UK will formally leave the single market at the end of the Article 50 process, in March 2019. The mid-November agreement with the EU on the terms of the UK's withdrawal and a political declaration on the shape of the future relationship were finalised at an EU summit on November 25th. The withdrawal agreement contains a transition period, which will last until end-2020 and will allow the UK to maintain access to the single market during negotiations on the shape of the future UK-EU trading relationship. However, according to the withdrawal agreement, the UK and the EU have until July 2020 to agree on a future trade agreement, otherwise they must agree to operationalise the backstop for the Irish border from the start of 2021, or extend the transition period. If no trade deal is agreed before July 2020, we expect the transition period to be extended for a short time, allowing a deal to come into effect during 2021, but possibly later.
We expect trade negotiations to result in a comprehensive free-trade agreement that includes special provisions for some sectors, for example those where supply chains are highly integrated. The UK and the EU have committed to negotiating a free-trade area with deep regulatory and customs co-operation. They will pursue an equivalence regime for financial services, and mobility arrangements will be reciprocal. However, the details of the future relationship in these areas, including transport arrangements, energy, fishing opportunities, security and institutional arrangements, will depend on the outcome of complex negotiations.
The UK will pursue an independent trade policy after Brexit, and it is focusing on improving trade ties with a number of countries, including the US, Australia and New Zealand. The government is also considering joining the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership, which includes several countries in Asia, Australasia and Latin America. However, UK-EU trade negotiations will take priority in the coming years, and the scope of non-EU trade agreements will be limited by the degree to which the UK remains aligned with EU regulations.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
The UK's departure from the EU has encouraged policymakers to address some of the structural deficiencies that have held back the economy in recent years, including lacklustre productivity growth. In 2016 the chancellor of the exchequer, Philip Hammond, announced a National Productivity Investment Fund to boost the UK's digital infrastructure and spending on research and development over the next five years. We expect these measures to support a recovery in productivity, but they are too modest in scope to close the UK's productivity gap with its G7 peers.
The government's legislative agenda has been dominated by Brexit since mid-2017; eight of the 27 bills announced in the Queen's Speech in June of that year related to the transfer of EU law into British law, a UK customs regime, independent trade policy, controls on immigration, fisheries policy, agricultural policy, nuclear safeguards and the UK's ability to impose international sanctions.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
In the Autumn Budget, delivered on October 29th, Mr Hammond declared that austerity was coming to an end, but that "discipline will remain". Public borrowing has been lower than expected this year, and therefore more funds were allocated to the National Health Service (NHS) and to support the troubled rollout of Universal Credit (a form of social welfare payment). The chancellor also announced a number of pro-business measures aimed at stimulating investment, and a new digital-services tax that will increase the amount of tax paid by "established tech giants", such as Amazon and Google (both US). The personal allowance threshold, under which no income tax is paid, will be increased from £11,850 (US$15,117) currently to £12,500 in 2019, one year earlier than planned.
Owing to a decline in public borrowing in 2018, we estimate a calendar-year fiscal deficit equivalent to 1.3% of GDP, down from 1.8% in 2017. However, the fiscal easing announced in the budget should mean that the deficit will widen slightly in 2019, to 1.5% of GDP. In the event of a smooth Brexit in 2019, Mr Hammond has promised a "deal dividend" that will allow further fiscal easing, although it is uncertain that this will materialise. In the remainder of our 2019-23 forecast period we expect the government to decrease discretionary spending as a proportion of GDP. We expect the deficit to narrow again in 2020, to 1.3% of GDP, and to reach 0.5% by 2023. We expect public debt to decline from about 87% of GDP in 2018 to less than 80% by 2022.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The monetary policy committee (MPC) of the Bank of England (BoE, the central bank) voted unanimously to keep its policy interest rate unchanged in November, at 0.75%, having increased it by 25 basis points in both August 2018 and November 2017-the first rate increase in a decade. Once the influence of higher energy and import prices on inflation has faded, the BoE expects domestic price pressures to build, keeping inflation above its 2% target in the coming years. This outlook has justified the decision to tighten monetary policy since late 2017, although this will depend on the nature of the Brexit process. Economic uncertainty is heightened, and the bank has said that further rate increases will be "limited and gradual". We expect the BoE to delay the next policy rate increase until the second quarter of 2019, and follow that with four more rises that will take the rate to 2.5% by end-2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
Average annual real GDP growth was firm in 2016 and 2017, at 1.8% and 1.7% respectively. However, the pace of growth slowed sharply in early 2018, partly reflecting the impact of adverse weather conditions on activity. Despite a modest rebound in the third quarter, we expect political turmoil and associated economic uncertainty about the outcome of Brexit negotiations to have weighed on activity in the fourth quarter. In response, we have revised down slightly our estimate of full-year GDP growth in 2018, from 1.4% to 1.3%. Nevertheless, we expect some degree of economic confidence to return in early 2019, assuming that the withdrawal agreement negotiated in late 2018 will make a smooth Brexit transition possible in March 2019. We forecast real GDP growth of 1.5% in 2019.
The economic slowdown in 2018 has been led by a deceleration in domestic demand, but we expect it to firm slightly in 2019. Consumer spending will continue to be supported by recent employment gains, high levels of household borrowing and a decline in the savings ratio. Consumer spending weakened in 2018, as high inflation reduced real household incomes, but we expect this effect to fade in 2019 as external price pressure-from the past depreciation in sterling and high oil prices-eases. Persistent Brexit-related uncertainty and slower employment growth will weigh on the pace of consumer spending growth in 2020-21. We expect growth to strengthen in 2022-owing to pent-up demand as uncertainty recedes-but to moderate thereafter.
Businesses have been particularly sensitive to Brexit-related uncertainty in 2018, leading to a decline in gross fixed capital formation (GFCF), despite accommodative financial conditions. After a deceleration in GFCF growth in 2018, we expect it to firm gradually for most of the forecast period as uncertainty recedes and capacity constraints make capital spending necessary. Nevertheless, increased borrowing costs arising from tighter monetary policy will hold back the pace of recovery in both consumer spending and GCFC during these years.
In 2017 export volumes benefited from a competitiveness boost from sterling's depreciation following the Brexit referendum. This effect faded in 2018, but we expect export growth to remain firm in 2019-20, before slowing in 2021-23 as the UK's new relationship with the EU (which we expect to take effect during 2021) weakens trade flows. Services exports will be particularly weak during this period, reflecting our expectation that services will not feature in the trade agreement. The weaker domestic demand environment is reducing import growth this year, but a recovery in 2019-23 should mean that the external balance will exert an increasing drag on GDP growth from 2020.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
The headline rate of annual inflation-as measured by the consumer price index including owner-occupiers' housing costs (CPIH)-accelerated to 2.6% on average in 2017, from 1% in 2016. The increase partly reflected a rebound in oil prices, but was amplified by the sharp depreciation of sterling following the Brexit vote. The pass-through from sterling's weakness has since faded, producing an average inflation rate of 2.3% in January-October, in line with our full-year estimate. As tighter monetary policy offsets firming domestic price pressure (particularly wage growth), we forecast that inflation will ease to 2% next year and 2.1% on average in 2020-23.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
Following a sharp decline in the external value of sterling after the Brexit vote, the pound depreciated against both the euro and the US dollar in 2017. It has since recovered some value against the dollar, but after significant volatility related to the risk of a "no-deal" Brexit, the pound is on course to weaken slightly more against the euro on average this year. In 2019 foreign-exchange markets will remain sensitive to Brexit, contributing to significant volatility in the pound. We expect a modest "relief rally" in the pound to accompany the agreement and ratification of the UK withdrawal deal, set to take place at the end of 2018 and in the first quarter of 2019 respectively. However, we expect the pound to lose value against the euro thereafter and in 2020, partly reflecting the difficulty in finalising Brexit negotiations, but also owing to tighter monetary policy in the euro zone. We expect an average exchange rate of EUR1.13:£1 in 2018-19 (revised slightly lower from EUR1.14:£1), weakening to EUR1.11:£1 in 2020. We then expect it to recover modestly, to EUR1.14:£1 on average in 2021-23, as a new UK-EU trade relationship is established. Against the US dollar, we expect the pound to average US$1.35:£1 in 2019-20, before recovering more value in 2021-23.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The current-account deficit has narrowed in recent years, from about 5% in 2013-16 to 3.7% in 2017. We expect it to widen slightly in 2018-19 as a decline in the services surplus offsets a slight narrowing in the trade deficit. By 2020 we expect the current-account deficit to widen to 4.3% of GDP as domestic demand recovers. From 2021 we expect looser trade relations with the EU to mean a larger goods trade deficit and a smaller services surplus, although this will be partially offset by a reduction in secondary transfers as the UK reduces its contribution to the EU budget. We forecast an annual average current-account deficit of 4.8% of GDP in 2021-23.
In 2017 foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows totalled US$64.7b; we expect Brexit-related uncertainty to mean that they will dip below US$20bn by 2019. We forecast that they will recover gradually, to almost US$80bn by 2023. Net FDI flows are currently negative, but we expect them to turn positive in 2021-23 as confidence in the UK economy recovers after Brexit.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The government-comprising Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza, the party of the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras) and the small, right-wing Independent Greeks (AE)-has a two-seat majority in the 300-seat parliament and it is vulnerable to further defections, especially regarding the implementation of further austerity measures and the Macedonia name change agreement reached in June.
The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that an early election will be held before the end of the parliamentary term in October 2019, possibly in conjunction with the European Parliament and the local elections in May 2019. We expect the centre-right New Democracy (ND) to win the most seats and to form a government, but it would probably have to secure the support of at least one other party to muster a parliamentary majority.
Greece will remain subject to strict policy conditionality over the medium term and until its debt to its international creditors is substantially reduced. Protests are likely to continue as the government strives to meet ambitious annual primary surplus budget targets of 3.5% of GDP until 2022 and 2.2% from 2023, as agreed with Greece's creditors. Mr Tsipras's promises to lower tax, reverse spending cuts and abandon the pension reform could cause tensions with the country's international creditors and investors.
Greece is facing its biggest macroeconomic challenge now that it has exited the bail-out programme and no longer has access to official borrowing at preferential interest rates. However, Greece does not face short-term financing difficulties, as it will have sufficient funds to cover its debt repayments until the end of 2020. A Greek exit from the euro zone represents a risk over the long term.
We expect that real GDP growth will pick up from 1.3% in 2017 to a moderate 2% per year on average in 2018-23. Public debt is forecast to continue to exceed 170% of GDP in 2023. Meeting large primary surplus targets and restoring competitiveness will prove difficult.
We estimate that annual average inflation will ease, from 1.1% in 2017 to 0.8% in 2018, before rising to an annual average of 1.4% in the forecast period (2019-23), reflecting higher oil prices and a pick-up in domestic demand. These factors will result in widening, but still moderate, current-account deficits in 2018-23.

Greece's score recovers modestly in our forecast period, from a low base. The main areas of improvement are expected in the macroeconomic environment, as a result of efforts to improve policy towards foreign investment, private enterprise and competition, and the labour market.
Country forecast overview: Greece's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The country's privatisation agency (under new management) gains momentum, unblocking some delayed deals.
2021-23: Efforts to valorise public property through concession management and long-leasehold development agreements.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: The Investment Incentives Law of 2016 offers more tax relief and fewer subsidies, and focuses predominantly on small firms. Plans to cut down on bureaucracy make little progress.
2021-23: "Fast-track" legislation could become more important if the economy normalises. It will cover "strategic" investments in energy, tourism, transport, communications and health.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Capital controls introduced in June 2015 are eased gradually. Capital buffer of about EUR26bn sufficient to cover almost two years of the government's financing needs
2021-23: There is a significant risk of Greece leaving the euro zone in the long term if growth continues to disappoint. Grexit would probably result in the reintroduction of exchange controls, and possibly restrictions on trade.
Taxes
2019-20: Extensive efforts to widen the tax base. Government pledges to pursue aggressive tax collection, but implementation is difficult. Indirect taxes increase. Mandatory introduction of electronic point of sale terminals helps.
2021-23: Limited progress in cutting corporate income tax or value-added tax (VAT). Measures to tackle tax evasion stepped up. Independence of tax authority remains in doubt.
Financing
2019-20: Liquidity tight. Uncertainty constrains lending capacity. Steps to reduce non-performing loans (NPLs) extremely slow, but foreign interest picks up. A moratorium on foreclosures is lifted for the majority of debtors.
2021-23: Lending hampered by need to increase provisions for still high NPLs. More Greek bank foreign subsidiaries are sold off.
The labour market
2019-20: Labour market reforms now mostly passed, but implementation is problematic. Unemployment remains high.
2021-23: EU funded job-creation schemes, particularly for youth, raise employment, but create few productive jobs.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Energy infrastructure comes to the fore as Trans-Adriatic Pipeline (TAP) nears completion. Privatisations pick up pace.
2021-23: Despite technical assistance from the EU, problems with absorption of funds persist.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Greece rolls out high-speed internet, at a slow pace. The private sector adopts electronic payments by law.
2021-23: Significant financial and technical assistance from the EU, but Greece remains a laggard..

Background: After 400 years of Ottoman rule Greece emerged as a sovereign state in 1830. A devastating civil war followed the retreat of German occupying forces in 1944. A military junta ruled the country from 1967 to 1974, but since then a democracy has been in place. In 1981 Greece joined the European Economic Community, now the EU. It became a member of the economic and monetary union (EMU) in 2001, but its public finances became unsustainable, resulting in a sovereign debt crisis in 2009-10. Greece's public debt has put its continued membership of the EMU into question.
Political structure: Greece is a parliamentary republic, with deputies elected for four-year terms. The prime minister and the government hold executive powers. The president is elected by the 300-member parliament for a five-year term. The government requires the support of parliament to hold office. Since the 2010 crisis, the traditional party system has broken down. Voters have blamed the parties that ruled Greece after the return of democracy in the mid-1970s-New Democracy (ND) and the Panhellenic Socialist Movement (Pasok)-for causing the crisis, which led to the imposition of painful austerity by the country's external creditors. The result has been political fragmentation and the rise of populist parties such as the left-wing Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), which came to power in 2015, and far-right parties such as the neo-fascist Golden Dawn (XA).
Policy issues: The ND-Pasok government of 2012-14, like its two predecessors, imposed draconian austerity packages. It also enacted fiscal and some structural economic reforms to meet the conditions of two EU-IMF bail-out packages totalling EUR240bn. Implementation proved difficult and ultimately brought down the government. After a seven-month confrontation with Greece's creditors, the Syriza-led government negotiated a new three-year European Stability Mechanism (ESM) programme in August 2015. In 2012 Greece restructured its public debt, reducing the value of private-sector creditors' holdings by EUR107bn. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any further debt write-down. Now that Greece has exited the programme, it is subject to an "enhanced supervision" monitoring regime by its euro zone creditors.
Taxation: The tax rate on corporate profits is 29% and on distributed dividends is 10%. The top marginal personal income tax rate is 45% for income of more than EUR40,000. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at rates of 24%, 13% and 6%.
Foreign trade: In 2017 goods exports (fob) were worth EUR27.9bn and imports (fob) amounted to EUR46.3bn. The current account registered a deficit of EUR1.8bn, equivalent to 1% of GDP.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
The coalition government-comprising Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza, the party of the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras) and the small, right-wing nationalist Independent Greeks (AE)-has survived since September 2015, despite having only a slim majority in the 300-seat parliament. However, tensions within the coalition persist on a range of issues, including the continued implementation of austerity measures and the Macedonia name issue. Two members of the AE defected in protest to the agreement reached with Macedonia on the 27-year Macedonia name dispute in June, leaving the government with a majority of just two seats. Mr Tsipras insists that he intends to see the parliamentary term through to its end, in October 2019, but The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a pre-term election, possibly to be held in conjunction with the European Parliament and the local elections in May 2019.
Following a consultative referendum held on September 30th in which Macedonians voted overwhelmingly in favour of changing their country's official name to Severna Makedonija (North Macedonia), the Macedonian parliament has begun the process of ratifying the agreement, despite the turnout of well below 50% at the referendum. The fragility of the Syriza-led coalition government means that it may struggle to ratify the agreement if it is brought before the Greek parliament in early 2019, as is currently envisaged. The AE, which is now reduced to seven seats, has said that it will oppose the agreement.
On August 20th 2018, after eight years of austerity and unpopular reforms under three economic adjustment programmes, Greece exited the third bail-out programme signed by the Syriza-led government in 2015. However, during this period in power, Mr Tsipras has lost much popular support and will struggle to revive his party's political fortunes before the next election. The party will receive a boost in popularity after the European Commission accepts the government's plan to cancel agreed pension cuts in 2019 on the grounds that they will not be needed in order to achieve the country's fiscal targets (a 3.5% primary surplus in 2018-22). However, we remain sceptical that real GDP growth will rise much higher than 2% during the 2019-23 forecast period, and expect that failure to implement other structural reforms agreed with Greece's international creditors could lead to delays in the implementation of debt relief measures.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Syriza trails in opinion polls behind the centre-right New Democracy (ND), led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis; the gap has exceeded 10 percentage points for some time. ND's lead may narrow during the election campaign, as Mr Tsipras is a formidable campaigner, whereas there is little overt enthusiasm for Mr Mitsotakis or his party. However, given widespread popular disaffection with the government, the election-due by October 2019-is ND's to lose. If, as we expect, ND wins the largest share of the vote, it would benefit from the 50-seat bonus rule for the winning party. Even so, it would probably have to secure the support of at least one other party to muster a parliamentary majority.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
In mid-June 2018 Greece and Macedonia (the official name of which is the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia; the constitutional name is the Republic of Macedonia) reached an agreement to change Macedonia's constitutional name to Northern Macedonia, in order to end Greece's opposition to that country's accession to NATO. However, there is strong opposition to the agreement in both countries, and Greece's coalition government is divided on the issue. Although the prospect of ratification by Macedonia has improved slightly, the agreement remains a major source of tension within the Greek government, as illustrated by the resignation on October 17th of the foreign minister, Nikos Kotzias, one of the main architects of the agreement.
Tensions between Greece and Turkey have been threatening to boil over, increasing the risk of military hostility, particularly in the Aegean Sea. However, we believe that both sides will seek to avoid clashes. Points of contention-such as historical territorial disputes in the Aegean Sea and the Greek courts' rejection of Turkey's extradition request for Turkish soldiers who fled to Greece on the night of the July 2016 failed coup in Turkey-have fuelled distrust. Turkey's release in mid-August of two Greek soldiers arrested for alleged espionage in March 2018 while on patrol in the border area of Evros has eased tensions slightly.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Despite exiting the third economic adjustment programmes in August 2018 without a precautionary credit line, the government will be subject to huge policy constraints during the forecast period and beyond. General government debt is huge-officially projected to reach EUR335bn by end-2018, or almost 185% of GDP, according to our GDP estimates. It is also now almost entirely owed to official creditors (the EU and the IMF), so another debt write-down, as happened in 2012, is unlikely.
At the June 21st meeting of the Eurogroup Greece's official creditors agreed to close the final review of the third bail-out programme, paving the way for a disbursement of EUR15bn, which was released on August 6th. Of this, EUR3.3bn was earmarked to repay more expensive IMF debt, and the balance to create a buffer for Greece to use while it builds up market access. The total buffer, estimated at EUR26bn, should be sufficient to cover almost two years of the country's financing needs. This is more onerous than a precautionary credit line would have been, as Greece will be accruing interest on money that it does not currently need. However, intense political pressure not to invite further policy conditionality led the government to choose the more expensive option.
The Eurogroup meeting agreed to further debt relief for Greece, which was granted a ten-year grace period and a ten-year maturity extension on EUR96bn of its loans (provided by the European Financial Stability Facility). It will also get a reduction in the interest rates (for loans of EUR130.9bn), and a return of profits from the securities market programme and from the Agreement on Net Financial Assets, which comprises the official sector holders of Greek debt-the European Central Bank (ECB) and national central banks of euro area countries. The value of the return is estimated to be about EUR5bn in total in 2018-22.
In response, Greece has committed to long-term fiscal prudence. It must achieve annual primary budget surpluses of 3.5% of GDP in 2018-22 and 2.2% thereafter, until 2060. It will also be subject to an "enhanced surveillance" regime, which is a more exacting system of post-programme monitoring than those applied to other former bail-out countries. The debt-relief measures will be subject to quarterly reviews of the state of the economy and of the government's adherence to its commitments. As these reviews will be published, transgression by Greece would adversely affect market access.
After a three-year absence Greece has returned to the financial markets three times since July 2017. However, after its exit from the bail-out programme in August, it will do so without the backstop of an official credit line. Recent emerging-market turbulence and investor risk aversion highlight the difficulties that Greece could face in the future on the international capital markets. Greece should have sufficient funds to meet its financing needs in the short term, until end-2020. However, in the medium and long term the political and, arguably, the economic price of meeting high annual primary surplus targets may become unbearable. During the past two years Greece has exceeded its annual primary surplus targets, but at the expense of economic growth, which has been disappointing. Meeting such targets will remain a constraint on growth, alongside other negative factors, such as poor demographics and a weak business environment. Grexit is not a short-term risk; however, given that Greece is highly unlikely to improve competitiveness inside the euro zone or to grow its way out of its huge debt burden, it will represent a risk in the long term.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
In 2017 the budget surplus was equivalent to 0.8% of GDP and the primary surplus (budget balance minus interest payments) exceeded the bail-out programme target of 1.75%, at 3.9%. We estimate a minimal budget deficit in 2018, of 0.2% of GDP, and expect Greece to fall just short of its annual primary surplus target of 3.5% of GDP this year and in 2019-22. Although the primary surplus target will decline to 2.2% of GDP in 2023, it will still be difficult to achieve, owing to the fact that debt repayments become much more onerous from that year on. We forecast that the deficit will widen gradually during this period, reflecting constraints on revenue collection, a relaxation of spending restraint and only modest economic growth.
The restructuring of government debt owed to the private sector cut the debt/GDP ratio to 159.4% at end-2012, from 171.9% in 2011. However, large primary surpluses in 2016-17 were insufficient to arrest the growth of gross consolidated government debt. We expect that, without a debt write-down and assuming moderate nominal medium-term GDP growth rates, the public debt/GDP ratio will still be above 170% at the end of 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The ECB is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a quantitative easing (QE) programme that ran at EUR30bn per month in January-September 2018. The programme is running at EUR15bn per month in October-December before coming to an end. Economic activity has softened this year, but the ECB's view of the outlook remains positive. Rising commodity prices and evidence of building domestic price pressure in parts of the euro zone should mean that sufficient inflationary pressures will begin to emerge on the policy horizon in 2019-20. In response, we expect the ECB to take steps towards normalising its policy stance, with an increase of 25 basis points in the main refinancing rate to 0.25% in early 2020, followed by five more rises that will lift the main refinancing rate to 2% by end-2023. An increase in the deposit rate, which currently stands at -0.4%, may come sooner, in 2019.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
Compared with 2007 levels, real GDP has shrunk by more than a quarter, government consumption by almost a quarter, household consumption by one-fifth and gross fixed investment by almost two-thirds. The recovery, which began at the start of 2017, is fragile and vulnerable to domestic and external developments. After real GDP growth of 1.3% in 2017, we estimate growth of 2% in 2018. In 2019-23 real GDP growth will remain constrained at an average of 1.9%. The risks to our forecast are balanced. Upside risks include a continued strong tourism performance, if capacity constraints are addressed. Downside risks include the frailty of the banking sector and political instability.
Seasonally and calendar-day-adjusted real GDP growth slowed from 0.9% quarter on quarter in January-March (2.5% year on year) to 0.2% (1.8% year on year) in April-June, despite steady expansion of domestic consumption and strong export of services (largely driven by tourism). Our estimate for 2018 real GDP growth is a disappointing rate of expansion in the context of the slump of the past decade. We expect a combination of more and higher taxes, higher social security payments, debt repayments and spending cuts to put pressure on household disposable income. Although we expect a modest acceleration in household spending in 2018-23, this will be from a low base and will be constrained by large primary surplus targets of 3.5% of GDP per year up to 2022 and 2.2% in 2023, continued high unemployment and insipid lending growth.
Quarterly gross fixed investment has been volatile in recent years, but recorded strong full-year growth in 2016-17, albeit from a low base. However, reflecting base effects and a loss of momentum, investment contracted by 7.9% year on year in the first half of 2018. We expect a pick-up in the second half of the year to reduce the contraction to 1% in 2018 as whole, followed by average annual growth of 5.2% in 2019-23, leaving fixed investment still about 50% below its 2007 peak. Underinvestment during the crisis, and the depletion of Greece's capital stock, as well as uncertainty about the country's euro zone membership, are likely to restrict growth potential in the medium term.
Greece's external trade will be constrained by its relatively uncompetitive goods exports. Over the medium term we expect tourism to continue to support services export growth, contributing to annual average growth of exports of goods and services of 4.7% in 2019-23.
Greece will face its biggest macroeconomic challenge now that it no longer has access to official external financing at preferential rates. How the economy performs over the next five years (and beyond) will determine whether the country will remain in the euro zone. We believe that there is a significant risk that Greece will exit the euro zone in the long term, given the difficulties that it will face in attaining rapid growth while meeting large primary surplus targets, and in restoring competitiveness without a currency devaluation. Grexit would lead to a sovereign default and severe recession in the first few years, but the economy would then recover, assuming a responsible fiscal policy guided by the necessity to achieve a primary surplus.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
After averaging 1.1% in 2017, driven by higher global energy prices, Greece's annual consumer price inflation rate (seasonally adjusted, EU harmonised) dipped sharply at the start of 2018, before accelerating moderately since May. The economy has returned to growth, but significant slack remains in the labour market, and domestic demand is subdued. Higher global commodity prices and increased tourist demand pushed the annual rate of price growth up to 1.8% in October, but we estimate that inflation will average 0.8% in 2018 (it averaged 0.6% in the first ten months of the year). We forecast a pick-up to inflation of 1.4% per year on average in 2019-23 as the pace of growth quickens.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
The euro rallied in late 2017 as the region's economic recovery strengthened and expectations of QE tapering increased, and as political risk waned in Europe but rose in the US. It peaked at almost US$1.25:EUR1 at the beginning of February 2018, but had weakened to US$1.16:EUR1 by late May in response to the formation of a populist, Eurosceptic government in Italy, and remained close to that level in June-July before weakening to US$1.13:EUR1 in mid-August. The euro has recovered some value in September-October, but weakened again in November to US$1.13-1.14:EUR1, and will remain under pressure from political risk in Italy and monetary tightening in the US. We expect it to begin strengthening against the US dollar from the second half of 2019, on the assumption that the region's recovery will continue while growth momentum in the US slows. We forecast an average of US$1.19:EUR1 in 2019 and then US$1.21:EUR1 in 2020-21 as monetary policy in the euro zone is gradually tightened. The euro will also receive structural support from a large current-account surplus, and we expect it to appreciate to US$1.24:EUR1 on average in 2022-23.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
Greece's current-account deficit has narrowed since the start of the crisis. This mainly reflects the compression of imports due to contracting domestic demand, but is also partly the result of improved competitiveness in the tourism sector. The current-account deficit narrowed to 1% of GDP in 2017, from 1.3% of GDP in 2016, according to the Bank of Greece (the central bank). We expect widening deficits in 2018-23 as import volumes pick up in line with higher domestic demand and import prices rise, but these will be much smaller than the average annual deficit of 7.2% of GDP since Greece joined the euro zone in 2001.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
In June Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected as president for a second term in snap presidential and parliamentary elections, in which his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a coalition majority in parliament with the right-wing Nationalist Action Party (MHP).
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Mr Erdogan and the AKP to remain in power throughout the forecast period (2019-23), and possibly beyond.
Following the June elections, an executive presidency has replaced the former parliamentary system of government. The new system provides few checks on the president's powers, raising the risk of discretionary policymaking.
Since the failed coup in July 2016 there has been a marked deterioration in Turkey's relations with its Western allies. We expect a rupture to be avoided, but tensions will remain high and relations could sour quickly.
Turkey's relationship with the US will remain tense. Points of contention include Turkey's pivot towards Iran and Russia (from the US' perspective), and the perceived lack of US support after the failed coup (from Turkey's perspective).
Turkey's relationship with the EU will remain transactional. Turkey will not make progress with accession talks and is unlikely to manage to renegotiate the terms of its customs union with the EU.
The government's focus on domestic power struggles, economic growth and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate.
We forecast a slowdown in real GDP growth, from 7.3% in 2017 to about 3.5% per year in 2018-23, reflecting the impact of the August 2018 currency crisis, higher interest rates, global trade tensions and more moderate export growth.
The lira will depreciate in nominal terms against the US dollar during the forecast period, to about TL6.3:US$1 at end-2023, as a result of negative foreign investor sentiment, high inflation and the large current-account deficit.
As a result of the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar (which will boost competitiveness), we forecast that the current-account deficit will shrink in 2019-23, to an annual average of 3.6% of GDP. Turkey will struggle to meet its external financing needs throughout the forecast period.

Turkey's score deteriorates only slightly in 2019-23, but in the global rankings the country falls by ten places, to 59th. The failed coup in 2016 and the government's response have increased the level of uncertainty about the direction of economic policy. Shortcomings include a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Political instability and adverse market conditions will delay further privatisation deals.
2021-23: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in several sectors.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but macroeconomic instability and concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2021-23: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Capital controls are not considered, despite the scale of the currency collapse. Political tensions resulting in tit-for-tat tariffs and US sanctions will disrupt Turkish-US trade and relations.
2021-23: Negotiations with the EU to update the customs union are likely to be protracted, given poor Turkish-EU relations.
Taxes
2019-20: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Tax rises introduced in 2018 to curb the widening of the budget deficit reduce company profits.
2021-23: Income tax base becomes broader as exemptions and exceptions are reduced.
Financing
2019-20: Asset quality likely to deteriorate on the back of financial market turmoil in 2018. Central Bank of Turkey to lower rates gradually as inflation moderates in 2019. Risk of the US imposing fines or sanctions on some Turkish banks.
2021-23: Lending growth to pick up again as banking system regains strength. Continued reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2019-20: Relatively high labour costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment.
2021-23: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2019-20: First phase of third airport in Istanbul becomes operational. Slower progress made on other projects.
2021-23: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. Other major urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks might persist.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Spending on research and development remains moderate, at about 1% of GDP, holding back efforts to move the economy up the value-added ladder.
2021-23: Turkey's young population spurs further rapid digital transformation of the banking sector.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West. The country became a member of the Council of Europe in 1949 and NATO in 1952, and signed an association agreement with the then European Community in 1963. A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but a coup attempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey currently has a presidential system of government, with parliament elected for a five-year term. To win seats, parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the AKP leader, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who was re-elected as president for a second term in June 2018. Following his re-election a presidential system of government was introduced and the post of prime minister was abolished.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability and stabilising the lira following the August 2018 currency crisis are Turkey's biggest policy challenges. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and tightening global liquidity conditions require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy tight to attract adequate capital inflows and slow the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar. The Kurdish issue, which has blocked economic development in the south east, is one of Turkey's most pressing policy challenges, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015, and there has been a resurgence in violence. Politicisation of the judiciary since the coup attempt has undermined its independence. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The corporation tax rate has been raised in 2018, from 20% to 22%. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Reducing tax evasion was one of the elements of previous IMF programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2017 goods exports came to US$166bn and imports to US$225bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$59bn and a current-account deficit of US$47.4bn (or 5.6% of GDP). The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
In June Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected for a second term in the first round of a snap presidential election. On the same day his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a parliamentary coalition majority with its right-wing ally, the Nationalist Action Party (MHP). The election process appeared mostly free, but largely unfair. Opposition candidates received little or no media coverage; the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP) candidate, Selahattin Demirtas, had to campaign from prison; and the government restrained freedom of speech and freedom of association. Mr Erdogan secured a majority of the vote after a high turnout. Results published by opposition observers were similar to those announced by the government.
Mr Erdogan's re-election concludes Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. This move was initiated with a constitutional referendum in April 2017, which the government narrowly won. The new system grants the president wide-ranging executive powers-including the selection of most of the officials in the judiciary-and will greatly weaken parliament. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the AKP and Mr Erdogan, who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in July 2016, to remain in power until 2023, and possibly beyond.
Mr Erdogan will continue to restrict political dissent and stifle the opposition. Despite allowing the state of emergency to expire on July 18th, parliament passed a security law on July 25th that imposes stringent barriers on freedoms. These are similar to those of the state of emergency, which was introduced after the attempted coup in a bid to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies who include the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric who is accused by the Turkish government of masterminding the coup plot.
Security risk remains high, as Turkey appears vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and Islamic State (IS). Neither the government nor the PKK is interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, which increased the risk that violence will return to 1990s levels. Turkey's military operations in Syria seek to block the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds affiliated with the PKK but risk fuelling the conflict with the PKK in south-east Turkey. The formation of a governing coalition between the AKP and the MHP will hinder attempts to resolve the Kurdish issue, as the MHP is likely to push for hawkish policies aimed at constraining and delegitimising the HDP. The MHP will advocate the repatriation of Syrian refugees and adopt a tough stance on all issues related to national security, in line with Mr Erdogan's ultra-nationalist and conservative views.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
On June 24th parliamentary and presidential elections were held, earlier than the originally scheduled date of late 2019. Mr Erdogan was re-elected as president in the first round, securing 52.6% of the vote with a turnout of 86.2%. In the parliamentary election the AKP lost its absolute majority (although it secured a coalition majority alongside its partner, the MHP), as the HDP managed to poll more than the 10% threshold needed to enter parliament.
Local elections are planned in March 2019. The shift of focus to the local polls in the aftermath of the June elections is a sign that Turkey will remain in the mood for an election until next year. The AKP and the MHP look unlikely to co-operate in the local elections after disagreements regarding the selection process for mayoral candidates in large cities.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Domestic political and security issues will continue to shape Turkey's actions in the foreign policy sphere. Although not our core forecast, there is a risk of a rupture in the country's ties with its traditional Western allies. Many factors have contributed to the deterioration in relations, including a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey after the failed coup; US military backing for PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurdish groups; Turkey's forging of closer relations with China, Russia and Iran; tensions with Cyprus over the delimitation of the two countries' exclusive economic zones in the Mediterranean; and US sanctions on Turkish government officials due to Turkey's detention of Andrew Brunson, a US pastor, on terrorist charges (sanctions were lifted in November after Mr Brunson was released in October).
Turkey's relations with the EU and the US are likely to remain antagonistic and transactional rather than strategic. However, we expect Turkey and its Western allies to avoid a breakdown in relations. Turkey and the EU have a common interest in handling refugee inflows from Syria and Iraq; the fact that Mr Erdogan visited Germany in late September lends credence to this view. However, EU-Turkey relations would deteriorate quickly if the EU suspended Turkey's moribund accession negotiations, or if Turkey re-imposed the death penalty, closed the Incirlik air base to US forces or withdrew from NATO (none of these options are part of our core forecast).
Turkey's involvement in the conflict in Syria will continue to influence the direction of its foreign policy. Turkey-Russia relations reached a low point following Turkey's downing of a Russian fighter jet in November 2015; bilateral ties have improved in the past two years, but the level of trust between the two countries remains low. In October Turkey and Russia finalised the creation of a jointly patrolled demilitarised zone in Idlib, the last rebel-held governorate in northern Syria. However, this does not alter our view that they are co-operating in Syria while pursuing contrasting goals (Russia backs the government led by Bashar al-Assad, the Syrian president, whereas Turkey provides support to rebels).
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
The government's past focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business, and investment, climate. Nonetheless, Turkey's economy has shown resilience during previous bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing to its solid public finances, its well-capitalised banking sector, and its dynamic and diversified private sector.
In the aftermath of the failed coup in July 2016 a highly accommodative policy stance has exacerbated fiscal and external imbalances. This, together with heightened political uncertainty, the tightening of global liquidity conditions and tensions with the US, led to a currency crisis in August 2018. The heavily pro-growth approach to economic policymaking that Mr Erdogan has espoused enthusiastically over the past decade will remain a predominant feature over our forecast period (2019-23), at the expense of inflation control and fiscal discipline. This approach will continue to have an important effect on, for example, monetary policy, macroprudential regulation, public-private capital investments and social spending. Shortcomings such as cronyism and corruption, skills mismatches (a major factor behind the high unemployment rate) and tax evasion are unlikely to be addressed in 2019-23, as propping up economic growth-partly to avoid social unrest-will remain the priority.
In the case of a severe economic or banking crisis (not our core forecast), Turkey's options will remain limited, as Gulf Co-operation Council (GCC) countries appear unwilling to offer financial support. This is because Turkey is forging closer ties with Iran, a country with which Saudi Arabia is at odds. In addition, Turkey's ties with Saudi Arabia deteriorated (from an already low base) after Jamal Khashoggi, a Saudi journalist, was murdered in the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, Turkey's largest city, in October. Meanwhile an IMF programme would include what the government would regard as an unacceptable conditionality and would run counter to Mr Erdogan's nationalist, anti-Western rhetoric. Finally, there is little prospect of EU financial assistance, not least because there would be no consensus on this issue among EU member states. Only China, therefore, appears able at present to offer a financial lifeline to Turkey. Such assistance could come as part of China's Belt and Road Initiative, which seeks to boost transport infrastructure between Asia and Europe to foster trade and connectivity in the coming decades.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
The public finances have traditionally been one of the Turkish economy's most reassuring aspects. Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios reflect the positive impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past. Despite a series of tax rises this year and official promises of budgetary tightening, higher government spending on defence, security, infrastructure, public employment and social benefits will cause the deficit to widen in 2018, to 1.9% of GDP, from 1.5% in 2017. We subsequently expect a cautious approach to on-balance-sheet fiscal policy, which, alongside a recovering economy, will lead the deficit to contract gradually in the second half of our forecast period, to 1.5% of GDP in 2023.
We expect the central government debt/GDP ratio to have remained broadly stable, at 27.9% of GDP at end-2018 (from 28.3% at end-2017), despite economic turmoil following the August currency crisis and various government handouts to parts of the population ahead of the June election. The ratio will decline slightly, to 25.2% by the end of 2023, as macroeconomic conditions normalise and the budget deficit shrinks.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
On September 13th the Central Bank of Turkey's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) raised its main policy rate, the one-week repo (repurchase agreement) lending rate, to 24%, from 17.75% previously. The MPC's decision represented a response to the lira's sharp depreciation against the US dollar in August, as well as to the record rise in annual consumer price inflation. The average cost of central bank funding is likely to be above the main policy rate, however. The bank retains the option of providing some of its funding for the banking system at its overnight lending rates, which are 1.5-3% higher than the one-week repo rate.
We expect the central bank to keep monetary policy tight in the remainder of 2018. In 2019-20 the central bank will gradually lower its policy rate in response to declining inflationary pressures and a normalisation of financial market conditions. In 2021-23 we believe that it will miss its inflation target of 5%. This reflects the government's continued pro-growth stance; it will put pressure on the bank to keep nominal rates below what would credibly be required to lower inflation to the 5% target.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
Real GDP growth accelerated sharply in 2017, to 7.3% (from 3.3% in 2016), supported by government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit, improved export competitiveness and a pick-up in global demand. However, the surge in economic growth has exacerbated internal and external imbalances. These imbalances-coupled with heightened policy unpredictability, foreign investors' concerns regarding the independence of the central bank, reliance on short-term capital inflows, a rising interest rate environment in advanced economies and a diplomatic spat with the US-have contributed to the lira losing about 40% of its value against the US dollar in January-August, before it started to recover in September. The sharp depreciation of the lira caused consumer price inflation to accelerate from already high rates, increased input costs for corporations and raised the debt-servicing costs of foreign-currency-denominated liabilities. Higher domestic interest rates and rising risk premiums further dent the economic outlook.
High-frequency indicators for September (latest available data) suggest that the economy is decelerating in the wake of the currency crisis. After mild growth in the second quarter (5.7% year on year, down from 7.3% in full-year 2017), we expect the economy to contract on a quarterly basis in the third and fourth quarters of 2018, and in January-March 2019. There are substantial downside risks to this forecast; this growth profile does not reflect the possible impact of a severe banking crisis (not our core scenario), although we expect non-performing loans to rise and credit availability to be impaired in the coming quarters.
We believe that full-year growth will decelerate to 3.1% in 2018 and that GDP will grow only slightly in 2019, by 1%, mainly owing to base effects. In 2020 we expect full-year growth to rebound to 4.9% as the economy recovers and spare capacity is depleted. In 2021-23 economic growth will average 4%, broadly in line with the economy's forecast potential growth rate.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Even before the lira's collapse against the US dollar in August, inflation was already stubbornly high and well above the central bank's official 5% medium-term target; it averaged 11.1% in 2017. This year the currency crisis and rising global commodity prices have driven inflation higher, to a peak of 25.3% year on year in October (inflation started to decelerate in November, at 21.6% year on year). This will push inflation to an average of 16.8% this year (from 11.1% in 2017).
In 2019 inflation will remain elevated in the first half of the year and then moderate gradually on the back of a broadly stable lira (against the US dollar), an only limited increase in global oil prices and the emergence of spare capacity in the economy. On average, we forecast inflation of 16.6% in 2019-only marginally below the 2018 rate.
The moderating trend in inflation will continue in 2020, with an average inflation rate of 9.1%, as global oil prices decline owing to a slowdown in the US economy and the exchange rate depreciates only slightly (in nominal terms) against the US dollar. In 2021-23 we expect inflation to stabilise at an average of 7.3%-still above the central bank's medium-term target of 5%. Economic growth in these years will be close to the economy's potential growth rate (limiting upward inflationary pressures).
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
In 2017 the lira depreciated by an average of almost 18% against the US dollar. In 2018 we estimate a further average depreciation, of about 25% (in nominal terms) in the full year. The lira depreciated significantly in January-August, with the exchange rate briefly reaching TL7.2:US$1 on August 13th. After a substantial recovery from September, we expect the lira to remain broadly stable against the US dollar in the remainder of the year. This expectation is underpinned by our view that the decrease in tensions between the US and Turkey, the sharp reduction in the current-account deficit due to the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar, and the tight monetary policy stance will contribute to a stabilisation of the exchange rate in the near term.
In 2019 we forecast that the lira will continue to depreciate on average against the US dollar, albeit at a much more moderate pace than in 2018. A normalising economic and financial domestic situation will support the exchange rate. However, there will be an increase in global risk aversion as the effects of the US-China bilateral trade war are fully felt, the cooling of the global economy causes expectations of a recession in some advanced economies to build and central banks in advanced economies tighten their monetary policy stances. As a result, we expect an average exchange rate of TL5.7:US$1 in 2019. Risks surrounding our exchange-rate forecast for 2019 are tilted to the upside.
In 2020 we expect the exchange rate to remain broadly stable as the economy starts to grow more markedly after an expected slump in 2018-19. Thereafter in 2021-23 we expect a gradual depreciation of the lira against the US dollar in nominal terms, to TL6.3:US$1 by the end of 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The current-account deficit as a share of GDP will narrow in 2018, to 4.6%, from 5.6% in 2017, as the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar will depress imports (owing to a deceleration in domestic demand) and boost export competitiveness. In 2019-23 we expect a smaller average annual current-account deficit, of 3.6% of GDP. Significant gains in competitiveness from past lira depreciation, which moderated inflation, and the emergence of spare capacity will result in a boost to exports and a compression in imports over the medium term.

Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly. Outside of these areas, we do not expect much success in rolling back the PSUV's strong interventionist bent in the economy. Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Economic collapse and the erosion of the patronage scheme supporting the president, Nicolás Maduro, have put the ruling regime's internal cohesion in jeopardy. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a traumatic rift that will end in regime pragmatists allowing opposition participation in a "mixed administration" as a way to remain in power from 2019 onwards. There is a risk that the existing regime will retain cohesion and cling to power beyond 2019 if it finds financing to meet its debt obligations and boost dwindling oil production.
We estimate that inflation exceeded 2,500% at the end of 2017 and will reach 715,130% by end-2018. GDP will continue to contract in 2018-20. High inflation has led to a collapse in private consumption, and difficult operating conditions have hurt investment. Following a change in policy under a new government, we expect economic growth to resume in 2021.
The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. From 2019 a new government will stabilise the economy, but the wholesale rethink of the institutional framework needed to restore investment and confidence is unlikely.
Worsening shortages of consumer goods and hyperinflation will hit private consumption, and an increasingly difficult operating environment will accentuate a fall in fixed investment. The recession that began in 2014 will continue to deepen despite a partial recovery in oil prices as oil output slumps, and the economy will not return to growth until 2021-assuming that a new government takes power and implements reforms. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, reinforcing our forecasts of only a weak recovery.
US dollar measurements of Venezuela's market size provide an overly positive picture of the economy, given the marked overvaluation of the fixed exchange rate. In reality, recession and extremely high inflation (driven by shortages of foreign exchange and basic goods) will continue to restrict purchasing power. After 2020, under a new government, we expect purchasing power and the business environment to improve.
