Venezuela is in 82nd position globally in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings for 2019-23, the worst position in our ranking. This reflects the highly heterodox macroeconomic policies of an authoritarian government, a lack of legal security and weak institutions.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Start of roll-back of interventionist measures like price controls, but political-instability concerns slow liberalisation. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and undermine free competition.
2021-23: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Regulation by new government protecting property rights introduced in an attempt at attracting investment.
2021-23: Despite efforts, actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2019-20: Currency controls are made less opaque but restrictions on the private sector's access to foreign currency remain in place.
2021-23: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2019-20: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2020-22: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2019-20: Inflation remains high and concerns about economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2021-23: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2019-20: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. The current freeze on redundancies is fazed-out
2021-23: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Underinvestment in the water network and electricity grid ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2021-23: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued water and electricity rationing.
Technological readiness
2019-20: E-government services remain almost non-existent and deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment.
2021-23: Limited regulator capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has plummeted as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices has plunged the country into a massive economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded republican institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy mired in a years-long economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. At the same time, mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign-exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The VAT rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Using IMF data, The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$21.1bn in 2017 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages. We estimate the current-account surplus at 2.3% of GDP that year.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
Despite an extremely severe economic crisis, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) and the president, Nicolás Maduro, retain their hold on power. Regardless, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects worsening economic conditions to result in a chaotic political transition to a government with nominal opposition participation-a "mixed administration"-at some point in the forecast period. Currently, we assume that this will happen in 2019, but the process will be highly uncertain and may feature several false starts. We expect the forecast period to be characterised by political instability.
The opposition, owing to internal infighting and years of government harassment, is in disarray and incapable of channelling the populace's dissatisfaction. The regime has been pushing for a new dialogue, widening longstanding rifts in the opposition on how to best oppose the regime and force political change.
The opposition's troubles notwithstanding, the PSUV is dependent on the military for support. The country is run by civic-military alliance and a network of businessmen with military or political connections. This network is sustained by opportunities for corruption made possible by foreign-exchange controls, subsidised imports, clientelism, control of wasteful state-owned companies and the government's tacit approval of transnational organised crime (as evidenced by numerous press reports, and sanctions and indictments related to drug-trafficking on regime leaders abroad).
Regime factions are primarily explained by personal and patronage ties, resulting in different civic-military factions coexisting within the regime. Outside of potential outright criminal income, the resources maintaining this patronage system come from export revenue generated by PDVSA, the state-owned oil company.
Mismanagement and underinvestment at PDVSA has led to declining output and exports, destabilising the regime. Purges of the military and re-organisations in civilian government are common as factions jostle for power. A reshuffle in the judiciary and the national intelligence agency in October seems to have strengthened Mr Maduro, to the detriment of his main internal rival, Diosdado Cabello, head of the Constituent Assembly (ANC), the country's de facto legislature. With resources dwindling, control of the coercive apparatus is key to maintaining regime cohesion. Mr Maduro has thus seemingly increased his capacity to wrangle the regime's competing factions.
However, our baseline view is that the government's proven inability to increase PDVSA output or secure sufficient financing makes the status-quo unsustainable. This process may be hastened if exports are disrupted by external forces, such as US government sanctions on the oil trade (the US is PDVSA's largest cash-paying market and a key source of production inputs) or asset seizures stemming from unpaid debts. With oil output dropping to around 1m barrels/day (b/d), down from 2.5m b/d when Mr Maduro took office, we currently expect an internal fracture in 2019 but, regardless of the timing, what happens next is hard to predict.
Given that the regime's raison d'etre is the enrichment of its members, stabilisation of PDVSA and the economy would take priority under a new government. We expect regime pragmatists to seek assistance from Western governments and multilateral organisations. To gain international legitimacy and secure financing, these pragmatists would allow nominal opposition participation in a "mixed administration". Given past behaviour, there should be plenty of opposition figures willing to participate. This administration would still face pockets of resistance in places such as the judiciary, the ANC and the radicalised supporters of the PSUV known as colectivos. As such, political stability through the forecast period will be limited.
Three key assumptions underpin our baseline view. A crucial assumption is that, given economic conditions, Mr Maduro cannot sustain regime cohesion indefinitely. Changes at the national intelligence agency introduces risks to this assumption. A second assumption is that Russia and China-erstwhile financiers-will not provide substantial funding to the current administration (or to a PSUV-only successor administration). We base this view on the regime's inability to repay already expired loans and the fact that it has received limited Chinese or Russian aid since 2015. Venezuela's oil wealth, however, remains a draw-especially if sold off at low prices by a bankrupt regime.
A significant third assumption is that the need to restore macroeconomic stability and steady resource flows through the patronage system has become so urgent as to allow pragmatists to accept Western-demanded democratic and macroeconomic reforms. Democratic reform would be likely to involve judicial retribution on a number of current regime leaders, while macroeconomic reform would eliminate the economy's distortions, closing avenues for corruption and enrichment.
As such, there are strong risks to our baseline view, and there is a strong possibility of alternate scenarios. These include: a PSUV-only administration securing enough Chinese financing; a permanently impoverished nation led by an outright military government (or one with civilian figureheads); or-as an outside possibility-prolonged chaos, if regime cohesion fails but no faction gains clear control of the state apparatus across the country.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
We do not expect free and fair elections in the short term. Municipal elections are scheduled for December 9th. Most of the opposition has been proscribed and only some parties are participating (which has led to further infighting). In this context, a PSUV sweep is all but guaranteed. Based on our political assumptions, an electoral timetable may be announced, as international financing would almost certainly come with demands for democratic reforms.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Most regional governments have denounced the Venezuelan government, as has the EU. The US has put individual sanctions on most regime leaders, including potential successors to Mr Maduro. This limits the field of negotiating partners in the event of an internal fracture of the regime, but sanctions are reversible. US country-level sanctions block Venezuela from refinancing its debts. Military intervention and sanctions banning the oil trade are not part of our baseline assumption, but a hawkish US foreign policy team increases risks.
Russia and China seem unwilling to provide the necessary financing-amounting to tens of billions of dollars per year-to stabilise the economy and PDVSA. The regime openly courts the two countries, but with little apparent success. A change in the current Chinese stance represents a major risk to our forecast.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Monetisation of large public deficits, coupled with mismanagement of the state-dominated oil industry, has led to hyperinflation and shortages of foreign currency, basic goods and industrial inputs. The government remains technically unable and politically unwilling to undertake the deep and wide-ranging policy and institutional changes needed. Its latest economic plan, launched in late August, was self-defeating, and the government has not complied with a cornerstone promise to abolish the monetisation of public deficits. As such, imbalances will persist and foreign exchange will continue to be rationed.
Economic policy will remain interventionist in the short term, deepening the economic crisis that underpins our baseline forecast for political change. Furthermore, outside of promising a hard-to-implement reduction in fuel subsidies, the plan had little focus on PDVSA's falling output; production at PDVSA remains a crucial factor in supporting the economy amid a collapse in the non-oil sector.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect that more orthodox economic policies will be implemented under a new government. However, the pace and depth of the adjustment will be constrained by uncertainty over the stability of any new regime, and whether this takes precedence over the likely demands for reform from multilateral and bilateral lenders. Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and multilaterals (totalling US$19bn in 2019-22) and the restructuring of the government's debt obligations. This in itself will be a huge task for any administration. At the same time, PDVSA will need wholesale reform to open itself to the foreign finance needed to increase output, a process that will require considerable political capital.
Pockets of resistance are likely to exist. Internal stability within the PSUV is a major risk to our forecast, as the success of a mixed administration would depend on PSUV pragmatists fending off more radical party members. These members would oppose international assistance, foreign investment and policy reforms on both ideological and personal grounds (as many regime insiders profit from the state's indirect and direct control of the economy).
Outside of these areas, we do not expect much success in rolling back the PSUV's strong interventionist bent in the economy. Thus, we expect limited real investment inflows, the vast majority going into the oil sector, which will restrict economic recovery and fuel continued unrest.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
Authorities have not published complete official data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We estimate that the fiscal deficit is well into double figures as a percentage of GDP. The government relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency.
High inflation and the overvalued official exchange rate make debt/GDP ratios misleading indicators of fiscal stability. Considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) understates the true size of total public liabilities. Most sovereign and state-owned bonds (including PDVSA's) are in arrears. Bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy changes or a change in leadership. The exceptions to arrears are debts that threaten Citgo (PDVSA's US subsidiary) and leased facilities in the Caribbean. Both facilitate PDVSA's capacity to export oil and import production inputs. So far, Venezuela has taken a defensive stance, treating each claim individually and stalling as much as possible before complying when seizures seem imminent. Given PDVSA's strained financial situation and the lack of further sources of financing, the strategy does not seem sustainable.
Citgo, itself indebted and posted as collateral for loans and bonds, could have its fate be resolved by a prolonged judicial process in the US. We believe that, if forced to choose, the government would prioritise its Caribbean assets over Citgo, as the former are key for PDVSA's capacity to export, while import-export trade with Citgo could be re-routed to other US companies. However, it is unclear when the government may have to choose or if would have the capacity to do so. PDVSA's strained financial situation means that the risk of default and seizure will remain high in the short term. Stalling tactics (including partial compliance with payments) will continue.
Under our baseline forecast, we expect a restructuring with external creditors in 2020. Owing to the need to maintain political stability, we do not expect the closure of the various handout programmes in operation, nor the complete removal of utility subsidies or the reformation of inefficient state-owned firms. Therefore, we expect public expenditure to be hard to reduce; the deficit will be substantial throughout the 2019-23 period.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The government's financing needs will continue to force the Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank) to print money. Money supply (M2) continues to grow rapidly, expanding by 96% month on month at end-November. We expect a new administration to place a much greater emphasis on tackling hyperinflation and expect a substantial monetary adjustment in the context of a macroeconomic stabilisation plan. The introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) in such a context is highly likely.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 15% in 2018, we expect further contractions in 2019-20. A forecast recovery in 2021-23 rests on the assumption of a political transition that, supported by IMF assistance, produces a credible macroeconomic programme with improved management of oil wealth. However, reform will be limited in scope by a weak government, and we expect only a partial rebound in real GDP, following a decline of around 50% in 2013-20.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2018, reflecting the effect on real wages of hyperinflation, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will also contract, reflecting difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange. Our forecast for a recovery in investment later in the forecast period assumes a political transition and a pick-up in oil investment.
We expect oil output to bottom out at 1m b/d in mid-2019, kept from going lower by PDVSA's joint-venture partners. Under our baseline forecast of openness to foreign investment under a new government from 2019, production will start to recover in the second half of 2020 but will remain well below 2m b/d, the average output in 2017, even at the end of our forecast period.
Export volumes will only start to recover in 2020, as an increase in domestic demand, which has been artificially constrained, will initially absorb the increase in oil output. For the same reason, import demand will rise sharply in 2019.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Decimated domestic supply, severe limits on imports and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official data have not been published since 2015, but the opposition-led National Assembly estimated that monthly inflation was 148% (833,997% year on year) in October. In the context of a macroeconomic stabilisation plan in 2019, we expect much tighter monetary policy and lower inflation.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
Under our current baseline forecast, the introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) amid deep imbalances and as a means to try to tackle hyperinflation is possible in 2019. The exact nature and implementation of such moves are hard to foresee, but our baseline forecast includes the continuation of some currency controls for the duration of the forecast period.
Since the start of the year the government has devalued the official exchange rate by over 99%, but exchange controls remain. The official rate is determined by an auction process, but the government-which monopolises the country's exports-does not supply the system with foreign-exchange, making the system unsustainable and access to foreign exchange practically impossible. In early December the black-market exchange rate was around BsS500:US$1; the official rate stood at BsS152:US$1.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
After an estimated current-account surplus of US$14.3bn in 2018, we expect the current account to remain in surplus for most of the forecast period. The surplus is buoyed by non-payment of interest on bonded debt ("savings" in excess of US$5bn in 2018 alone). Our export data, which are based on IMF data, may overstate receipts, as some exports are actually payments in-kind for loans, the repayment of which may not be included in their totality under forecast interest repayments (we have excluded repayments to Chinese lenders to maintain consistency with the World Bank's data on which our debt forecasts are based).
By 2020, with a new government in power, we expect that-following debt renegotiation-external financing will be restored. Although we expect exports to grow as oil production increases, we also expect a surge in imports, as Venezuela's own productive base has been decimated and imports have been compressed to artificially low levels. In addition, the government will be complying with its debt obligations, meaning that the restructured debt will actually result in increased outflows in interest payments. These factors will erode the current-account surplus from 4.8% of GDP in 2020 to a deficit of 1.2% by 2023.
We currently expect that the new administration will secure sufficient finance to stabilise the balance-of-payments dynamics. However, there are considerable risks to this rosy outlook. In addition to assuming the installation of a pragmatic mixed administration capable of retaining power, it hinges on substantial finance from the IMF, the quick implementation of a successful macroeconomic stabilisation package, the fast resolution of a debt renegotiation process in 2019-20, substantial inflows of financial and real investment into the economy in 2020-23, and a fast recovery in oil output after years of underinvestment and mismanagement.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
BCV: Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics

Abstract: [...]uncertainty surrounding tightening monetary policy in major developed markets, including the US, the risk of a disorderly economic slowdown in China (which is not our core forecast) and the impact of increasingly protectionist trade policies espoused by the US president, Donald Trump, continue to pose risks to our forecast. [...]exchange-rate trends may help to keep a lid on global commodity prices. Since April the US dollar has rallied strongly against other major currencies, and we expect the dollar (in which most raw materials are traded) to continue to remain fairly strong against most emerging-market currencies in 2018-19, especially as the sharp depreciation of the Turkish lira and the Argentinian peso in recent weeks sparks concerns over potential contagion in other emerging markets. Full text: Economist Intelligence Unit commodity price index: food, feedstuffs and beverages
Price forecast summary

Note. WCF (World commodity forecasts) is an index of 22 hard and soft commodities. FFB (Food, feedstuffs and beverages) is a price index of 13 soft commodities. The beverages sector has a weight of 20% in the FFB index, grains 46.4%, oilseeds 28.6% and sugar 4.9%. The FFB index has a weight of 55.6% in the WCF index.
Agricultural prices made a fairly modest recovery in 2018
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects its food, feedstuffs and beverages (FFB) price index to rise by 2.1% in 2018, down from our previous estimate of 2.8% owing to weaker prices for beverages such as coffee and cocoa, as well as sugar. The bilateral trade war between the US and China has disrupted existing trade patterns and caused the prices of some products that are subject to tariffs, including soybeans and soymeal, to diverge in various markets. A number of other markets, including grains such as rice and maize, are also beginning to tighten slightly, which will support sustained price growth through to 2020. Nonetheless, supplies in most markets remain comfortable by historical standards. Several crops registered record harvests in 2016/17, including wheat and soybeans, and large carryover stocks will limit the potential for price growth in 2018. Downside risks related to a potentially disruptive El Niño event will persist, but we do not forecast an agricultural price shock. FFB prices are forecast to remain flat in 2019 as the effects of the US-China bilateral trade war start to impact markets. However, by 2020 we expect producers and consumers to have adapted to shifting supply chains, supporting 4.9% growth in the FFB index owing to strong price growth in beverages, sugar and grains. Overall, we expect rising populations and incomes to continue to support modest growth in demand (and therefore prices) in the FFB sector in the medium and long term.
FFB prices will rise again in 2020, and risks to the forecast remain mixed
Nonetheless, the road ahead will be bumpy. Agricultural markets have been well supplied for several consecutive seasons, providing ample stocks to draw on. We expect global GDP growth to remain relatively firm, at an average of 2.6% per year in 2019-20. However, uncertainty surrounding tightening monetary policy in major developed markets, including the US, the risk of a disorderly economic slowdown in China (which is not our core forecast) and the impact of increasingly protectionist trade policies espoused by the US president, Donald Trump, continue to pose risks to our forecast. In addition, exchange-rate trends may help to keep a lid on global commodity prices. Since April the US dollar has rallied strongly against other major currencies, and we expect the dollar (in which most raw materials are traded) to continue to remain fairly strong against most emerging-market currencies in 2018-19, especially as the sharp depreciation of the Turkish lira and the Argentinian peso in recent weeks sparks concerns over potential contagion in other emerging markets. This will weigh on import demand in many emerging markets and encourage exporters to increase output, further contributing to global supplies.
Grain prices registered strong gains in 2018
We estimate that grain prices will rise by 12.6% in 2018. Maize prices rose by about 10% on average in February in response to worries about drought and rapidly shrinking production prospects in Argentina. We estimate full-year maize price growth to average 7.7% in 2018, as new crops arrive on the market and carryover supplies from the bumper 2016/17 crop remain available. Global wheat production is expected to fall by 5.8% owing to adverse weather conditions. Major wheat producers such as the EU, China, the US and Australia are expected to register lower than average harvests. As global demand remains strong, the wheat market is likely to register a deficit in 2017/18. This will help to boost wheat prices by 15.4% year on year in 2018 (from 17% previously) and by a further 3% in 2019 (from 2% previously).
Oilseed prices will fall in 2019-20
Oilseed prices are estimated to fall by 1.3% in 2018 after a decline of 2% in 2017, largely as a result of bumper soybean crops in major producers such as the US and Brazil. Despite strong global demand, this has driven global soybean stockpiles higher. We expect soybean prices to decline by an average of 2.1% per year in 2019-20. While China's imposition in July of a 25% tariff on soybean imports from the US has created the potential for greater price volatility, we expect China to source imports from other suppliers, avoiding a sharp increase in prices for now. Sunflowerseed oil prices are likely to continue to weaken in 2019, reflecting comfortable supplies. Palm oil prices are forecast to follow a similar trend as global output surges and changing consumer habits result in lower demand growth, particularly in developed economies, where health concerns have caused consumers to opt for alternative products.
A forecast recovery in coffee prices in 2019 will lift the beverages sub-index
We estimate that the beverages sub-index, which includes coffee, cocoa and tea, will fall for the sixth consecutive year in 2018. We expect cocoa prices to rise by 12.1% in 2018 before declining by around 6.6% in 2019, although the gain in 2018 will do little to erase the massive drop of nearly 30% in 2017, which was caused by soaring global production and fairly weak demand growth. Global coffee prices (arabica) are forecast to fall by 13.4% in 2018 on the back of higher than expected production from Central America as well as the comparative strength of the US dollar, which will encourage exporters to sell their stocks. In 2019 we expect prices of higher-value arabica coffee beans to rebound by 6.7%, as several consecutive years of market deficits begin to erode global supplies.
Sugar prices will recover in 2020
Sugar prices are expected to decline by around 26.1% in 2018, following a decline of 11.3% in 2017. This reflects crop-friendly weather conditions in key producer markets, which are fuelling expectations of a larger global sugar surplus than we had previously anticipated. Policy moves to restrict import dependence in key consumers (notably China, India and the EU) have weakened market sentiment further. This decline will continue in 2019, but we expect supplies to begin to tighten in 2020 as higher ethanol prices encourage farmers to divert more cane to ethanol (rather than to its rival, sugar). This should support growth in global sugar prices of 4.6% year on year in 2020.

Cocoa
Demand
After expanding by an estimated 1.5% in the 2017/18 season (October-September), global cocoa consumption growth is forecast to slow during 2018/19-2019/20. Although cocoa consumption in the world's largest consumers-mainly developed economies and some large markets in the developing world-is forecast to remain positive, consumption growth will remain weak in many of these countries, at less than 1%. Demand growth will prove stronger in other, smaller cocoa consumers, but these markets will not be sufficiently large to drive stronger overall growth in global cocoa consumption. By region, Asia accounts for much of the increase in global demand, although rising demand in the Americas and Europe will also contribute to overall demand growth. The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that global cocoa demand growth will average 1.3% per year in 2018/19 and 2019/20. Already high per-capita consumption levels in major developed markets will prevent faster demand growth. Another factor precluding more rapid demand growth are retail prices, which may rise in response to the increase in global cocoa prices in recent months, potentially pushing some consumers towards non-chocolate confectionery. Meanwhile, the size of many chocolate bars has shrunk-partly in response to consumer concerns about obesity but also to protect profits against a background of rising cocoa prices in previous years-which will also hamper consumption growth.
Balancing demand between cocoa powder and butter will be challenging
Asian countries will see slightly faster growth in cocoa demand than the global average, as these markets are far less saturated and GDP growth will remain higher than in developed economies. Stronger demand in Asia will have implications for global demand for cocoa butter (used in richer products, such as chocolate confectionery) and cocoa powder (used to add chocolate flavour to products such as biscuits, cakes and drinks). The demand balance between cocoa powder and butter is both delicate and cyclical. We expect demand for cocoa butter to remain strong in the short term, but it will not outstrip demand for powder indefinitely. Given that Asia accounted for 27% of the world's imports of cocoa powder in 2016/17, compared with just 11% of global imports of cocoa butter, firmer consumption growth in that market is likely to lift demand for powder.
Consumption growth will remain fairly low in more saturated markets
We forecast modest but positive growth in demand for cocoa in developed markets in 2018/19-2019/20. Health concerns, market saturation and changing retail habits will constrain demand (the rise of internet grocery shopping is eroding spur-of-the-moment in-store chocolate purchases). However, rising demand for dark chocolate-which has a higher cocoa content than milk chocolate and is perceived to be healthier-will support overall consumption. Consumers in the US (the largest cocoa-consuming country, which accounts for 18% of global demand) and in European countries, which collectively account for 46% of global demand, are showing an increasing preference for premium chocolate with a higher cocoa content, but with less frequent purchases. However, somewhat weaker underlying economic conditions will contribute to a gradual deceleration in cocoa consumption in many of these markets over the course of2018/19-2019/20.
Cocoa consumption growth will remain firm in Asia
China and India have huge potential for further expansion in cocoa demand, given currently low per-head consumption levels of just 35 g in India and 62 g in China in 2016/17, compared with 2-6 kg in developed markets. However, demand growth will be constrained by high retail prices. Chinese demand will continue to rise firmly, at a rate of around 5.1% per year in 2018/19-2019/20 on the back of a relatively firm GDP growth forecast. In India, we expect demand growth to pick up from an estimated 2.1% in 2017/18 to an annual average of 3.1% per year during the forecast period.

Supply
After falling by an estimated 3% in 2017/18, prospects for global cocoa production are weak for the 2018/19-2019/20 forecast period, reflecting a projected drop in production in Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana, respectively the world's largest and second-largest cocoa producers. Although output in both countries will remain high by historical standards, relatively unsupportive domestic policy frameworks and weaker confidence among growers will drag down cocoa output. Notwithstanding a rise in prices in 2018, the previous long-running period of weak prices is likely to have dissuaded farmers from investing in fertiliser and pesticides, raising the incidence of crop disease and contributing to the broader decline in global cocoa production. Rising production in other Asian and Latin America producers will fail to offset the decline in cocoa output among several of the largest African producers.
Structural and geographical factors will hamper long-term supply
Longer-term structural problems will also constrain supply. Not only have farm-gate prices in several large producing countries begun to fall in line with lower market prices for cocoa, but farmers are also getting a much smaller share of the final retail price than in previous decades owing to higher costs further down the supply chain. In West Africa, for example, many farmers remain below the poverty line, and as a result few young people are choosing to work in the cocoa sector. Governments are trying to lift farmers' incomes to attract new workers, but it is uncertain how effective this will be in the long term.
Geographical considerations will also hamper the diversification of production. Cocoa can only be grown in certain regions (three-quarters of world production comes from regions that are located within eight degrees of the equator) under warm and humid conditions. Cocoa production is therefore likely to remain concentrated among a small group of countries, limiting the scope for strong and sustained output growth. Periodically, there is speculation that climate change will hamper production in these countries to such an extent that cocoa production will plummet. However, we believe that some countries have significant potential to expand production, mainly in Latin America, where high-quality cocoa is produced. The expansion of grinding facilities in producing countries may also encourage new investment to lift output.
Côte d'Ivoire's production is set to drop in 2018/19 and 2019/20
In Côte d'Ivoire, we estimate that cocoa output fell by 3.5% in 2017/18, partly as a result of dry weather, which affected the mid-year-crop. We are forecasting production to fall again in 2018/19, but by just 3.1% (an upward revision from last month's projected 5.1% drop), with overall production remaining extremely high in the context of the 27.8% jump in output in 2016/17 to record levels. Weather prospects at the start of the 2018/19 crop season are fairly positive, and farmers have voiced optimism about expected production trends during the October-March main crop. A 7.1% increase in farm-gate prices by the Conseil du Café-Cacao (CCC) will also prove supportive, even though prices remain lower than in neighbouring Ghana (which will sustain problems of smuggling across the border). Despite these supporting factors, our baseline forecast for a drop in cocoa production in 2018/19, followed by another contraction of 2.1% in 2019/20, reflects several downside factors. Plans to accelerate the replacement of old crops infected by swollen shoot virus with new crops over the course of the next three years will hamper production. In addition, there have been reports of reduced use of fertiliser and pesticides over the past year, with the incidence of crop disease rising as a result. A stabilisation fund is supposed to protect farmers' revenue from price volatility, but the amounts have been insufficient, and given the lack of transparency over the financial reserves held by the CCC, neither farmers nor exporters are confident that losses arising from low global prices in 2016/17 will be recouped.
Ghanaian production is set to decline in both 2018/19 and 2019/20
Similar production trends are evident in Ghana. Adverse weather and a difficult policy backdrop hampered production in 2017/18, with cocoa output declining by an estimated 10.3%. We are forecasting a continued, albeit gentler, contraction in 2018/19 and 2019/20. The cocoa authority, Cocobod, is encountering financial problems that are affecting the amount paid to farmers, with farm-gate prices on hold in 2018/19, which in turn will depress output. Cocobod was forced to seek a bridging loan from the Bank of Ghana (the central bank) last year, and following the recent depletion of its stabilisation fund and continued reliance on debt financing, Cocobod has announced that it is considering amending the way in which farmers are paid. This is likely to involve the removal of a scheme that pays subsidies to farmers (guaranteeing a minimum income level). The authorities are instead considering a scheme in which farmers are paid 70% of the cocoa export price, which would expose incomes to considerable market volatility. Given anxiety among farmers about the government's intention to prioritise other crops over cocoa, the ongoing encroachment by gold miners, the government's decision to stop providing free fertiliser and the fact that around one-fifth of trees are affected by swollen shoot disease, production is forecast to fall by 5.2% in 2018/19 and by 3% in 2019/20.
In the longer term, the New Patriotic Party government plans to rehabilitate cocoa farms, cutting down trees that are over 30 years old and replanting them while providing financial compensation to farmers until the trees start yielding fruit (generally 3-5 years). The authorities aim ultimately to raise production significantly, with Cocobod recently indicating that it is targeting output of 1m tonnes within the next five years (an apparent downgrade from previous statements citing a target of 1.5m tonnes within four years), driven by better soil management, pest and disease control and improved irrigation. These plans are positive, since Ghana has a large share of unproductive trees (estimated at 40% by Cocobod) and consequently a low average yield per hectare (at 400 kg/ha, compared with 600 kg/ha in Côte d'Ivoire and 1 tonne/ha in Indonesia). However, it will be difficult to secure the necessary funding. We think it is unlikely that these ambitious plans will come to fruition, since the weak macroeconomic backdrop is likely to hamper public investment and external creditors are unlikely to fund the project.
The production targets of Cameroon and Nigeria will prove overambitious
Cameroon's cocoa production is estimated to have moderated in 2017/18 by 8.5% as political unrest in the south-west of the country, which produces around half of the country's output, dragged down national production, with rising numbers of farmers fleeing their plantations in the wake of violent clashes between separatists and the security forces. We have downgraded our forecasts this month and now expect a continued drop in cocoa output by 11.1% in 2018/19, on the basis that continued domestic political instability will impinge on cocoa production. Although we are forecasting a robust recovery in 2019/20 by 10%, overall production levels will remain weak owing to two years of consecutive declines. Cuts in farm-gate prices will be a disincentive to farmers, meaning that the government will remain significantly off track from its 2020 production target of 600,000 tonnes-a level that even the national Cocoa Development Corporation has described as "unrealistic and unattainable". Plans to increase the harvested area by 100,000 ha each year are highly unlikely to materialise in the context of the recent political instability.
Cocoa production in Nigeria has recovered in recent years after a slump in 2014-16, rising by an estimated 4.1% in 2017/18 to 255,000 tonnes (still below the government target of 300,000-320,000 tonnes). The authorities are seeking investment to raise cocoa production with the aim of diversifying and expanding sources of foreign-exchange earnings beyond the mainstay of oil, with the Ministry of Agriculture recently stating that it believes Nigeria can boost cocoa production above the levels recorded in Côte d'Ivoire. However, we remain pessimistic about production prospects and are forecasting a contraction of 0.9% on average per year in 2018/19-2019/20. Government initiatives meant to support farmers-including efforts to introduce high-yielding cocoa and to increase the distribution of free seedlings-have not been successful. In addition, investment has been slow to materialise, and reports of an increase in fungal disease as a result of recent heavy rains will hamper production in the near term. Structural problems, such as weak infrastructure, corruption, poor and expensive access to financing and weak implementation, remain unaddressed and will prevent a significant increase in output. We are forecasting a 3.9% contraction in cocoa output in 2018/19, followed by a partial 2% recovery in 20219/20.
Production will continue to recover in Indonesia
Indonesia is among the few major cocoa producers that are likely to see output rising firmly during the forecast period. Stable weather conditions in 2017/18 are likely to have lifted cocoa output by an estimated 7.4%. We forecast continued growth of 5.1% during the forecast period, but at 320,000 tonnes in 2019/20 output levels will remain weak by historical standards. The authorities have ambitious plans to triple cocoa output by 2020, from 325,000 tonnes in 2014/15, but these targets are highly unlikely to materialise. Indonesian firms will probably rely increasingly on imported processed cocoa from nearby Malaysia to meet domestic demand.
Strong potential for growth in Latin America
Structurally, there is scope for both of Latin America's two largest cocoa producers, Brazil and Ecuador, to lift output as manufacturers look to develop production centres outside West Africa. The region's reputation for producing high-quality cocoa will help in this respect, given rising global demand for premium chocolate. Although some of this investment will be slow to materialise, we still expect annual average output growth of 3.5% in Ecuador and 4.9% in Brazil during 2018/19-2019/20.

Stocks and prices
We expect the surplus in the global cocoa market to narrow sharply, from an estimated 402,000 tonnes in 2017/18 to 147,000 tonnes in 2019/20. Although production is forecast to fall steadily, the fact that it will do so from such a high base (output was exceptionally strong in 2016/17) means that we continue to forecast a market surplus, despite signs of continued (albeit weaker) demand growth. Stocks are forecast to reach 2.5m tonnes at the end of the 2019/20 season. Although this is high by historical standards, the relatively gloomy production outlook is likely to bolster prices towards the end of the forecast period.

Market surplus will put downward pressure on prices in 2019
Cocoa prices traded at comparatively low levels between February 2017 and February 2018, mainly in the range of US$1,950/tonne and US$2,050/tonne. However, prices rose sharply in March-May, to US$2,600-2,700/tonne, on the back of gloomy prospects for production in Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana. Better weather conditions subsequently led to a reduction in prices to around US$2,050/tonne in early October. However, firmer prices earlier in the year mean that our full-year average price estimate, at US$2,275/tonne, implies a 12.1% year on year increase.
Despite falling production in 2019, weaker demand and a persistent market surplus will suppress prices, which are forecast to average US$2,126/tonne, marking a decline of 6.5% year on year. The cocoa authorities in Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana have indicated that they plan to work together in an attempt to lift cocoa prices next year, but our baseline assumption is that this will have a very limited impact (if any) on global cocoa prices, not least because farm-gate prices remain different in each country. Although the same supply-demand factors will remain in play in 2020, amid declining production and weaker demand growth investor concerns about the impact of several years of falling output will place some support under prices, which we expect to pick up to around US$2,300/tonne by the last quarter of 2020.

Coffee
Demand
Global coffee consumption has been accelerating moderately in recent years, growing by an estimated 3.1% in the 2017/18 crop year (October-September), largely boosted by rising consumption in coffee-importing countries-mainly developed economies, which account for two-thirds of global demand. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects growth in global coffee demand to decelerate to 2.6% in 2018/19 and 1.9% in 2019/20, mainly reflecting less supportive underlying economic conditions. Continued monetary policy tightening in some of the large coffee consumers will affect overall domestic demand, although with the policy stance remaining relatively loose and most economies decelerating rather than entering into a recession, coffee consumption will rise more steadily.
In coffee-exporting countries, many of which are emerging markets, consumption growth will be lower, averaging 2.3% per year in 2018/19-2019/20. Tepid demand growth in Brazil, which currently accounts for around 40% of exporting countries' consumption owing to the sheer size of its domestic market, is the main factor contributing to weak overall growth in coffee consumption among coffee exporters. Consumption growth will be strongest in Asia-notably China, whose economy will continue to grow firmly. However, per-capita coffee consumption levels are low in China, so even as domestic demand rises quickly, this will contribute only modestly to global growth (China will account for only 3% of the total global rise in coffee production in 2017/18-2018/19).
Coffee habits are shifting around the world
Consumption trends will change in both the home and out-of-home sectors. In the latter, the expansion of coffee-shop chains will continue, providing a boost to demand, particularly in North America (with 46% of coffee in the US now consumed out of the home) and Europe (which saw the number of coffee shops rise by 6.4% in 2017), but store formats will evolve. Increasing demand for "on the go" beverages will result in larger numbers of smaller shops, including within petrol stations and supermarkets, as well as the spread of coffee delivery services by large chains. In some markets-including the US and China-both large coffee chains and new start-ups are increasingly focusing on prepayment through smartphone apps, allowing customers to pick up their purchases without having to queue. These technological developments are likely to help the out-of-home sector to defend its market share at a time when a large number of consumers have single-serve coffee-capsule machines at home. This will be accompanied by the heavy marketing of other coffee beverages, including iced coffee and cold brew. Although accounting for only a small share of the out-of-home segment, sales of these products are likely to grow rapidly.
Single-serve coffee will help to drive growth in developed markets
Demand for coffee at home that rivals the quality of beverages found in cafes will result in a shift away from the consumption of instant coffee. On a global level, coffee-pod sales are approaching the total combined value of instant and ground coffee, although the higher cost of pods means that in volume terms the instant- and ground-coffee market remains larger. Despite the sharp slowdown in sales of machines and capsules after initial firm growth, the coffee-pod market will continue to provide important support for overall demand of arabica coffee (most pods contain predominantly arabica beans).
Coffee consumption growth in North America will continue to rise
We expect US coffee consumption to continue to grow at a more moderate pace than in recent years. From an estimated 4.8% in 2017/18, coffee consumption growth is forecast to decelerate to 4.1% in 2018/19 and 1.8% in 2019/20, reflecting a gradual slowing of underlying consumer demand growth. That said, coffee consumption is not expected to fall, with the US National Coffee Association estimating that the percentage of people drinking coffee is continuing to rise (up from 57% in early 2016 to 62% in early 2017, according to the latest data). Daily consumption is rising, and consumers are increasingly attracted to a variety of products; for example, US consumption of cold coffee products has risen by 75% over 2015-17. Moreover, the number of coffee shops is increasing at a rate of around 3.6% per year, while the share of 13-18-year-olds drinking coffee has gone up from 23% in 2014 to 37% in early 2017. Demand growth among 18-24-year-olds is also rising strongly, which bodes well for medium- to long-term coffee consumption trends.
Similar dynamics are evident in Canada, with the share of 18-24-year-olds drinking coffee jumping from 48% in 2015 to 58% in 2016 (up from just 32% in 2009). Younger consumers, in particular, are showing a much stronger preference for speciality coffees and for drinking coffee in out-of-home locations. We expect Canada's demand growth, which has been fairly steady at around 2.5% in recent years, to slow moderately to an average of 2% per year in 2018/19-2019/20.
Coffee consumption in Brazil will moderate
Brazil is the world's second-largest coffee consumer, but consumption levels per head are still modest (at around one-third of those in most European countries), so there is scope for a significant increase in demand. As Brazil emerges from a sharp economic recession that caused coffee consumption to remain fairly flat in 2014-16, coffee consumption is showing signs of strengthening and is estimated to rise by 3.6% in 2017/18. Growth is likely to moderate but remain fairly firm at around 2.3% per year in 2018/19 and 2019/20, although the local coffee processing association, the Brazilian Coffee Industry Association (ABIC), is expecting firmer coffee consumption growth in 2018 as the economy recovers. However, household consumption will remain constrained by high unemployment and rising fuel prices, which will all act as a drag on disposable income.
Continued coffee consumption growth is forecast in Japan and South Korea
Japan is the largest coffee market in Asia, with coffee boasting around the same share of the beverages market as tea. After rising by an estimated 0.9% in 2017/18, we expect coffee consumption growth to accelerate by an average of 1.2% per year in 2018/19-2019/20. This growth will be driven by coffee sales in convenience stores, given that the number of coffee shops is falling. Meanwhile, in South Korea the coffee market has expanded rapidly in recent years, with imports more than trebling in the past decade and the number of coffee shops increasing even faster. We expect the pace of growth to slow but remain firm by global standards, at an annual average of 2.6% per year over the forecast period.
China consumption and production data
Until recently we did not include China in our list of top coffee consumers and producers, instead including it in our list of "others". This reflected the fact that the International Coffee Organisation (ICO) does not report China's coffee consumption and production, complicating direct data comparisons with other consuming and producing countries. Widespread acknowledgment of China emerging as a major player in the coffee market has prompted us to amend our tables to include figures for China. However, a lack of historical data series means that these figures should be regarded as estimates.
Consumption
We have based the historical series of our coffee consumption data on a paper written by the ICO, in which it estimates consumption based on production, export and import figures. It provides data to 2013/14, with annual consumption calculated from domestic production plus net exports. From 2013/14 onwards we have estimated coffee consumption based on growth in private consumption to provide a rough guide to the size of the Chinese coffee market. According to these calculations, China is the sixth-largest coffee consumer among coffee-exporting countries, but at 2.4m bags in 2016/17 its market is significantly smaller than those of many coffee-importing countries. By comparison, Chinese coffee consumption remains lower than consumption in the UK, despite huge disparities in population size.
Production
We have used data from the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO), which are current until 2016/17. This series indicates that coffee production rose sharply between 2008/09 and 2013/14, more than trebling, but output has since stabilised at around 1.9m bags. This makes China the world's tenth-largest coffee producer.
Demand in China and India will continue to grow
Coffee demand in China and India, which have similar levels of consumption, will continue to grow, aided by still-firm economic growth in both countries, which will lift disposable incomes. Although GDP growth is likely to be stronger in India, we expect coffee consumption growth in China to be firmer. This reflects the fact that the middle class has expanded much more rapidly in China than in India, where disposable income levels for the most part remain extremely low. The emergence of a coffee-shop culture in urban centres is a key factor contributing to the rise in coffee consumption in China, aided by a rapid expansion of international coffee chains. Starbucks now runs 3,200 outlets in 139 Chinese cities, up from 2,300 in October 2017. Of these, around 600 are in Shanghai alone-Starbucks' largest presence in a single city. A new store which opened in the city last December, the Shanghai Reserve Roastery, is the company's highest-earning branch worldwide. Despite signs of weaker sales growth in China amid greater competition from fast-growing start-ups offering coffee delivery and pick-up points, the company is still planning to have 6,000 stores open by the end of 2022. With the out-of-home sector expanding slightly less rapidly in India, coffee consumption will grow more slowly. We therefore forecast average growth of 2.1% per year in 2018/19-2019/20, compared with estimated growth of 2.2% in 2017/18.
South-east Asia also has relatively low levels of coffee consumption per head, but demand is increasing rapidly in some countries, mainly in coffee-producing economies such as Indonesia and Vietnam. Rising incomes are encouraging companies such as Starbucks to expand in Indonesia and the Philippines, where consumption is increasing. Costa Coffee is expanding in Thailand, Singapore and Cambodia and opened its first store in Vietnam last October.
Asian markets will drive demand for robusta beans
Given taste preferences for soluble and instant coffee-which generally use the robusta variety-in faster-growing Asian markets, demand will be stronger compared with the more expensive arabica blends. Improved quality of robusta will also play a part here, with such beans slowly losing their reputation for inferior taste. In addition, improvements in processing technology mean that it is possible to use a larger proportion of robusta in coffee blends while maintaining quality.

Supply
The biennial crop season in Brazil, the world's largest producer, will continue to have a significant impact on overall global coffee output trends. Global output fell by 0.3% in the 2017/18 crop year, which mainly reflected a drop in output in Brazil as the crop year switched to a lower-producing (off-season) year. However, we expect global coffee production to rebound by a firm 6.5% in 2018/19. A recovery in Brazil's production as the crop switches back to a higher-producing year will account for over 80% of the global increase in coffee output. Rising production in several other Latin American coffee producers as well as Asian growers will have a marginal but positive impact on coffee output. However, with Brazil switching to another off-season year, we are forecasting a 1.8% drop in global coffee production in 2019/20. We are currently forecasting only mild production increases elsewhere, which will fail to compensate for the decline in Brazil. This is based on the assumption that recent low coffee prices will hamper output in the medium term as cutbacks on pesticide and fertiliser usage affect production levels.
Coffee production is Brazil is estimated to reach record levels in 2018/19
In Brazil, notwithstanding the shift from an on-season crop in 2018/19 to an off-season crop in 2019/20, production in both years is forecast to be high by historical standards. Although some arabica-producing areas reported dryness earlier in 2018-delaying harvest progress-recent weather conditions have been much better, which will bolster prospects for 2018/19. Local observers have stated that there is potential for a bumper crop, with some even suggesting that output of up to 65m bags is possible, which would be a record high by some margin (to date, the highest production was recorded in 2012/13, at 55.4m bags). We believe that this figure is out of reach and are forecasting coffee production of 59.5m bags for the 2018/19 season. This is similar to the estimate from Conab, Brazil's food statistics agency, which recently raised its projection from 58m bags to 59.9m bags. The strong result is likely to reflect a firm recovery in both arabica and robusta production (which are expected to account for three-quarters and one-quarter of total output respectively). Our expectation that coffee production will fall to a still-strong 54m bags in 2019/20 is based on the belief that the continued weakness of the local currency will continue to provide an incentive to growers.
Coffee production in Vietnam is set to stabilise at historically high levels
In Vietnam, supportive weather conditions led to a sharp 15.5% increase in the 2017/18 crop, with coffee production coming in at 29.5m bags. We expect a slight decline in coffee production in 2018/19 and 2019/20, although at around 29m bags output levels will remain high compared with recent years. These forecasts are more optimistic than the authorities' projections for medium-term coffee production, which tend to be fairly low. However, recent weather conditions have been relatively supportive, while government efforts to replant 140,000 ha of coffee, targeting 25,000 ha a year, as well as a rising arabica crop will underpin still-firm output, particularly given that yields from new bushes are typically higher. Firm demand for robusta in the domestic market and other Asian countries will also encourage growers. We expect coffee output to decline by 0.8% per year in 2018/19-2019/20.
Output growth is Mexico and Central America will flatten
Coffee production also stood at historically high levels in Mexico and Central America in 2017/18, growing by 7.6% to close to 21m bags (surpassing the 20m-mark for the first time on record). After several outbreaks of disease in recent years greater use of fungicides and fertiliser boosted coffee production, with weather conditions also proving supportive. We expect coffee production in the sub-region to stabilise at around current levels in 2018/19 and 2019/20. We expect some countries to register slightly weaker production levels, in particular the sub-region's largest producer, Honduras, where output will moderate after an exceptionally strong 2017/18. Guatemala will also register a decline owing to the effects of a volcanic eruption in the south-west of the country in June, which is believed to have wiped out 1% of the country's coffee plantations. However, this will be offset by moderate rises in coffee production elsewhere in the sub-region, including Mexico and Nicaragua, which will benefit from ongoing programmes to rejuvenate ageing coffee plantations.
Colombian production is set to recover after a weather-induced fall in 2017/18
After five years of rising coffee production in Colombia, output fell by 4.3% in 2017/18 to 14m bags as cloudy weather conditions affected flowering on coffee bushes early in the season, which was followed by very wet weather. However, the sector's fundamentals are strong, including a comparatively high percentage of rust-resistant bushes, and as such we do not expect the decline to persist. Recent additional planting in existing plantations has focused on improving yields, which at 18 bags/ha in 2016 were much lower than in other large growers (27 bags/ha in Brazil and 35 bags/ha in Vietnam). As a result we expect production to recover in 2018/19 and 2019/20, with output growing by 5% and 2% respectively. Towards the end of the forecast period the 2016 peace agreement between the government and the then FARC rebels will allow coffee cultivation to expand in previously isolated areas of the country (although we view the government's statements that output could reach 20m bags by 2020 as overly optimistic).
Coffee production is likely to recover but remain fairly weak in Indonesia
Indonesia's ambitious expansion plans for the coffee sector, which include more than doubling production within five years to make the country the world's second-largest producer after Brazil, have been completely derailed. The El Niño weather phenomenon brought excessively dry weather to the main coffee-growing areas, affecting the harvests in both 2016/17 and 2017/18. Even assuming a 5.5% increase in 2018/19 and a 2.6% rise in 2019/20, at just 11.8m bags output will remain low by historical standards. Low average yields-at only around one-fifth of the levels recorded in Vietnam-reflect high levels of structural inefficiency in the sector, which we do not expect to be tackled during the forecast period.

Production prospects in Africa, which accounts for around 11% of total global coffee output, are relatively bright. Many of the continent's coffee producers have very low levels of output; together, Ethiopia and Uganda account for 70% of African coffee output. Production rose firmly in both countries in 2017/18, mainly on the back of better weather conditions. We expect output to continue to rise in 2018/19 and 2019/20, reflecting an extensive reseeding programme in recent years, an expansion of the coffee-growing area and domestic efforts to streamline the organisation of the sector.
Stocks and prices
After falling marginally in 2017/18, we expect global coffee stocks to rise in 2018/19 on the back of a sharp rise in production, coupled with continued sales of stocks by exporting countries, with producers taking advantage of weak local currencies against the US dollar to boost locally denominated profits. However, with coffee production falling and consumption continuing to rise (albeit more mildly) in 2019/20, the market balance is expected to remain in deficit. By end-2019/20 we expect global stocks to have fallen to 30.3m bags, which will support a partial recovery in prices.

Coffee prices are increasingly reactive to changes in the strength of the US dollar
Arabica prices have fallen more or less steadily since the beginning of 2017, averaging around US$1.25/lb in August-September (compared with close to US$1.70/lb in January 2017). Futures prices are trading even lower, with arabica for December delivery falling below the US$1/lb mark in mid-September (a 12-year low), before a recovery to around US$1.11/lb in early October. Given that the global market is estimated to have registered a slight deficit in 2017/18, the fall in prices-to levels not seen since 2013-is curious. We believe that coffee prices are increasingly driven by investment trends, with swings in sentiment often caused by a spate of positive or negative news on the supply side. Coffee prices are also becoming increasingly reactive to changes in the strength of the US dollar, with dollar depreciation tending to lead to higher coffee prices. In recent months speculation about bumper production levels in Brazil in 2018/19 has pushed prices lower. The fact that several large exporting countries are continuing to sell spare stock to take advantage of weak local currencies is also suppressing prices, because this has been accompanied by a rise in coffee stocks in importing countries, which in turn may contain demand in the future.
Aside from positive signs from Brazilian producers, continued high levels of coffee output from other main producers are likely to keep prices suppressed in the near term. We expect prices to fall further in the fourth quarter of 2018, with an estimated average price of US$1.31/lb for the full year representing a 12.8% year on year decline for arabica. Given that the next off-season in Brazil (2019/20) is likely to hit market confidence during the 2019 calendar year, we forecast a recovery in prices to an average of US$1.39/lb in 2019 marking a gain of 6.4% year on year, and growing by an additional 11.8% to US$1.56/lb in 2020 as the global market balance slips into deficit. Prices for cheaper robusta will also decline during much of 2018 as bean supply picks up. We expect prices to average 84.3 US cents/lb in 2018-a 16.5% year-on-year decline-before rising to 90 US cents/lb in 2019 and US$1.03/lb in 2020.

Maize
Demand
Global demand for maize has increased at an astonishing pace during the past two decades, rising from just 600m tonnes at the turn of the millennium to a projected 1.09bn tonnes in 2018/19, up by 3.4% compared with the previous year. Provisional demand projections for 2019/20 are for further, albeit more modest growth of 1.37%, to 1.1bn tonnes. Apart from 2012/13, when US crops were badly affected by drought, consumption has increased each season, with growth averaging 3.1% per year over 2012/13-2016/17. While stocks mostly tightened through to 2006/07, the spike in demand was accompanied by an even steeper rise in production, resulting in a build-up of inventories over the next decade. However, trends in underlying fundamentals have subsequently changed course, with growth in consumption outstripping increases in supplies since 2017/18.
Maize is primarily used as a feed ingredient, which accounts for around 55% of total usage. Amid broad-based gains in world meat production, especially of poultry and pork, demand for high-starch, high-energy feed maize continues to trend higher almost everywhere, with growth averaging around 3% per year since 2015/16. Demand for maize-based biofuels continues to increase year after year, albeit at a slower rate than during the policy-driven boom in the mid-2000s. With production of other sugars and starches also trending higher, partly in response to improved economic conditions, global use for industrial processing has increased at an average of 3.6% per year over the past five year and is seen totalling a record 305m tonnes in 2018/19. Helped by a series of large crops in Sub-Saharan Africa, food maize demand has also seen relatively firm growth in recent seasons and is forecast to reach 123m tonnes in 2018/19.
World feed demand will rise by 3% in 2018/19
Growth in global demand for meat and other animal proteins shows no sign of slowing, with consumption gains driven by population growth, greater purchasing power and changes in diets and tastes. Maize is an extremely useful ingredient in animal feed, which can contribute to rapid livestock weight gain. We expect 3% annual growth in the use of maize for livestock feed in 2018/19, broadly in line with the previous year, with overall demand touching a new record of 621m tonnes. The EU and China are likely to account for much of the increase, with notable gains also expected in Russia, Brazil, Iran, Saudi Arabia and Vietnam. The outlook for 2019/20 remains highly tentative at this stage, as a projected pullback in feed demand in the EU could limit overall use to 627m tonnes. Although this would still be a new peak, it would be only 1% higher than in the previous season.
African swine fever could affect demand for feed in China
African swine fever, a highly contagious viral disease for which there is no vaccine, has recently been detected for the first time in China and is now spreading rapidly. The virus is transmitted by ticks or direct contact between animals, as well as by contaminated animal feed or meat products, where it can survive for months. The virus is not harmful to humans but is often lethal for domestic pigs and wild boars. Infections have also been reported this year in parts of the EU, as well as in Russia and Ukraine. However, with half of the world's pig population located in China, this latest outbreak is by far the most alarming. The local authorities have moved quickly to contain the infection, culling thousands of pigs, banning the transport of live animals and closing markets in affected areas. At this early stage of the outbreak the potential impact on animal feed demand remains unclear. In the short term, any sharp reductions in slaughter rates might actually strengthen spot feed demand, while in the longer term much will depend on the severity of the outbreak and how many animals are affected. At an emergency regional meeting called by the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) in early September, officials cautioned that the infection would likely spread to other parts of Asia.
World industrial demand set to rise again in 2018/19
Led by gains in the US and China, global industrial use has surged from around 75m tonnes 20 years ago to a projected 305m tonnes in the 2018/19 marketing year. After earlier extremely rapid growth, the US ethanol industry is expanding at a comparatively much slower rate, with almost all gasoline sold in the country now containing 10% ethanol (E10). With exports to China also stalling owing to the current trade dispute, ethanol producers are extremely keen to expand the demand base through other measures. Processing margins are currently very thin, with profitability squeezed by a recent slump in ethanol prices. The administration of the president, Donald Trump, has repeatedly stated its intention to approve the year-round use of 15% ethanol blends (E15). Currently E15 can not be sold for use in non-flex fuel vehicles between June 1st and September 15th owing to concerns about smog formation. Given concerns about performance and fuel economy, any such policy change would probably also need to be accompanied by a big marketing effort if consumers are to be persuaded to use higher ethanol blends.
A breakthrough in NAFTA negotiations
US maize farmers and exporters were relieved by the recent announcement of a preliminary trade agreement between the US, Mexico and Canada. Negotiators have concluded a deal to replace the North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA) with the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), with duty-free access for most agricultural products, including maize, maintained.
