Supply
Global maize production has increased by an average of 3% per year over the past two decades, rising from less than 600m tonnes in 1999/2000 to more than 1bn tonnes since 2016/17. During this period production has declined on just five occasions, typically as a result of spells of difficult cropping weather. In general, production has been driven steadily upward by increases in both areas and yields. Amid strengthening demand for animal feed and industrial products, high market prices have encouraged additional plantings almost everywhere. New seed varieties, fertiliser and better farming practices have also been used with great effect to push up average yields, which are now approaching 6 tonnes/ha, compared with 4.4 tonnes/ha in the late 1990s.
The 2018/19 the world supply outlook currently appears fairly comfortable. Farmers in the US, by far the world's biggest producer, consumer and exporter of maize, have just started harvesting a massive crop, while good results are also in prospect in Ukraine, Brazil, Argentina, Canada, China and India. With gains in the major exporters counteracting a smaller outturn in the EU, Russia and South Africa, the 2018/19 global crop is forecast to increase by 2.5% year on year, to 1,062m tonnes, the second-largest on record. The outlook for 2019/20 remains highly provisional at this stage. However, assuming a rise in US sowings and potentially even bigger crops in South America, global output could tick higher, to around 1,064m tonnes, marking a rise of 0.2% year on year.
US output is seen increasing by 1.5% in 2018/19
Despite early planting delays across the Midwest US maize crops developed quickly during the key summer months, speeded up by periods of mostly warm and wet weather. Harvesting has started quickly too, advancing to 39% complete as at October 15th, four percentage points ahead of the five-year average. Unusually heavy rains at the beginning of the month caused some localised flooding in some states, but damage is expected to have been fairly minimal. Early results from the harvest have been slightly disappointing but are expected to improve sharply during the coming weeks. Indeed, the latest survey-based analysis from the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) suggests that record yields are now expected in many of the largest producing states, including Illinois, Iowa, Nebraska, Indiana and Ohio.
With excellent productivity more than offsetting this season's drop in area, 2018/19 production is forecast to be up by 1.5% compared with the previous year, at 376.6m tonnes, 6.1m tonnes above our previous forecast. Large supplies are expected to filter through into export channels, with marketing-year shipments (September-August) seen little changed year on year at around 62m tonnes, equivalent to just under 40% of the world total.
Looking ahead to 2019/20, deepening concerns about the US-China trade war could result in a shift in Midwest acreage away from soybeans into maize. Projecting yields is becoming more difficult, since productivity growth in the past two seasons has been unusually strong, surpassing long-term linear trends even with less than perfect weather. Assuming a 4% increase in sowings and with yields down slightly from this season's record, production could potentially reach 374m tonnes, down by 0.7% year on year.
Early 2018/19 crop prospects are favourable in Brazil
Planting of Brazil's first maize crop, sown mostly in the south of the country and used predominantly for feeding local livestock, has started quickly, seen complete on 33% of intended area as at the end of September. Early conditions have also been quite favourable, with ample soil moisture reported in most areas. Assuming producers expand soybean plantings in central and western parts, there could be large areas of farmland primed for sowing the second (safrinha) maize crop after the oilseeds are collected in the early part of 2019. Given a quick start to soybean planting this season, there is some cautious optimism that oilseeds might be harvested quickly, thereby allowing for an early start to safrinha maize fieldwork, which could support yields. We expect total sowings to increase by at least 4% in 2018/19, which, based on normal yield levels, could see production rebounding to around 94m tonnes (from 81.4m tonnes in the previous year). If prices remain attractive, a further increase, to around 97m tonnes, is possible in the next season.
Emergency taxes on primary exports will be imposed in Argentina
After assuming office in December 2015 the Argentinean president, Mauricio Macri, moved quickly to abolish export taxes on wheat and maize and introduce a series of gradual cuts for soybeans and products. The move was welcomed by farmers and contributed to a renewed willingness to incorporate maize and wheat back into crop rotations, which had been increasingly dominated by soybeans. However, with the government seeking additional income streams as part of efforts to improve the fiscal situation ahead of a new funding deal with the IMF, and with traders deemed to have benefited from a massive slump in the value of the peso in recent months, the president has opted to introduce emergency taxes on commodity exports. Effective until the end of December 2020, maize exports will be subject to a levy of 4 pesos per US dollar exported, currently equivalent to a tax of 10.5%. The announcement coincided with the start of the 2018/19 sowing season. With interest rates also climbing sharply in recent weeks, potentially raising financing costs for input-intensive maize crops, there are now considerable doubts about maize/soybean cropping mixes for the season ahead. For now we maintain our expectation of a modest increase in area, which could support production of around 41m tonnes, a rise of almost 30%. However, with so much uncertainty, this figure could be subject to revision in the months ahead.
A larger than average harvest is predicted in Ukraine
After earlier dryness, the weather in July and August across much of Ukraine was much more favourable for 2018/19 maize crops, boosting yields. Harvesting has now started in all regions, with very good results reported so far. Production is forecast at 30m tonnes, up by 24% from the season before and potentially enough for exports of 23m tonnes, possibly the highest on record. Overseas demand is expected to be very strong in the year ahead, especially from buyers in the EU and China.
Our 2018/19 production forecast for Russia, where maize has become an increasingly important export crop in recent years, is cut by a further 1m tonnes, to 11.6m tonnes, with the risks still skewed to the downside. Farmers had been expected to sow even more maize this season, but difficult weather conditions have prompted many to turn instead to oilseeds, planting additional acreage to sunflowerseed, rapeseed and soybeans. Hot weather in key growing regions has also had an adverse effect on yield potential.

Stocks and prices
With the authorities in China keen to reduce burdensome stockpiles, overall supplies have tightened, and global stocks are projected to decline in both 2018/19 and 2019/20. We expect global stocks to ease back to 278m tonnes by end-2018/19, down by 10% compared with the previous year. As China remains only a small player on the world stage, importing less than 4m tonnes in a typical year and exporting only limited amounts to North Korea, it is helpful to exclude notional estimates of Chinese inventories (no official data are published) in an analysis of world stocks. Because of overall strong export demand, cumulative inventories in the major suppliers (Argentina, Brazil, Ukraine and US) are forecast to tighten to 60.9m tonnes at end-2018/19, which would imply a decrease of 8% year on year, potentially the lowest level since 2015/16. Owing to reports of larger than previously estimated US stockpiles, our forecast is boosted by 4.5m tonnes from last month. A similar trend is projected in 2019/20. Led by further drawdowns in China, world stocks could shrink to around 235m tonnes, including 58.7m tonnes in the top exporters.
Using year-end stockpiles as a gauge for measuring market supplies is the most widely used tool for evaluating the size of surpluses or deficits in a particular year. Leaving aside difficulties with definition and whether stocks can actually be accurately judged at any one particular point in the season, the differences in marketing years between the biggest producers mean that any efforts to assess cumulative stocks are subject to even more uncertainties. For example, with South American stocks typically at their lowest in February and those in the US at their lowest in August, any analysis of combined stocks is inherently flawed, since inventories are never as low (or as high) as suggested by just adding together stocks in individual countries.
A relatively comfortable outlook for US supplies
The US is one of the few major grain economies to actively survey its producers and commercial facilities for stocks, publishing the results on a quarterly basis. The latest report, which details stocks as at the end of August 2018 and which therefore correspond to the end of the 2017/18 marketing year, showed inventories at 54.37m tonnes (-7% year on year), including 15.75m tonnes on farms (-21%) and 38.62m tonnes (+1%) in commercial storage facilities. The estimate was significantly higher than pre-report expectations, signalling weaker than expected feed demand in the last three months of the marketing year. However, with record livestock numbers during this time, there was speculation that the larger stock numbers were instead probably linked to an understated 2017/18 production estimate. The larger carry-in boosts this season's supply figure, and incorporating this month's uprated crop number, the 2018/19 carry-out forecast is raised by 4.3m tonnes to 48.5m tonnes. Supplies at this level would be significantly larger than assumed just a few months ago, easily big enough to cover rising demand from local and foreign users. Initial projections for 2019/20 are for a modest tightening in stocks, potentially down to around 46.7m tonnes, which would be broadly in line with the recent average.

Average prices are above year-ago levels
Despite occasional price volatility in recent months, global maize markets have generally trended lower since late August. Price weakness has been tied to the confirmation of another bumper US crop, as record yields more than compensated for a pullback in spring plantings. Traders have been eager to secure outlets on the export market, with US supplies continuing to fill the lion's share of global demand. While this has provided some light underpinning to prices, quotations continued to work lower in September, dropping by an average of 3% compared with the month before. US maize has now established itself as the cheapest feedgrain on the world market, undercutting prices of feed-grade wheat out of the Black Sea region, as well as barley and sorghum. Despite the recent declines, average prices are still around 7% higher compared with year-ago levels.
Mainly because of recent changes to the US supply outlook, world availabilities are looking much more comfortable than just a few months ago. While we still expect prices to bounce higher from current levels, especially if, as expected, the US-China trade war has little impact on US maize exports, our price forecast profile has been pared back further this month. Background expectations for an increase in 2019/20 US plantings have also dampened our price outlook. US prices (fob Gulf) are now seen as averaging US$173/tonne in 2018, compared with an average of US$195/ tonne in the five-year period ending 2017. Price growth is likely to moderate over the forecast period, with growth of 3.4% per year on average during 2019-20.

Palm oil
Demand
Trends in palm oil consumption in the 2017/18 season have been mixed, with demand growth estimated at 5.1% year on year over the season. While consumption in the major importing countries generally did not live up to early-season expectations, major producers continued to drive much of the demand growth through increases in domestic consumption. The changes to The Economist Intelligence Unit's consumption estimates continue to reflect this shift. Our estimate of 2017/18 palm oil consumption has been mainly revised up to reflect higher consumption in Indonesia and Malaysia. The energy sector offers the best prospects for growth in 2018/19, although the relative shortage of soybean and rapeseed oils also provides opportunities for extra palm oil consumption. We expect consumption growth to accelerate slightly in 2018/19, to 5.4%, and to moderate slightly in the following season to 4.1%.
India will remain the largest market for palm oil
In India, estimates for palm oil demand have been below expectation throughout 2017/18. At 9.1m tonnes, these estimates reflect a decline of 2.6%, similar to the levels recorded in both 2014/15 and 2015/16. Although this season's reduction is in part accounted for by the imposition of higher import duties, it also points to a more fundamental shift in demand away from palm oil to other vegetable oils. Using free-trade agreements to import palm oil via Bangladesh and other countries has the potential to undermine the new import tariff levels, although the government is taking steps to limit this trade. In any event, the expected reduced availability of soybean and rapeseed oils in 2018/19 will encourage Indian consumption of palm oil when demand is expected to rebound by almost 5%, approaching 9.6m tonnes. However, given the experience of 2017/18, this forecast may yet turn out to be too optimistic. Further we expect demand to remain subdued in 2019/20 and only grow marginally by 0.5%
Indonesia's biodiesel sector will post solid growth in 2018-19
Indonesian biodiesel production continues to run well ahead of expectations, reflecting the increased competiveness of palm oil as a feedstock following a build-up of local stocks. Improving biodiesel exports, notably to China and the EU, and greater offtake in the domestic market have both contributed to estimated growth of 14.8% in the 2017/18 season. There is plenty of spare production capacity in Indonesia, and the authorities plan to increase the domestic incorporation further. From September 2018 all diesel engines are required to run on B20 biodiesel. There is a wide divergence between forecasts of consumption in 2018/19 (from approximately 11m tonnes to more than 12.5m tonnes). We have adopted a forecast of 11.8m tonnes, reflecting robust year-on-year growth of 11.7%. Indonesia is also trying to secure palm-based biodiesel facilities overseas by linking its purchase of Boeing and Airbus aircraft with the establishment of biodiesel production facilities using palm oil in the US and the EU, which we expect to contribute to further demand growth of 8.5% in 2019/20.
China's palm oil demand is hindered by soybean competition
In China, palm oil continues to face strong competition from other oils, but falling palm oil prices and a modest recovery in the instant noodles sector have improved the outlook. We have made a small reduction in our estimate of 2017/18 palm oil consumption but still estimate growth 6.1%. While the 2017/18 consumption level has ended four consecutive years of decline, this growth level has failed to live up to early-season optimism. The bilateral trade war between the US and China presents an upside risk to palm oil demand; however, there are few indications to date of any increase in Chinese imports of palm oil as a result of this. At the moment we are forecasting only a modest growth of 3.6% in 2018/19. While it had been hoped that the domestic biodiesel industry would import significant quantities of palm oil to process, it now seems that imports of biodiesel are the more likely route to meet China's bio-energy requirements. Future growth will rely on a continued recovery in the edible sector, and we expect demand growth to be sustained at a pace of 3.5% in 2019/20.
Energy demand in the EU will rise, boosting usage
In the EU, palm oil has become a more attractive feedstock for energy production compared with other oils. This is encouraging growth in palm oil imports and consumption, despite increased competition from imported biodiesel. Consequently we estimate demand growth of 1.3% in 2017/18. The pace of growth is expected to accelerate to 2.2% on average per year into the 2018/19-2019/20 seasons. While the long-term future of palm oil in the EU is clouded by legislative issues, we now expect slightly higher demand growth throughout the forecast period, reflecting growing energy use and stable consumption in the food sector. The 2018/19 season is likely to see above-normal consumption growth, reflecting the local shortfall in expected rapeseed oil for biodiesel production.
Biodiesel consumption in Malaysia is set to rise
While the commitment to local consumption of biodiesel in Malaysia has been less strong than in Indonesia, solid exports of biodiesel have provided a boost to the sector. Domestic demand for B7 biodiesel has also contributed to an improved outlook. Our estimate of 2017/18 palm oil consumption has been raised again and now stands at 3.2m tonnes, marking robust growth of 17.5% during the season. A continuation of this growth is expected in 2018/19, supported in part by the expected implementation of the much-delayed B10 incorporation mandate. Our forecasts for palm oil consumption in 2018/19 and 2019/20 have both been increased to reflect the improving outlook, and we expect growth of 6.6% on average per year during the forecast period.

Consumption prospects in other countries are broadly positive
The geographical markets for palm oil are diverse, with the top five consumers accounting for less than 55% of global consumption. With palm oil continuing to improve its competitive position vis-à-vis other oils, these "other" markets have been active buyers of palm oil. Our estimates of consumption by these other consumers over the forecast period have been increased, and we expect them to sustain demand growth of 4.2% per year over the forecast period, similar to our estimate for 2017/18.
Supply
In 2017/18 we estimate output to diverge from expectations in the main two propducers, Malaysia and Indonesia. While output is expected to exceed expectations in Indonesia, it is likely to be below expectations in Malaysia, dampening our global supply outlook. Overall, we have raised our forecast of global growth in 2017/18 palm oil output only marginally and now expect growth of 5.4% year on year. The fact that the estimated overall growth rates is only just above average is mildly surprising, given the strong growth in output in 2016/17. Slowing growth in global production is likely to be a feature of the next two seasons. Despite the slowdown, output is forecast to expand by 3.7% in the 2018/19 season and by a further 1.2% in the following year. The deccelerating trend chiefly reflects the slow expansion in mature area and only sluggish yield growth.
Yield cycle may offset favourable growing conditions
Indonesian production of palm oil continues to exceed expectations and is now estimated to expand by 4.5% year on year in 2017/18. Our estimates of output in 2016/17 and 2017/18 are both increased to reflect upward revisions to estimates of the mature palm area. It now looks likely that 2017/18 production will reach 38.6m tonnes, with risks mainly to the upside. While the growth rate is below recent levels, it is building on particularly rapid growth of 17.2% in 2016/17. We continue to expect good yields over the next 6-9 months, although there are early signs that the rate of growth in yields is slowing. Indeed, slow yield growth has been a persistent feature of Indonesian production. Despite the slowdown in plantings, the mature area for next season will be higher. A modest yield increase would result in palm oil production of just over 40m tonnes, leading to growth of 4.5% in 2018/19. Output is likely to moderate in the next season, and we expect output to expand by 1.3% in 2019/20.
Malaysian output continues to disappoint
In Malaysia, output has resumed its normal seasonal increase, but output levels in June and July were almost 20% below those recorded over the same period in 2016/17. Recent output has been closer to year-ago levels. August production was only 10% below last season's level, and it is estimated that September production will be more or less in line with last year's total. We have again revised down our estimate for 2017/18 production, to 19.7m tonnes, representing growth of 4.6% year on year. The 2018/19 season should see an increase in average yields, although any improvements will be inhibited by an ageing tree population. We have adopted a relatively cautious production forecast of 20.4m tonnes in 2018/19, only 3% higher than in 2017/18. We expect output to moderate significantly in the 2019/20 season, when it is forecast to grow by a measly 0.2%.

Thailand output exceeds expectations
There has been a recent slowdown in yield growth in both Thailand and Colombia. The increase in yields in Thailand during 2017/18 has been especially strong, reflecting good weather and favourable oil extraction rates. While our estimate for 2017/18 is little changed, we expect a reduction in output in 2018/19 as tree stress and the probable use of lower inputs reduce yields. In Colombia, we have marginally reduced both our estimate of output in 2017/18 and our production forecast for 2018/19. There remains potential for further land for palm oil cultivation without any deforestation issues. Recent yields have been well above year-earlier levels but should revert to more normal levels in 2018/19 and 2019/20. Some other, smaller palm oil-producing countries, such as Honduras, will also see solid output growth in 2017/18.
Stocks and prices
Seasonal increases in palm oil production underpin continuing increases in stocks in both Indonesia and Malaysia. By contrast, stock levels in importing countries are at, or slightly below, normal levels. Overall, 2017/18 continues to show a market surplus, albeit a smaller one than previously forecast. At the end of the season stocks will be equivalent to 64 days of consumption. This is lower than in 2014/15 but still above normal levels. We expect stock levels to peak in 2018/19 before reverting to more normal levels of around 60 days of consumption in the 2019/20 season.

Rising stock levels will push prices down further
Physical palm oil prices continued to weaken in September. However, they were the most resilient of the major vegetable oils, recording only a very small decrease. Futures prices also eased during the month. We continue to expect global palm oil prices to drift lower during the rest of 2018 and into 2019, given the likely persistent build-up of palm oil stocks. Current projections suggest that prices will reach a trough in mid2019 at around US$560/tonne before starting to increase during the 2019/20 season. The price increases could set in earlier if some of the more bullish consumption forecasts are realised.

Rapeseed oil
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that global rapeseed oil demand contracted by 3.7% for the third consecutive year in 2017/18 to its lowest level since 2012/13, despite upward revisions to consumption estimates for the EU, China and India. Rapeseed oil continues to lose price competitiveness against the other major oils, and our forecasts for consumption in 2018/19-2019/20 remain tentative despite some improvement in the production outlook. We expect demand to grow marginally by an average of 0.9% per year during the forecast period.
EU consumption is threatened by biodiesel imports
Despite strong competition from recycled cooking oil and imported biodiesel, demand from the EU biodiesel sector has helped total consumption in 2017/18 to expand by 0.7% year on year. However, the reduction in local availability will inhibit any consumption gains during 2018/19, causing demand to contract by 1.5% in the region as whole during that season. The decline in local availabilities will lead to significant imports of rapeseed for local crushing or rapeseed oil. So far there has been an active import market in rapeseed from the Ukraine, but other sources will be needed to make good the local shortfall and realise this consumption forecast. Following this, we expect demand to rebound in the 2019/20 season by 0.9% year on year, but the pace will be insufficient to achieve the levels seen in 2017/18.
Chinese consumption is limited by supply constraints
In China, local rapeseed oil availability is limited, despite recent improvements in local crushing of imported rapeseed. In 2017/18 we expect demand to decline significantly by 14.4% year on year, but consumption of 4.8m tonnes looks likely to be achieved following active rapeseed oil imports. Higher local estimates of rapeseed production in 2018/19 should help to boost consumption, pushing demand growth to 8% in that year. However, competition for imported rapeseed for local crushing as well as for imported rapeseed oil is likely to be intense. At this stage we project 2018/19 rapeseed oil consumption at just over 5.2m tonnes; given the competition for available supplies, this total may turn out to be too optimistic. In 2019/20 we expect demand growth to moderate to a slower pace of 2.2%
India's consumption will contract over the forecast period
In India, 2017/18 rapeseed oil consumption is expected to grow by a robust 19.4% year on year, driven by improved local availability and strong GDP growth. Rapeseed oil is the preferred oil in north and central India. Local production is typically absorbed along with a small but increasing volume of imports. However, import volumes are being inhibited by high import duties. An improving domestic production outlook means that 2018/19 consumption will at least match the level achieved in 2017/18. Demand is likely to contract over the forecast period, but even though consumption is expected to decline by 4.1% in 2019/20, this level would be still high by historical standards owing to the robust growth witnessed in 2017/18.
Only modest demand growth is likely in the US market
In the US, rapeseed oil has been losing out to cheaper soybean oil over recent years. This pattern continued into 2017/18, when we estimate that rapeseed oil demand declined by 4.1%. This was followed by only marginal growth of 2.5% year on year in 2018/19. In 2019/20 we forecast growth of 4.3%.
After switching away from rapeseed oil in 2016/17, several smaller consumers have recently returned to the market. However, growth in rapeseed oil consumption among this "other" consumers category during 2017/18 has been constrained by more competitive sunflowerseed oil.

Supply
We estimate that in 2017/18 rapeseed oil output remained at 25.6m tonnes, 2.2% higher than in the 2016/17 season. However, prospects for global rapeseed production in 2018/19 have been adversely affected by dry conditions in the EU, Canada and Australia. While estimates for both the EU and Australia continue to be revised downwards, they are being offset by higher numbers for Canada and India. In 2018/19 we expect global output to contract marginally by 0.4% owing to a significant decline in EU output. This decline will be partially offset by buoyant production in other countries, such as China and India. Global production will rebound in the 2019/20 season on the back of strong output growth in the EU, by 1.4% year on year.
Rapeseed oil production in the EU is estimated to have declined marginally for the third consecutive season in 2017/18. We expect this trend to continue into the next season, when production is forecast to contract more significantly, by 5.8% year on year, as a result of the hot and dry summer. We continue to use the European Commission's estimates for a rapeseed harvest of only 19.2m tonnes, making this the smallest crop since 2008/09. The area was virtually unchanged, so the reduction is almost entirely attributable to poor yields, and the decline in output was seen across all the major producing countries within the EU. Even allowing for high carry-in stocks and higher rapeseed imports, 2018/19 rapeseed oil production will be affected by the low seed production level. For the moment we have retained our forecast of EU rapeseed oil output of 9.5m tonnes. A higher output level will depend on very high import levels, which will in turn depend on canola output in Canada and Australia. In 2019/20 we expect production to rebound by a robust 8.3%, rising for the first time in five years.
China will rely on imports for oil production
Chinese rapeseed oil production is becoming increasingly dependent on imported seed supplies, and we estimate that output grew by 2.4% in 2017/18 to 3.7m tonnes. Forecasts of the size of the 2018/19 Chinese rapeseed crop vary considerably. Tight rapeseed stocks are partly a reflection of a reduced estimate of the size of the 2017/18 crop, and our forecast for the 2018/19 harvest remains tentative for now. We have reduced our estimate of the crop size, although for the moment we have retained our forecast of 2018/19 rapeseed oil output growth of 6% year on year. This forecast relies on record imports of rapeseed and may turn out to be optimistic. Demand for rapeseed meal is reported to be strong, reflecting the impact of tariffs on US soybean imports. This in turn is providing good crush margins and should give Chinese crushers an edge in obtaining international rapeseed supplies. In 2019/20 we expect rapeseed oil production to decline by 8.3%.
Canada's 2017/18 harvest will rise
A strong export market for canola has underpinned record Canadian canola oil production in 2017/18, which is estimated to be up by 4.5% year on year. Statistics Canada has updated its estimate of the 2018/19 canola crop, which at 21m tonnes is more in line with trade estimates (up from 19.2m tonnes previously). Canadian canola oil production is typically more dependent on market developments than on the availability of seed for crushing. The larger crop will help Canadian crushers to obtain sufficient supplies in the face of strong competition from China and the EU. At the moment we maintain that canola oil production will grow by almost 2% in 2018/19, before accelerating by 7.7% in 2019/20.

India's production is set to grow owing to higher rapeseed imports
In India, our estimate of 2017/18 rapeseed oil production remains at a record 2.5m tonnes, growing by almost 22% year on year. There is increased optimism for the 2018/19 crop, in part reflecting the government's actions to boost production (measures include higher vegetable import tariffs and increased minimum support prices). Local rapeseed prices are higher, and local estimates suggest that the 2018/19 crop could be as high as 7m tonnes. While monsoon rainfall has been below average, early sowings are taking place under good conditions. If realised, this crop would allow 2018/19 rapeseed oil production to grow by a further 4.3. India has been urging China to lift its ban on Indian rapeseed meal imports in light of the US-China bilateral trade war. Indian imports were banned in 2011 amid quality concerns; we expect the ban to be lifted during the forecast period, providing a further boost to Indian rapeseed crushing. In 2019/20 we expect rapeseed oil production to decline by over 10%.
Australian production could be constrained by dry conditions
The 2018/19 Australian canola crop has been further impacted by drought conditions. Estimates have been reduced, and the most recent official estimate puts the crop at just 2.8m tonnes, the smallest crop since 2010/11. An early and plentiful 2018/19 rapeseed harvest in Ukraine has resulted in an active export market. The harvest estimate remains at 2.7m tonnes. Rapeseed is reportedly the most profitable of the oilseed crops in Ukraine, and further expansion of the area planted to rapeseed is expected.
Stocks and prices
The small market surplus in 2017/18 has allowed a modest recovery in rapeseed oil stocks. At the equivalent of 18 days consumption, stocks are still at the low end of recent years. Rapeseed stocks also show a modest increase but remain below normal levels. With a slightly better outlook for production than before during 2018/19, we now expect the rapeseed oil market to remain largely in balance during that year. However, rapeseed stocks are forecast to continue to fall, which may mean that the production outlook will not reach the forecast level, tipping the market back into deficit. Early projections suggest a slight easing of the stock position for rapeseed oil during 2019/20, but this would only be achieved at at the expense of even lower rapeseed stocks. For now we expect a modest surplus in 2019/20, pushing up stocks to the equivalent of 18 days of consumption.

Concern over production leads to firmer prices
Rapeseed oil prices eased in September in line with the weakness in the edible oil market. Rapeseed oil continues to trade at a high premium relative to other major vegetable oils. Futures prices for rapeseed ended the month virtually unchanged in Canada but were firmer in Europe. We are still expecting rapeseed oil prices to remain firm during the 2018/19 season, although the increases are not likely to be as large as previously expected. Prices are forecast to approach US$900/tonne by the third quarter of 2019 before easing back in the 2019/20 season. In 2020 we expect prices to largely remain range-bound, will little fluctuation from the 2019 year-end price.

Rice
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that global rice consumption expanded by 1.4% year on year in 2018/19, to a record 500m tonnes. As usual, the increase is largely driven by Asian countries-with the notable exception of China, where domestic demand is estimated to have edged lower. Latin America and Africa have also contributed to rising global consumption. Prospects for the following season remain tentative, especially since we refer to an international trade year that will not commence until January 1st 2020. Nevertheless, global demand is expected to continue on an upward trajectory in 2019/20, rising by 1.1% to 506m tonnes.
Rice feed use may edge up on increased uptake in China
The use of rice in animal feed mixes could edge up in 2019-20, largely owing to developments in China, which is by far the biggest consumer. The government is looking to scale back production, and possibly imports, to avoid the potential for a further build-up of inventories. In addition, both domestic and export markets offer another way of reducing inventories. While food use could edge lower, it is likely that consumption in feed sectors may grow further as the government encourages the disposal of inventories through feed channels.
Japan has utilised stocks of imported rice in feed mixes, but data suggest that demand for domestic rice feed may have peaked. Overall, the non-food usage of rice globally (including by the industrial sector) will continue to account for only a small proportion of overall demand.
Trade should remain robust in 2019-20
Africa and Asia account for more than two-thirds of all rice imports, primarily white and parboiled grades sourced from Thailand, India, Pakistan and Vietnam. A significant share of the demand in Sub-Saharan Africa, mainly for high-quality white and parboiled supplies, is met through imports. Following record global rice purchases in 2017 of 45.7m tonnes, many Asian buyers are likely to be well stocked. Furthermore, strong demand for Thai rice from African buyers in 2017 was largely linked to availabilities of attractively priced rice from the government's stockpile. We expected global trade to increase to nearly 47m tonnes in 2018, with further modest increases expected in the following years through to 2020, reflecting strong demand from Indonesia, Bangladesh and the Philippines in the first half of the year. Nevertheless, it is worth noting that trade would still acount for less than 10% of total production or consumption-an exceptionally low share when compared to wheat (the other major food grain) or soybeans.
China's imports are likely to fall over the forecast period
China is by far the world's largest consumer of rice, accounting for almost 30% of global demand. Although locally produced rice makes up the bulk of national consumption, China is also the world's largest importer. Domestic early-season long-grain milled rice still commands hefty premiums over supplies from other major origins in Asia, owing to the easy availability of rice from major suppliers outside China. We expect China's purchases to peak at 5m tonnes in 2018 before declining slightly in the following two years. Although it remains unclear how lower state support will affect rice imports, for now we think that imports are likely to fall in future years as the government seeks to reduce inventories. Nonetheless, volumes are likely to remain substantial, given that local prices are above international values. Although we expect rice imports to fall to 4.1m tonnes by 2020, China would still be the world's biggest importer.
Bangladesh's imports set to fall in 2019-20 as local supplies improve
Bangladesh is one of the leading rice markets within Asia, with annual demand reaching at least 35m tonnes. The three domestic crops cut each year are the boro (seeded in December-January and harvested in April-May), aus (planted in March-April and cut in June-July), and aman (sown in July-August and normally threshed in November-December). Although the bulk of the country's rice needs is met by domestic crops, significant quantities are sometimes procured from the world market, especially in times of shortages. Purchases in 2018 are expected to reach 2m tonnes-more than three times their 2017 level-before falling again in 2019 and 2020 as domestic supply improves.
The Philippines is expected to remain a key buyer
Following the destruction by Thyphoon Mangkhut of over 250,000 tonnes of paddy and amid rising oil prices, which threaten to push inflation even higher, the president of the Philippines, Robert Duterte, has authorised additional rice imports. Stocks held by the National Food Authority, the grain procurement agency, have dwindled to their lowest level in about a decade. In contrast, inventories held by private households and commercial warehouses remain comfortable. Underscoring thin state reserves, imports are estimated to have risen further in 2018, to reach 1.6m tonnes, and are expected to average close to 1..5m tonnes annually in coming years as the country looks to ensure adequate domestic supplies.
Solid growth in Saudi consumption of cereals
In Saudi Arabia, consumption of cereals, including rice, has posted strong growth over the past two decades. As the preferred ingredient for inclusion in feed rations, barley accounts for more than half of aggregate domestic demand, while growth in the use of other commodities, including wheat and maize in the food and feed sector, respectively, has been particularly notable.
Rice is a staple food, with kabsah, a traditional dish, being consumed widely. In addition, significant volumes are eaten by foreign workers, chiefly from South Asia. However, demand for white rice among middle- and high-income families has fallen, reflecting a shift towards an increased uptake of protein as well as fruits and vegetables. Overall, therefore, growth in rice consumption has been relatively modest. Consumption is forecast at around 1.3m tonnes in both 2018/19 and 2019/20, little changed on the previous year, and only marginally higher than the 1.1m tonnes seen a decade ago.
Saudi Arabia's local market is one of the largest in the Middle East
Nevertheless, the domestic rice market in Saudi Arabia remains one the largest in the Middle East-comparable in size to Iraq and second only to Iran. As climate conditions do not allow for domestic rice cultivation, local market needs are met entirely through imports, which are typically of a very high quality and consist mainly of fragrant-especially basmati-varieties. The origins of the nation's international rice purchases have changed little over the years, with South Asian exporters the most important suppliers. Purchases from India and Pakistan are predominantly of basmati varieties, with relatively smaller quantities of high-quality white and parboiled types secured from a range of origins, including Thailand, Vietnam, the US, China and Australia.

Supply
Following some slight revisions to our previous estimates, we now expect global rice production to fall marginally in 2018/19, to 493m tonnes, pending harvest outcomes in Asia's main producers, primarily India, where the monsoon season began on June 1st. All of our scenarios assume continued state support for farmers in Asia, although seeding in China is set to fall as the authorities seek to reduce production-and possibly imports-to draw down excess inventories. In 2019/20, however, we tentatively expect production to rise by around 1.5% to a record 500m tonnes, as bigger crops in some parts of Asia, including India, compensate for falling output in China.
In any year, global prospects are to a large degree shaped by India's main summer-sown (kharif) crop, which is crucial in terms of domestic supplies and the surplus available for export. Planting was completed in the previous month, with government data placing the area at 38.6m ha as of September 20th, up from a year earlier and slightly above normal. To a large degree, the increase in acreage is attributable to the government's lifting of minimum support prices for the 2018/19 kharif season. However, there have been concerns about prospects, mostly in relation to yields, because of a disappointing monsoon, which is crucial to providing as much as 70% of the nation's annual rainfall.
Despite a disappinting monsoon, rice output could reach 2017/18 levels
However, in its most recent assessment of prospects for this season's summer (kharif) crop, the Department of Agriculture, Co-operation and Farmers Welfare forecast production of kharif rice (milled weight) at 99.2m tonnes, up from 97.5m tonnes in the previous year. This was above the government's pre-season target of 98m tonnes, with the target for the much smaller winter (rabi) harvest at 15m tonnes in line with last season's result. Given these figures, our forecast of total production (kharif and rabi crops) remains unchanged at 113m tonnes-almost the same as in the 2017/18 season owing to an official upward revision. It is almost impossible to make any meaningful assessment of the outlook for production in 2019/20 because this depends on a number of factors, including monsoon rains and prevailing farmer support.
India will remain the leading rice exporter throughout the forecast period
India has been the world's largest exporter of rice since 2011. Volumes have been shaped by demand for high-value basmati varieties from buyers in Europe and the Middle East, as well as shipments of low-quality white and parboiled rice primarily to markets in Africa and Asia. In 2017 India exported a record 12.5m tonnes to world markets, up by nearly 30% year on year owing to substantially bigger sales in Africa and Asia, and especially to buyers in South Asia amid domestic shortfalls. For 2018 the pace of the nation's shipments has matched that of the previous year, and we expect the full-year total to match the 2017 record of 12.5m tonnes. In the following two seasons exports are predicted to remain high as India further entrenches its position as the dominant supplier of white and parboiled rice to global markets.
Drought conditions in Pakistan harm rice production prospects
The rice crop outlook in Pakistan remains uncertain owing to water shortages in the main producing areas, following persistent below-average rainfall since the end of 2017. Water availability in the main reservoirs is estimated to be more than 50% below average, constraining planting operations.
A reduced crop will tighten exportable supplies
Rice sowings usually commence in late May and early June in southern areas of the country, while cultivation in northern areas usually takes place in late July. However, in the current season fieldwork has been behind schedule by as much as 45 days. Some growers will therefore seed much less than anticipated, and yield potential could be significantly down. While the situation may have improved owing to increased monsoon rains, we now expect output in 2018/19 to fall by 2.8% year on year to 6.8m tonnes, from 7m tonnes previously. This will have a knock-on impact on export volumes, given that around half of the crop is typically exported. We project that a crop of 6.8m tonnes would support exports of 3.8m tonnes in 2019, down from 4.1m tonnes in the preceding season. In the following year shipments are likely to edge up again as better crops are harvested.
The Chinese government is keen to reduce inventory levels
Following a fall of 4m tonnes (year on year) in 2018/19, rice production in China is likely to drop further in 2019/20, to an eight-year low of 141m tonnes because of acreage reductions. The Chinese government aims to reduce rice acreage by around 2% in 2018/19 by scaling back low-quality rice production. Ultimately, this is meant to address the significant structural imbalance between domestic supply and demand. In late April the Communist Party leadership of Hunan Province stated that it aimed to reduce plantings by 200,000 ha in the province during the current year, shifting land to high-value specialty rice crops. This development is significant, since state policy had previously been geared towards stabilising or increasing paddy (rice) output. Acreage has changed little over the years, so a fall of 2% would represent the first significant decline since 2003/04. Furthermore, the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) outlined lower minimum purchasing prices in early 2018 across all types of rice, with falls of between 8% and 11% noted. This is important, because it represents the second consecutive annual cut in farmer support and suggests that the government is aware that supply and demand must be rebalanced owing to burdensome inventories.
The government has also announced a reform of its minimum price support scheme for rice. This year's programme sets stricter conditions for activating minimum price procurement, which can only take place when the market price has remained below the minimum set price for three consecutive days. The scheme must be suspended once the market price exceeds the minimum support price for another three days. This latest policy shift illustrates further the administration's eagerness to reshape the rice sector by introducing market-based conditions under which rice will be procured from farmers. As with efforts to reduce the production of low-quality indica rice, this underlines the government's awareness that domestic stock levels are unsustainably high.
Exports offer a convenient way for China to reduce stocks
Procurement of early indica rice runs from August 1st-September 30th, while middle and late indica rice procurement runs from October 10th until January 31st. Japonica rice procurement commences on November 1st and must close by the end of February. China's exports of rice have traditionally been nominal and shaped by sales of japonica varieties, including to Japan and South Korea, for example. However, there was a big shift in 2017, with shipments rising sharply, largely owing to sales of indica rice to African nations. These included particularly substantial deliveries to Côte d'Ivoire, Liberia, Mozambique, Senegal and Sierra Leone. Prospects for exports are somewhat uncertain at this stage. Nevertheless, the export market offers a viable way of reducing state reserves during the next two years. We anticipate shipments to African nations to remain significant as total exports range between 1m tonnes and 2m tonnes.
Thailand's main crop prospects boosted by good rainfall
Prospects for rice production in Thailand in 2018/19 were boosted by above-average precipitation in the first half of 2018, and the national meteorological office expects rainfall to remain above average thoughout the crop's main reproductive stage to end-October. Owing to expanded acreage amid high farm-gate prices for fragrant paddy and with yields expected to be better than in the previous season, total rice output in 2018/19 is expected to expand by 1m tonnes (5%) to 21.5m tonnes. This includes an assumption of increased secondary (off-season) plantings.
Thailand's exports of all varieties of rice amounted to 11.6m tonnes in 2017-easily its highest total and up from 9.9m tonnes the year before. The strong increase was mainly attributable to a large expansion of shipments to markets in Africa, with a portion almost certainly consisting of older intervention reserves from the government's long-held stockpile. Since the government is reported to have sold off food-quality stocks from past harvests last year, exporters will have no access to significant quantities of attractively priced inventories that can be sold to buyers in Africa and other regions. We expect export volumes to fall to 10.6m tonnes in 2018, largely owing to lower volumes going to African countries and China. Although sales could trend up slightly in 2019-20, they will remain well behind India's volumes.
The US crop will rebound strongly, with exports also expanding
In the US, harvesting of the 2018/19 rice crop was estimated to be complete on 70% of intended area by the end of September. This represented a modest year-on-year fall, mainly owing to a slower pace of fieldwork in Arkansas, although it was still ahead of the average for this stage in the season. In its latest assessment of prospects, the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) forecast an almost 25% year-on-year expansion of milled rice production to 7m tonnes, driven by a big increase in long-grain acreage and a slight rise in yields. After a year in which exports fell significantly, the bigger outturn is expected to boost the US exportable surplus, with shipments in 2018/19 (August/July) officially predicted to expand by 13% from the year before. Weekly export sales data show that cumulative exports (product weight basis) amounted to about 388,000 tonnes, up from 356,000 tonnes a year earlier. In 2019/20 a further increase in production is anticipated, with exports also seen edging higher.
Rice production puts pressure on Egyptian water supplies
Egypt has traditionally been a relatively small but important rice-producing country. Although the bulk of its crop is channelled to the local market, it has also been a modest exporter of medium-grain varieties to global markets, competing with nations such as the US and Australia. The government has for a number of years been using restrictions on exports to ensure availabilities for local consumption. It is now seeking to reduce the cultivation of water-intensive crops, including rice. According to reports, 1,400 litres of water are used in the production of 1 kg of rice, with agriculture accounting for an estimated 80% of Egypt's total water resources. The Ministry of Water Resources and Irrigation has announced a reduction of more than 30% year on year in the approved rice area in 2018/19, to 304,080 ha. According to local reports, this is because farmers have grown more rice than the government's allotted total during the previous year. In addition, growers have faced financial penalties for exceeding the official area target.
Large-scale imports could feature in the longer term
Given that rice cultivation in Egypt is attractive for farmers, it seems possible that growers could again boost plantings above the allotted target. Nevertheless, we still anticipate a fall in output in 2018/19 of about 1m tonnes, to 3.3m tonnes, the lowest in eight seasons. Although local demand has been falling in recent years as the population increasingly turns to alternative, cheaper forms of carbohydrates, such as pasta, imports of rice are likely to rise to 300,000 tonnes, but this is still small in terms of the overall supply-and-demand balance sheet. However, the Egyptian prime minister, Sherif Ismail, has announced that the country would import rice so as to increase stocks and control the market. While no timeframe was provided, the statement could be significant, potentially signalling a switch to large-scale imports as production continues to fall. Some traders and analysts have suggested that purchases from the world market could end up totalling as much as 1m tonnes/year. Exports are expected to remain officially banned in 2018-19. However, modest amounts-around 50,000 tonnes per year-are expected to find their way on to international market, as has been the case in recent years during times of restrictions.

Australia's production is set to fall sharply in 2018/19
Australia is a relatively tiny producer of rice, with annual production of milled rice averaging less than 500,000 tonnes in the past five seasons. Nevertheless, the country's position in the medium-grain sector, which accounts for the bulk of cultivation, is important. Although output can vary significantly from one season to the next owing to the impact of weather, a good crop will typically depend on yields, which are among the highest in the world. Compared with global average productivity of around 3 tonnes/ha, Australian farmers usually record yields of more than 7 tonnes/ha. The 2018/19 crop will be grown during the Australian summer period, entirely in the state of New South Wales, with seeding beginning in the month of October, while harvesting is set to start in March and end in May.
According to a recent assessment by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics and Sciences, released in mid-September, the area planted to rice was projected to fall by 10% to 54,000 ha owing to reduced irrigation water supplies, while storage levels in the Murrumbidgee valley were estimated at 64% in early September 2018, 10 percentage points lower than at the same point in 2017. With the government assuming that yields will be in line with the average of recent seasons, production is expected to fall by 12% year on year, to 400,000 tonnes. The lion's share of the country's rice crop is usually exported, with shipments mainly heading to markets in the Middle East, Asia and Oceania, where supplies compete with other exporters of medium-grain rice, including the US and Egypt. Prospects for 2019/20 are highly provisional at this stage, since planting will not begin until October 2019, and much will depend on prevailing price trends and water availabilities at that time.
Stocks and prices
We expect global rice stocks to contract by about 7m tonnes in 2018/19 compared with the previous season. Inventories are expected to narrow in a number of markets, and there is a risk that they could fall even more if production disappoints in major exporting countries, such as India and Thailand. In China, the government is actively encouraging farmers to scale back production of low-quality rice and diversify into high-value varieties to curb the recent build-up of stocks. As these trends continue, we expect global stocks to narrow again in 2019/20, to 98m tonnes.
However, caution is advised when making judgments about stocks data; the bulk of year-end figures provided is arrived at via residual calculation, as most countries do not collect or provide meaningful figures. Furthermore, inventories in China on a milled weight tonnage-equivalent could total as much as 70m-80m tonnes. However, since no official data are published, it is likely that the actual level could differ considerably from consensus estimates. As we have previously noted, the exclusion of Chinese stocks therefore produces a more realistic figure for what is available on the world market, mostly located in the five major exporters, and specifically in India.
Asian rice markets exhibited mixed trends during the month of September and in early October. Physical markets in South-east Asian exporters, notably Thailand and Vietnam, advanced over the month amid a tightening of old crop stocks, and as signs of firmer demand from importers provided a boost to the market. This included the news that the Philippines was planning to purchase as much as 750,000 tonnes in a series of tenders for delivery in late 2018/early 2019. Iraq, too, was reported to have been an active buyer of smaller volumes from key origins. As of September 3rd the price of 100% Grade B for export (Bangkok) was typically around 1% higher month on month, at US$401/tonne fob. Similar increases were recorded for the main broken grades, as well as for parboiled rice.
In contrast, export quotations for milled varieties of rice actually fell in South Asia as sluggish near-term demand prospects weighed on sentiment. In India, this compounded pressure from the winding-up of the kharif (summer) season, with another heavy crop expected. In Pakistan, earlier support from worries about production owing to dry conditions in important areas were eventually overridden by pressure from weak demand and initial arrivals from the 2018/19 harvest. In India, early September export values for 5% broken stood at US$383/tonne fob, a drop of US$14/tonne over the month.

Outside Asia, Gulf export prices for US rice (No.2, 4% broken) were slightly lower than a month ago, with pressure largely stemming from the progressing harvest. However, with quotations typically around the US$515/tonne-mark, they were little changed from a year earlier.
We have increased our price projections slightly, reflecting the tightening supply outlook. For full-year 2018 we now expect prices for 100% Grade B to average US$405/tonne fob Bangkok, up from US$390/tonne in 2017. A further increase is likely through to the final quarter of 2020, with the full-year average value in that year at a six-year high of US$416/tonne. The outlook for prices does, however, depend on the current policy environment remaining mostly unchanged. Export restrictions in key world suppliers could lead to significantly higher prices, especially if they were introduced at a time of firm demand.

Soybeans
Demand
Global soybean consumption has expanded rapidly in recent decades, with growth outstripping that of other oilseeds and grains as increasingly large amounts are being channelled into the poultry, livestock and dairy sectors, especially in Asia. Along with their high protein content, soybeans provide an economical combination of fats and carbohydrates. Soybeans are particularly useful when fed in combination with other ingredients to pigs, providing a good source of vital amino acids, as well as being highly digestible. After ten years of uninterrupted growth, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects world demand to rise again in 2018/19, by 4.2% to a record 351.5m tonnes, despite the ongoing US-China bilateral trade war and the consequent imposition of a 25% tariff on soy imports from the US, among other items. With China importing in excess of 90m tonnes of soybeans in a typical year-one-third of which is normally sourced from the US-these tensions provide an extra layer of uncertainty to supply-and-demand forecasts for the current marketing year and beyond. Projections for 2019/20 are therefore extremely tentative. Factoring in potentially below-par expansion in China, world consumption is tentatively seen at 355.8m tonnes, up by 1.2% year on year in 2019/20.
The US-China trade war will have serious implications for soybeans
The principal driver of demand for soybeans over the past decade has been the rising use in Asia, mostly China, underpinned by the increasing uptake in that country's vast animal feed sector, as well as for aquaculture. Growth has been fuelled by a monumental rise in soybean imports since the early 1980s, rising from less than 50,000 tonnes to around 94m tonnes in 2017/18 and crushed at strategically located local plants. Overall consumption growth in China is likely to moderate in 2018/19 and 2019/20 compared with recent years, assuming that rising trade barriers cause China to limit its purchases from the world market. Given the very high soymeal content in feed rations in China, estimated by some to be around 20% for a typical pig-feed mix, there is some scope for soymeal inclusion rates to be pared back and substituted for alternative protein meals such as rapeseed meal, cottonseed meal or distillers dried grains. However, this would probably incur additional costs. With US export prices looking increasingly competitive, even accounting for the 25% import duty, we suspect that much will depend on the determination of local companies to support its government in the trade war. There is also a question mark over whether the authorities would introduce additional non-tariff measures to minimise shipments originating from the US.
African swine fever outbreaks could also affect consumption
China's massive pork industry accounts for around one-third of global consumption of soybean meal, a major feed ingredient for pigs. The recent outbreak of African swine fever in a number of Chinese provinces is therefore of huge importance for the soybean market and could have substantial implications for future demand. The authorities have moved swiftly to control the outbreak, culling thousands of animals and introducing bans on the transport of live animals and on markets in affected areas. However, new cases were being reported on an almost daily basis in early September. The effects on local feed demand are difficult to assess at this early stage, however. Despite lower imports in 2018/19 we expect higher domestic output and some destocking to support modest demand growth in 2019/20. We will keep an eye on these events and adjust our forecast accordingly.
Broad-based gains in global demand are forecast in 2018/19
Compared with Asia, soybean consumption in other regions is relatively small, although it has also risen steadily in recent years, most notably in the EU, South America and parts of Africa. The upswing is expected to continue into 2018/19. US soybean consumption in 2018/19 is estimated to reach an all-time high of 60.1m tonnes, up fractionally from the previous season, with another large crop boosting supplies for processing. In South America the outlook for consumption is much improved for 2018/19, with processing in Argentina expected to rebound strongly should production recover to more normal levels. Consumption in Brazil is forecast to rise by 2.3%, a slightly slower pace than in 2017/18, with increased regional competition and likely strong soybean export demand expected to limit the amount of soybeans sent for local processing. While South American consumption could rise further in 2019/20, a smaller crop could result in a small decline in the US.
World trade forecast to rise more slowly than in the past
We forecast that global trade in soybeans in 2018/19 (September/October basis) will reach 153m tonnes. While China's purchases may actually fall, this will be more than offset by bigger imports by other buyers. Chinese purchases of US soybeans have floundered since April as bilateral trade tensions have escalated. The impact on Chinese processors has been limited, since this period coincided with the southern hemisphere export programme. As supplies at South American origins are likely to be tighter than normal from October 2018 until new crops are threshed in early 2019, it is possible that Chinese buyers will be required to source as much as 15m tonnes from the US in 2018/19, although this is well below its purchases of around 30m tonnes per year in recent years. China's total imports are forecast to fall by 1% in 2018/19-the first fall in eight years-and are expected to remain at this level in 2019/20.

Imports are central to EU requirements
The EU has achieved successive record crops in recent seasons. Nevertheless, at less than 3m tonnes domestic outturns represent only a tiny share of overall consumption. The remainder is typically met by imports of soybeans and soybean meal, which typically account for up to 35m tonnes. After relatively strong gains in the season before, soybean imports are expected to rise by a further 8.3% in 2018/19. Import demand has strengthened, with buyers taking advantage of the heavy fall in US market prices and attempting to compensate for a series of poor rapeseed and grain harvests across the northern parts of the EU. Another season of elevated imports is expected in 2019/20, but consumption is forecast to dip from the levels recorded in 2018/19.
Supply
Following an unusually sharp decline in 2017/18 global output, tied mainly to a very difficult year of cropping weather in Argentina, we expect production to rebound sharply in 2018/19, possibly by as much as 10% year on year, to a record 369m tonnes. While a massive US crop is looking almost certain, there is still a long way to go in South America, where crop projections remain tentative and are still highly dependent on weather conditions. Our very early projections for 2019/20 suggest that US plantings could decline, with farmers perhaps switching to maize and spring wheat. Even if South American crops are larger, world production might therefore drop to 361m tonnes, down by 2% year on year.
US yields are expected to be excellent in 2018/19
US farmers have enjoyed generally favourable cropping conditions over the spring and summer. With plantings completed on time, the weather in June and July was warm and wet in many areas, setting the scene for successful pod filling in August, the key month for determining soybean yields. The mostly favourable weather continued into September, and the second objective yield survey assessment from the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) suggests that average yields will climb to a new record high, surpassing the previous record in 2016/17. According to the agency, expectations for pod weight (and yields) will benefit from this season's extended period of crop development. Incorporating this uprated yield figure, we have raised our production forecast by a further 2.9m tonnes to an unprecedented 127.7m tonnes, up by 6.9% on the previous season. Harvesting was almost one-quarter complete by 30th September, a touch faster than last year's pace and quicker than average. Given huge local stockpiles, relatively weak prices and the potential for a protracted trade war with China, there is some pessimism about prospects for 2019/20 acreage. Pencilling in a 3% drop in plantings, and should trends revert back to previous levels, production could possibly decline by 10% in 2019/20, to 115m tonnes.
US farmers will be compensated for ongoing trade disputes
On September 4th the USDA formally launched a US$12bn aid package aimed at assisting local farmers hit by current international trade disputes. The flagship Market Facilitation Programme will provide payments to eligible producers of soybeans, wheat, maize, sorghum, cotton, dairy and pigs. Payments will be made on 50% of actual 2018/19 production volumes, with soybean growers eligible for a payment of US$1.65/bushel, up to a maximum of US$125,000 per farm. Additionally, a Trade Promotion Programme will assist in developing new export markets, while a Food Purchase and Distribution Programme will purchase surpluses of certain affected commodities for distribution through nutrition assistance programmes. While the payments were well received in certain quarters, most farm groups have reiterated their desire for a resolution to the trade disputes with major US trade partners and called for a more permanent solution.
Brazil's economic and political landscape is challenging for farmers, with exchange-rate uncertainty, higher freight costs, US-China trade relations and Brazil's 2018 presidential election contributing to heightened market uncertainty. Problems with inland transport costs have also remained broadly unresolved. With local supplies mainly transported by lorry from producing areas to ports, recent legislation instituting minimum freight rates has had a big impact on the agricultural sector, squeezing profit margins. The costs of transporting fertiliser and other key farm inputs in the other direction, from ports to farms, have also increased in recent months. Brazil's Supreme Court has held a series of public hearings regarding the new minimum freight rates, introduced to appease independent lorry drivers, who launched a damaging nationwide strike in May. However, a decision on the law's constitutionality is not expected to be made until November.
Soybean area is set to increase even further in Brazil
Despite background uncertainty over freight costs, worries about the rising costs of production and volatility in foreign-exchange markets, the allure of high prices and potentially huge demand from China are expected to encourage a 12th successive increase in soybean area in 2018/19. We continue to expect a 4% rise in plantings, with area mostly coming from the conversion of degraded pasture land and a possible switch out of other agricultural commodities. Sowings have started relatively quickly, with progress in the first few weeks of the planting season ahead of both last year's pace and the five-year average. Farmers in Parana have made a blistering start to fieldwork, especially in western areas of that state, where crops could be ready for harvest before the turn of the year. Strong prices should also encourage high levels of fertiliser application, and assuming that productivity is broadly in line with trend, output is projected to reach 122m tonnes in 2018/19, up by 3.4% on the previous season. If US-China trade tensions continue into the following year, Brazilian farmers might be encouraged to plant even more soybeans, potentially boosting 2019/20 output by 1.6% year on year.
A difficult economic backdrop in Argentina
Faced with another financial crisis and the need to appease the IMF ahead of a new loan agreement, the authorities in Argentina have once again turned to grain and oilseed exporters as a source of much-needed revenue. With agricultural exporters deemed to have benefited from the massive drop in the value of the peso in recent months, the president has reneged on previous pledges to gradually reduce taxes on soybeans and their products. Under a series of changes, effective from September 3rd until the end of 2020, the soybean export tax has been raised to 28.5% (from 25.5% previously), with levies on soybean oil and meal raised to 25.8% (from 23% previously). The taxes had previously been scheduled to be reduced by 0.5% per month until the end of 2019. The announcement came just a few weeks before the start of the 2018/19 planting season, due to get under way in central parts in October.
Local prices are currently very supportive, and despite the changes in the tax regime it appears likely that soybeans may be a less risky proposition than maize for many growers. Financing costs for soybeans are comparatively lower, and farmers may be more incentivised to plant soybeans, especially given the potential for increased buying from China. We expect acreage to increase by about 2% in 2018/19. Should yields revert to normal, production is forecast to rebound sharply, to around 55m tonnes in 2018/19, up by more than 47% from the very poor results of the preceding season.
Paraguay and Uruguay could expand production in 2018/19
Production elsewhere in South America is also projected to increase in 2018/19. Paraguay is a modest but important exporter of soybeans to a range of world markets. The EU is the main market for Paraguay, accounting for 30-40% of all shipments, while sales to the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), mainly Russia, have risen strongly in response to rising local demand in the region. Output has sometimes varied sharply from one season to the next but has generally trended up over the past decade. Despite increasing local consumption, this has resulted in bigger surpluses for export. The production calendar is similar to that in southern Brazil, with planting starting around September. Based on expectations for a small rise in acreage, production in Paraguay could rise by 3%, to 10.2m tonnes. Uruguay is a relatively small player among South America's soybean producers. After poor results in the season before, output could potentially rebound by 50%, to 3m tonnes in 2018/19. Since domestic consumption is marginal, the bulk of the country's crop is exported, with China by far the largest market. Other destinations include Europe and Argentina, as well as North Africa and the US.
Production in China is rising but lags behind demand
China is by far the world's largest importer but only a minor producer of soybeans. However, potential has been capped over the years by limited yield gains compared with those of the world's big players as well as the attraction of alternative crops such as wheat, maize and rice. Nonetheless, the government is keen to boost production of oilseeds, particularly soybeans, at the expense of corn in north-eastern areas as part of a supply-side adjustment programme. To this end, Jilin and Heilongjiang provinces issued orders in early 2018 to increase soybean planting with the promise of public financial support. Based on an area increase of about 14% year on year, production in China in 2018/19 is projected to reach a ten-year high of 15.5m tonnes, expanding by 8.4%. Given continued efforts to boost production, output could climb by a further 1m tonnes in 2019/20, to 16.5m tonnes. Nevertheless, this still meets only a small portion of overall domestic need, the bulk of which is served by imports channelled to the country's vast feed sector.

Stocks and prices
Amid a period of mostly steady trading, world prices have strengthened from the middle of September, gaining on average of 7% during the next three weeks. Advances in US prices were linked to technical gains in local futures, as well as reports of continued strong ex-China demand, with the USDA confirming a very large sale to Mexico. Worries about wet weather leading to harvest delays added to the bullish tone. Additional support to prices was provided by completion of the ongoing North-American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) negotiations, which culminated in a renewed trade agreement between US, Mexico and Canada.
With these negotiations wrapping up quickly, some traders became more optimistic about the possibility of a timely resolution to the US-China trade war. However, comments from both sides suggested that there will be no easy solution to the current stand-off. Amid dwindling old-crop availabilities and a very strong pace of exports, fob quotations in Brazil (Paranagua) were also stronger. Partly reflecting a firmer local currency, farmers have become more reluctant sellers in the past few weeks, lifting the premium over equivalent US prices from US$60/tonne a month ago to more than US$90/tonne in early October. With Argentina's exportable surplus having been dramatically reduced by the smallest outturn in about a decade, quotations there were largely nominal.
