Sugar
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that global annual sugar consumption will expand at a fairly modest rate of 1.2% per year in 2018/19-2019/20 (years ending September 30th). Increasing global consumption will continue to be underpinned by population growth and rising incomes in emerging markets, where urbanising populations are adopting the food and drink habits of developed countries. Sugar plays a key role in this dietary shift as a sweetener in food and beverages and a binding and preserving agent in processed foods.
However, heightened awareness of the health implications of excess sugar in diets will put a brake on consumption growth, amid consumer calls for the food processing industry to reduce sugar and, in an increasing number of markets, the introduction of "sin taxes" on sugary products. These taxes have the potential to suppress sugar demand, although their impact will vary according to the level of taxation, the rigour of implementation and the elasticity of consumer demand. In addition, the growing supply of cheaper, starch-based alternative sweeteners in both Asia (where Chinese production is expanding rapidly) and Europe (where the market was liberalised in September 2017) will limit demand for sugar in the food and drinks industry. Meanwhile, the impact of low global sugar prices on demand will be muted by long-standing domestic pricing policies, which will limit the extent to which lower prices pass through to consumers.
China will remain a key consumer, but growth is set to moderate
We expect total private consumption in China to soften, owing largely to issues in the property markets, but this pressure on real disposable income is likely to strengthen demand for cheaper food and drink products, many of which rely on sugar as a preservative. This will spur demand for industrial sugar. However, consumption growth will be held back by the growing supply of starch-based sweeteners and rising concerns among wealthier consumers about the health implications of excess sugar in diets. On balance, we therefore expect annual sugar demand growth in China of 1.2% per year in 2018/19-2019/20, a level that is above the global norm but well below the pace of rapid consumption growth in China in 2012/13-2016/17.
Import demand will be constrained by higher domestic output and the government's protectionist policy agenda. Amid pressure from domestic producers to support the local industry, the government reduced import permits in mid-2017 to 1m tonnes/year (t/y), roughly half the previous level, and raised duties on some out-of-quota sugar imports from 50% to 95%. Initially these tariffs applied only to imports from the largest global producers, but the rules were amended in August to apply a 90% duty to all out-of-quota imports. Sugar imports have fallen to multi-year lows, and even if China grants some tariff exemptions, weak import demand is likely to prevail through 2019-20. However, China will be unable to scale up domestic production anytime soon to a level that could fully satisfy its domestic demand and preserve its strategically high levels of stocks. It will therefore continue to make purchases overseas, and with prices higher in China than the global norm, it will remain an attractive export destination.
Urbanisation and income growth will drive Indian consumption
Demand in India is forecast to reach 27.4m tonnes in 2019/20, driven by fairly rapid urbanisation and steady income growth. Amid pressure from producers to support prices the government has hiked import duties, imposed stockholding limits on mills and approved plans to create a buffer stock of some 3m tonnes. These measures, coupled with a recovery of demand among bulk consumers during the festive season, lifted domestic prices in the third quarter of 2018. The government is, however, facing opposing pressure from industry stakeholders (who require even higher domestic prices to reach break-even point) and lawmakers (whose electorates oppose government moves to increase retail prices). Regardless of the government's interventions, though, large domestic stockpiles will place a firm lid on prices in 2018/19-2019/20, signalling that weak prices will continue to support demand.
Demand growth elsewhere in Asia is threatened by starch-based rivals
Beyond China and India, the outlook for sugar consumption in Asia is mixed. Demand growth in the more developed countries (such as Malaysia and South Korea) is expected to slow, but this will be offset by rising incomes in populous developing countries (such as Indonesia, the Philippines and Vietnam). However, even in these developing countries demand will be tempered somewhat by concerns over the health impact of excessive sugar in diets. Policy measures to ensure that sugar consumption remains within recommended health guidelines will soften demand growth, with sugar taxes now in place in Thailand and the Philippines. Several other Asian countries are considering similar moves, and the prospect of a tax hike will limit investment in sugar-reliant food- and drink-manufacturing industries. Sugar demand will be further dampened by a gradual shift in the food and drink industry towards cheaper, starch-based sweeteners as China (Asia's largest producer of such sweeteners) seeks export markets. In light of these pressures, we expect demand growth in Asia (excluding China and India) to moderate to an average of 1.7% in 2018/19-2019/20, down from average growth of 2.5% over the previous five years.
Health warnings may eventually dent developed-world demand
The liberalisation of the EU's sugar regime in September 2017-when production quotas, guaranteed farm-gate prices and export caps were abolished-has limited the need for imports and brought European sugar prices (which have historically traded at a premium) closer to the global norm. Although lower prices should support demand, the production of isoglucose (a starch-based alternative to sugar) was also liberalised in 2017, which is likely to make a dent in the market share of the sweetener industry.
Health concerns are spurring this shift away from sugar. In many EU countries average consumption levels of sugar are already far higher than recommended by the World Health Organisation (WHO). In an effort to tackle this, in April the UK introduced a tax on sugary drinks, and the French government intends to hike its so-called soda tax in 2018. The WHO scrapped its non-binding recommendation to impose a sugar tax in May, calling instead on governments to improve labelling and regulate the marketing of sugary products. Regardless of policy interventions, we expect consumer pressure to make manufacturers wary of using excess sugar in their products, which will reduce demand growth in the medium term. We therefore expect sugar demand to remain broadly flat in 2018/19-2019/20, despite low prices and population growth.
Changing consumer tastes will boost demand growth in Africa
African consumption will continue to increase on the back of population growth, rising incomes and urbanisation. Several countries (including Nigeria, the region's largest importer, as well as Kenya and Ghana) are pursuing long-term investment plans in the sugar sector in the hope of becoming self-sufficient. However, inefficient domestic supply chains will impede the development of Africa's sugar industries, and most will be unable to compete with cheap imports from an oversupplied global market. Aggregate import demand from Sub-Saharan Africa will therefore remain well above 5m t/y in 2017/18-2018/19. A sugar tax came into effect in South Africa in April 2018, but amid pressure from food and drink manufacturers it has been set at just 10%, and we doubt that it will have a significant impact on overall sugar demand.
Policy changes will shift global sugar trade dynamics
The overhaul in 2017 by the EU of its sugar policy will drive the bloc's emergence as a net exporter. Exporters in the EU will focus in 2018/19-2019/20 on capturing market share in European countries with a sugar deficit, which will crowd non-EU producers out of the European market. The smaller producers, particularly in Africa and the Caribbean, which supply the EU under preferential trade deals, will be hit hardest by this shift. Some smaller producers have increased their market share in China since the May 2017 tariff regime was introduced, but they are unlikely to retain this market under the latest iteration of tariffs. Some countries (notably India) are seeking tariff exemptions from China, but their approval appears far from guaranteed. Brazil, which was hardest hit by China's tougher import rules, has opened a consultation with the WTO to examine these rules, but any possible intervention by the international body is a long way off.
Elsewhere, trade patterns will be influenced by the liberalisation of sugar sales under the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) free-trade agreement, which will probably cause less efficient producers such as Vietnam to rely more heavily on imports from elsewhere in the region (probably Thailand). Intra-regional trade in North America is also likely to increase following a trade deal agreed by the US and Mexico in mid-2017.

Supply
After rapid global production growth of some 11.8% in 2017/18 we expect output to moderate slightly in 2018/19-2019/20, to 181.7m tonnes. This dip will be driven by lower output from Brazil, where producers can respond to the low global sugar price environment by diverting cane to ethanol production. However, global supply will remain high by historical standards, with output in India, Thailand and Europe still hovering around all-time highs. This will keep the global market in surplus and sustain pressure on prices. Most of the world's sugar producers will therefore struggle to break even, and some mills will be forced out of business in the coming years.
This correction will, however, be slow to take effect. Sugar is a multi-year crop, and the industry is characterised the long contracts. Taken together, this will delay the responsiveness of farmers to low cane demand. Moreover, increased cane acreage and greater access to high-yielding inputs will deliver another strong harvest in 2018/19-2019/20 in most markets. Government intervention (notably in India) will also keep unprofitable sugars mills in operation.
Trade deals and policy measures will shift the direction of global trade flows, but trade volumes will ultimately be defined by production levels in countries (notably India) that have significant fluctuations in their domestic supply balance. The bulk of India's output is consumed domestically, but a strong harvest will lead to higher exports; much of this will probably go to emerging markets with costly local production. We expect total trade flows to dip slightly in 2018/19 as most countries already have large stockpiles, but flows will remain above historical norms throughout 2018/19-2019/20. There is, however, a downside risk of further protectionism in the sugar industry as governments attempt to shield their local manufacturers from cheap imports, and this could act as a major weight on trade flows.
Output in Brazil will be determined by price dynamics
We expect sugar production in Brazil to decline to an average of 33.9m tonnes in 2018/19-2019/20. This is largely due to the diversion of cane to ethanol production, which is more profitable than sugar production in the current price environment. Indeed, since the local 2018/19 season began in April, Brazil has crushed more cane than in the previous year, but sugar production is down and ethanol production is on course for all-time highs.
However, ethanol production cannot absorb all of the country's cane supply, and domestic prices of the biofuel are already tumbling as demand fails to keep pace with surging supply. There is a risk that ethanol prices will drop below sugar prices, particularly if the newly elected government caps fuel prices, which would prompt producers to switch back to sugar and sell more supplies into the saturated global market. However, this is not our central forecast, as we expect oil prices to remain relatively high (thereby boosting demand for ethanol in Brazil) and the depreciation of the Real to be fairly modest (thereby failing to provide a significant incentive for dollar-denominated sugar exports). Moreover, even if the ethanol/sugar price dynamic does change, output will be limited by low investment in aging cane fields. The profitability of soy crops in Brazil is also prompting farmers in the sugarcane belt to switch crops wherever possible, and although long-term contracts and multi-year crops will delay this crop rotation, a resurgence in Brazilian production seems unlikely.
A strong post-drought crop revival is expected in India
After a record-high crop in 2017/18 we expect output in India to edge higher in 2018/19, as cane supply remains plentiful. Production is forecast to dip slightly in 2019/20 as drought-like conditions in some parts of the country are negatively affecting plating, but output is expected to remain well above historical norms, reflecting the larger area under plantation. Producers are, however, unable to break even in the current price environment. Millers' arrears to farmers are estimated to have reached some US$3.5bn already, and the government's bail-out package to millers covers just 40% of existing arrears.
The government will therefore remain under political pressure from both millers and farmers to intervene. Policies designed to restore balance in the local industry include removing export duties, setting a price floor for domestic sugar prices, subsidising a portion of millers' contracts with farmers, and subsiding loans to increase ethanol production capacity. In September the government announced mandated sugar exports of 5m tonnes in the 2018/19 season, which according to industry calculations benefit from indirect subsidies that are collectively worth some US$150/tonne. Other sugar-growing countries, notably Brazil and Australia, argue that this tantamount to state-sponsored dumping, and they intend to seek intervention from the WTO. Regardless of external pressure, though, the government cannot subsidise an oversupplied and unprofitable industry indefinitely, and if it wants to bring the domestic market back into balance, it will eventually have to allow some producers to fail. Political expediency and a general election in 2019 (in which the government will be seeking the support of farmers) make it unlikely that this will happen any time soon, though.
Brisk EU production growth following sectoral liberalisation
Production in Europe is forecast to average 19.7 tonnes/year in 2018/19 and 2019/20. This follows a record-high year of production in 2017/18 of 21m tonnes as producers sought to take advantage of the lifting of the EU's 50-year-old sugar quota system at the start of the season. Under the new regime producers (led by France and Germany) extended their crush seasons, thereby making better use of existing capacity, and increased the acreage under plantation. These factors will support production over the coming years. However, output in 2018/19 will be hit by the heavy rains that delayed springtime planting and by the hot summer months in key producing countries, which will reduce sugar yields. However, the impact of recent weather patterns is somewhat uncertain, given the varying crop conditions in Europe.
More fundamentally, European producers are struggling to break even in the current price environment, with Germany's Südzucker reporting a 49% drop in profits in the first quarter of 2018. Weak global prices, coupled with the fact that the liberalisation of the sugar industry has removed the premium at which European sugar was previously traded, will place a firm brake on investment in the sugar industry over the coming years.
In Russia, production will continue to benefit from the significant investments that have been made in modernising sugar factories in recent years. After favourable growing conditions in 2017/18 led to record-high production, though, both cane acreage and yields are expected to be lower in 2018/19-2019/20. Production will continue to exceed domestic consumption, but soft demand in Central Asia (Russia's main market) will lessen its export potential.
Output in Thailand is recovering but pressures are mounting
Thai sugar production is surging as both crop acreage and yields exceed the long-run averages. After reaching a record-high of 13.7m tonnes in 2017/18, we expect output to edge up further in 2018/19-2019/20, driven by more planting. Output growth will, however, be somewhat constrained by the increased diversion of cane to ethanol production. This diversion reflects limited export opportunities in an oversupplied global market and mounting price pressures in the local sugar industry. The local industry was formally liberalised in early 2018, after Brazil successfully argued that Thailand was violating WTO rules on free competition. Quotas for sugar production will therefore be phased out and the domestic price-fixing system will be revoked, but mills are still obliged to reimburse farmers if the final sale price drops below a pre-agreed level. This protects farmers from global volatility, but with global prices at their current lows, mills are struggling to turn a profit. This will lead to some consolidation in the industry. Moreover, weather-related risks are rising as farming moves towards more drought-prone interior regions.
China's output will rise but will still fall short of government targets
After falling sharply in 2013/14-2016/17 owing to adverse weather conditions and the impact of rapidly rising costs of labour, land and farm machinery, China's sugar output has begun to recover. We expect this trend to continue, with output rising to 10.7m tonnes in 2019/20 on the back of normal weather conditions and government support. Despite initial concerns, the sugarcane crop has been largely unaffected by September's Typhoon Mangkhut. However, producers will face price pressures. Production costs have increased, driven by higher prices for fertiliser and pesticides, and prices have come under pressure from a rebound in local output and global oversupply. The government has been quick to intervene to protect local producers by hiking import duties, and this should provide some support to prices in 2018/19-2019/20. Even so, prices will remain too low to spur much investment in the sector. In addition, the sector is dominated by smallholder farmers, labour costs are high, and sugarcane areas do not lend themselves to mechanisation. We therefore expect that China will fall far short of achieving the 10% annual supply growth that would be needed for the state to meet its medium-term production goals.

Stocks and prices
Global sugar stocks increased to an estimated 100.5m at end-2017/18 on the back of a large market surplus. We expect this surplus to decline, from 13.1m tonnes in 2017/18 to 2.9m tonnes in 2019/20 as modest consumption growth is matched by a slight drop in output. Even so, these dynamics will not be significant enough to bring the market back into balance, and successive years of global surpluses will lift stocks. We therefore expect global stocks to reach 111.2m tonnes in 2019/20, equivalent to over 62% of consumption.

A prolonged global surplus will sustain the pressure on prices
Significant oversupply in the sugar industry is piling pressure on prices. Global sugar prices fell to an average of 16 US cents/lb in 2017, down by 11.3% year on year and more than 30% lower than the 2016 peak of 23 US cents/lb. Prices have remained under pressure through the course of 2018, dropping to a multi-year low of 10.75 US cents/lb in August. Prices found some support in September from uncertainty over the impact of recent weather conditions on the European crop and weaker prospects for Brazilian exports as the Real strengthened. However, the Indian government's announcement in late September that it intends to subsidise significant export trade sent prices tumbling again.
Brazil is the only producer able to act as a shock absorber, given millers' ability to divert significant cane supply to ethanol production when prices drop. However, owing to Brazil's falling market share this is insufficient to raise prices, and the link between ethanol/sugar price parity has become less significant globally as a floor on sugar prices. Far-reaching policy interventions by Asian governments are also likely to keep unprofitable producers in the market and delay a market correction. Hence, we expect prices to remain under pressure through 2018, averaging 10.8 US$ cent/lb for the year.
We expect prices to drift slowly higher from 2019. This will in part be driven by the sugar-trading market pricing in more risk, particularly as regions that are highly exposed to weather shocks gain prominence in global supply. More fundamentally, the market will gradually tighten over the medium term as costlier producers are forced out of the market. With traders taking their price cues from markets some two years ahead, this will provide some support to prices. Moreover, as less favourable weather in India has heightened the prospect of a slowdown in output from that country in 2019/20, we have made a slight upward revision to our price forecasts for 2019-20.

Sunflowerseed oil
Demand
Growth in global consumption of sunflowerseed oil is expected to slow down in 2017/18, following record year-on-year growth of almost 15% in 2016/17. Nonetheless, consumption growth of 4% still represents a good performance in 2017/18. With sunflowerseed oil becoming more competitive again, this momentum is now more likely to be maintained into the 2018/19 season. Our current projection is for modest growth of 2.6% in consumption to 19.4m tonnes in 2018/19, with the 20m-tonne barrier likely to be breached in 2019/20.
Improving price competitiveness will boost EU usage
The price discount of sunflowerseed oil to other oils remains at historically high levels, ensuring continued consumption growth in the EU. In 2017/18 sunflowerseed oil consumption, at 4.8m tonnes, recorded a steady increase of 4.4% year on year, following substantial growth of almost 16.5% in the previous season. In 2018/19, however, consumption may be constrained by local availability, although in principle imports could fill any gap. At this stage we expect only a modest increase in consumption of 1.4%. Trends in soybean oil prices, following US-China trade tariff changes, are also likely to have a strong influence on sunflowerseed consumption levels, and we expect EU consumption to grow by 2% in 2019/20.
Russian consumption set to rise in 2018/19 with higher local output
A strong export market for Russian sunflowerseed oil has had a limiting impact on consumption by bolstering domestic prices. Our estimate of 2017/18 consumption is unchanged, at 2.4m tonnes, which marks a decline of 2% year on year. We expect consumption growth to rebound by 2.7% in 2018/19, supported by higher domestic production and continued GDP growth. However, changes to trans-fat regulations may discourage the use of sunflowerseed oil in the margarine sector. Consumption growth is forecast to accelerate further in the 2019/20 season, to 5% year on year.
Transshipment into India increases
India's previously robust pace of sunflowerseed imports began to slow in early 2018, reflecting the imposition of higher import tariffs. However, import levels have since risen again. In part this is attributable to a loophole in India's import tariff arrangements, which allow duty-free imports via countries such as Bangladesh and Sri Lanka. Transshipment of oils through these locations is rising and is partly responsible for an increase in our estimate of 17% year-on-year consumption growth in 2017/18, to above 2.5m tonnes. We take a cautious view of likely consumption in 2018/19 following two years of substantial growth. The effects of the higher tariff rates will continue to be felt despite the transshipment trade, and imported vegetable oil prices will be adversely impacted by the depreciation of the rupee. We expect 2018/19 consumption growth to be relatively modest at 2.2%, before accelerating slightly by 3.7% in 2019/20.
Consumption growth to moderate in "other" countries in 2017/18
Many countries, including Turkey, Iran, Iraq and Egypt as well as several other smaller states, increased their purchases of sunflowerseed oil to take advantage of competitive prices. In 2017/18 consumption growth in these "other" countries is estimated to have slowed down significantly compared with the previous season. Turkey has recently reduced its import tariff on sunflowerseed as an anti-inflation measure, which could stimulate additional consumption both locally and in its traditional export markets during 2018/19. With sunflowerseed oil production expected to increase, consumption in these other countries is expected to continue to grow by 4.4% per year on average in both 2018/19 and 2019/20.

Supply
We estimate that the overall global supply of sunflowerseed oil in 2017/18 will be close to the record levels achieved in 2016/17. Northern hemisphere harvesting is now sufficiently progressed to firm up forecasts of likely 2018/19 sunflowerseed output. While estimates have generally been reduced, we are still expecting a new record to be set, with output growth of 2.6% in that season. At the moment we continue to forecast sunflowerseed oil output above 19m tonnes. However, this implies a reduction in sunflowerseed stocks and may turn out to be too optimistic, depending on the final outturn of the ongoing harvest. In 2019/20 we expect output to expand further, by 5.6% year on year, reaching new record levels.
Crush rates improve slightly
We have increased our estimate of 2017/18 Ukrainian sunflowerseed oil to reflect the most recent data. At 5.8m tonnes, output will be the second-highest on record, although this will still represent a decline of almost 10% year on year. The sunflowerseed area for 2018/19 is 3% larger than in 2017/18, despite earlier concerns that falling profit margins would act as a disincentive to farmers. With harvesting complete on around 40% of the area, yield reports indicated a final outcome just shy of 15m tonnes (the record harvest was 15.1m tonnes in 2016/17). A harvest of this size should ensure sufficient raw material to boost sunflowerseed oil output to 6.3m tonnes, 9% higher than in 2017/18 but still below 2016/17 levels. In 2019/20 we expect output to build up on the strong growth of 2018/19 and grow by a further 7.7% to a new record.
Russia's 2018/19 crop could be constrained by dry conditions
In Russia, recent crush rates indicate that the final output of sunflowerseed oil in 2017/18 will be around 4.6m tonnes, just short of the record output of 2016/17. Yield reports from the small, already harvested area suggest that earlier forecasts of the 2018/19 crop were too high. Our current estimate puts the crop at 11.7 tonnes, still a new record; some local estimates put the total lower. A notable feature of this year's crop is the significant variation in yield reports, which are making an assessment of the crop more difficult than usual. At this stage we have retained our forecast of 2018/19 growth in sunflowerseed oil output of 1.8% year on year in 2018/19. In the following season we expect growth to accelerate significantly, to 9.3% year on year.
The outlook for the 2018/19 EU sunflowerseed crop remains firm
The record 2017/18 sunflowerseed oil production in the EU is confirmed by the most recent information. The early optimism on the size of the 2018/19 EU sunflowerseed crop has dissipated, principally as a result of poor growing conditions in France. The outlook is more positive in Romania, Bulgaria and Spain. Most estimates put the crop in the 9m-9.8m-tonne range, although some still consider that a 10m tonne crop is possible. We are using an estimate of 9.5m tonnes. We expect EU sunflowerseed oil production in 2018/19 to be lower than in 2017/18, falling below the 3.6m-tonne mark. This would still be the second-highest total on record. In 2019/20 we expect sunflowerseed oil output to rebound and expand by 1.4% year on year, compared with a decline of 2.9% in the previous season.
Prospects for Argentina's crop remain positive
We estimate that 2017/18 Argentinean sunflowerseed oil production will reach 1.3m tonnes, marking growth of 0.8% year on year. We continue to expect the planted area to expand in 2018/19, although some local analysts suggest that the increase may be below early expectations. Plantings have proceeded ahead of normal, and the condition of the young crop is mostly rated fair to good, although not as good as last season's crop at this stage. Our current forecast is for robust growth in oil production of 13.4% in 2018/19. In 2019/20 we expect production growth to remain mostly flat in year-on-year terms, but given the high growth rate achieved in the previous season, this will still be high by historical standards.

Stocks and prices
Although global stocks of sunflowerseed oil at end-2017/18 will be plentiful, this will be only achieved at the expense of sunflowerseed stocks, which will end the season at low levels. Current projections indicate that both sunflowerseed oil and sunflowerseed stocks will tighten further in 2018/19. It is possible that crushing will be inhibited by the reduction in sunflowerseed stocks during the season, which would mean that sunflowerseed oil stocks would be lower than currently estimated, but still above normal levels at around 51 days of consumption. Our early forecasts suggest that sunflowerseed oil stocks will fall to more normal levels of around 41 days of consumption in 2019/20.

Tea
Demand
Global tea consumption is growing steadily, driven mainly by China, which accounts for nearly 40% of world tea consumption and is drinking ever-greater quantities of green tea. However, demand is growing in other major consuming regions as well, including India, which has offset weaker growth in demand in Europe. Despite press coverage of strengthening consumer demand for high-end luxury tea as well as iced tea, this accounts for only a tiny share of the market, with lower-cost varieties continuing to dominate. As such, demand for tea will remain less exposed to economic cycles than other commodities, meaning that tea demand will remain driven principally by demographics. This explains why The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecast for tea consumption growth, of 4.6% a year on average in 2019-20, is relatively high and in line with the long-term historical average. It also explains why our demand-side forecasts tend to remain relatively stable, since consumption of tea is attributable to structural factors to a much greater degree than other beverages.
Global demand for black tea will continue to rise, driven in particular by its increasing popularity in China, but the pace of growth will be outstripped by that for green tea, fruit tea, herbal tea, rooibos (from South Africa), purple tea (mainly from Kenya) and high-end organic tea, reflecting their greater reported health benefits and heavy marketing. Iced tea and other ready-to-drink tea beverages account for a small share of the market but have seen rapid growth in sales-notably in the US, but also in traditional markets such as China.
Tea demand will benefit from changing consumer habits
The main tea-consuming countries are also the largest producers, with a rising share of output retained for domestic consumption, partly reflecting domestic marketing campaigns by various tea boards to promote tea-drinking. The premise behind these efforts is that higher domestic consumption will incentivise producers to lift output in order to raise exports. In producing countries, tea will also benefit from changing consumption habits related to rising incomes, but in most places it will continue to remain a consumer staple. Combined with favourable demographics, consumption growth in producing countries is therefore likely to rise further. The fact that a smaller share of tea than coffee is consumed in the out-of-home sector-owing partly to customer perceptions that tea in cafés offers less value for money-will shield tea consumption from adverse economic developments, which tend to have less of an impact on at-home consumption.
Both India and China will continue to see robust demand growth in 2019-20
Tea consumption will continue to be dominated by Asian consumers, particularly China and India, which together accounted for an estimated 59% of global demand in 2018, up from 48% in 2010. In China, where growth in tea consumption has averaged over 10% per year in the past decade, we expect tea demand to continue to rise firmly, albeit by a more moderate average of 6.9% per year in 2019-20. Despite this strong growth projection risks to our forecast are primarily to the upside; average consumption per head stands at just over 1 kg/year, ranking China 14th in the world. This leaves room for growth, particularly as only around 35% of the population drinks tea.
Given that tea is regarded as a traditional drink, it will suffer from mounting competition from coffee and soft-drink retailers, owing to a growing preference for these beverages among younger Chinese consumers. Moreover, younger segments of the population are also showing a preference for black tea over green tea (black tea consumption has risen by an average of 26% per year since 2008, while green tea consumption has risen more gradually), which should bolster demand for black tea, albeit from a low base. Although ready-to-drink products are gaining market share, particularly in cities, the importance attached to the quality of tea means that sales of loose-leaf tea will continue to dominate the local market.
We estimate that India's tea consumption rose by 6% in 2018. In 2019-20 we expect strong economic growth to be accompanied by higher household spending, firm consumer confidence and supportive demographics, driving annual average growth in tea consumption of 6.4% in 2019-20. Structurally, the Indian market has significant potential-aside from its sheer size, average consumption per head is lower than in China, at just 740 g per year, which bodes well for longer-term demand growth. Currently the out-of-home sector accounts for just under 50% of tea consumption, compared with 85% of the coffee market. From a low base, the expansion of tea bars across many cities aims to lift this share and fuel overall growth in tea consumption.
Structural constraints will hamper tea consumption growth in many markets
Demand in some large consuming countries will be hampered in 2019-20 by market saturation and weakening demographics. Despite a firmer economic performance the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) forecasts overall stagnation until 2027 in European markets (which together account for 4% of global consumption) as well as in Russia, which accounts for 2.5% of global consumption and is the world's largest tea importer. Turkey, which accounts for around 4% of global consumption, has a particularly saturated market, with the highest consumption of tea per head in the world by some margin. The EU also registers some of the world's highest per-capita levels, particularly in the UK and Ireland. Although our forecasts anticipate further growth in demand, reflecting population growth and in many markets ongoing (if weaker) growth in private consumption, the pace will be fairly mild. In 2019-20 we forecast average annual demand growth of 1.2% in the EU and just 0.1% in Turkey, reflecting underlying economic difficulties in the latter. Russian demand growth will be stronger, at an average of 1.7% per year in 2019-20, but this is flattered by a weak base of comparison following a sharp decline in consumption in recent years.
There is plenty of room for market growth in the US
The US is a small market for tea, accounting for an estimated 2.2% of global consumption in 2018, and per-capita consumption is relatively low. However, with most of the larger tea markets dominated by loose-leaf tea, the US remains one of the most important single markets for instant tea and iced tea, with the latter accounting for 85% of the country's total tea consumption. It also remains one of the world's largest tea importers. We expect demand to increase by 3% in 2019, before weaker underlying economic conditions in 2020 prompt a deceleration to 0.7% that year. In the medium term we expect relatively firm demand for tea, with a continued shift away from carbonated drinks towards other beverages that are perceived as healthier.

Supply
Although tea production has dropped in India, output has recovered firmly in 2018 in both Kenya and China, following a poor outturn in 2017. We estimate that this will cause global tea production growth to pick up slightly, to 3.1%. We expect global production growth to decelerate slightly in 2019-20, to an annual average of 2.9%, below the long-running average of 4.5% growth per year in 2006-16, with several structural factors preventing faster production growth during the forecast period. In inflation-adjusted terms, farmers' profits are lower than in past decades owing to the higher cost of inputs, which will weigh on investment. In some cases, falling real earnings mean that smallholders' incomes place them within international and national measures of poverty. Investment will also be hampered by overall market perceptions that prospects for longer-term global consumption growth are weaker than those for some other, more fashionable beverages such as coffee, despite the fact that global tea consumption growth will remain fairly strong. In addition, many local currencies will remain weak against the US dollar in 2019-20, which will hamper operating conditions for farmers.
Much of the forecast growth in 2019-20 will come from a rise in green tea output, where growth has outpaced black tea by a significant margin in recent years. Green tea now accounts for one-third of total global tea production, compared with less than one-quarter a decade ago. This mainly reflects rising production in China, where loose-leaf green tea accounts for 68% of domestic production, and in Vietnam, where it now represents 55% of tea output, up from 43% a decade ago. We expect these trends to continue in 2019-20.
Structural efforts in China to bolster tea production
China's tea production rose by an estimated 5% in 2018, after heavy rains hit several of the large tea-producing provinces in southern China mid-year, including Hunan, Jiangxi and Zhejiang. The rains were followed by extremely hot weather in some areas (including parts of Zhejiang), which is likely to have hampered production. However, we are forecasting a deceleration in 2019-20, reflecting broader government efforts to improve the enforcement of environmental regulations, with local authorities destroying illegally planted tea bushes. Although we do not believe that these efforts will escalate to a level that would lead to a decline in tea production, it will take the edge of what had previously been extremely strong levels of tea production growth, at an average of 9.1% per year in 2004-16. Despite the tighter enforcement of environmental regulations, the government will still seek to boost agricultural productivity. A focus on eliminating rural poverty is likely to be accompanied by continued efforts to improve farmers' access to credit from the Agricultural Development Bank of China, the Agricultural Bank of China and rural credit co-operatives.
Official efforts to promote innovation, increase the use of technology and lift quality standards will also help to spur production, and better availability and quality should boost exports (only about 15% of tea production was exported in 2016). Germany and the US are China's main tea export markets; although trade relations with the US have deteriorated in recent months, tea has not been included in the list of items attracting US import tariffs. We believe that there is potential for gains in productivity, which would also increase long-term tea output growth, since China's average yield per hectare is low by global standards (at 801 kg/ha in 2014-16, compared with 2,153 kg/ha in India and 2,088 kg/ha in Kenya).
India's tea production will grow slowly in 2019-20
After rising by 0.9% in 2017, growth in tea production in India has been disappointing in 2018. Output fell by 1.5% in the first eight months of the year, according to the Tea Board, reflecting dry conditions in Assam (India's largest tea-growing state) as well as in Bengal and parts of southern India. We estimate a 2.3% drop in tea production in the full calendar year. In 2019-20 we forecast that output will recover gradually, rising by an average of 2% per year. Efforts to channel funding to tea growers and to introduce an insurance scheme for smallholders (who account for 50% of production) to protect against falls in market prices and weather-related crop disruption will provide support, but several structural factors will hold back firmer growth in production.
There has been little progress on reforms to boost foreign direct investment (FDI) in several sectors, including agriculture. Furthermore, India's tea bushes are old: nearly 40% of existing bushes are over 50 years old, compared with Kenya, where fewer than 30% are over 40 years old, and Vietnam, where the entire tea plantation is less than 20 years old. Replanting has progressed slowly, and rising input costs have eroded profits; labour now accounts for 50% of production costs (a figure that has grown by 12% in the past three years). As a result, India will struggle to raise output as significantly as other major producers in the long term. With several tea manufacturers reporting losses (the world's largest firm, McLeod Russel, made losses in India, compared with profits in Uganda, Vietnam and Rwanda), it is unclear how much FDI the sector will attract.
High costs will prevent a significant recovery in Sri Lanka's 2018-19 output
Tea production in Sri Lanka bounced back strongly after landslides and severe flooding in May 2017, with full-year production actually rising by 4.1%, despite alarmist warnings of a collapse in output following the heavy rains. In 2018 favourable weather early in the year has been followed by more adverse conditions in recent months, with tea production dropping by 1.5% in January-August compared with the year-earlier period. We have downgraded our full-year estimate and now expect a marginal fall in output, compared with a previous forecast of 1% growth in tea output. The government's decision to lift a ban on the use of glyphosate weed killer (used by all major tea producers) in tea plantations will provide some support in the near term, since there had been speculation that some key export markets (notably Japan) would cut imports from Sri Lanka on the basis that farmers had resorted to using a replacement chemical, MCPA, which is more stringently regulated in Japan.
However, there are several structural hurdles that will restrict the pace of growth in the medium term. Despite some replanting as a result of a 20% increase in subsidies to small tea farmers, the replanting rate is not high enough to lead to a significant and sustained increase in output. Local reports also show that fertiliser use has been low, and the risk of industrial unrest persists. Sharp wage rises and low mechanisation mean that production costs in Sri Lanka are some of the highest among the world's main tea producers. Reflecting these factors, we forecast a weaker rate of tea production growth, of 1.6% in 2019-20.
Continued production growth in Kenya is likely in 2019-20
After poor weather conditions in the first three quarters of 2017 led to a full-year decline in Kenya's tea production of over 7.4%, tea production is showing solid signs of recovery so far in 2018, with output in January-June rising by 14% year on year. As such, we estimate a record output of 500,000 tonnes this year. In 2019-20 we expect only modest production growth, averaging 2.5% per year, as periodic industrial action over pay disputes, combined with a change in the tea levy on farmers-which is now based on the value rather than the volume of sales-undermines profitability and prevents faster growth. The government has pledged to support small farmers and reduce the tax burden, but conflicting interests and a lack of funds will also hinder progress.
Investment will have an impact beyond our forecast period
Many countries have been investing to stimulate tea production, including large producers such as India (which is raising subsidies for plantation rejuvenation), Kenya (where processing plants are being expanded and production is being diversified to non-black varieties) and China (which is concentrating on raising black tea output for export), and even a minor producer, Ethiopia (where Saudi investment is seeking to expand tea production). Other smaller producers, such as Tanzania, Uganda, Rwanda and Bangladesh, have also seen renewed investment. However, we assume that some of these investment plans will be scaled back or suspended altogether, while others will progress only slowly, reflecting overambitious investment plans, bureaucratic hurdles and broader concerns about long-term global oversupply. In addition, it takes 3-5 years for a tea bush to become commercially productive, so the impact of recent price falls on output will be evident only after the forecast period.

Stocks and prices
With consumption growth expected to outstrip production growth in 2019-20, the market balance is expected to fall from an estimated surplus of 31,000 tonnes in 2018 to a deficit of 181,000 tonnes in 2020. Given that there is no global measure of total tea stocks, it is impossible to gauge the degree to which these movements will affect actual physical stock levels. Stock movements have only a limited effect on prices, not least because much of the increase in consumption and production is the result of consumption and output (mainly of green tea) in China. Although some of the annual production data are broken down into green and black tea, the consumption data are not, which prevents a calculation of the market balance in relation to black tea.
Only a fraction of the increase in production will be exported, and even this will not be in any of the three markets (Colombo, Kolkata and Mombasa) where our average tea price is measured. Prices in these markets respond to demand and supply dynamics in Sri Lanka, India and Kenya, respectively (essentially black tea). Often prices diverge between these three markets on the back of local developments that have an impact on supply and demand in the respective auction or to reflect the quality of tea offered at each auction. For example, prices at the Colombo and Mombasa auctions have fallen so far in 2018 as production in Sri Lanka and Kenya has risen, while prices at the Kolkata auction have fallen as Indian output has declined.

Although some of the auction houses are becoming digitised, we do not believe that the tea market will attract sufficient interest from investors to make price dynamics vulnerable to broader global macroeconomic changes. There is currently no futures market, although the latest meeting of the FAO Intergovernmental Group (IGG) on Tea, which took place in May, discussed the feasibility of introducing one in an effort to address price volatility and differentials between individual tea auctions. However, given that the IGG meets fairly sporadically (usually once a year), we do not expect the introduction of a futures market within the forecast period. Prices will therefore remain volatile and largely led by local supply-and-demand factors.
Prices will retreat in 2019 before recovering slightly in 2020
Average tea prices fell from US$3.19/kg in the third quarter of 2017 to US$2.79/kg in the third quarter of 2018. We expect prices to stabilise around this level during the fourth quarter of 2018; however, this will be not be sufficent to prevent a 7.1% drop in average prices over the full year, to US$2.88/kg. We forecast that average prices will fall further in 2019, to an annual average of US$2.81/kg, before picking up to US$2.90/kg in 2020 as demand remains relatively firm, outpacing production growth.

Wheat
Demand
Global wheat consumption has nearly tripled since the 1960s, to more than 730m tonnes in recent years. However, gains in demand, mainly for food and milling purposes, have failed to keep pace with increases in production, resulting in a five-year period of stock accumulation between 2013/14 and 2017/18 (local marketing years). Although stronger demand for wheat has mainly been driven by a rising global population, it should also be noted that wheat demand growth has generally outpaced population growth. Wheat's popularity in diets has been sustained, as has its use as an animal feed ingredient. A small proportion is also used for brewing and the manufacture of starch and ethanol. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global wheat consumption to increase only fractionally in 2018/19, by 0.7% year on year to 738m tonnes, as gains in consumption for food only partially compensate for an expected drop in use for animal feed. Initial projections for 2019/20 remain highly tentative at this stage. Assuming larger crops and renewed growth in the use of wheat as an animal feed, total consumption is projected to rise by 1.9%, to 752m tonnes.
Rising food use is being driven by emerging and developing markets
Annual growth in global wheat consumption for food use has remained relatively consistent over the past decade. Urbanisation, together with shifts in diets and incomes, has also resulted in greater consumption of wheat-based convenience foods, such as noodles and Western-style bakery products, which are best produced using high-quality wheat and flour. With almost all of the growth in demand stemming from countries outside the main wheat-producing belts, rising demand for milling wheat and flour has been accompanied by an increase in imports in most years. We expect the global use of wheat for food to rise by 1.3% in 2018/19, to around 520m tonnes. Growth will be driven mostly by India, Indonesia and Sub-Saharan Africa. Similar trends are projected for 2019/20, with overall demand for food wheat predicted to climb to around 527m tonnes.
Growth in mature wheat markets has been much more static, with per-capita consumption of wheat flour declining in some countries in recent decades. In the early 2000s the popularity of low-carbohydrate diets caused a relatively sharp drop in US demand. In subsequent years consumption of wheat for food use failed to recover fully, with more recent declines in per-capita usage mainly linked to rising demand for gluten-free products. It is estimated that as many as 3m people now try to follow a gluten-free diet in the US. Of these, around 70% do not have celiac disease-those affected avoid the intake of gluten commonly found in wheat, barley and rye. As wheat consumption for food use in the US is estimated at about 28m tonnes, compared with about 93m tonnes in India, the slowdown in US growth is unlikely to have a major impact on the generally upward global trend.
World livestock feed use is expected to drop in 2018/19
Wheat is the world's second-most important grain for use in animal feed, with annual consumption roughly equal to the feed use of barley, sorghum, oats and rye combined. Wheat usage is typically equivalent to one-quarter of the amount of maize that goes into animal feed each year. Given shrinking supplies and continued strong competition from maize-especially in the EU and the US-we expect feed use of wheat to drop below recent peaks to a five-year low of 133m tonnes. Demand will depend on relative pricing and overall levels of quality. Following huge crop losses across northern Europe, feed-wheat supplies are expected to be much tighter in 2018/19, and demand will potentially need to be rationed. Feed-wheat use in the EU, which accounts for around 40% of the world total, is currently predicted to drop by around 6m tonnes in 2018/19 to around 48m tonnes as users switch to more competitively priced alternatives, mainly imported maize. Strong export demand for barley may limit how much of that grain is fed domestically in the coming season. However, given this season's very short pasture and grazing availabilities, prospects for the EU feed-grain market outlook are still quite uncertain, and much will depend on how price relationships develop over the coming months. While feed-wheat use in South Korea, Thailand and Vietnam could also decline, feed use in China is expected to rise as more sub-standard domestic supplies are diverted into feed mills in the main southern meat-consuming hubs. Assuming much larger harvests in the EU and Russia next year, feed use is projected to return to growth, provisionally seen rebounding to around 140m tonnes in 2019/20. We expect overall wheat demand to rise by 0.5% per year in EU over the forecast period.
China has imposed 25% tariffs on US origin wheat imports
Following the souring of the US-China trade relationship in recent months, a number of US agricultural products, including wheat, are now subject to an additional 25% duty on imports into China. With purchases mainly linked to quality shortfalls in its own huge domestic crop and capped by a restrictive licensing system, China is usually not an overly large importer of wheat. Annual imports have recently averaged 4.1m tonnes/year, with the US typically maintaining a 32% share. Buying interest has almost completely dried up in recent months, mainly reflecting price considerations, but with some importers also reportedly wary of the risk of additional checks or holdups when sourcing US wheat. Instead, local buyers have looked to secure more supplies from Russia and Kazakhstan. We expect growth in Chinese demand to recover in 2018/19-2019/20 by 2.1%, after an estimated decline of 1.3% in 2017/18.

Supply
World wheat production has reached unprecedented levels in recent seasons, with output climbing to successive highs in each of the past five years. Part of this upswing is linked to a small overall rise in plantings, with harvested area trending marginally higher, but much of this has been tied to better average yields, seen close to 3.5 tonnes/ha in 2017/18, compared with 2.8 tonnes/ha a decade ago. Despite concerns about years of underinvestment in wheat-seed technology, productivity gains have been achieved almost everywhere as farmers employ ever more advanced agronomic practices. However, following extended periods of adverse weather across many key producers and exporters, world output in 2018/19 is projected at 714m tonnes, down by 5.8% year on year and potentially the smallest crop since 2010/11. Harvests are expected to be much smaller than average in the EU, Australia, China and the US, but comparatively good in Argentina, India and North Africa. Despite an earlier build-up of stocks, the sheer scale of the drop in production, combined with a solid demand base, has quickly shrunk exportable availabilities. Prices have begun to rise, especially in Europe, with US supplies gradually turning more competitive. Assuming more normal weather conditions, world production is expected to rebound by 5% in 2019/20, to 750m tonnes.
A drop in 2018/19 plantings and yields will cause EU production to decline
Cumulative production in the EU is forecast to slump by 10.7% in 2018/19, the smallest total in six seasons. Yields across northern Europe were badly affected by extremely dry weather over the summer months, with unusually small harvests confirmed in Germany, Poland, the Baltic states and across Scandinavia. Although cropping conditions were slightly better in France this year, weather in the bloc's leading producers and exporters was far from perfect, with production dipping below average levels. The production shortfall is expected to limit exportable supplies in the 2018/19 marketing year severely, with exports potentially down 6% from last season to perhaps the lowest level seen since 2011/12. We expect the situation to improve in 2019/20, when overall EU output is forecast to grow by 9.6%, still around 3m tonnes less than the 2017/18 level. Winter plantings are now under way. Owing to current high prices and delays in sowing of the 2019/20 winter rapeseed, the stage could be set for a rebound in wheat area. However, after a very dry summer in many parts, rains are now urgently required if fieldwork is to proceed normally.
Russia's output will decline by almost 19% in 2018/19
Based on the latest harvest updates, it appears that recent cuts to our production forecasts for Russia might have been overly pessimistic, with total output now seen at close to 69m tonnes (from 68m tonnes previously), slightly more than the recent average but down sharply from last year's enormous crop of 84.9m tonnes. Harvesting of winter wheat is now complete, with yields holding up slightly more strongly than we had previously anticipated. Yields are, however, down across all key growing regions, most notably in the Volga Federal District, where productivity is down by about 30% year on year. The spring wheat harvest has progressed very slowly so far, but with yields to date better than a year ago. The sowing of winter grains for harvesting in 2019, which has progressed quite quickly so far, is complete on around three-quarters of planned area. Worries about deficient soil moisture have been partly placated by widespread rainfall in late September.
Speculation about possible export controls has gained traction in recent months amid meetings between the Ministry of Agriculture and the National Association of Exporters of Agricultural Products (NAESP). While there remains some disagreement about exactly what was discussed at these meetings-with some observers pointing out some subtle differences between Russian and English-language statements-it is clear that the authorities are monitoring the situation closely. Local feed manufacturers are said to be particularly concerned about tightening local supplies and rising prices. There have been some indications that grain exports could be capped at 30m tonnes, including 25m tonnes of wheat; based on the current very strong pace of shipments, this level could potentially be reached as soon as January 2019. This year's early harvest has quickly replenished exportable pipelines, and with a much weaker rouble inflating exporter returns, 2018/19 (July-June marketing year) shipments have started very rapidly. The threat of export controls has also spurred additional sales as exporters look to maximise shipments ahead of possible restrictions later in 2018.
Average yields in Ukraine are likely to drop
Ukraine's Ministry of Agriculture announced in August that it had reached an agreement with exporters to ship 16m tonnes of wheat in 2018/19 (July/June), including up to 8m tonnes of milling varieties. These Memorandums of Understanding (MoUs) are signed each season and are used as an informal mechanism to ensure adequate domestic supplies. In some press reports and across social media the deal was instead reported as a formal limit on exports. With markets already nervous about shrinking exportable wheat availabilities, prices quickly spiked higher before dropping again on official confirmation that exports were not being restricted. The harvest is now complete and is forecast at around 25.4m tonnes, almost 6% lower than in 2017/18. After a dry start, conditions for 2o19/20 winter wheat sowings turned much more favourable in the second half of September. Plantings are projected to be similar to the previous year, but assuming an improvement in yields, output could increase by about 4.3%, to 26.5m tonnes in 2019/20.
Chinese output is expected to drop in 2018/19
Based on the latest production data by province, we expect Chinese output to decline by 5.6% in 2018/19-a five-year low of 122.5m tonnes. Excessive rains have badly affected yields and quality in parts of Henan, Anhui and Jiangsu provinces, where final results were even worse than previously anticipated. Local officials have reportedly been instructed to support affected farmers by procuring sub-standard wheat under the minimum support price programme. It is unclear how much wheat will be procured and exactly what it will be used for, but it is expected to be diverted into feed channels as long as mycotoxin specifications are met.
Mixed results from the US wheat harvest
According to the US Department of Agriculture (USDA), the US 2018/19 wheat crop totalled 51.3m tonnes (up by 8% year on year), including 32.2m tonnes of winter wheat (a contraction of 7%), 2.1m tonnes of durum (an increase of 41%) and 16.7m tonnes of other spring wheat (an increase of 50%). The massive increase in spring wheat (excluding durum) was particularly impressive, tied partly to a strong rise in plantings and record-breaking yields. Although all-wheat production increased quite strongly from the season before, the crop was still much smaller than average as farmers across the southern Plains sought to minimise winter wheat in their crop rotations. Given the current improved price outlook, producers could be encouraged to plant more for the 2019/20 harvest. Recent rains have provided a good early platform for winter planting. Accounting for some nominal projections for spring-sown wheat, the 2019/20 crop could potentially rise to 53m tonnes, marking a 3.3% gain.

Argentina imposes an export tax on primary exports
Faced with deepening financial market woes, which include a massive depreciation in the value of the peso, soaring interest rates and rampant inflation, the Argentinean president recently unveiled new revenue-raising measures aimed at an accelerated loan agreement with the IMF. As part of this, the president has announced a reversal of his flagship commodity tax-cutting policies, applying a floating tax of 4 pesos per US dollar on primary exports, including agricultural products such as wheat, maize and soybeans. The policy, which is effective from September 4th 2018 until the end of 2020, is based on current calculations and basically places a 10.5% export tax on wheat. With the levy only recently announced, there is still uncertainty as to whether previously declared export sales will be subject to the new arrangements. In the short term, farmers may hold back from selling dollar-denominated agricultural products by means of a hedge against currency movements, especially if foreign-exchange-market volatility continues. However, the announcement will have no bearing on 2018/19 wheat production, as plantings are already complete.
After an extremely favourable start to the cropping year, with soil moisture adequate almost everywhere, conditions have turned progressively drier. Rains have been particularly scarce in parts of Cordoba province and in the north of the country. However, local sources continue to report better conditions in core central producing areas. Because of expected strong returns, plantings increased by around 7% year on year. Farmers are also reported to have maximised fertiliser use, which should be supportive of yields. Forecast production is maintained at a record 20m tonnes, marking an increase of 8.1% in 2018/19. This trend will continue in 2019/20, and production is forecast to increase by an additional 5% in that year.
Stocks and prices
Following five consecutive increases, the world wheat carryover is forecast to contract by 8.8% by the end of 2018/19 to around 247m tonnes, still the second-highest level ever recorded and some 9% higher than the previous five-year average. Stockpiles in China are expected to grow even larger, seen rising by as much as 5% to 132m tonnes, equivalent to more than half the global total. Since stocks there will only ever be used to satisfy local demand, many observers have argued that China should be excluded from global stock calculations. The USDA recently announced that its supply-and-demand outlook would at some point in the future include such estimates. Other organisations suggest that it is perhaps more useful to measure stocks in the eight largest exporters as a proxy for global supply. Cumulative stocks in these countries are expected to tighten by one-quarter, to 61.7m tonnes, their lowest level in five seasons. Declines are expected across the board, most notably in the EU (43%), Russia (30%), Australia (30%) and the US (15%). A smaller exportable surplus and the need to ration demand away from feed channels are expected to provide a floor to prices going forward, especially in the event of further crop downgrades for southern hemisphere exporters or any government-imposed restrictions on Russian shipments. Based on early projections for 2019/20 supply and demand, wheat ending stocks could decline again by the end of the following season by an additional 1%. However, exporter inventories are projected to be larger by 8% in that year.

An earlier spike in prices has been partly undone
World wheat markets have become more volatile in recent months. As the focus turned on increasingly tight wheat supply-and-demand fundamentals, average milling wheat prices rallied by around 15% between late June and mid-August. Despite expectations of much tighter availabilities in the season ahead, around half of these gains have since been reversed. This most recent downturn was linked to speculation that the gains had been overdone, especially given that no restrictions had yet been imposed on Russian exports. While prices have corrected somewhat, falling a little faster than we had previously anticipated, we would still argue that risks are to the upside.
We expect that price direction in the coming months will largely be shaped by the exact size of Russia's 2018/19 surplus and whether or not the authorities move to limit shipments. Any such rationing would probably see prices rise, with demand shifting to other, more expensive origins. Final harvest results in Australia and Argentina may also be an important factor. Average prices are expected to strengthen in 2018, but assuming Russian shipments remain high in the coming years, world prices are expected to show only limited upside potential over the remainder of the forecast period.
